It now applies only to the first $51,300 earned each year; the bill would raise it to $125,000 or $130,000. A worker earning $85,000 a year, for example, would pay $1,233, or $489 more than present law. A $50,000 earner would pay no more. The tax is matched by the employer.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Down
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed Friday at 25,005.64, down 346.99 points or 1.37 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Yale Scientists Develop Vaccine Against Lyme Disease in Lab Mice
DOC.TEXT: Research with mice at Yale University may lead to a vaccine to protect humans from Lyme disease and perhaps even syphilis, said a study published today. Yale scientists reported in the journal Science that they found a laboratory mouse that can be infected with the Lyme disease spirochete bacteria and then used genetic engineering techniques to make a vaccine that protects the animal against the disease. The work could point the way to vaccines for humans, said Richard A. Flavell, leader of the Yale team, but that is several years away. ``It's very likely that we'll be able to get a good Lyme vaccine for humans from this technique,'' he said. ``If it works on this disease, then it may be used to develop vaccines against other diseases with spirochetes, such as syphilis.'' A Harvard researcher, however, said the success of a Lyme disease vaccine, even for mice, cannot be proven until the immunity is tested against disease in the way it is naturally spread - through a tick bite. David H. Persing of the Harvard School of Public Health said the saliva of Lyme disease-infected ticks also contains substances that depress some immune functions. A vaccine would be proven, he said, only when it is shown to give protection against the effects of these substances also. Lyme disease was first identified in 1975 and named for the Connecticut town where a Yale study was conducted. The disease is spread by a small deer tick that passes along the spirochete when it sucks blood from a victim. The disease can cause heart problems, arthritis-like joint pain, skin rash and even brain disorders. Diagnosed early, it can be successfully treated with antibiotics. Flavell said that to develop the vaccine, the Yale scientists first had to find a special inbred strain of laboratory mice able to contract Lyme disease. Stephen W. Barthold, a Yale veterinary scientist, tested many strains before he found that a mouse called C3H-He could be infected with the Lyme disease spirochete and develop symptoms within five days. To make the vaccine, the researchers cloned a gene for a protein, called OspA, that is on the surface of the Lyme spirochete. The gene was then spliced into a common laboratory bacteria which, in turn, produced the OspA protein. A purified form of OspA was injected into a group of mice and tests showed that the rodents developed antibodies to the protein. Inoculated mice then were challenged with Lyme disease by injecting them with the Lyme spirochete. Mice that received shots of OspA protein did not get Lyme disease. Antibodies made by the mouse immune system in response to the OspA protein were able to keep the bacteria in check. Other mice that had not received the OspA shots developed the Lyme symptoms. Dr. Erol Fikrig, a member of the Yale team, said the study required use injected bacteria because the researchers had to know exactly how much spirochete each mouse received. Using a tick to spread the disease, he said, ``would be highly variable and could not be reproduced'' precisely. Fikrig acknowledged that laboratory work is not a true test of vaccine effectiveness against the tick-born disease. ``In nature, things could be different and further studies on that will have to be done,'' he said. The importance of the study, he said, is that some immune protection was demonstrated against a spirochete bacteria. ``The fact that we can make a vaccine against this organism is certainly encouraging that vaccines against other spirochete illnesses can be developed as well, and that includes syphilis,'' said Fikrig. Flavell said it will take five to eight years of additional laboratory work before the candidate Lyme disease vaccine can be tried experimentally on humans. Science, which published the study, is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Final Child Care Bill Takes Shape
With PM-Congress Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A new $2.5 billion program of grants to the states is emerging as the centerpiece of major child-care legislation nearing enactment in Congress. Key House and Senate sponsors said their agreement on the program would break a months-long deadlock over child-care assistance. Differences remain over additional related elements, including an expansion of tax credits for low-income families. But congressional sponsors said those differences would be resolved with the pending deficit-reduction tax package and would not hamper the grant program. The Senate passed a version of the bill more than a year ago, and the House approved a more ambitious measure earlier this year, but the issue has been stalled in conference panels for months. Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., told reporters Thursday that final negotiations had gained the support of House leaders for the child-care agreement he worked out with administration officials earlier this month. ``I'm confident whatever the (budget) reconciliation bill looks like, child care will be a part of it,'' Dodd said. The agreement calls for establishment of a program of block grants to the states to provide direct assistance to low-income families for child-care and support to schools and community agencies that provide child care. Details of a roughly $13 billion expansion of the earned income tax credit sought by congressional tax writers remain to be worked out. The money would go to low-income working families with children, but it would not be tied to child care expenses. Dodd said the credit expansion was intended primarily to make the total package of tax increases in the budget bill more progressive. Rep. Tom Downey, D-N.Y., a sponsor of the House's child-care bill, balked last week after Dodd agreed with the White House on the grant program and the Senate quickly incorporated it into its version of a deficit-reduction package. Downey said Thursday he now will go along with the grants but is trying to add a program of child-care assistance for poor families under the Social Security Act. The price tag on that would be an additional $1.5 billion over five years. Downey and Dodd said the money could come from scaling back the tax credit. The grant program would carry a $2.5 billion authorization over three years, and Dodd said he expected it to reach $5 billion in five years. A portion, $180 million of the $750 million first-year total, would go to early childhood education and ``latchkey'' after-school care, based in schools or run by community groups. The long holdup in final congressional approval, and the scaling back of the package from earlier versions, drew criticism from members of the Congressional Caucus for Women's Issues. They also complained that no women were included in two conference committees that considered the bill. ``Minuscule,'' Rep. Mary Rose Oakar, D-Ohio, said of the legislation. ``It's about a quarter loaf, compared to what the House passed.'' ``We'll take whatever it is and build on it next year,'' said Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo. On other domestic legislation Thursday: -The House approved by voice vote a compromise, $57.4 billion housing bill. It would restructure housing programs, shore up the financially troubled Federal Housing Administration and extend the life of low-interest mortgage programs. The bill authorizes $27.5 billion this fiscal year, a 63 percent increase over the previous year's appropriations and $3.3 billion over what would be required to maintain current policies. It provides $29.9 billion in fiscal 1992. The FHA overhaul will assess a new annual premium on borrowers of FHA-backed loans that would increase minimum upfront closing costs. For example, the buyer of a $65,000 home would need $3,639 in cash, about $800 more than the current average requirement. -The House rejected for a second time a bill that would permit taxpayer-financed abortions in the District of Columbia. The bill was identical to the appropriations bill for Washington's city government that the House rejected, 211-185, last Saturday. This time the vote to reject was 211-195. Rep. Julian Dixon, D-Calif., chairman of the D.C. appropriations subcommittee, said he would return the bill to a House-Senate conference and delete the expanded abortion provisions. The bill would permit the city government to use locally raised taxes for abortions, and would permit use of federal money for abortions for poor women in cases of rape or incest. -A $182 billion spending bill for the Labor, Education and Health and Human Services departments was held up by unrelated Senate amendments. The bill, which would increase spending by $22 billion over last year's levels, is the largest domestic appropriations bill. -A $78 billion spending bill for the Veterans Affairs and Housing and Urban Development departments and independent agencies was approved by the Senate and sent back to the House with amendments. It includes $14 billion for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, whose 14 percent increase was the largest of any agency in the bill.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Donates Part of Lung to Daughter in Pioneering Transplant
DOC.TEXT: Doctors who transplanted part of a woman's lung into her dying daughter said the procedure - believed to be a first in this country -greatly reduces the chances of transplant rejection. The girl, 12, and her mother, 46, whose names were withheld at the family's request, were reported in good condition after their operations Thursday at Stanford University Medical Center. ``The mother was a far closer tissue match than could have been expected from an unrelated donor,'' said Dr. Vaughn Starnes, who heads the medical center's heart-lung transplant team. Kidneys and a portion of a liver have been transplanted from living donors, but all lung transplants in this country have previously involved brain-dead donors, Stanford officials said. People have survived removal of a disease lung. Starnes said that the mother and child matched on four of six genetic markers, or tissue antigens, compared with no more than two such matches in previous lung and heart transplants involving brain-dead donors. He said transplants from related, live donors are particularly important for children because youngsters have a higher rate of rejection than adults. Half of 14 children who have received heart-lung transplants at Stanford suffered rejection severe enough to impair lung function. That's nearly twice the rejection rate of the 71 adults who have undergone the same operation at the medical center. ``These children have so much trouble with rejection that the transplant almost isn't worth it with an unrelated donor,'' said Marguerite Brown, a nurse who coordinates Stanford's donor program. During Thursday's surgery, doctors removed the upper one-third of the mother's right lung and transplanted it in the child's chest in place of her right lung. The girl suffers from a rare malady called bronchopulmonary dysplasia that causes scarring and high blood pressure of the lungs. ``The child was already experiencing difficulty breathing and required home oxygen and therefore was going to sustain serious damage,'' Starnes said. He said the mother should regain almost total function of her partial lung. The daughter is expected to be able to fully use the transplanted lung, which will likely increase in capacity and may even grow in her body. ``Both mother and daughter are expected to resume normal activity within a few months,'' Starnes said. Stanford doctors expect the girl to remain hospitalized for several weeks. The mother probably will go home earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Agency Investigates False Positive at North Carolina Lab
DOC.TEXT: Officials of the National Institute on Drug Abuse are trying to find out why drug testing by a government-certified laboratory in North Carolina incorrectly identified five people as using illegal methamphetamines. In each case, the lab's confirmatory tests confused the stimulant drug with high doses of over-the-counter cold medications containing ephedrine and other stimulants, said Dr. Joseph Autry, director of applied research at the government institute. ``This is one (type of) test in one lab for one drug, and it's the only time a false positive has happened in a NIDA-certified lab,'' Autry said. ``We're taking it very seriously.'' The case that brought the problem to the government's attention was that of a truck driver, who was removed from his job last July despite his vehement denials that he was falsely accused, officials said. Officials did not identify him and said his case has resulted in litigation. He was tested under Transportation Department regulations requiring drug testing of employees in department-regulated industries. This testing must be done by one of the 57 labs certified by the institute. The laboratory that conducted the tests was suspended last week while institute officials try to determine whether the problem was with the lab's testing or was inherent in the testing procedure itself, Autry said. The testing problem could have broad repercussions, such as if the case were used by critics to try to block drug testing altogether, he said. The lab was identified in the Federal Register as Roche Biomedical Laboratories of Research Triangle Park, N.C. Company officials did not return a telephone call for comment Thursday. In the case of the truck driver, his vehement denial of methamphetamine use prompted more confirmatory testing by the lab. This further testing showed the previous result to have been incorrect. When institute officials learned of the false positive, they checked the seven other samples that had tested positive for methamphetamines by Roche in recent months, and found five were negative, officials said. NIDA officials alerted the 56 other laboratories the institute has certified for drug testing, and found that eight were using the same methamphetamine test Roche was. About 100 samples tested by these labs had come out positive, and all are being rechecked, Autry said. He expected results in about two weeks. The testing procedure being questioned is used to confirm the presence of methamphetamines. Several other methods also are used and no false positives have been discovered with any of those, Autry said. He said he did not know how many private testing laboratories may be using the method Roche was using. Transportation Department testing regulations require that a worker who tests positive for methamphetamines, amphetamines, PCP, opiates, marijuana or cocaine be removed from a safety-sensitive job. But if the finding is reversed, regulations do not require that the worker be reinstated; they only prevent the employer from refusing to reinstate the worker on the basis of the inaccurate test.

DOC.HEAD: Election Time in Hollywood: Lights, Cameras and Political Action
LaserPhoto LA3
DOC.TEXT: Republicans enlisted Bart Simpson without his permission, Chevy Chase added $50,000 to Dianne Feinstein's campaign and Angela Lansbury was lambasted for what critics called ``Distortions, She Wrote.'' It's lights, camera and political action in Hollywood, where a few golden words from a celebrity can speak decibels louder than dozens of stump speeches by politicians. Movie and television stars are getting behind gubernatorial candidates from both parties, as well as Big Green, a sweeping state environmental initiative. ``There are many entertainers who by their past work have become trusted by the public, and for them to research and then support an issue like Big Green helps us spread the word,'' said initiative spokesman Duane Peterson. As the political free-for-all nears its Nov. 6 election day conclusion, one cartoon celebrity found himself backing a cause he didn't embrace and a highly regarded TV star opposed a pair of measures she didn't fully understand. Bart Simpson, the animated underachiever of TV's ``The Simpsons,'' was quoted at length in a Republican news release about Democrat Feinstein's use of crib notes during a debate against U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson. ``If you're gonna use cheat sheets, man, use `em right,'' Bart was quoted as saying. He even offered this advice: ``The best is taping the notes in your shoe, dude.'' The Fox Broadcasting Co., which broadcasts ``The Simpsons,'' never gave permission to use the character or his words, but Bart's creator, cartoonist Matt Groening, shrugged it all off. ``That doesn't surprise me,'' said Groening. ``Republicans think they own everything anyway.'' Television commercials by Miss Lansbury, star of CBS' ``Murder, She Wrote,'' opposing a pair of intiatives that would limit terms for most state officials went on the air Tuesday and drew harsh criticism from supporters. Lewis Uhler, a primary author of one bill, labeled the TV spots ``Distortions, She Wrote.'' The actress did not know the commercials were paid for by state legislators and did not fully understand other provisions of the bills, said her son and agent, David Shaw. Proponents of the Uhler-written bill said the commercials incorrectly suggest that the measure would require public funding of campaigns. ``She doesn't really read newspapers,'' Shaw said, adding that his mother does oppose term limits and would not seek to have the ads pulled. Station KCBS-TV said Thursday is planned to pull the ads until a dispute over truth in advertising was resolved. Ads typically must include a mention of who paid for them. Feinstein got a boost from comedy actor Chase with his $50,000 donation. He also performed at an event that featured Henry Mancini and Michael Tucker and Jill Eikenberry of ``L.A. Law.'' The large donation brought criticism from the Wilson camp, but Wilson got his share of celebrity support at an October fund-raiser headlined by first lady Barbara Bush. Among the stars on hand were Chuck Norris, Donald O'Connor, Scott Baio, Phyllis Diller, Efrem Zimbalist Jr. and ``Entertainment Tonight'' hostess Mary Hart. For sheer star power, nothing beat the campaign for Big Green, which would affect a wide range of environmental issues including toxic dumping, offshore oil drilling and trash recycling. The campaign is co-sponsored by Assemblyman Tom Hayden of Santa Monica and state Attorney General John Van de Kamp, who lost to Feinstein in the Democratic primary. Celebrity supporters include Jane Fonda, Meryl Streep, Robin Williams, Bette Midler, Goldie Hawn, Cher, Olivia Newton-John and Ted Danson. ``This is not a point of view,'' Danson said. ``I'm not comparing environmental issues to other issues. ``The environment just pretty much is - it's rocks are hard, water is wet. You may agree or disagree, but it has nothing to do with the reality of what's happening. Acid rain is not a point of view. Dirty harbors are not a point of view. It's reality.''

DOC.HEAD: Farm Bill Sent to President Bush
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 farm bill, an omnibus measure that could reshape American agriculture, is headed to President Bush, who is expected to sign it. The Senate approved the bill 60-36 Thursday, two days after 318-102 passage in the House. Bush administration officials, who worked with Congress in devising the package, have said the president would be satisfied with the five-year, $40.8 billion measure. The bill sets policy for virtually every operation in the Agriculture Department. It establishes new environmental rules for farmers, sets the government's nutrition programs, including food stamps, determines trade policy for food products and sets the government's support programs for commodities. Opposition to the bill came from senators who feared for farmers in their states if a 15 percent reduction in subsidized acreage in the measure goes into effect. The change in support hinges on Congress passing a $13.6 billion spending cut for agriculture over the next five years. Sen. Thomas Daschle, D-S.D., who voted against the bill, said the change in the subsidy program ``amounts to a slow economic death sentence for the nation's family farmers.'' Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., said it threatens the livelihood of one out of every three farmers. ``I don't think the senators know what they will be doing to American farmers if this bill becomes law,'' Baucus said. ``Next year we must make improvements in the farm program.'' But Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., the ranking Republican on the Senate Agriculture Committee, said debate over farm bills often includes forecasts of dire consequences for farmers. ``Predictions for the last two farm bills were egregiously off the mark,'' Lugar said. He said farm income need not fall simply because subsidized acreage is reduced. Lugar said target prices have been frozen and loan rates in some areas raised. He said farmers would be able to use the 15 percent of the acreage being taken off government subsidized crops to plant according to consumer demand. ``American farmers will determine their income by the expertise they have,'' he said. Throughout debate on the bill, Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., emphasized its environmental provisions. He called it ``one of the most important environmental laws passed by this Congress.'' He blamed ``free-wheeling'' spending policies of the Reagan-Bush administrations for the need to cut farm subsidies. ``If we'd had more of this reality over the last 10 years we wouldn't have the deficit we have today,'' Leahy said. The legislation's environmental measures would: -Allow farmers to drain wetlands for farming without net loss of important wildlife habitats by selling the federal government a conservation easement on their property that can be restored to wetland status. -Create an incentive program to help farmers prevent contamination of ground and surface water on 10 million acres of land. -Require the Agriculture Department to help farmers meet state and federal environmental standards. -Require farmers to keep records of hazardous pesticide use and authorize the first effort to assess the threat of global climate change on agriculture. The conference committee dropped a provision in the original Senate bill that would have prohibited export sales of pesticides banned or unregistered in the United States. Chemical companies said it would cause grave economic damage, but Leahy said he would reintroduce the measure next year. The bill also: -Establishes a program to protect 25 million acres of private forestland. -Creates national standards for organic farming. -Creates a rural development administration within USDA to help communities recover economically from the loss of farms. -Sets up a satellite program for rural hospitals and schools to receive information from urban areas. -Establishes a matching fund program for rural businesses. -Authorizes increased funds for existing water and sewer programs in rural communities to improve drinking water and waste disposal. -Freezes target prices on wheat at $4 a bushel; corn, $2.75 a bushel; grain sorghum, $2.61 a bushel; barley $2.36 a bushel; oats, $1.45 a bushel; cotton, 73 cents a pound, rice $10.71 per hundred pounds. -Sets an 18 cent loan rate on sugar. -Freezes government dairy prices at $10.10 per hundred pounds, but requires the agriculture secretary to report to Congress on other options for the dairy program by Aug. 31, 1991. An assessment will be levied on dairy producers if government surpluses exceed 7 billion pounds. -Sets a $5.02 a bushel loan rate on soybeans with a 2 percent service charge.

DOC.HEAD: Governor's Race Hot in Oklahoma
DOC.TEXT: Democrat David Walters is billing himself as a political outsider while Republican opponent Bill Price is emphasizing his crime-fighting credentials in a bitter governor's race in Oklahoma. Price is suing Walters for libel. Walters is accusing Price of trying to buy the election. And the Republican is emphasizing Walters' ties to Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis. President Bush flies to Oklahoma on Monday to campaign for Price and Vice President Dan Quayle was in Oklahoma on Oct. 9 on a fund-raising mission for the Republican. For Walters, a victory would be a comeback. The 38-year-old businessman became mired in a long legal battle over a questionable $162,500 campaign loan in 1986, when he won the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. He lost in the general election four years ago to Republican Henry Bellmon, who is retiring. Price, 42, is making his first political race. But he was a high-profile federal prosecutor in the early 1980s, heading an investigation into a county commissioner kickback scandal in Oklahoma in which some 240 people were convicted. Walters, as he did in 1986, is offering himself as a political outsider who can bring a new approach to government. Price has portrayed Walters as a liberal in a conservative state. Walters was the Oklahoma chairman of Dukakis' presidential campaign. Walters is the person who tried to ``ram Michael Dukakis down the throats'' of Oklahomans, says one Price radio ad. The reduced office rental rate which Walters gave Dukakis is the subject of a federal election complaint filed by the state GOP chairman. The Walters-Price race is the most expensive political campaign in Oklahoma history. Walters is expected to spend more than $2 million and Price upwards of $1.8 million. The bill for the governor's race, counting losing candidates in the primaries, is expected to be about $8 million - more than double the amount spent four years ago. The Walters campaign collected $600,000 at a fund-raiser this week. Walters has accused Price of trying to buy the election by putting $435,000 of his own money into the race. Walters alleged this month that Price was involved in price gouging on oil taken from land held in a family trust. Price, according to Walters, was among a group of people fined $1.74 million for oil overcharges. Price denied the accusations and filed a libel suit against Walters and a campaign consultant. ``Bill Price can dish it out, but he can't take it,'' Walters told Price on a radio broadcast this month. ``You have a total disregard for the truth,'' Price snapped. The clashes over campaign financing, political affiliations and business practices have obscured issues such as education and taxes. The two candidates differ on repeal of a $223 million school reform and tax bill enacted earlier this year, with Bellmon's backing. Walters opposes repeal, saying that would cause too many problems for schools and hurt the state's image nationally. Price says the threat of repeal through an initiative petition is the only way to force the Legislature to enact what he views as needed education reforms, such as an open transfer policy for students and merit pay for teachers. There has been no publicly released independent polling data on the governor's race. Walters is considered the frontrunner, mainly because Democrats outnumber Republicans by a 2-to-1 ratio in Oklahoma. Also, Price was embroiled in an unusually heated GOP primary. Price had to rally from a second-place showing in the primary in order to upend businessman Vince Orza in a runoff election.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Bill Headed for Final Passage
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Senate action scheduled 10 a.m. EDT; lead planned
DOC.TEXT: Congress is taking final action on a 1991 defense bill that slashes President Bush's budget request for the Strategic Defense Initiative and barely keeps alive the B-2 stealth bomber program. The Senate was expected to approve companion military spending and authorization bills today. The spending bill totals $268 billion, a cut of $19 billion from Bush's initial proposal in January. Among the provisions in the bills are a nearly $2 billion cut in the president's $4.7 billion request for the anti-missile SDI program, a reduction in funds for the B-2 bomber that keeps the program alive for at least one more year and sharp cuts in money for land-based nuclear missiles. The bill also provides money for the V-22 Osprey, the tilt-rotor aircraft that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has tried to cancel for two years. The House on Thursday gave voice-vote approval to the spending bill, which largely tracks the authorization bill but diverges from that blueprint on several issues. The spending plan calls for a troop cut of 78,500 from the 2.1-million-member active force, just over $900 million for the MILSTAR communications satellite and full-scale development of the Advanced Tactical Fighter. Bush requested $283 million for full-scale development and $763 million to complete the demonstration and validation phase of the prototype aircraft. The defense blueprint provides $964 million for the program but prohibits full-scale development in the current fiscal year, which began Oct. 1. The authorization bill emphasizes the need for the Air Force to finish demonstrating several technologies, including aerodynamic performance, low observability and engine capability, before beginning full-scale development of the new fighter. The Pentagon plans to begin buying the first of 750 planes, intended to replace the Air Force's F-15, in 1996. The spending bill concurs with the administration's request on the fighter as well as its proposal for the SRAM-T, a tactical nuclear weapon. The authorization measure reduces U.S. troop levels by 100,000, but, bowing to pressure from the Pentagon, gives the defense secretary added authority to limit the troop cut to 80,000 if he believes the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf warrants such a step. The authorization bill also provides $600 million for MILSTAR, but again, responding to Pentagon demands, permits Cheney to transfer money from other accounts for the program.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Farm Bill
Congresswoman Can't Attend Her Fund-raiser with President
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Pat Saiki won't be at her fund-raiser in Honolulu on Friday night to greet her featured guest, President Bush. Saiki, R-Hawaii, said Thursday night that she has to stay in Washington for a budget vote scheduled for Friday afternoon in the House. Saiki would try to return Honolulu on Saturday and meet with Bush over the weekend, Saiki spokesman Bob Wernet said. Bush still planned to attend the fund-raiser at the Hilton Hawaiian Village in Waikiki, Wernet said. Saiki will address the gathering via videotape, he said. Saiki was to have accompanied Bush to Hawaii aboard Air Force One. ``I know that the people of Hawaii will receive President Bush with warmth and aloha,'' Saiki said. ``I only wish I could be there with him to participate in all the activities. ``I express my sincere gratitude to him for coming to Hawaii and focusing the nation's attention on the Pacific, which will be accomplished by his summit with the island leaders,'' Saiki said. Bush was scheduled to arrive at Hickam Air Force Base on Friday, and on Saturday, the president was to meet with Pacific island leaders at The East-West Center.
DOC.HEAD: Sign Says It All For Dissatisfied Electorate
DOC.TEXT: The large sign outside his house succinctly expresses Wendell Gilbert's preferences in the Nov. 6 election: ``Bye-bye Incumbents.'' ``I think there are a lot of people fed up,'' said the Rush City teacher, who's on a leave of absence and living in Cannon Falls. The sign idea came after a conversation with a friend at a high school football game. ``I said that we should vote 'em all out,'' Gilbert said. His friend agreed and the sign, which overlooks a highway, went up earlier this month. Gilbert vows not to vote for either Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz or Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich. ``I've never cared for either Rudy,'' he said. ``There are no issues coming from either one of them ... they campaign the same way.''
DOC.HEAD: President Campaigns For `John Inhofe'
DOC.TEXT: A letter signed by President Bush seeking support for GOP candidates in Oklahoma mentions ``leading Republicans such as Don Nickles, John Inhofe and Mickey Edwards.'' But Mr. President, it's Jim Inhofe. The letter was mailed to Oklahomans recently in search of GOP campaign funds, the Tulsa World reported. Inhofe and Edwards are Oklahoma congressmen. Don Nickles is an Oklahoma U.S. senator. The wrong-name syndrome is hardly new for Republican presidents campaigning in Oklahoma. In 1986, President Reagan referred to Nickles as ``Don Rickles'' at a GOP rally at the University of Oklahoma. In 1964, GOP presidential nominee Barry Goldwater came to Tulsa to campaign for then-U.S. Rep. Page Belcher. He urged the re-election of ``my good friend, Page Bellmon.'' Henry Bellmon was governor at the time.
DOC.HEAD: Durant Unleashes Emotional Ads In Supreme Court Race
DOC.TEXT: A television ad by Michigan Supreme Court candidate Clark Durant re-enacts a murder and criticizes the high court for throwing out a 200-year sentence in the case. The 30-second ad begins with a pistol firing two shots and then cuts to a woman struggling with a man and then running through a house screaming for help. The re-enactment ends with a close-up of a knife held up in the air. ``This is unprecedented. There's never been anything like this in Michigan. This is Freddy Krueger hits the campaign trail for the Supreme Court,'' said political analyst William Ballenger, referring to a horror movie villain. The re-enactment is of a Feb. 25, 1985, murder in which a woman was shot twice, then stabbed at least seven times. Timothy Moore was convicted of second-degree murder in Detroit Recorders Court and sentenced to 100 to 200 years in prison. The Michigan Court of Appeals upheld the sentence, but the high court struck it down. An incumbent justice now up for re-election, Michael Cavanagh, wrote the opinion in that case.
DOC.HEAD: Gay Endorsement For Both Governor Candidates
DOC.TEXT: The New Mexico Lesbian and Gay Political Alliance on Thursday endorsed both Republican Frank Bond and Democrat Bruce King for governor. The alliance said in a news release that ``for the first time in New Mexico history, both gubernatorial candidates oppose discrimination against gay men and lesbians.'' Both Bond and King said they would support a state law prohibiting discrimination based on sexual orientation, the alliance said.
DOC.HEAD: Ag Commissioner Loses Fingertip
DOC.TEXT: A bandaged Jim Hightower will remember this re-election campaign as the one when he lost - lost a piece of his finger, that is. The state agriculture commissioner had an accident with a lawn mower Saturday and cut off the tip of the ring finger on his left hand. The Democrat initially tried to blame Republicans. After a news conference Thursday, Hightower said, ``I was pointing out the economic and environmental failures of the Bush administration and there was just too many of them for one finger,'' Hightower said. But later, Hightower came clean. He said he was rushing to mow his yard before sunset after a full day on the road campaigning. ``I tried to move some flowers, so I could mow under those flowers,'' he said. ``I managed to put my finger under a lawn mower. If you'll check you're manual and remember what your Mama said and what common sense tells us is don't do that. ``And now I can tell you from personal experience. Don't do that,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Hundreds of Daily News Workers Go On Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in 5 grafs with trucks rolling out of other two plants, color; pick up 3rd graf, `Michael Alvino . . .'; SUBS 7th graf, `Picket lines . . .', with 1 graf to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY24
DOC.TEXT: Truck drivers, pressmen and hundreds of other union workers for the Daily News went on strike Thursday night after months of bickering erupted in violence over a worker sitting down on the job. News management published a Friday edition. Relief drivers trucked the first copies out of the paper's Garden City, N.Y., plant early Friday past 200 to 300 picketing strikers. Police said five picketers there were arrested. Within an hour, six trucks accompanied by 25 police officers in riot gear carried papers out of the News' Kearny, N.J., plant. The vehicles' windows were covered with duct tape to protect them against rocks thrown by the crowd of 200 strikers. A short time later, three trucks surrounded by 100 police officers rolled past jeering protesters outside the News' printing plant in the city borough of Brooklyn. Strikers there pelted buses carrying replacement workers with bottles, rocks and eggs, breaking some windows. A fireworks-style explosive was set off underneath one bus. Police reported two arrests. Michael Alvino, president of the drivers' union, got cheers from his membership when he announced the strike. Seven of the newspaper's 10 unions followed the drivers' lead, said George McDonald, head of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella group for the unions. A ninth union, the Newspaper Guild, said it would honor the picket lines. The 10th union, for typographical workers, had said it would not strike because it has lifetime guaranteed jobs for its 200 members. About 1,800 workers went on strike. The Newspaper Guild, whose members planned to meet Friday, has about 800 members. Picket lines were set up at the newspaper's Manhattan building and outside its three printing plants. About 2 a.m. Friday, three to four hours later than usual, the first copies of Friday's edition were trucked out of the Garden City plant, said a News management source who spoke on condition that his name not be used. The source could not say how many copies would be printed. The paper's usual weekday circulation is 1.18 million. ``The trucks have been in and out. The papers are getting out,'' Lt. William Fitzpatrick of the Garden City police confirmed. He said five of 200 to 300 picketers were arrested, mostly on disorderly conduct charges. He reported no serious injuries. Two people were charged with disorderly conduct at the Brooklyn plant, police said. One threw a rock at a bus carrying replacement workers but missed and hit a police officer. Details of the second charge were not immediately available. ``It is indeed unfortunate that a strike was provoked by these unions against the Daily News at a time when we were involved in the collective bargaining process to resolve our differences,'' said John Sloan, the newspaper's vice president for labor relations. The strike comes more than six months after the expiration of contracts between the Daily News and its 10 unions, months marked by bitter exchanges but stalemated negotiations. The strike followed a walkout early Thursday at the Brooklyn printing plant in a dispute over a union worker's right to do his job sitting down. A bus carrying replacement workers at the plant was attacked by about 200 employees with sticks, smashing its windshield. Police cited two workers. Following the attack, labor accused management of a lockout. A coalition of the newspaper's 10 unions met Thursday afternoon, then sent leaders to a meeting with management at the Daily News' headquarters. They emerged 50 minutes later, shaken. The Daily News is the nation's second largest metropolitan daily and has 3,500 employees. But during the past decade it has lost about $115 million and seen daily circulation slip by about 700,000. The Daily News has been caught in one of the nation's fiercest newspaper wars and analysts have questioned whether the city can support three tabloids and The New York Times. The New York Post and New York Newsday planned to increase press runs. The Daily News' managers say they need to end labor abuses, have the ability to set staff sizes and save $50 million to $70 million annually. The unions say the newspaper is trying to break them and they have called for an advertisers' boycott. The workers walked out early Thursday after their business agent, Seymour Goldstein, was ejected from the plant by management, according to George McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, a union umbrella group. ``It's indeed unfortunate, No. 1, that the drivers union has struck the Daily News when we are in the process of collective bargaining. And, No. 2, it's indeed unfortunate that they resorted to unruly and violent behavior,'' responded Sloan. Sloan said about 800,000 copies of Thursday's News had been printed. The crisis apparently began when Goldstein became involved in a dispute involving a drivers' union member who was working while sitting down. McDonald said the man's job did not involve driving, but required him to make sure newspapers properly came off of a conveyor belt; that he was on ``light duty'' because of a disability; and that many healthy workers normally sit and read magazines while doing the job. When supervisors told the man to work standing, Goldstein said, ``He appealed to me. I told him to sit down. They gave me two choices: leave or be escorted out. They escorted me out.'' When Goldstein went out, so did the drivers, McDonald said. Sloan said Goldstein was expelled for ``countermanding a direct order from the supervisor. As far as we are concerned, (whether the employee is disabled) is not the issue here.'' The employee was suspended. The bus carrying replacement workers arrived little more than half an hour later. ``This was an organized plan to lock us out,'' Goldstein said. ``Security is under orders to not let us in.'' Two men were given tickets for criminal offenses, one for allegedly inciting workers to do further damage, the other for letting the air out of delivery truck tires. Neither was held. Other News employees were seen draining radiators on delivery trucks, and police later said the radiators of 40 trucks were punctured. Firefighters put out a small fire in the back of a delivery truck, and another truck was gutted by fire. Angry employees also blocked the street with about 20 delivery trucks.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Justice Powell: Vote in Georgia Sodomy Case Probably a `Mistake'
DOC.TEXT: Retired Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell says he ``probably made a mistake'' in casting the pivotal vote in a 1986 decision that denied the right of privacy to consenting homosexuals. But he still regards the decision upholding Georgia's anti-sodomy law as ``one of little or no importance'' because no one actually had been prosecuted for homosexual conduct, Powell said. His current views on the matter were revealed during a question-and-answer session after a lecture the retired justice delivered at New York University School of Law on Oct. 18. According to The National Law Journal, Powell told the law students, ``I think I probably made a mistake in that one'' when asked about the 5-4 ruling in 1986. In a report to be published Monday, the legal newspaper quotes Powell as saying in an interview that he now believes sodomy decision conflicts with the court's approach to privacy rights in its 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision, which legalized abortion. Powell voted with the majority in that ruling. ``I do think (the 1986 decision) was inconsistent in a general way with Roe,'' Powell told the newspaper. ``When I had the opportunity to re-read the opinion a few months later, I thought the dissent had the better of the argument.'' Powell told The Associated Press on Thursday he stands by the statement he made to the National Law Journal. But he said he is surprised his re-evaluation of the 1986 ruling is considered newsworthy. ``I thought it was a frivolous case,'' Powell said. ``I still think it was a frivolous case. But perhaps on more reflection I could have reached a different result.'' The 1986 ruling was one of the most publicized and controversial high court rulings of that term. The Washington Post later reported that Powell originally planned to vote to strike down Georgia's ban on sodomy. The newspaper, quoting anonymous sources, said Powell voted at a private conference of the nine justices to strike down the Georgia law. Such votes are tentative, and justices may change their minds before the decisions are announced. Justice Byron R. White, who wrote the court's majority opinion in the 1986 case, said, ``The proposition that any kind of private sexual conduct between consenting adults is constitutionally insulated from state proscription is unsupportable.'' The decision has been bitterly denounced by gay rights groups. The court's interpretation of the scope of privacy rights remains one of the hottest issues confronting the justices - especially in the area of abortion. The court has held that Americans have a fundamental privacy right to marry, have children and practice birth control. The Georgia law was challenged by Michael Hardwick, an Atlanta bartender and homosexual who was arrested in 1982 for allegedly committing sodomy in his home. Prosecutors later dropped the charge, which carries a maximum 20-year prison penalty upon conviction. The case reached the Supreme Court after Hardwick sued Georgia officials to have the law declared unconstitutional. In Atlanta, the Atlanta Gay Alliance said it understood Hardwick had moved to Key West, Fla. There was no telephone listed for him there.

DOC.HEAD: Elusive Scientist Agrees To Appear for Cold Fusion Review
DOC.TEXT: A scientist who pioneered Utah's cold fusion research and dropped out of contact before skipping a state oversight committee meeting belatedly agreed to meet with the panel early next month. Members of the Fusion Energy Advisory Council on Thursday voted to try to force electrochemist B. Stanley Pons to appear for the Nov. 7 review. Minutes later, Pons agreed in a telephone call to show up. ``I told him he was wanted, that it was necessary,'' Chief Deputy Attorney General Joe Tesch told the council. ``Stan Pons committed he would be here on Nov. 7.'' The telephone call arranged by Pons' attorney appeared to ease the panel's irritation with Pons and British colleague Martin Fleischmann for missing the meeting and being virtually unreachable, except through their lawyer. ``We are perfectly willing to fund the work, but we do expect accountability,'' said Raymond Hixson, council chairman. ``We must know what we are getting for the money.'' The advisory council oversees the state's interest in the research. The Legislature appropriated $5 million following the electrochemists' March 1989 announcement that they had achieved a fusion reaction in a tabletop experiment at room temperature. If true, the achievement could prove a cheap solution to energy sources. But most scientists remain skeptical, Fritz Will, director of the National Cold Fusion Institute, told the panel in an overview of the institute's research. Will said dozens of scientists around the world have reported achieving similar results. He said experiments continue to produce excess heat and other nuclear fusion indicators. He declined to discuss the specific experiments being done by Pons and Fleischmann. Fusion is the process that powers the sun, stars and hydrogen bombs. It is achieved when atomic paticles fuse and release large amounts of energy. The process usually requires millions of degrees of heat to get started. The panel's unanimous decision to ask University of Utah President Chase Peterson to apply pressure on Pons to attend a review grew out of its frustration with his unexplained absence. The pair's attorney, C. Gary Triggs, told Tesch the researchers were reluctant to appear Thursday because of a patent application they were preparing. Hixson said that argument was faulty because the state will own any patents produced from the work and panel members are sworn to secrecy. Fleischmann, reached at his home in Tisbury, England, said he had not learned of the council meeting until a journalist told him late Wednesday. Will said he had faxed a notice to Fleischmann more than a week ago and later telephoned the scientist's office, only to be told he was unavailable. ``We have attempted to have the two present during an external review in October. We have abundantly explained; they have categorically refused,'' Will said before the meeting. Triggs said Pons and Fleischmann had explained they would be out of the country during October. The attorney would not say where Pons had gone, although the teacher of his young son said Wednesday the family had told her they would be in France for ``a year or two.'' Pons has applied for a one-year sabbatical. Peterson said the request would be handled by the Chemistry Department, whcih Pons once chaired. Besides the scientific review, the institute is scrambling for renewed funding. An audit was completed recently, but State Auditor Tom Allen said he would not disclose its recommendations until the institute has responded.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Committee Orders Investigation of News Leaks
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee says it has arranged for an outside investigation of unauthorized disclosures after news leaks from its probe of five senators linked to a failed savings and loan. The panel, after a lengthy closed meeting Thursday, also labeled as false a report saying it was considering giving Charles H. Keating Jr., who headed failed Lincoln Savings & Loan Association, an assurance that information he gives to Congress will not be used against him. ``The committee has at no time discussed or considered granting immunity to Charles Keating Jr.,'' the panel said. ``Reports to the contrary are incorrect.'' The Los Angeles Times quoted unidentified committee sources in a Thursday report that said Ethics Committee members were weighing a guarantee known as limited immunity for Keating. The Times' national editor, Norman Miller, said Thursday the newspaper stood by its story. ``We believe our sources are accurate,'' Miller said. ``It may be there's some technical difference that could account for their statement. But we're confident we were given a correct story.'' A grant of limited immunity for a defendant appearing before Congress could jeopardize a criminal prosecution. This kind of immunity means a prosecutor can make no use of the testimony. The committee is investigating whether the so-called ``Keating Five'' senators violated ethics rules in interceding with federal regulators on behalf of Lincoln Savings. Hearings are scheduled to begin Nov. 15. Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich.; John Glenn, D-Ohio; and John McCain, R-Ariz., received a total of $1.3 million in campaign contributions, or donations to favored causes, from Keating, former chairman of Phoenix-based American Continental Corp., Lincoln's parent company. All five have denied any connection between Keating's money and their help for the Irvine, Calif.-based thrift, which was seized by the U.S. government in April 1989 at a potential cost to taxpayers of more than $2 billion. If the committee eventually decides Senate rules were broken, it could recommend that the full Senate impose severe sanctions such as a censure or expulsion or it could administer a mild punishment itself such as a letter of rebuke. In a statement signed by Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., the chairman, and Vice-Chairman Warren Rudman, R-N.H., the panel said Thursday ``it appears ... some committee sensitive documents have been disclosed to the press.'' ``Some of these press articles have contained a number of inaccuracies, distortions and misstatements,'' it said. ``Because some of these disclosures may have come from the committee itself, we concluded that an outside organization would be best able to conduct an independent and impartial inquiry into this matter.'' The panel said it asked the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, to conduct the probe. ``The committee will not speculate upon motives,'' the statement said, ``but does observe that such conduct discredits the individuals responsible, and violates the committee's rules.'' Keating, 66, and the three associates face 42 counts of securities fraud related to the sale of $200 million in bonds by Lincoln's Southern California branches to thousands of investors. Lincoln collapsed in April 1989, rendering the bonds worthless. Bailing out Lincoln could cost taxpayers $2 billion, regulators have said. Keating is free on $300,000 bail. Trial in Superior Court in Los Angeles is set to begin on Nov. 26. Documents recently obtained by The Associated Press and others indicate that Cranston, DeConcini and Riegle had more extensive relationships with Keating than they previously acknowledged. For example, the documents show that Cranston wrote Keating to thank him for a $250,000 contribution to a Cranston-backed voter registration project and at the same time expressed his pleasure that Keating met with the top thrift regulator to plead his case about Lincoln.

DOC.HEAD: Influence Peddling Charges, Infighting Shake Brazil's Government
DOC.TEXT: Resignations, charges of influence peddling and infighting are damaging the image of President Fernando Collor de Mello's 7-month-old conservative government. ``The government retains its authority but its credibility has been substantially weakened,'' said prominent sociologist Helio Jaguaribe. ``Collor must take action soon to control the damage.'' The charges are especially harmful because Collor promised to build a ``new Brazil,'' with morality and austerity as its foundations, waging a painful war on inflation. Even though the president has not been directly implicated in any alleged wrongdoing, his image appears to have suffered. On Wednesday, Collor addressed the subject for the first time during a five-day visit to Portugal, saying he would dismiss any government official who ``sacrificed the ideas that are taking us forward.'' The president reportedly called a Monday Cabinet meeting to discuss the situation. Collor's administration has been shaken in recent weeks by a series of well-publicized events. Among the most damaging: -On Oct. 19, Luis Octavio da Motta Veiga, head of the huge state oil monopoly Petrobras, was forced to step down. He said the cause was his refusal to approve a $40 million loan to a Sao Paulo businessman, despite pressure from Collor's friend and power broker Paulo Cesar Farias. Presidential spokesman Claudio Humberto Rosa e Silva said Motta Veiga was fired due to ``incompetence and insubordination.'' Motta Veiga said he would not reply to a ``circus helper.'' -Justice Minister Bernardo Cabral resigned in early October after the press revealed he was having an affair with Economy Minister Zelia Cardoso de Mello. Cabral accused Rosa e Silva of plotting behind his back and calling the press spokesman ``worthless.'' The media observed that Cabral's resignation broke an earlier pledge by Collor that all his ministers would serve until his term expired in 1994. -Despite official denials, the economy minister's job is also rumored to be in jeopardy, due to the romantic scandal and slow progress in bringing inflation down from its current monthly level of more than 12 percent. -Eduardo Cardoso, a Brasilia businessman and also a friend of Collor, recently received a large loan with generous terms from the Caixa Economica Federal, the government savings bank. Some charged it was granted on political grounds. So far, negative fallout from the events and rumors seems largely limited to the small middle class and the university-educated elite. Most observers say Brazil's poor majority are far more concerned with bread-and-butter issues than political intrigue. But Luis Eduardo Soares, a political science professor at Rio's University Research Institute, said: ``Political opinion in Brazil is largely formed by a very small group. It is exactly those people who have reacted most negatively to all the current noise.'' Carlos Castello Branco, the country's most prestigious political writer, recently noted a ``growing apprehension'' about events taking place. ``The impression being formed is that `New Brazil' is in fact no more than a remake of `Old Brazil,''' he wrote in a Wednesday newspaper column. Jaguaribe said the government was being ``surrounded by an aura of corruption'' due to a few bad apples. Some analysts say Collor's difficulties have been exaggerated, however. They note conservatives won major victories in Oct. 3 congressional and gubernatorial elections, greatly strengthening the president's hand. ``Too much significance is given to these court skirmishes, which are really quite usual,'' said political analyst Sergio Abranches.

DOC.HEAD: Faisal Husseini Ignites Strong Feelings on Both Sides
DOC.TEXT: When the Israelis jailed Palestinian leader Faisal Husseini in 1987, he spent much of his 18 months behind bars teaching himself Hebrew. The son of the Palestinians' most famous war hero used his new language to launch a campaign urging Israelis to back his people's drive for independent statehood. On Thursday, fresh from another spell in jail, Husseini renewed his appeal, this time in English and his native Arabic. ``We are fighting to free our people, not to enslave any other people,'' he told a crowded news conference in Arab east Jerusalem. ``We are fighting to build our state, not to destroy any other state.'' Husseini was arrested Oct. 8 on suspicion of fomenting riots on the Temple Mount in which Jewish worshipers were stoned and Israeli gunfire killed at least 19 Palestinians. He walked free 17 days later into a new ``circle of blood,'' as he put it - a wave of Arab attacks on Jews and Jewish vengeance assaults. He condemned the bloodshed. ``There is no difference for me between the crying of a Palestinian woman who lost her son or the crying of an Israeli woman who lost her son,'' Husseini said. Husseini denies fomenting the Temple Mount violence. He blames Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's government for creating ``a sense of hopelessness'' among Palestinians by refusing to negotiate peace and by settling Jews on occupied land that is home to 1.7 million Palestinians. He said Israel's refusal to accept a U.N. probe of the Temple Mount incident could spur further violence. ``If there is no hope, if Israel decides to be outside international legitimacy ... they are ensuring we will live in a jungle,'' Husseini said. Israel says such an investigation wold challenge its self-proclaimed sovereignty over Arab Jerusalem. An outspoken voice for coexistence, Husseini is recognized by both Palestinians and Israelis as the Palestine Liberation Organization's top supporter in Jerusalem, and the political leader of the 34-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation. Balding, asthmatic and not given to rousing oratory, 50-year-old Husseini nonetheless arouses strong emotions in both camps. When his name came up during a televised debate Wednesday night, all four Israeli lawmakers on the panel began talking heatedly at once. Uzi Baram of the opposition Labor Party argued that Husseini represented Palestinian moderation and that if Israel didn't talk to him, it might end up having to talk to Hamas, the Moslem fundamentalist movement. But Uzi Landau of the ruling right-wing Likud bloc wouldn't hear of it. ``The difference between Faisal Husseini and Hamas is exactly the same as the difference between Saddam Hussein and the Ayatollah Khomeini,'' he said. Arab opinion is divided, too. His friend and colleague Sari Nusseibeh says Husseini is a natural leader ``who feels the responsibility to lead.'' A recent Islamic fundamentalist tract, however, pounds Husseini for conducting armchair politics instead of fighting in the streets. Such resentment stems partly from Husseini's high-profile contacts with Israelis, noteably Yael Dayan, daughter of the late Israeli war hero Moshe Dayan. They made a joint lecture tour of the United States this year. Husseini was a child of revolution. He was born in Baghdad, where his father, Abdul Khader Husseini, was hiding from the British army for participating in the 1936-39 Arab uprising in what is now Israel. He was 7 when his father died leading an assault on Israeli troops in the 1948 battle for Jerusalem. Husseini attended universities in Baghdad, Cairo and Beirut, but never graduated. Later he joined the Palestine Liberation Army, a military arm of the PLO scattered in the Arab world. Husseini thinks his much-revered father would identify with his activities today, would understand the shift from the battlefield to the international political arena. ``I believe he was fighting starting from his love for his people, for his land, not starting from hating others,'' Husseini said. The Israelis first arrested Husseini in 1967 after they captured Arab Jerusalem. Parts of a gun were found in his house, and he spent the next year in jail. In 1987 he was detained without charge for two periods adding up to 18 months. On Wednesday, he was freed on personal bail, and police say inquiries continue.

DOC.HEAD: Once Dying Breed on Comeback Trail
DOC.TEXT: Once replaced by a fatter breed of cattle, the legendary Texas Longhorn is on the comeback trail in grocery stores as Americans become more health-conscious, cattle raisers say. ``Probably the largest hurdle we have is convincing old-time cattle raisers they need to change,'' Bill Anthony, president of the International Texas Longhorn Association, said at the group's first meeting Thursday. Anthony, an Ardmore, Okla. rancher, started raising Longhorns 25 years ago and has fallen in love with the breed. ``They are extremely intelligent. You can make housepets out them if you want.'' But it's not their intelligence that is putting them back on the market. ``The bottom line is the Longhorn has qualities consumers want on their dinner plates and the qualities many ranchers are seeking to develop in their livestock,'' said Mike Moeller, deputy state agriculture commissioner. Moeller said Longhorn beef has 10 percent fat and yields a greater percentage of lean beef than any other breed. The hardy breed had been replaced by fatter stock by the turn of the century. For cattlemen, Longhorns are a low-maintenance, genetic gold mine. Descended from Spanish cattle brought here centuries ago, the Longhorn has adapted to severe climates, can forage on poor quality grass, is resistant to several diseases and produces rich milk. When bred with other breeds, the Longhorns cut down on the number of calving problems, Moeller said. Also there is the mystique of raising an animal that helped create the cowboy and turn the country into a people of beefeaters. ``When you have something that has been for so many years of historical greatness, it's hard not to be fond of Texas Longhorn cattle,'' Anthony said. The first Longhorns were sent out of Texas to New Orleans in the 1840s. A few were driven to Missouri later in that decade. In the 1850s, Longhorns were herded all the way to Chicago. But the Civil War intervened and the men who had been driving cattle took up arms or sold the cattle they raised to armies from both sides. After the war, driving Longhorns to railheads in Kansas became big business. The Texas State Historical Association estimates that 10 million Longhorns were driven northward on the Chisholm Trail during the first 25 years after the the Civil War. The Longhorn replaced the buffalo as meat for men who were building the railroads and helping the population move westward. The huge buffalo herds had been decimated by too much hunting.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Prostate Cancer Drug for Treating Endometriosis in Women
DOC.TEXT: A drug newly approved for fighting a painful and fertility-threatening condition among millions of women also may help treat premenstrual syndrome, benign breast tumors and other ailments, doctors say. The drug, Lupron Depot, was approved by the federal Food and Drug Administration this week for treating endometriosis, a sometimes painful condition that occurs when tissue lining the womb migrates to the abdomen and pelvis. If it develops in the ovaries or fallopian tubes it can cause blocking, scarring and infertility. Lupron Depot previously had been approved only for use as a prostate-cancer medicine, but doctors had for years prescribed it to women suffering from endometriosis because they knew it worked. Insurance companies, however, refused to cover its costs - $252 per monthly injection, typically administered for six months - because it did not have approval for that use. Doctors said this week's OK could also encourage its use in many other gynecological applications. ``These agents (in the same class as Lupron Depot) are clearly effective for a number of other diseases, such as premenstrual syndrome, uterine fibroids, and polycystic ovary syndrome,'' said Dr. Robert L. Barbieri, chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at State University of New York at Stony Brook. Premenstrual syndrome is marked by irritability, tension or depression in possible combination with breast tenderness, fluid retention and headaches; fibroids by the growth of benign tumors in the womb; and polycystic ovary syndrome by the growth of cysts in the ovaries. Dr. Edward L. Marut, director of reproductive endocrinology and infertility at Michael Reese Hospital and Medical Center in Chicago, said Lupron Depot also may be useful in treating benign breast tumors. In combatting endometriosis, the drug suppresses production of the female hormone estrogen, which controls the growth of the tissue lining the womb, called the endometrium. An estimated 2 million to 5 million women have endometriosis. It is mild or symptom-free in some people but in others it can cause severe menstrual cramps, pain during sexual intercourse, painful urination or painful bowel movements. Doctors say side effects of Lupron Depot resemble those of menopause, including hot flashes, but the effects are not permanent and may be relieved with other medication. ``The main downside of the drug is it does cause a low estrogen state, and it may cause thinning of vertebral bones,'' Barbieri said. He added that further study will be necessary to determine whether the amount of bone-thinning is significant. ``In essence what we're doing is creating a temporary, medically induced menopause, a reversible menopause, that, in turn, stops the stimulation of the endometriosis,'' said Dr. James Miller, medical director at TAP Pharmaceuticals, which manufactures the drug. Barbieri said the only other drug products approved for endometriosis treatment are Synarel, a nasal spray that has a similar biological mechanism as Lupron Depot and costs about the same, and Danazol, a derivative of the male hormone testosterone that costs about half as much. Synarel has the disadvantage of requiring twice daily doses for six months and being poorly absorbed by the body, he said. Danazol has the disadvantage of causing women to develop male traits - a deepening of the voice, facial hair, oilier skin and upper body muscles.

DOC.HEAD: Summer Choice Between Young, Sexy Styles and Sensible Chic
DOC.TEXT: Exuding youth and sex, or worldly chic, ready-to-wear fashions for summer shown recently offered split-personality alternatives. Will the real Paris fashion world please stand up, observers at last week's shows are tempted to ask. On one hand, there were unabashed, nubile silhouettes molded by Lycra body stockings, with fancy toppers. On the other, Paris still opts for fitted, chic suits and a new line of looser, fluid dresses and blousons, airy shirt-jackets or flared tops to keep women of all ages moving in comfort. Lacy lingerie inspirations, decolletes, hot pants, navel-baring bra-and-sarong outfits abound. But for the 1990s, there's also a refreshing return to looser looks in airy, long duster jackets or trapeze coats, or new-looking billowing party pants. In silky Turkish style, they're done with panache at both Givenchy - with genteel chic - and Saint Laurent, with showy glitz. Highlights from the collections offer ideas for everybody: Claude Montana turned in an outstanding collection of short, skimpy mini dresses in full, belted coats or modified A-lines. They came most often in silk fabrics, with hemlines often swooping deep in the back. In white or ivory spangled with silver, or in acidic shades of pink, yellow and green, Montana's clothes were stunning displays of talent. Statesmen's teen-age daughters, rather than their wives, will now want to dress at Chanel, as shown by Karl Lagerfeld. Youngsters took up his idea of wearing just a long jacket over tights or leggings, and now Lagerfeld has varied the menu with a bevy of great jackets, short or long. And they can be worn with other things than merely tights or pleated minis. But winds of change are also blowing for Chanel in new, loose and easy toppers. Christian Lacroix's collection was as vibrantly glowing with color as ever, with a calculated risk in mixes of plaids and patterns, brocades, taffetas and chiffons. Even the Lacroix solid-color suits with their typical fitted or flyaway bolerojjackets and straight minis or shaped oval skirts came in mixes of hot-colored raw silks. Like many Paris designers, Lacroix could not resist the call of the body stocking. He showed some of the liveliest Pucci-style prints in town on lycra bodysuits and easy shirt-jackets. Ungaro's flowery extravaganza went both new in style with his blousing chemise dresses and typically Ungaro sexy in style with fitted, draped late-day wear. He also offered a fine array of less-constricting dresses with jackets or suits - typical of this great tailor. Jean-Louis Scherrer, the animal-lover whose star model and daughter Laetitia also hosts a weekend TV wildlife show, brought out his panoply of jungle and wild-animal prints in clothes fitted and loose. Nearly everyone from Saint Laurent to Guy Laroche and Scherrer showed impeccable yet individual mariner styles in navy, white and sometimes red. Safari or bush jackets are another favorite, along with a welter of well-cut long and tailored or slim pants to vie with the bodysuits, hot pants and wider, flaring shorts in 1930s style. There is hope for those who wish for longer skirts, as women still wear them on the streets, even in Paris. A few new versions in slim or flared mid-calf skirts crept in at Saint Laurent, Sonia Rykiel and Kenzo. Fabrics to watch for spring and summer are on the light side: lightweight gabardine and broadcloth or cashmere blends come out in spring coats and suits. Colors run the gamut, with plenty of navy and white in classic daytime wear. There is heavy emphasis on reds and pinks from smoky and tea rose to mandarin orange, Day-Glo or shocking pink.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Saudis Expelled More Than 400,000 Yemenis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: SAN`A, Yemen (AP) - Yemen, a nation born only five months ago from the merger of North and South Yemen, is already at odds with its powerful neighbor, Saudi Arabia. More than 400,000 Yemenis have left Saudi Arabia in the past five weeks, in what Yemen's foreign minister says is a Saudi bid to cripple its fledgling government. The foreign minister, Abd al-Karim al-Iryani, said Saudi pressure was not over Yemen's support for Iraq but rather territorial claims and other issues. He said Saudi Arabia had already complained officially that Yemen would not move ``on certain aspects of our relationship'' which Iryani described as boundaries in a potentially oil-rich quarter. The two Yemens united on May 22, raising old border issues predating the establishment of Saudi Arabia in the 1930s. The Saudis hoped that Yemen would be overwhelmed by the deluge of refugees, Iryani said. Also, the remittances from Yemenis in Saudi Arabia had made up a third of the gross national product, so the Saudi move was a financial blow. ``We are easily reabsorbing 400,000 people,'' Iryani said. ``There will be difficulties, of course, but we will not go down the drain as the Saudis wish us to do.'' On Sept. 18, Saudi authorities withdrew special status for the 1 million to 2 million Yemenis in the kingdom, many of whom had been residents for more than 30 years. They were given a month to find a Saudi sponsor or go home. On Tuesday, the Saudis extended the deadline by a month. ``We are simply saying that all foreigners are created equal,'' a senior Saudi official told The Associated Press on Monday. ``Why should we give them special treatment when they turn on us?'' Iryani dismissed as ``malicious nonsense'' what he called Saudi-inspired rumors that Saddam Hussein had promised Yemen the disputed Asir region or that Iraqi missiles were installed here. Yemen condemned the invasion of Kuwait, he said, and objected only to non-Arab troops in the region. He said Yemen abstained on crucial Security Council votes against Saddam because its envoy was awaiting word from the Arab League. ``Yemen never took a firm stand in support of Iraq,'' he said. Yemen, like Jordan, argued that Saddam should be pushed out of Kuwait - but not by hardening his position with a Western presence. ``The Saudis expected us to toe the line without question,'' Iryani complained. He acknowledged that Saudi Arabia had committed $100 million a year in budgetary support and had made major concessions to Yemen. ``We are not denying they have done very well in helping Yemen, but to what end do you want to help?'' he said. ``Quite clearly, we have discovered it was not for simple neighborliness, common faith, common destiny. Apparently, it was intended for something else.'' Western diplomats in San`a estimate the returnees at about 350,000. One, who had toured the border area, said he saw no sign that Saudi authorities had prevented them from selling their holdings and bringing out property. ``It looks like they can absorb 400,000 without too much trouble,'' said the diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But what happens if it goes to a million?'' The Saudis dispute the 350,000 figure as inflated. Iryani estimated that Yemen's economy would taken up to three years to recover from the shock but would emerge stronger as a result. The main hope, he said, is oil. Hunt Consolidated Inc. of Dallas is already producing 210,000 barrels a day near Marib at the southern end of the empty quarter. Recently, Saudi engineers reported a find in the south that might increase their reserves by 20 percent. That, Iryani said, was the heart of the dispute. ``If there is oil to the south and oil to the north, it is likely there is oil in the middle.''

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Reaches 89 in Hindu-Moslem Violence
DOC.TEXT: The religious dispute that pits Hindus against Moslems is threatening to bring down the government, and the death toll in the violence has risen to 89, according to news reports today. United News of India reported that 71 people died Wednesday and Thursday in religious riots in the cities of Jaipur and Jodhpur in western Rajasthan state. The news agency quoted hospital sources as saying 68 bodies of people killed in the rioting had been brought to Jaipur, and at least three other people were known to have died. Elsewhere in the country, news reports said that at least 18 others had died in Hindu-Moslem clashes since Tuesday when the leader of a right-wing Hindu party was arrested. Lal Krishna Advani was detained while leading a caravan across northern Indian to rally support for a campaign to replace a 16th century Moslem mosque with a Hindu temple in the Uttar Pradesh city of Ayodhya. Hindus claim the mosque, built in 1528, is on the site of the birthplace of Lord Rama, and thus is as holy to Hindus as Mecca is to Moslems. The arrest of Advani, president of the Bharatiya Janata Party, triggered riots in a half-dozen states where large Moslem communities are mingled among the Hindu majority. As many as 50,000 supporters of Advani's party have been placed under ``preventive arrest'' over the past two weeks. Indian law allows people to be detained without charges when authorities fear there is a threat to public safety. After Advani's arrest, his party withdrew its support for Singh's coalition government, plunging India into a political crisis. The party's defection deprived Singh of a parliamentary majority. Singh said he would seek a vote of confidence on Nov. 7 to prove he could still muster a parliamentary majority. But the Congress Party, the largest opposition party, said it would oppose Singh in any vote of confidence because of his handling of the religious dispute. Within Singh's fractious Janata Dal party, there appeared to be moves under way to oust him as party leader. The Times of India newspaper reported a concerted effort in top party circles to replace Singh so Janata Dal could remain in power. The national daily said smaller parties in the government coalition had indicated they ``would not be adverse to support a government minus V.P. Singh ... if it can spare the nation travails of another parliamentary poll within a year.'' Singh's Janata Dal party and smaller partners in his National Front coalition government now hold 146 seats in the 522-member policy-making lower house - the Lok Sabha, or House of the People. He still has the support of the Communist-led Left Front alliance, which has 51 seats, but the loss of the 86 seats held by the Bharatiya Janata Party has cost him his majority. The opposition Congress Party and its allies hold 210 seats. The remainder are held by smaller parties and independents. The political crisis was triggered by a religious dispute over a shrine in Ayodhya, a town of 40,000 in Uttar Pradesh. Tens of thousands of Hindus have converged on Ayodhya this week to help build the temple. The government has dispatched tens of thousands of police and paramilitary troops to prevent violent clashes. Singh and his Janata Dal party allies who run Uttar Pradesh's state government have tried to halt construction of the temple until a court can rule on the religious dispute. Moslems comprise only 12 percent of India's 880 million people. India is officially a secular state, but the Hindus make up 82 percent of the population and dominate the government.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Grills Industry, Administration Officials On Oil Prices
DOC.TEXT: An administration energy expert says consumers can expect the price of gasoline to hover between $1.30 and $1.62 over the next year, that is if no war breaks out in the Persian Gulf. U.S. Energy Information Administrator Calvin Kent also told a Senate panel Thursday to expect home heating oil prices to range between $1.13 and $1.45 per gallon through 1991, roughly equal to the high levels heating oil reached in last winter's cold snap. Kent's forecast came in the opening session of a three-day hearing on why oil prices shoot up on the slightest rumor of trouble in the Mideast but don't seem to come down on rumors of peace. Kent told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee that an improvement in the Mideast situation might lower the price of crude oil, but an immediate response at the gasoline pump shouldn't be expected. ``Prices go up more quickly than they come down,'' Kent said. Kent's price estimates assume that the Persian Gulf crisis does not dissolve into war, that the winter is normal in severity and that market factors such as inventories and daily oil production remain relatively stable. Also assumed in his forecast was that crude oil remains at about $30 per barrel. That assumption seemed open to question even as he testified; in New York's mercantile exchange oil jumped $3.17 per barrel in early trading to $34.25 by mid day.
DOC.HEAD: New York Congressman Hospitalized After Becoming Ill
