DOC.TEXT: A New York congressman was hospitalized and undergoing tests after he reportedly complained of feeling ill at his office. A spokesman said Rep. Raymond McGrath, a Republican, was admitted to Walter Reed Army Medical Center Thursday. ``He felt faint. He broke out in a sweat. He said he felt a heaviness in the chest - not pain,'' said Dan Zielinski. ``He was conscious, he was speaking.'' A doctor examined McGrath, 48, before he was taken to Walter Reed about 1:30 p.m., Zielinski said.
DOC.HEAD: Survey: Majority of Catholics Oppose Bishops' Political Involvement
DOC.TEXT: A large majority of Roman Catholics oppose the involvement of U.S. bishops in abortion politics, according to a survey released by a private group of Catholics. The poll commissioned by Catholics for a Free Choice found that 71 percent of Catholics and 74 percent of all respondents said Catholic bishops should not ``use the political arena to advance their moral opinions.'' Results of the survey were made public. ``What we find is that Catholics and non-Catholics are opposed to the style and approach the bishops are taking on abortion politics,'' Frances Kissling, president of Catholics for a Free Choice, said at a news conference. Helen Alvare, public information director at the pro-life office of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, disagreed with the results of the survey. ``It promotes the idea that the bishops shouldn't speak out on the human rights issue of abortion,'' she said. ``It would prefer to gag us as moral leaders in the public square. ``In fact, the bishops won't be silenced on any human rights issue, including things like economic justice, civil rights or abortion,'' Alvare said, contending that most of the poll questions involved the church's getting involved in elections, ``which we don't do.'' She also said the survey did not distinguish between regular churchgoing Catholics and Catholics who don't go to church regularly. Kissling said the U.S. Catholic Conference and a number of bishops were inappropriately participating in the political process by attacking individual candidates and elected officials whose views on abortion differ from theirs.

DOC.HEAD: Female Deserter a Male And Ready for Duty, Army Says
DOC.TEXT: The Army reservist that military officials mistakenly listed as a deserter and a female is neither. Pfc. Lavern Fay Johnson is willing to serve. And he's a man. Army officials said Thursday they mistakenly identified Johnson, 26, of Bluford, as a female deserter Wednesday while discussing the case of Spec. Stephanie Atkinson of Murphysboro. Atkinson, who has refused to report for duty with the 300th Adjutant Postal Company, says she has become a concientious objector and opposes the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf. ``Someone erred,'' said the Army's Fort Sheridan spokesman, Maj. Bob Host. ``He has been removed from the classification of deserter.'' Army officials said they discovered the mistake Thursday while looking up more information on Johnson in response to a reporter's questions. Johnson, who was working with a carnival in Florida, couldn't be reached for comment. But his mother, Dorothy Johnson, said he had already made plans to report for duty and had been told to ``stay put'' until he was needed. ``He said some time ago that if his unit went to Saudi Arabia, he would go,'' his mother said. ``His younger brother already is over there in the Army.'' She said she hadn't been told about the mix-up involving her son, but was glad to hear it had been resolved.

DOC.HEAD: Once America's Largest Newspaper, Daily News Strength Had Eroded
With PM-Daily News, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News, once America's largest newspaper, has seen its circulation and financial stability slowly erode in recent decades. The tabloid slipped to being the nation's second largest metropolitan daily this year, giving up the top spot to the Los Angeles Times. Before the strike called Thursday, circulation stood at 1.18 million on weekdays and 1.46 million on Sunday. The Daily News first went to print in 1919 as the Illustrated Daily News, founded by late publisher Joseph Medill Paterson. It billed itself as ``New York's Picture Newspaper,'' a slogan that still appears on the masthead. It gained a reputation as a feisty tabloid, specializing in crime stories, exposes and colorful local features. In 1928, one of the most gruesome but spectacular newspaper pictures ever published was the paper's front-page shot of Ruth Snyder in Sing Sing prison's electric chair as she was executed for the murder of her husband. The photo was snapped secretly by a photographer with a camera strapped to his leg and smuggled out under the noses of prison officials. When President Ford decided not to bail New York City out of its fiscal crisis in 1975, the News published one of its most famous headlines: ``Ford To City: Drop Dead.'' Circulation reached its zenith in the years after World War II when it sold 2.4 million copies on weekdays and 4.7 million on Sundays, the largest ever for a U.S. newspaper. Like many of its competitors, the paper began to experience harder times. Television lured people away and blue-collar workers formerly loyal to the Daily News began to move out of the city and turned to suburban newspapers. Along the way such notable New York dailies as the Herald Tribune, the Sun, the World-Telegram, the Journal-American and the Daily Mirror folded. The News survived along with the New York Post and The New York Times. In 1980, the paper embarked on a disastrous attempt to lure afternoon readers away from the Post with an evening paper called Tonight. The experiment folded after one year. By the end of 1981, the News was offered for sale by its owner, Chicago-based Tribune Co., but no buyer surfaced and the paper struggled on through various cost-cutting efforts. Unions representing most of the News's 3,500 employees have been locked in bitter negotiations with management since January. The News claims losses of $115 million from 1979 to 1989 on revenues of $4 billion. Management says it needs to eliminate featherbedding and other alleged labor abuses and save $50 million to $70 million annually so that it can invest $500 million in new color presses to remain competitive. The Allied Printing Trades Council, an umbrella group of 10 unions at the News, says the Tribune Co. is really interested in making the paper lean enough to interest a buyer, or it will shut down the paper. By destroying the unions first, the paper would save $100 million in shutdown costs, union leaders say. Central to the negotiations has been the News' determination to give management broad powers over staffing levels, work rules and other areas of operations now controlled largely by the unions. George McDonald, head of the Allied, has said the unions will never agree to the management rights concept. During the past few months, the News has been preparing to print and deliver the paper without its union workers, recruiting replacement workers and training management in various areas of the paper's operations.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Weather in East and Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Temperatures dipped into the 30s in the East and Midwest early today and rain was falling in upstate New York. Clear, cold weather was predicted for much of the country today, with nly Virginia, North Carolina, Idaho and Montana looking for any rain. Chilly northern winds were expected to keep temperatures in the 40s and 50s from the Great Lakes to the Southeast. Winds of up to 40 mph were expected in the Northeast. The northern Plains and the Rocky Mountain states were looking for comtinued warm weather, with highs in the 60s and 70s. Temperatures were expected to reach the 50s in the central Plains, the 80s in Northern California and the 90s in the Southwest. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 101 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. and Monrovia, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major foreign currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices rose on the back of robust world oil prices and persistent jitters over a possible military flare-up in the Persian Gulf. One Frankfurt dealer said expectations of a resolution in the U.S. budget talks might spur more speculation of U.S. interest rates easing next week. To a growing extent, however, the expectation of lower rates has already been factored into the dollar's current weakness, the dealer said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.35 yen to a closing 128.50 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 128.20 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: -1.5180 German marks, up from 1.5130 -1.2815 Swiss francs, up from 1.2765 -5.0790 French francs, up from 5.0645 -1.7097 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7050 -1,135.75 Italian lire, up from 1,132.75 -1.1663 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1676 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9555, more expensive for buyers than $1.9545 late Thursday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $377.30 per ounce at midmorning, from $376.25 bid per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $377.40, up from $374.80 late Thursday. Financial markets in Hong Kong were closed for a holiday. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.22 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $4.24 dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Nine Killed, Scores Wounded in New South African Unrest
DOC.TEXT: Police opened fire to break up protests and black factions clashed in several towns, leaving nine blacks dead and scores wounded, police said today. Five blacks were killed Thursday and about 80 injured in battles with riot police in Khayelitsha township outside Cape Town after police broke up a march with shotgun fire, police said. It was not clear how many died from police bullets. Clashes continued Thursday night, with police shooting at youths who erected barricades to block streets. At least 50 shacks were burned, but no other casualties were immediately reported. Residents said the area remained tense today and that heavily armed police units roamed the township. The independent South African Press Association and several newspapers reported seven people had been killed in the clashes. Police denied the reports. A police statement today said four people were killed in black factional fighting in Natal Province during the previous 24 hours. A group of blacks with rifles attacked a house at Ntzuma, killing two men and wounding a woman, the statement said. Two black men were killed at Mnjamda, but police gave no details. Three blacks were hurt late Thursday in Pretoria when passengers jumped out of a moving train after men with whips attacked people, police said. Police said the attackers were trying to enforce a work boycott. They said they had no details of the boycott. Tension has been high in Khayelitsha since the slaying last week of Momsa Mapongwana, the wife of an anti-apartheid leader in the township. There have been no claims of responsibility or arrests in the slaying. Violence broke out Thursday when an explosion started a fire at the town council building, police said. They said the blast could have been caused by a limpet mine. Many residents of black townships oppose the local councils and consider council members collaborators with the white-led government. Firefighters put out the blaze, but police said township residents began hurling stones at officers, who then fired tear gas, rubber bullets and birdshot. Maj. Gen. Flip Fourie said police initially did not object to the march Thursday. ``But when extensive damage was done to the (town council) offices in an explosion and thousands of residents started gathering in the streets at 4 a.m., stoning cars, erecting burning barricades and torching vehicles, we had to act,'' Fourie said. Witnesses said police declared the march illegal and gave people a minute to disperse. Some marchers began walking toward police with their hands up, making peace symbols with their fingers, and police began shooting, the witnesses alleged.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations, 1st Ld - Writethru
Eds.: CORRECTS first Item to (N.Y.) sted (N.J.)
DOC.TEXT: ``The trucks have been in and out. The papers are getting out.'' - Garden City (N.Y.) police Lt. William Fitzpatrick, saying that copies of the Daily News in New York were being distributed despite a strike that began Thursday night. --- ``It's the wrong size force. It's too big to stay there and too small to attack.'' - House Armed Services Committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., criticizing the number of troops currently deployed in Saudi Arabia. --- ``We were astonished and I must say embarrassed. We actually didn't know until last week that the funding had even been asked for.'' - Shirley Fredricks, daughter of bandleader Lawrence Welk, responding to criticism of congressional approval to spend $500,000 to renovate the house where her father was born.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators Clear Egypt Debt Relief, Salvador Aid Cut
DOC.TEXT: House and Senate negotiators agreed early today on a $15.5 billion foreign aid bill for the coming year that will set a new U.S. policy direction in El Salvador and forgive Egypt's military debt to the United States. Accord came after a marathon, and at times stormy, all-night bargaining session that hinged on the administration's swallowing a 50 percent cut in military aid to El Salvador in return for the $6.7 billion debt relief for Egypt, which President Bush badly wanted. The compromise package now goes back to the full House and Senate for ratification before going to Bush, whose advisers have threatened a veto over the El Salvador provisions. Administration officials have said erasing Egypt's past military debt from the books is crucial to maintaining the international coalition that has been built against Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. ``The entire U.S. and world position against (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein and Iraq will be at risk'' if the debt were not forgiven as Bush promised, said Sen. Robert Kasten, R-Wis., the senior GOP member of the Senate Appropriations foreign aid subcommittee. But House subcommittee Chairman David Obey, D-Wis., countered that he would have difficulty winning votes for the bill in the House if it fully forgives Egypt's debt. And he complained heatedly that Bush made the promise to Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak without first consulting lawmakers. The El Salvador provision calls for an immediate 50 percent cut in this year's $85 million in military aid as a step toward creating incentives for the San Salvador government and the leftist FMLN rebels to end their decade-long civil war with a negotiated political settlement. If the rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front walk away from U.N.-sponsored peace talks, the aid could be restored. But if the government fails to pursue peace, it could lose the other half of its military aid. The arrangement represents a major change in U.S. policy toward El Salvador, which has received aid at a rate of nearly $1 million a day in recent years. It also was a victory for congressional opponents of administration policy, who are weary of 10 years of aid that has done little to encourage moderation in the Central American country. In other provisions, the bill pointedly omits any specific earmark for Pakistan, which in past years has been the third-largest recipient of U.S. aid. In fact, it erects new hurdles before aid can be granted, including certification that this week's elections were free and fair and restoration of full civil liberties in the country. In the past, Pakistan has been particularly important because of its role in supplying anti-communist rebels in neighboring Afghanistan. The United States has looked the other way when Pakistan advanced its nuclear weapons program. But with U.S. participation in that war winding down, Congress is taking a more critical look at the aid. As usual, Israel is the top beneficiary of the bill with some $3 billion in cash military and economic aid, and millions more in non-cash benefits. The conferees agreed to include a section that would let the United States give Israel up to $700 million worth of new weaponry from Pentagon stocks. In addition to the debt forgiveness, Egypt is the second-largest cash aid recipient, with $2.1 billion. The money for the two Middle Eastern countries stems from their Camp David peace accord and their status as staunch U.S. allies in the region. The bill provides a total of $3.1 billion for economic aid and $4.6 billion for military aid. Congress is giving the administration more latitude than usual to decide how to distribute the money. But lawmakers did include specific earmarks for several favored countries: Jordan, $35 million in economic aid; Morocco, $20 million in economic and $43 million in military aid; Greece, $350 million in military aid; Turkey, $500 million in military aid; and $62.5 million in economic aid for Peru, Bolivia and Colombia. The bill also includes $800 million for sub-Saharan Africa, $7.5 million for Lebanon, $20 million for Ireland, $364 million for Eastern Europe and up to $20 million for humanitarian and development aid in Cambodia. The Philippines would get $160 million for this year's payment on a five-year, $1 billion aid program called the Multilateral Assistance Initiative. That is $40 million less than the administration had asked, and the same as last year's amount.

DOC.HEAD: 100-Year-Old Woman Favors Driver's Seat Over Rocking Chair
DOC.TEXT: Jessie Fiedler just turned 100 and she'd rather sit in a driver's seat than a rocking chair. ``Driving is one of my pleasures in life,'' said Fiedler, who hit the century mark Thursday. ``It keeps me young and interested in life.'' Her driver's license expires in 1992. ``Of course I plan to renew it,'' she said. ``If I had to sit in a rocking chair all day, I'd feel pathetic,'' she said Wednesday after taking a pre-birthday drive around the block in her 1980 Buick Century. ``I always say it's better to wear out than to rust out.'' Fiedler's brother taught her how to drive on a Sunday afternoon when they were growing up in Uniontown, Pa., and she was ``driving the next day.'' She admits she wasn't a very good driver at first but said her few accidents were usually ``the other fellow's fault.'' Age has improved her driving, Fiedler said. ``When you practice for a lot of years, you'd have to get better,'' she said. ``I had my car insurance reduced because I've been a safe driver. That's good for a 100-year-old.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Chamber Votes To End State Monopoly on Mail and Media
DOC.TEXT: The lower house of Parliament today voted to abolish the government's monopoly on radio, TV, telephones and postal services, which would formally open the door to private ventures in those sectors. The law was approved by the Sejm on a vote of 256 to 1 with five abstentions. It must still be passed by the Senate and signed by President Wojciech Jaruzelski, but approval was expected. The move is another step in the former Communist country's free-market reform program that began the first of the year. Private radio stations and at least one TV station already have been functioning during the past year with the official acquiescence while the new legislation was being drafted. The new law allows for the assigning of specific broadcasting frequencies to licensees under the supervision of the Ministry of Communications. It would end the government's legal monopoly over postal services, telecommunications, radio and television. Before passage, the Sejm accepted one amendment to limit radio frequencies assigned to military and police. Before whole sections of the wave spectrum were assigned to these units, but now they will be limited to specific channels. Several foreign companies have expressed interest in helping to establish a third commercial TV channel in Poland, in addition to the two government-owned channels currently operating.

DOC.HEAD: Planetary Lineup Spurs Early Suspension of Magellan's Mapping Mission
DOC.TEXT: NASA decided to suspend the Magellan spacecraft's Venus map-making mission today, three days earlier than planned, because a planetary lineup is affecting its navigation and communications with Earth. It will be at least 12 days before Magellan can resume its $744 million mission to use radar to make pictures and maps of cloud-covered Venus, said Jim Scott, mission director at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. The space agency had planned to halt mapping by Magellan for nine days starting Monday. But laboratory spokesman Jim Doyle said increasing difficulty with Magellan's navigation, communications with Earth, solar panels and ability to make quality pictures prompted the decision to suspend operations today. Scott said the problems may stem from an astronomical event called ``superior conjunction.'' That occurs next Thursday when Venus and Earth are at their maximum distance from each other - about 161 million miles - and the sun lies almost directly between the two planets. Magellan was launched from the space shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989. It went into orbit around Venus 2{ months ago, and started mapping Venus full-time Sept. 15. So far, its radar pictures have shown extensive quake faults, a wide variety of volcanos and lava flows, Los Angeles-sized meteorite impact craters and 600-mile-wide bulges that are like the ``hot spots'' on Earth's crust that created Hawaii.

DOC.HEAD: Church Plans To Burn Moslem Books, `Satanic Paraphernalia'
DOC.TEXT: A church plans to burn books by Moslems and Jehovah's Witnesses along with pornography and ``satanic paraphernalia'' on Saturday in what the church's pastor hopes will become an annual event. ``Our purpose is to rid our city - and throughout the years we'll continue to rid our city - of more satanic paraphernalia, and then we believe the Holy Spirit will have a greater freedom to flow,'' the Rev. Donovan Larkins, founder of the non-denominational Victory Bible Church, said Thursday. The church distributed fliers in several neighborhoods this week inviting people to bring in books by Moslems and Jehovah's Witnesses; books on New Age religions, witchcraft, yoga, transcendental meditation and Christian Science; horoscopes; playing cards; and ``secular albums, tapes and bumper stickers.'' Larkins said he doesn't care if his bonfire offends everyone in the city. ``What God says is what's important to me,'' he said. He suggested that anyone who wonders why items from other religions were chosen should ``come to our church ... so that we can expound to them the unadulterated word of God.''

DOC.HEAD: Heart Attack Victim Dragged Out of Store After Owner Thought He Was Drunk
DOC.TEXT: A man who suffered a fatal heart attack was dragged out of a grocery market on his stomach when the store manager mistook his semiconscious condition for drunkeness. B&M Market cashier Charelle M. White said the man was left outside for 20 minutes Thursday morning before paramedics were called. The victim, identified as James Drumright, 57, of Baltimore, died at Liberty Medical Center. Paramedics said they couldn't determine if Drumright would have lived had he received medical assistance sooner. Police said a community relations officer and members of the group Alliance of Rosemont Community Organizations planned to investigate. Alliance president Leslie C. Howard said the incident could inflame racial tensions because the store's owners are Korean and the victim was black. Many Korean store owners operate in predominantly black neighborhoods in Baltimore, and cultural differences have caused misunderstandings. Several storekeepers have been the targets of violence. In New York City, blacks have been demonstrating since early this year over an incident in Brooklyn, where a black woman claimed she was roughed up by a Korean store worker. Several angry passersby stayed at the B&M Market until late Thursday, urging people not to shop there. ``If we had any idea he had had a heart attack, we would have called the paramedics,'' said the store's owner, Kenny Kang. ``I feel bad now, but I thought he was drunk,'' said store manager Marcus Gaffney, who helped drag the man outside. Gaffney said a shopper told him the man was slumped over a meat case in the back of the market. When he went to investigate, he said he saw a liquor bottle poking out of the man's back pocket. White said Kang told Gaffney and another employee to drag the man outside.

DOC.HEAD: Human Hair Grown in Test-Tube Could Lead to Cure for Baldness
DOC.TEXT: Human hair has been grown in a test tube for the first time, and the discovery could lead to a cure for baldness by the year 2000, a Cambridge University scientist said today. ``This is the real thing,'' said Dr. Terence Kealey, leader of the research team at the Department of Clinical Biochemistry. ``We have for the first time succeeded in getting hair to grow in vitro.'' The balding scientist stressed in a BBC radio interview that growing hairs in a test tube ``is not in itself a cure for baldness,'' but it does provide the perfect arena for experiments. The next step, he said, is to find out why the normal ``kickback'' mechanism that triggers the growth of new hair when existing hair follicles come to the end of their normal growth cycle stops working in many middle-aged men. ``I hope that within 10 years we could come up with a cure for baldness,'' he said. He said the successful growth of test-tube hair came after a team member, Dr. Michael Philpott, devised a method for extracting hair follicles from the skin without damaging the hair roots. The two top layers of skin have to be carefully sliced away before removing the follicles with fine tweezers, he said. The follicles are then grown in a synthetic blood substitute maintained at body temperature. Watching human hair growing in a test tube is ``an amazing sight,'' Kealey said. ``It grows absolutely identical to normal hairs - at the same rate of 0.012 inches a day and in the same shape.'' He said his team will now expose the test-tube hair to a variety of different biological materials and observe the results. The team's research, funded by the Anglo-Dutch consumer giant Unilever and Britain's Science and Engineering Research Council, will be published in next month's issue of the Journal of Cell Science. Kealey said the research could also produce a much more effective depilatory for women to remove unwanted hair. He explained that hairs grow for about two years and then spontaneously shed. ``If you can promote ... that process up, you have a natural depilatory,'' he said. ``In fact what we can do now in the laboratory is persuade hairs to shed in this very natural manner and so we hope that we might quite quickly start trying to work on improved depilatories as well as a cure for baldness.'' Cambridge is known for its scientific breakthroughs, including discoveries of the electron, the neutron and the structure of DNA, the building blocks of genetic material. Asked how the test-tube hair compared with the other scientific breakthroughs, Kealey replied: ``We're absolutely thrilled to have made this breakthrough, but I think honestly as an intellectual breakthrough, it has to be viewed as rather trivial. I am myself bald, but I don't think it's something that bothers me very much.'' But Kealey added: ``One has to be fairly catholic and understand that for many people it is intensely traumatic - maybe because it is the first visible sign of advancing age.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev, in Spain, Seeks Economic Backing
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived today for a three-day visit to Spain intended to drum up support for his country's troubled economy. The trip is the Soviet leader's first abroad since he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize on Oct. 15 and is the first by a Soviet head of state to Spain. The Soviet president and his wife, Raisa, were greeted by Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez at Madrid's airport. King Juan Carlos was hosting an official welcoming ceremony at the palace. Soviet flags lined Madrid's main avenues, and large crowds turned out to try to catch a glimpse of the Gorbachevs. In an interview published today in Spain's largest daily El Pais, Gorbachev hailed growing U.S.-Soviet cooperation. ``We believe we're at the start of a long and stable period of normal, strong and equal relations,'' he was quoted as saying. ``It fills us with hope that these relations have already passed the tests of the dramatic events of Eastern Europe, and the first serious international crisis since since the end of the Cold War in the Persian Gulf, which has not perturbed, but strengthened Soviet-U.S. cooperation,'' Gorbachev told the newspaper. ``This indicates we have found the key to common efforts to create a safer and more just world order,'' he added. The trip to Spain, where Gorbachev is widely admired, provides a welcome break from the growing economic problems and nationalist tensions at home. On the eve of the visit, the Soviet central Asian republic of Kazakhstan because the latest republic to declare its sovereignty from Moscow. After protracted debate, the Soviet Parliament this month approved Gorbachev's plan to switch from a centrally planned to a market economy, a move that could exacerbate problems in the short run. Gorbachev, who was accompanied by Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, was to meet with parliamentarians, receive two honorary degrees and meet business leaders in Madrid and Barcelona. The Soviet entourage included about 40 top political, economic and cultural figures. Gorbachev and Gonzalez were expected to sign up to a dozen accords aimed at boosting trade, investment and strengthening bilateral relations. Officials of the two countries were negotiating an agreement under which Spain would extend to the Soviets a $1.5 billion line of credit to buy Spanish goods and technology. Spanish-Soviet trade totaled about $2 billion last year, 70 percent of it in Soviet crude oil exports. Gonzalez and Gorbachev were to sign a joint political statement covering what Gorbachev called coinciding views on a wide range of European and international issues. The Soviet president was to leave to Paris on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Kazakhstan Declares Sovereignty, Bans Nuclear Tests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with state of emergency declared in region of Moldavia. Pickup 10th graf pvs, `The Kirgiz...' Gagauz is pronounced GAGA-ooz. Komi is KAW-mee. Chuvash is CHOO-vash.
DOC.TEXT: The republic of Moldavia today declared a state of emergency in its restive southern region, and Kazakhstan has become the 14th of the 15 Soviet republics to declare sovereignty, Soviet media reported. In its sovreignty declaration Thursday, Kazakhstan defied the national legislature and banned nuclear tets on its territory. Environmental activists in the Central Asian republic claim its 15 million people suffer an elevated cancer rate and other health problems because it is the site of one of the country's main testing grounds for nuclear warheads. In Moldavia, which borders Romania, authorities imposed a state of emergency in the Gagauz region, where an ethnic minority has declared sovereignty and begun holding elections. Moldavia's parliament also voted to abolish local governments in the region and replace them with committees appointed by the republic, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. Movement in and out of the region was restricted and public rallies and other meetings banned, the news agency said. The state of emergency will be enforced by Soviet Interior Ministry troops under the control of officials in the republic, it said. Busloads of college-age volunteers were also headed for the area today. Konstantin Rabu, a member of the Moldavian People's Front, said in a telephone interview from the Moldavian capital of Kishinev that the volunteers were unarmed and would try to end the Gagauz independence drive peacefully. ``We want to talk them out of this craziness,'' he said. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev made a telephone call to Moldavia's president, Mircha Snegur, to warn that ``violence and confrontation are impermissible,'' Tass said. About 150,000 Gagauz, who are of Turkish descent, live in Moldavia and make up 3 percent of the population. The chairman of Moldavia's parliament, Alexander Moshanu, made a televised appeal Thursday night for ``maximum restraint, calm and tolerance to prevent clashes between volunteers and the Gagauz people.'' Militants on both sides are ready to ``cast us into the abyss of violence,'' he said. Kazakhstan's parliament ordered a halt to all nuclear testing on its territory, stretching from the Caspian Sea to the Chinese border, the independent Interfax news agency reported. With Kazakhstan's sovreignty call, the only republic that has not declared sovereignty from the central Soviet government is Kirgizia. The republic is a mountainous region in Central Asia with 4.2 million people, about half of whom are ethnic Kirgiz and predominately Moslem. The Kirgiz parliament is debating the issue and is likely to take the step soon, the republic's most famous native son, writer and Presidential Council member Chingiz Aitmatov, said in an interview with The Associated Press on Tuesday. The accelerating breakaway of the republics, which began with Lithuania's declaration of independence on March 11, has plunged the Soviet government into a constitutional crisis. The national legislature passed legislation Wednesday saying its laws take precedence over decisions by parliaments in each republic. But the republics have shown no intention of complying. Kazakhstan's parliament said its decisions would hold sway in cases of conflict with national laws, and it claimed control over the republic's natural resources, Interfax reported. Gorbachev has been trying to persuade the republics to negotiate a new treaty that would redefine and preserve the union as a confederation of sovereign states. Kazakh lawmakers have indicated willingness to join such a confederation. But the leaders of many republics have been reluctant to participate, and negotiations have yet to begin in earnest. While the republics are pushing for autonomy from the central government in Moscow, some also are simultaneously trying to stop separatist movements in smaller regions inside their territory. Moldavia faces independence movements not only by the Gagauz, but also by a smaller number of ethnic Ukrainians in another corner of the republic, the so-called Dneister republic. The huge Russian Federation faces separatist movements from Finnish-speaking people in the northern Komi Autonomous Republic and from the Chuvash, a region of 1.3 million people along the Volga River. It is the largest of the Soviet republics with about two-thirds of the nation's land mass and half the country's population. On Wednesday, the Chuvash parliament declared itself a full Soviet republic. The central government and 15 recognized republics have not recognized the claim. In Georgia, fighting has broken out between the mostly Christian majority and the Moslem minority in Abkhazia, a region of about 500,000 people along the Black Sea. Azerbaijan also has been fighting for two years to retain control of Nagorno-Karabakh, an enclave of ethnic Armenians. On Thursday, Tass reported that Soviet Interior Ministry officials were taken hostage by people demanding the release of Armenians detained in a passport check. The agency did not say how many hostages were involved.

DOC.HEAD: Police Identify `Human Bomb' Victim; Irish-British Talks Founder
DOC.TEXT: Police today identified the body of a man killed when he was turned into a ``human bomb'' by the IRA as a 42-year-old handyman who worked for the Defense Ministry. Patrick Gillespie was killed Wednesday when IRA gunmen held his family hostage and forced him to drive a vehicle laden with a 1,000-pound bomb into a military checkpoint near Londonderry, Northern Ireland's second city. Five soldiers also died in that blast and a sixth soldier was killed in a simultanous bomb attack at Newry, 100 miles southeast of Londonderry. In London, meawhile, six months of negotiations between Britain and the Irish Republic aimed at restoring local government to British-ruled Northern Ireland ended in deadlock late Thursday. British and Irish officials told a news conference they would try to overcome differences, but the outlook was bleak. ``We have gone as far as we can - and that is generally accepted. The situation is somber,'' Irish Foreign Minister Gerry Collins told reporters. The officials said the main sticking point was when the Irish government should become involved in the negotiations between Northern Ireland's Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders. The Irish Republic wants to be involved at every stage, while the Protestants, who are the majority in Northern Ireland, envision a role for Dublin only at the last stages. Collins and Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Brooke, Britain's top official in the province, also condemned Wednesday's IRA violence. In a joint communique, they expressed ``absolute abhorrence of the appalling inhumanity involved in the coercion of human victims to deliver bombs to the point of attack.'' Thirty-five people were injured, including a 65-year-old man forced to drive the bomb-laden car in Newry. It was the most deadly Irish Republican Army attack in Northern Ireland in two years. A third attempted bomb attack at a British army base near Omagh, 55 miles west of Belfast failed when the bomb did not go off. Gerry Kelly, the Roman Catholic man forced to drive that vehicle, said he was convinced he would die when IRA men strapped him in the seat and followed him to the Sherwood Foresters military base. ``The sweat was dribbling down my face. All sorts of things were going through my mind and I thought this was it,'' Kelly said Thursday. He said his IRA kidnappers told him the explosives were attached to a 40-minute timer. ``They said, `Don't do anything stupid, we have a rifle trained on you,' '' Kelly said. In new violence today, a railway line between Newry and Dundalk in Northern Ireland was closed after reports of an explosion, police said. The IRA is fighting to unite Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland with the mainly Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland. The IRA is banned on both sides of the border.

DOC.HEAD: Bargainers Agree on Tax Increase
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, editing to shorten.
DOC.TEXT: Congressional negotiators inched toward final approval of a deficit-reduction plan today as the chairmen of two tax-writing committees agreed on most elements of a $250 billion package of tax increases and spending cuts, staff members said. The only remaining issue in the plan was how to restrain spending for Medicaid health services for low-income Americans. Spokesmen for Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, who heads the Senate Finance Committee, said details of the final agreement would be announced later in the morning. The plan includes increases in consumer taxes on gasoline, tobacco, alcoholic beverages and luxuries. It carries a considerable tax increase on upper-income Americans. Medicare recipients would foot $10 billion more of their own health costs under the bill. The deficit-reduction package was one of the last major items of business for a fractious, wearying congressional session that extended several weeks beyond expectations. ``I think this session has gone on long enough,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. The House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee arranged meetings later in the day to give their approval to the package. That would open the way for Congress to get the bill to President Bush's desk by Sunday. Although there was stiff opposition to the bill from many lawmakers in both parties, House Democratic and Republican leaders predicted its passage. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu said Bush considered the plan ``real and credible.'' ``I haven't been working on this for so long to have something go down,'' said House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill. In other action as Congress pushes toward the end of it its long election-year session: -The House gave voice-vote approval to a $268 billion defense spending bill, while the Senate planned to vote today on that measure and the companion military authorization bill. The spending bill is a cut of $19 billion from Bush's initial proposal in January. It slashes the president's request for the Strategic Defense Initiative and barely keeps alive the B-2 stealth bomber program. -The Senate voted 60-36 Thursday to send Bush the 1990 farm bill, passed by the House two days earlier. The president is expected to sign the five-year, $40.8 billion measure, which sets new environmental rules for farmers, sets government nutrition programs, including food stamps, and aims to reduce subsidized acreage for farmers by 15 percent. -House and Senate sponsors announced agreement on a new $2.5 billion program of child care grants to the states, as the centerpiece of a long-debated child care bill. Differences remain over some elements, including an expansion of tax credits for low-income families. -The House approved by voice vote a $57.4 billion housing bill, including $27.5 billion this fiscal year and $29.9 billion in fiscal 1992. The massive deficit-reduction package - product of half a year of partisan brawling and interminable negotiations - would affect almost all Americans. It raises the 9-cent-a-gallon federal gasoline tax by about a nickel and increases levies on alcohol, tobacco and jewelry as well. It boosts - from 28 percent to 31 percent - the income-tax rate on the richest Americans, but drops the rate paid by the upper-middle class from 33 percent to 31 percent. The measure also reduces the deductions available to people earning more than $100,000 yearly by 3 percent, and phases out their $2,050 personal exemptions. The details were subject to change in late negotiations. Bargainers agreed informally late Thursday to slow the growth of Medicare benefits by $10 billion through 1995, officials said. That figure matched a House proposal that was about $7 billion lower than the reductions the Senate voted for. Medicare helps pay medical bills for about 33 million elderly and disabled people. An official demanding anonymity said that under the agreement, the $75 annual deductible paid by beneficiaries would increase to $100. The monthly premium - $28.60 this year - would grow gradually to $46.20 by 1995. Disagreement remained over the exact size and nature of cuts in Medicare reimbursements to doctors and hospitals. Those reductions were expected to total about $33 billion over the next five years. The plan cuts student loans, farm aid and other benefit programs. Final agreements were being sought over Medicaid, which helps the poor pay medical bills. Although the program will be cut, liberals wanted to provide an additional $2.9 billion for low-income elderly people. The Bush administration was trying to reduce that figure. Also under negotiation were $2.5 billion worth of tax breaks for the oil and gas industry, championed by Senate Finance Committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas. The Senate also wanted $5.6 billion worth of tax breaks for businesses, including those doing research, and individuals, for items such as employer-provided educational benefits. With Election Day approaching, members were getting itchy to halt the budget bickering and return home for campaigning. If the leaders were reading their votes correctly, the House and Senate - where few problems were expected - would dispose of the bill quickly and let Congress adjourn for the year over the weekend. Michel expected only about 50 of the House's 175 Republicans to vote for the plan, mainly because of disgruntlement over its approximately $150 billion in new taxes and spending cuts considered by some as insufficient. But a GOP pep rally for the plan on Capitol Hill, attended by Sununu and budget chief Richard Darman, left supporters encouraged.

DOC.HEAD: Pressler Foe Campaigns Against `Professional Politician'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 16th graf, Sioux Falls, to UPDATE with Pressler being criticized on congressional mailings. DELETES last 4 grafs to shorten.
DOC.TEXT: Republican Sen. Larry Pressler is a self-proclaimed political maverick who often is at odds with GOP party leaders. But on Election Days past, he has been a consistent landslide winner. Democrat Ted Muenster hopes the disenchantment of GOP leaders is spreading to voters, but polls indicate he's not having much success. The Sioux Falls businessman is trying to derail Pressler's campaign for a third Senate term. Muenster casts Pressler as an ineffective, publicity-seeking professional politician. Pressler laughs off such charges. He says he ruffles feathers because he sometimes votes against the White House and Republican congressional leaders to do what's best for his home state. ``I march to my own drum. I've been criticized for being independent, but I put South Dakota first,'' the senator says. The tactic has worked well in past elections, particularly when he won re-election in 1984 with the most votes ever cast for a South Dakota candidate. Earlier this year, Muenster was touted as one of the Democratic party's best hopes for defeating a Republican senator. But an independent poll taken early this month showed Pressler leading by a wide margin. Pressler was supported by 60 percent of those surveyed and Muenster by 26 percent in a poll with a 4.5 percentage point margin of error. Muenster says his own polls show a much closer race. He says he's winning the undecided voters, many of them swayed by ads done for him by Democratic Sen. Tom Daschle, probably South Dakota's most popular elected official. Pressler says most of his GOP critics are people who want his job. ``The real test of all this is not what people say, but what the voting results are,'' he says. Muenster acknowledges Pressler has been immensely popular but he maintains that voters are coming to believe the GOP senator is ineffective and gets no respect from other members of Congress. ``He portrays that as independence, but he is not independent,'' Muenster said. ``In fact, he's out of it in terms of being a factor in Congress.'' Most GOP grumbling comes in private conversations. But when former GOP Gov. Bill Janklow was asked last year to list Pressler's significant achievements, he said: ``I honestly can't think of anything.'' Sioux Falls businessman David Billion briefly considered challenging Pressler in a GOP primary, saying Pressler hadn't accomplished much for South Dakota. On Thursday, Pressler came under Democratic fire on the floor of the Senate after he complained about lax limits on the use of congressional mailings by members of the House. Sen. Wendell Ford, D-Ky., rose to question Pressler about his own mass mailings. ``I believe ... that he was the newsletter king last year,'' Ford said. Pressler responded that he had mailed just one congressional newsletter this year. Senate records show that last year, he sent out 10 mass mailings for every household in his state, more than any other senator. Last month, Ford made a campaign appearance for Muenster in which he said Pressler ``doesn't mingle'' and ``doesn't prepare for anything.'' Muenster says Congress isn't dealing with the nation's problems, particularly the need to balance the budget, and that Pressler is an example of what's wrong. ``I'm not a professional politician,'' he said. ``We need more citizen members of Congress and fewer professional politicians.'' Pressler responds by citing a long list of accomplishments for South Dakota. He says he's helped save a rail line, protected federal highway funding and air service, fought for senior citizens and small businesses and for open international markets for U.S. farm products. ``The point is, I put South Dakota first,'' he says.

DOC.HEAD: Students Strike Across Nation, Minister Vows More Guards
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of high school students staged protests today across France, intensifying pressure on education authorities to improve safety at crumbling, crime-ridden public schools. The demonstrations were the latest in a two-week series of strikes by students fed up with campus violence, overcrowded classrooms, and what they see as government indifference to the poor condition of their schools. On Wednesday, Education Minister Lionel Jospin promised that 100 security guards would be added to schools most troubled by the surging wave of campus violence that led to the original strikes. But student leaders in Paris derided the measure as insufficient. Police reported about 7,000 students marched today in the streets of Toulouse, 5,000 in Valenciennes, 4,000 in Amiens, 4,000 in Saint Etienne and 18,000 in seven other provincial cities. Regional authorities near Montpellier, in southern France, reported that four student demonstrators fell off a staircase and were injured. Two were hospitalized. The marches began a week ago in the tough northern suburbs of Paris with a few hundred students but have since swelled as a prelude to the one-week All Saints Day vacation period. The recent surge of crime at high schools has included the rape of a girl in a school lavatory, assaults on several teachers, and cases of extortion. Thousands of teachers held a protest last weekend in sympathy with the students and to demand higher pay. But Jospin warned teachers on Wednesday that salary increases of $1,192 promised this year would have to be cut to $384 due to budget constraints. The move seemed certain to escalate tensions between the government and teachers unions. The most violent schools are those built in the 1960s near hastily erected high-rise projects built to house immigrant workers and poor French families. French media reported this week on schools with crumbling concrete, holes in the ceilings, graffiti-scarred hallways, and classrooms with no desks or chairs.

DOC.HEAD: Girl, 3, Safe After Abduction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tonia, Donzie in 5th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A 3-year-old girl was reunited with her mother today after she was abducted from the family car and held for a ransom of cocaine and cash, authorities said. Three armed men took Porshea Hamilton from her mother's car in the driveway of their west Los Angeles home at 9:30 a.m. Thursday, said Officer Jim Farris. The child was released about midnight on a street in south-central Los Angeles. She knocked on the door of a nearby home for help, Ferris said. ``The child is safe. The child is in good condition. She was not harmed,'' said Cmdr. William Booth. Officers gave her an apple and milk to drink at the police station. Harold Bridges, 27, Tonia Hilt, 21, Donzie Hill, 20, Baron Williams, 20, and a 16-year-old boy were taken into custody, police said. The youth's identity was not released because of his age. Bridges and Hilt were booked for investigation of kidnapping and held on $100,000 bail, police said. Bail had not been set for the others early today. Police said Porshea was abducted as her mother, Gina Hamilton, backed the car out of their driveway. Later, Ms. Hamilton received telephone calls demanding a ransom of cocaine and cash, Booth said. Undercover officers negotiated with the callers and set up a ransom payment at a parking lot, which they staked out to make the arrests, Booth said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Charged In Sheriff's Campaign Worker Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Three men have been charged in what police called the politically motivated shooting of a campaign worker in the bitter election fight for sheriff. Authorities charged the three men on Thursday as the campaign between Cook County sheriff candidates Michael Sheahan and James O'Grady continued. Doctors at Christ Hospital in Oak Lawn upgraded Cook County Jail guard Irving Bell from critical to serious condition Thursday, said nursing supervisor Therese Murray. Bell, a Sheahan supporter, was shot three times outside a South Side tavern, the Surf Lounge, early Tuesday in a dispute over campaign signs. Bell's companions ran over him with a van as they fled, police said. Bell and other Sheahan supporters were hanging signs outside the when the shooting began, said Sheahan, the Democratic candidate trying to oust incumbent Republican O'Grady. But O'Grady accused Bell of trying to tear down his campaign signs and said Sheahan's campaign of intimidation and vandalism sparked the incident. The candidates have accused each other's campaign workers of vandalizing signs and offices. Tyler Sanders, 23, of Chicago was charged with one count each of attempted murder and mob action in the attack, said Chicago Police Detective John Boyle. Cook County correctional officer John Magett, 47, and Brian Frazier, 25, who worked as a disc jockey at the Surf Lounge, were each charged with one count of mob action, Boyle said. The trio, arrested shortly after Tuesday's shooting, remained in police lockups Thursday night awaiting bond hearings, Boyle said. Meanwhile, a third-party candidate for sheriff, placed back on the November ballot by a U.S. Supreme Court ruling on Thursday, said the incident proved that neither Sheahan nor O'Grady deserved to hold the office. ``Look at the way they've campaigned,'' said Harold Washington Party candidate Thomas Brewer. ``They have created this kind of environment that then filters down to their employees.''

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Government Strike Ends; Bus Gunfight Kills Three
DOC.TEXT: An anti-government strike ended today, and a shootout aboard a bus killed a policeman and two Communist rebels and left seven people wounded. The three-day nationwide strike, called by leftist unions, had been marked by attacks on public transportation. The strikers warned they would return to the streets if the government would not agree to their wage demands. However, they backed off somewhat on those demands and were awaiting a reply from the government on their latest call. The early morning gunfight in Laguna province south of Manila came after police questioned suspected New People's Army guerrillas when the bus stopped at a checkpoint in Pila town. Police Capt. Gilbert Sauro said the suspects opened fire, killing the policeman. Police returned the fire, killing two rebels. Sauro said the guerrillas were apparently planning to set the bus on fire. About 5,000 militant workers and students marched to the presidential palace for a rally today, where they announced the end of the strike. The demonstration ended peacefully. President Corazon Aquino ordered the Justice Department to study possible charges against strike leaders. She also ordered government employees who joined the strike to explain their action or face discipline.

DOC.HEAD: Temple University and Union Reach Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Temple University and the union representing professors reached a tentative agreement on a new contract, resolving disputes that led to a 29-day strike. But bitterness remained as the Temple faculty senate voted 116-1 on Thursday to have the entire faculty vote on a demand that university President Peter J. Liacouras resign. Liacouras' opponents said he was not giving the faculty enough voice in decision-making. Neither side would release details of the contract agreement reached late Thursday. ``I will talk to the members first,'' said Arthur Hochner, president of the Temple Association of University Professionals. The association represents 1,100 faculty members and other academic employees. The union rejected the university's offer of 5 percent annual pay increases and struck Sept. 4. The walkout ended Oct. 3 after a judge ordered professors to return to their classrooms. The university then revised the calendar, extending fall semester classes through Jan. 15. Union members will vote next week on ratification of the agreement, Hochner said. Temple spokesman George Ingram said the agreement grew out of 60 to 70 hours of negotiations over the past week. Negotiators resolved the issue of pay for teachers who have been asked to work an extended schedule to make up classes missed during the strike, he said. Liacouras released a statement saying the administration was pleased about the tentative settlement. ``We are especially pleased that the length of this contract will provide for long-range stability,'' he said. But he wouldn't say how long the contract was. Liacouras, a former dean of the Temple law school, has been university president since 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Candidates Register For Presidential Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Seven candidates, including rivals Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, say they have entered the race for the country's first popularly elected president. The seven said they had submitted the required number of signatures to enter the race, and the National Election Commission was checking the documents today. The deadline for registering as a candidate for the Nov. 25 election was midnight Thursday. Fifteen men had announced their candidacy, but only seven claimed to have met the registration requirements. Among the candidates are Mazowiecki, representing the Citizens' Movement for Democratic Action, and Walesa, running on the Center Alliance ticket. Both parties have their roots in Solidarity. The trade union divided into the two groups in June. Mazowiecki draws his support largely from intellectuals in Warsaw and Krakow, while Walesa is backed by workers and farmers. A nationwide poll this week by the government polling agency CBOS suggested Mazowiecki was the front-runner. According to the survey of 791 people who have decided on a candidate, 49 percent favored Mazowiecki, 34 percent support Walesa, and 17 percent backed other candidates. Walesas supporters dismissed the poll results as unreliable. If no candidate wins more than 50 percent of the vote on Nov. 25, a run-off election between the two leading candidates will be held Dec. 9. The other candidates and their affiliations are: -former Communist Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz, Social Democracy. -Roman Bartoszcze, Polish Peasant's Party. -Stan Tyminski, a Polish-born Canadian, an independent. -Leszek Moczulski, the KPN, a small right-wing party. -and Kornel Morawiecki, the Fighting Solidarity organization. Campaign broadcasting on the country's two state-run TV stations and four radio stations was scheduled to begin today and will last until Nov. 23.

DOC.HEAD: $500,000 Grant to Restore Lawrence Welk's Home Stirs Controversy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th graf, `She said...' to UPDATE with comment from Sen. Burdick's press secretary. Picks up 10th graf, `Welk Heritage ...' Neis is cq, 14th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Resentment is bubbling over congresional approval of $500,000 to restore the birthplace of Lawrence Welk, the king of champagne music. The project's leader defended the plan to renovate the sod farmhouse where Welk was born and develop a German-Russian history museum and other tourist attractions. ``People are saying we're taking money away from farmers. It's not so,'' Rosemary Schaefbauer, president of Welk Heritage Inc., said Thursday. ``This money was allocated for rural development. North Dakota is going to benefit a whole lot from it.'' The grant is included in a $52.2 billion agricultural appropriations bill that the House passed Monday and sent to President Bush. It piqued the interest of radio talk-show hosts across the country, who have been calling Schaefbauer. It also raised the ire of Rep. Silvio Conte, R-Mass., who said it's an example of the kind of projects the country cannot afford during a budget crunch. ``What will they do for an encore? Earmark funds to renovate Guy Lombardo's speedboat? Or restore Artie Shaw's wedding tuxedo?'' Conte asked. Welk, 87, does not grant interviews, but one of his daughters, Shirley Fredricks, said by telephone from Los Angeles that the grant caught the family by surprise. ``We were astonished and I must say embarrassed,'' she said. ``We actually didn't know until last week that the funding had even been asked for.'' She said the family would have preferred the money come from private sources, but Sen. Quentin Burdick, D-N.D., thought federal money could help. ``As the senator said, it's for the town, it's not for Lawrence Welk,'' press secretary Jean Broadshaug said today. The money will help with the town's plans to build a small hotel, community center and restaurants. ``Everyone does what they can for their own constituents,'' she said, replying to Conte's remarks. ``And I think in this case anyone who has ever been to Strasburg can recognize it needs some help.'' Welk Heritage Inc. applied for a federal grant three months ago, after a board member saw an application in a Farmers Home Administration office. Many in Strasburg, a town of 600 in south-central North Dakota, say the money could have been put to better use, but that the town may as well take it. ``If there's money to throw away, we might as well have it,'' said Fred Martin, a resident of the Strasburg nursing home. ``Farmers will get their share.'' ``If you want to do something with the money, why don't they do something to help the roads and bridges?,'' said resident Neis Norman. ``We're a farming community and if farmers don't have anything, the town doesn't either,'' he said. Welk lived on the farm near Strasburg until he was 21. Then, with a new accordion, he formed a band in Yankton, S.D., and began his career as one of the country's most successful bandleaders. The total cost of the restoration project is estimated at $750,000, including $500,000 for a trust to maintain the museum after it opens. Work began this summer in anticipation of a June 2 grand opening. ``I can well understand that citizens are very concerned that tax dollars are going into this project,'' Schaefbauer said. ``But it's very common for museums and so forth to get federal grants from time to time.'' ``It's more than just the birthplace of Lawrence Welk,'' she said. ``It's a perfect example of how their homes were built in that time frame.'' ``I think the payoff will probably come down the line in another generation, when our children will be able to go there and see how the pioneers lived.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
WASHN: the community
DOC.TEXT: ``Having failed as the good example he might have been, the defendant must now become an example of another kind,'' Jackson said. In issuing the sentence, Jackson forged a middle ground between the recommendations of prosecutors who urged that Barry be given the maximum one-year sentence and the defense, which argued for parole or community service. For the first time in his 10-month legal drama, Barry himself spoke in court and asked for leniency from the judge. ``I stand here truly remorseful and ask this court to impose community service as a sentence,'' Barry said. In court papers submitted late Thursday, Barry for the first time admitted he was a drug addict. MORE

DOC.HEAD: Woman Gets 10 Years for Killing That Touched Off Riots
DOC.TEXT: A judge ordered a 10-year sentence for a 19-year-old woman accused of igniting two nights of rioting when she killed a bystander while shooting into a crowd during a drug deal. Tamala Vergo was sentenced Thursday by state District Judge Eugene Bryson. ``This court has before it a 19-year-old woman who was at the wrong place - a drug area; with the wrong people - drug dealers; doing the wrong thing - trying to purchase drugs,'' Bryson said. In June, Vergo was convicted of manslaughter in the Sept. 20, 1988, death of David McKinney, a bystander in a parking lot where Vergo and a friend had gone to buy crack cocaine. The pair's car stalled when they tried to leave after an argument with the drug dealers. Vergo fired at the dealers, killing McKinney. She was acquitted of the more serious charge of second-degree murder, which carries an automatic sentence of life in prison. The friend, Cynthia Johnson, 27, was acquitted of charges of being a principal to McKinney's murder. A large crowd that gathered after the shooting pelted Shreveport police with rocks and bottles. The crowd also looted and burned four businesses. At her sentencing, Vergo maintained that she fired the gun in self-defense. ``I feel like the conviction was all wrong,'' she said tearfully. ``I was scared for my life.'' A wrongful death suit filed by McKinney's family against Vergo's parents was settled for $100,000, court documents show. Jack Bailey, an attorney representing McKinney's family, criticized the sentence. ``It wasn't very much recovery for the death of a son,'' Bailey said. ``I think a 10-year sentence for that crime is awfully lenient.'' Defense attorney Maurice Loridans said he will appeal Vergo's conviction. He would not comment on the sentence. She could have received up to 21 years. The judge denied prosecutor Howard Fish's request that Vergo be required to serve at least five years before becoming eligible for parole. She will be eligible for parole in three years.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: This serves as a writethru to the second item in PM-Washington in Brief, with an updated condition on McGrath.
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Raymond McGrath, R-N.Y., was reported today doing fine at a hospital where he was taken for tests a day ago after becoming ill at his office. Dan Zielinski, McGrath's press secretary, said tests showed McGrath had sustained no heart damage or blockage. Zielinski said he still did not know exactly what was wrong with McGrath. The 48-year-old congressman was admitted Thursday afternoon to Walter Reed Army Medical Center. ``He felt faint. He broke out in a sweat. He said he felt a heaviness in the chest - not pain,'' said Dan Zielinski. ``He was conscious, he was speaking.''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Vice President Hospitalized
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Chinese Vice President Wang Zhen has been hospitalized, an official report said today. The Guangming Daily said in a two-paragraph report that Wang received a delegation from the Japanese Friendship Association in his hospital room Thursday. He is onorary chairman of the Sino-Japanese Friendship Association. The report gave no details about Wang's condition, and the Japanese delegation could not be immediately reached for comment. Wang, 82, has been rarely seen in public in recent months. He was conspicuously missing on Sept. 30 from a National Day reception, which was attended by all other state and Communist Party leaders. Wang is not known to have any serious health problems although he walks with the aid of a cane. A former political commissar, Wang is a hard-line ideologue who rose through the military ranks. Although the vice presidency is a largely ceremonial post, Wang's influence is believed to have grown since the retirement of senior leader Deng Xiaoping. Wang was one of the old revolutionaries who took part in the Communists' guerrilla struggle against the Nationalists and the Japanese. He is believed to be close to Deng and have a high standing among the military.

DOC.HEAD: Probe into Garcia's Role in 1986 Prison Massacre Approved
DOC.TEXT: A congressional committee has approved an investigation into the role of former President Alan Garcia in the 1986 massacre of 250 prisoners. The committee, which is headed by leftist legislator Julio Castro Gomez, approved the measure unanimously on Thursday. ``There is sufficient proof for the investigation to proceed,'' Castro said. Garcia, who served as president from 1985 until July 28, has already renounced his congressional immunity, and could be jailed if found guilty of ordering the massacres. As a former president, Garcia was named senator for life when he handed over power to President Alberto Fujimori. Opposition congressmen say Garcia should share the responsibility for the June 1986 massacre, which occurred when the armed forces put down riots in three Lima prisons. Most of the dead were members of the Maoist Shining Path guerrilla movement. A 1987 Senate investigation produced a report blaming Garcia and his Cabinet for the killings. It said Garcia's decision to place control of the situation in the hands of the military led directly to the massacre. Garcia has maintained he and military leaders at the time were innocent. He accused lower-ranking military officials of carrying out summary executions of prisoners after they surrendered. In December, a military court found a police colonel and lieutenant guilty of killing 60 to 70 rebels in the Lima prison of Lurigancho. The court absolved another 76 army officers and policemen. Garcia, who at age 36 became the youngest president to be elected in Peru's history, brought on an unprecedented economic crisis. His free-spending, center-left administration left the country with 3,000 percent annual inflation and a $20 billion foreign debt on which no payments have been made since 1987. During Garcia's tenure, the rural insurgency and poverty increased amid charges of widespread government corruption.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Suspend Northwest Pilot's License After Small-Plane Incidents
DOC.TEXT: A Northwest Airlines captain had his pilot's license suspended after authorities said he buzzed a snowmobile race in one small plane and crash-landed another because of a fuel problem. Martin ``Roy'' Redman of rural Faribault and members of his family escaped injury when a twin-engine Beechcraft plane he was piloting crash-landed at Faribault airport in August. Chris Zurales, a Federal Aviation Administration attorney, said Tuesday that the National Transportation Safety Board already was investigating Redman for allegedly buzzing the race on Cannon Lake last winter. The board issued an emergency revocation of Redman's license Sept. 11 in response to the August crash, Zurales said. Redman appealed the revocation at an Oct. 9-10 hearing before an NTSB administrative law judge, who ordered a nine-month suspension of Redman's license. Bob Gibbons, spokesman for the Minnesota-based Northwest, said today that after a suspension, a pilot must requalify to fly for the airline. ``He'll have to go through ground training and simulator flight training and be evaluated by the Northwest training department and the FAA,'' Gibbons said. Rick Rabeneck, a sheriff's deputy who was at the snowmobile race, said Redman caused a panic when his 1948 Monocoupe plane dived toward the crowd, passing over it at 25 or 30 feet. Redman says he saw what looked like a runway and made a slow descent to get a better look. He then flew the plane over the race course. ``It was not a dive,'' he said. Redman admits he broke FAA regulations by flying lower than 1,000 feet above a crowd, but calls Rabeneck's allegations ``exaggeration.'' In the second incident, an FAA official said an engine quit because of fuel starvation. The FAA found that Redman had placed a fuel selector in an incorrect position, but the pilot insists a mechanical failure in the fuel system was the likely cause.

DOC.HEAD: Albania Condemns Writer's Defection as ``Ugly Act''
DOC.TEXT: Albania today condemned as ``an ugly act'' the defection of the country's leading writer, which embarrassed Communist leaders hosting their first high-level international conference in decades. Ismail Kadare, probably Albania's best-known public figure after President Ramiz Alia, requested political asylum Thursday during a visit to France with his wife and two daughters. France granted his request hours later. The announcement came as Albania, seeking to emerge from decades of self-imposed isolation, hosted foreign ministers from the other five Balkan nations - Bulgaria, Turkey, Greece, Romania and Yugoslavia. Albania is seeking to join the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. It was the only country in Europe which refused to sign the 1975 Helsinki Final Act which spawned the conference. Officials said Thursday the timing of Kadare's defection did not appear coincidental. ``He picked his moment,'' an official from the Albanian Journalists' Union said on condition of anonymity. Official Albanian media only reported the defection Friday. The official ATA news agency cited foreign media as the source of the news. ``The foreign press reports say that the writer Ismail Kadare ... requested political refuge'' in France Thursday, ATA said. ``Through this ugly act, which is a grave offence for the patriotic and civic conscience of our people, he abandoned the people and homeland and placed himself in service of the enemies of Albania and the Albanian people.'' The statement smacked of the Stalinist terminology often used by Eastern Europe's hard-line Communist leaders before the Soviet bloc was swept by democratic revolutions late last year. The defection dealt a blow to the Communist leadership just as it is introducing cautious reforms in the hope it can avoid the fate of Eastern Europe's fallen Stalinists. In a country where writers and intellectuals traditionally play a part in political movements, Kadare was seen as a spiritual leader for reform, as well as the nation's greatest author. Last year he was made deputy chairman of the Democratic Front, a leading Communist group, and had begun speaking out for human rights in Albania. He had strongly criticized the country's secret police. Some officials did not believe the news of Kadare's defection. Foreign Minister Reis Malile suggested Thursday it was a ``set-up,'' though he did not say by whom. ``Kadare is dead. Democratization is not dead,'' Malile said, suggesting that gradual reforms would continue. Kadare was respected, especially among the young, because of his international standing. His books are relatively well-known in France; a few have been published in the United States. He has never been a dissident in his own country. Even under Enver Hoxha, the country's post-World War II founder and dictator until his death in 1985, he was revered as a writer. Kadare's elevation by authorities to a leadership role in the ruling paty indicated he was supposed to help the process of gradual reform. But in his statement from Paris Kadare said reforms weren't coming fast enough. ``The promises made were not kept, and my disillusion, like that of the immense majority of Albanians, was all the more bitter,'' he said. In May, Albania loosened emigration controls, and about 5,000 of the country's 3 million citizens fled abroad. A draft election law published this week provides for more than one candidate to contest each parliamentary seat and for secret ballots. But it does not foresee a multiparty system.

DOC.HEAD: Battleship Heads for Mothballs for Third Time
DOC.TEXT: The battleship USS Iowa, which survived two wars and a catastrophic explosion and fire that killed 47 crewmen, was decommissioned today for a third time. The World War II and Korean War veteran, with 16-inch guns that sent their 2,000-pound projectiles at targets as far away as 20 miles, was taken out of service 47 years after it first joined the Navy. Strong wind and rain forced the ceremony to be moved from a pier at the Norfolk Naval Base to the bridge of the ship. Several hundred former Iowa crewmen and their families gathered in the ship's mess hall, where they chatted but could not hear the ceremony. Also aboard were some relatives of crewmen who were killed in the explosion and fire on the ship on April 19, 1989. ``He would want us to be here,'' said Paula Schwarz of Levittown, N.Y., whose brother, Peter Bopp, died in the blast. In the ceremony, the Iowa's chaplain said the ship's crewmen, living and dead, should be remembered for their role in preserving democracy. ``Although we bid farewell to the teak decks and steel plates, we do not say goodbye to Iowa, for Iowa is us,'' said the chaplain, Cmdr. Joseph C. Cappar. During World War II, the ship carried President Roosevelt to a war conference. The ship was fitted with a bathtub for Roosevelt, who had trouble standing because of polio. To this day, the Iowa remains the only ship in the Navy with a bathtub. After serving in the Pacific providing protection for aircraft carriers, the Iowa was decommissioned in 1949. The battleship stayed in mothballs for little more than two years before it was brought back to service in August 1951. Its guns fired more than 4,000 rounds during the Korean War. The ship was put in storage from 1958 until 1984, when it was recommissioned as part of the Navy buildup to a 600-ship fleet. At a cost of $435 million, the ship was modernized into a platform for cruise missiles. The big guns were considered a bonus. Perhaps the most shattering incident in the ship's history was the explosion and fireball that raced through the No. 2 turret during an open seas gunnery exercise last year. The crew fought the fire and saved their ship. In less than 60 days, the ship was able to make a scheduled Mediterranean deployment, with its No. 2 turret sealed. But because of federal budget deficits, officials decided not to spend the estimated $13 million it would cost to repair the ship. A Navy investigation into the explosion laid the blame on a disgruntled gunner's mate who died in the blast. Navy officials said the gunner's mate deliberately sabotaged the guns. That report has been challenged by some of the families of the 47 sailors and some members of Congress. Earlier this year, the Navy reopened a portion of the investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Court Turns Down Family's Suit Over Warning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The duty...', to CORRECT author of opinion to Justice Gary Strankman, sted Presiding Justice John Racanelli.
DOC.TEXT: Officials aren't legally responsible for the murder of a former district attorney by a man he once prosecuted, even though they didn't warn him that the released convict was in trouble with the law again, a court ruled. The state appeals court ruled Thursday in a suit filed by the family of William Weissich against authorities for allegedly breaking a promise to warn Weissich about the convict, who had threatened his life. The suit said officials of Sonoma and Marin counties and the state knew that Malcolm Schlette was convicted of possessing guns in 1983, eight years after his release from prison, but failed to tell Weissich. Weissich, Marin County district attorney from 1953 to 1960, was shot to death in his San Rafael law office in November 1986 by Schlette, who then killed himself. In upholding a judge's dismissal of the suit, the 1st District Court of Appeal said law enforcement officers may have made a binding promise in 1975 to warn Weissich about any menacing actions by Schlette. But any legal duty to warn the former prosecutor had expired by 1983, when Schlette was arrested again for the guns possession, the court said. ``The duty of a good Samaritan is of limited duration,'' said the 3-0 ruling, written by Justice Gary Strankman. ``A person who has performed a voluntary duty is not required to render aid indefinitely.'' Marin County Counsel Douglas Maloney said the court ``had to draw the line somewhere.'' ``There's a limit to how much protection you can give anyone,'' he said. He said the murder was ``a terrible tragedy, but the law can't solve all these things.'' Alvin Goldstein, a lawyer for Weissich's widow, Rosemary, and her family, said the ruling would be appealed. Schlette was convicted of arson and sentenced to 20 years in prison in 1955, and threatened the lives of Weissich and others in the case. He was paroled in 1966 and was promptly arrested again, carrying a list of names of people involved in the prosecution. He finished his sentence in 1975.
