The suit said county and state officials then promised to tell Weissich of any threatening behavior by Schlette. But they failed to tell him in 1983 when Schlette was arrested by federal agents, pleaded guilty to illegal gun possession and was placed on probation, the suit said. It also said Sonoma County learned in May 1986 that Schlette again had guns, but failed to detain him or warn Weissich. Weissich, who installed a bulletproof door and took other security measures after Schlette's earlier threats, moved to a new office and relaxed his guard after authorities promised to warn him, his family's suit said. A similar suit is pending in federal court accusing the federal government of improperly releasing Schlette on probation after his 1983 arrest.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Boom Expected After Spring Ice Storm
DOC.TEXT: Central Iowa hospitals are bracing for a late fall baby boom believed linked to a March ice storm that left many homes without heat or electricity for days. Des Moines hospitals that offer childbirth classes report sharp increases of enrollment among families expecting babies in late November or early December. Health professionals speculate most of those babies were conceived in early March after a storm that toppled power lines and left many homes without electricity for as long as three days. ``It's just our general idea that's what happened,'' said Pam Stephens, the receptionist at Gynecology and Obstetrics M.D.s in Des Moines. She said the three doctors on staff expect to deliver 45 babies in December, compared with about 35 in an average month. Judy Schlife, childbirth education coordinator at Mercy Hospital Medical Center in Des Moines, said enrollment in Lamaze classes rose by 25 couples from October to November. At Iowa Lutheran Hospital, 24 couples have signed up for Wednesday and Thursday childbirth classes, double the number usually enrolled for the midweek program. The Des Moines Birthplace reports a 50 percent increase in class size.

DOC.HEAD: Cabbies' Wives Arrange Gambling Bust
DOC.TEXT: A group of cabdrivers' wives, fed up with their spouses' gambling, led police to an eatery where 20 men were arrested on gambling charges. One wife didn't stop with calling police, said Officer Roger O'Brien. She also wrote letters to the district commander complaining about her husband's gambling losses. In addition, the commander received complaints from North Side residents because many cabs frequently were parked near the M & M Restaurant. ``In excess of 50 cabs were parked in the immediate area - in front of the restaurant and in a parking lot,'' O'Brien said Thursday. ``It was unbelievable.'' Several wives called police, some anonymously, to complain that money needed to pay family bills was being lost by their spouses at the restaurant, O'Brien said. O'Brien and two other officers raided the restaurant Wednesday night after observing gambling through a window during a weeklong investigation. Much of the action, O'Brien said, involved side bets on two pool games; other cabdrivers gambled on electronic games. The restaurant owner was charged with operating a gambling house.

DOC.HEAD: Guinea Ambassador Accused Of Assault On Hotel Maid
DOC.TEXT: Guinea's ambassador to the United States faces sex charges in connection with an alleged assault of a maid at a downtown hotel. Ambassador Moussa Sangare faces up to 18 months in jail and a $3,000 fine if convicted on one count each of misdemeanor sexual battery and false imprisonment, said Mike Qualls, spokesman for the City Attorney's Office. ``The State Department advised us to prosecute this case like we would any other and take it from there,'' Qualls said Thursday. Authorities said the maid at the Biltmore Hotel told them she knocked on the door of the ambassador's room Sept. 4 to ask if he wanted his bed turned down, a routine service. Sangare is accused of grabbing her and fondling her as she turned the bedsheets down. A telephone message seeking comment, left with the Embassy of Guinea in Washington, was not immediately returned. As an official representative of another country, the ambassador can claim diplomatic immunity. If he does, the case would be forwarded to the State Department, Qualls said. Arraignment in Municipal Court was scheduled for Jan. 3. The City Attorney's Office sent a letter to Sangare's Washington, D.C., residence on Thursday, notifying the ambassador that charges had been filed. The ambassador checked into the Biltmore on Sept. 3 with a group of other West African ambassadors. He left on Sept. 9, returning to Guinea.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology Of Anderson's Captivity
With AM-Hostage Birthday, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of Terry Anderson's captivity: 1985 March 16 - Anderson abducted in Beirut. Telephone caller says Islamic Jihad seized him as part of ``continuing operations against America and its agents.'' May 16 - First photo of Anderson in captivity released. Islamic Jihad warns of ``catastrophic consequences'' if Kuwait does not free convicted terrorists. June 7 - Anderson's daughter, Sulome, is born. Sept. 9 - The Rev. Benjamin Weir, another Islamic Jihad captive, is freed after 16 months in captivity. Nov. 8 - In an open letter, Anderson and three other American captives urge President Reagan to ``have mercy'' and negotiate. The hostages write letters to their families. Another to Archbishop of Canterbury appeals for Terry Waite to mediate with Islamic Jihad. 1986 Feb. 15 - Anderson's father, Glenn R. Anderson, dies of cancer at age 69. June 7 - Anderson's 46-year-old brother, Glenn Richard Jr., dies of cancer. July 26 - he Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco is freed after 19 months as a hostage. He says he was held with Anderson for a year. Oct. 3 - In a videotaped appeal, Anderson and American hostage David Jacobsen urge Reagan to work hard for their release. Nov. 2 - Jacobsen, freed after 17 months in captivity, says hostages ``are in hell.'' 1987 Dec. 24 - Islamic Jihad releases a videotape of Anderson. Appearing to read from a prepared text, he criticizes Reagan administration for failing to secure the Americans' release. 1988 March 16 - Anderson's third year in captivity. April 10 - Islamic Jihad threatens in a statement, accompanied by a photo of Anderson, that it will kill captives if any attempt is made to storm a Kuwaiti jetliner hijacked by Shiite extremists. Aug. 18 - Islamic Jihad issues a photo of Anderson with a statement containing new demands: Israeli withdrawal from south Lebanon and compensation for reconstruction of south Lebanon and south Beirut. Oct. 31 - Islamic Jihad issues a videotape of Anderson to mark his 41st birthday. He says: ``I find it difficult to keep my hope and courage high.'' 1989 Aug. 1 - Iran says it will help free Western hostages in return for help in freeing four Iranians seized by a Christian militia in July 1982. The four were believed killed. Oct. 27 - Anderson's fifth birthday in captivity. 1990 February - Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, visits Europe and Mideast for talks with Pope John Paul II, Yasser Arafat, Syrian and other leaders on her brother's plight. April 22 - American hostage Robert Polhill is released in west Beirut but says he can shed no light on Anderson's fate. April 30 - Pro-Iranian kidnappers free American educator Frank Reed in Beirut. He says he spent many months with Anderson, but had not seen him since early 1989. Aug. 24 - Irishman Brian Keenan is freed and says he spent more than four years in captivity with Anderson.

DOC.HEAD: Club Members Say Accordion Music is Wave of Future
DOC.TEXT: The artists take center stage, pouring their hearts into soulful renditions of Chopin's ``Waltz in C Sharp Minor,'' upbeat versions of ``You Are My Sunshine'' and jazzy interpretations of ``New York, New York.'' But these musicians aren't pounding pianos or plucking guitars. Their instrument is the accordion. ``The accordion is a personal instrument,'' said Lindy Kao, president of the Chicago Accordion Club. ``When you strap that accordion on your chest, it's a part of you. You really feel the music.'' The Chicago Accordion Club has 184 dues-paying members who meet on the fourth Monday of each month to play and listen to accordion music. ``A lot of people love accordion music, but they're sort of closeted,'' said Jimmy Dee, the club's 64-year-old treasurer. ``The club gives them the opportunity to come out.'' Dee said he hopes the accordion's popularity is on the upswing with the younger generation, but about two-thirds of club's members are over 40. ``When we're gone, we don't want to leave the instrument out in the cold,'' Dee said of the instrument he has played for 53 years. ``We've been just waiting for a revival.'' Club members say they're encouraged to see pop musicians like John Cougar Mellencamp and Billy Joel using accordions in their music. ``I made my living with the accordion, supported my family, sent my kids to school,'' said Manny Quartucci, 69, the club's vice president. ``When all the electronic instruments came along ... it hurt the accordion.'' But the accordion also is squeezing its way into the electronic world. Joe Petosa, 30, of Seattle, manufactures accordions, including the electric MIDI (Musical Instrument Digital Interface) accordion, which can function similar to synthesizers widely used in pop bands. ``I think the instrument's on its way back,'' Petosa said.

DOC.HEAD: Bridge to N.C.'s Hatteras Island Severed by Dredge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `No injuries...', to UPDATE with later calculation of segment of bridge that collassed, 250-foot sted 370-foot; CORRECT name of dredge to Northerly Island sted Northerly Isle, CORRECT that dredge grounded sted jammed under bridge. SUBS 14th graf, `There was..,', to add that dredge possibly grounded on debris.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XNAG1
DOC.TEXT: A gale blew a dredge into the only bridge to Hatteras Island today, severing the span and stranding thousands of people without power. The island's estimated 5,000 residents and an unknown number of tourists had no way off the island. Ferry connections to via neighboring Ocracoke Island couldn't be used because winds were gusting to 60 mph, creating waves of 5 to 7 feet in Pamlico Sound. No injuries were reported in the crash, which collapsed a 250-foot section of the Herbert C. Bonner Bridge, severed utility lines that run along it, and grounded the dredge Northerly Island. Another 50-foot section of the bridge was in danger of falling, police said. The 2{-mile-long bridge connects Hatteras Island with Bodie Island to the north along North Carolina's Outer Banks. ``There is no way to get across that bridge. It's gone, collapsed,'' said Gwen White, Dare County public information officer. The accident knocked out electrical and telephone service to Hatteras Island and to most of Ocracoke Island, located to the south and accessable only by ferry. Renee Hoffman of the state Emergency Management Division said authorities were trying to figure out how to get temporary electrical service set up. It is hoped that ferry service can be re-established witin 24 hours, she said this morning. Repairing the bridge could take months. Dare County Commissioner Gaskill Austin, who lives on Hatteras Island, said residents were ``literally in the dark out here'' but were used to minor power outages because of the frequent storms. ``As the word spreads, I'm sure my phone's going to be jammed,'' he said in an interview conducted by ham radio. ``A big need will be generators ... and to save as much foodstuffs as we have here in the stores. That and the water is my primary concern at this point.'' County emergency officials believe nobody was on the bridge when the 200-foot-long dredge struck it at about 1:30 a.m. They had gotten word a half hour earlier that the dredge had broken free of its anchor, and they closed the bridge. Highway Patrol Trooper A.C. Joyner was on the bridge when the dredge hit about 300 yards south of him. ``The bridge started bowing out in a westerly direction, and it bowed out from one to two to three feet as the ship was pressing against it,'' Joyner said. The bridge collapsed about an hour later, he said. ``There was an electrical explosion and all the power lines and telephone lines were destroyed.'' He said the dredge was stuck in the bridge, but later authorities said it appeared to be grounded, possibly on pieces of the collapsed bridge. Four of the 10 people on the dredge got off safely by climbing to the top of the dredge and onto the bridge. The six others were expected to remain on the dredge until the waves subsided, said Mikey Daniels, chairman of the Dare County Board of Commissioners. They were not in danger, authorities said. Daniels estimated the island's permanent population at 5,000. About 500 to 600 people live at Ocracoke. The Outer Banks are a popular destination for tourists, and while the peak summer tourist season has passed, it's still a prime season for fishermen. Repairing the bridge could take six months, Daniels said. Ms. White said state officials said the repair job was so big that a private contractor would have to be hired. The bridge was the only route to the island from the north. Residents would have to drive to a ferry taking them to Ocracoke Island, then to one of two ferries to the mainland. The detour for someone trying to reach Nags Head, about 10 miles north of the severed bridge, would involve more than 125 miles of driving and the two ferry rides, one about 25 miles long.

DOC.HEAD: Terry Anderson Spending Sixth Birthday in Captivity
LaserPhoto NY24
DOC.TEXT: Kidnapped American journalist Terry Anderson, the longest-held among 13 Westerners missing in Lebanon, turns 43 on Saturday, his sixth birthday in captivity. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was kidnapped at gunpoint in Moslem west Beirut on March 16, 1985. There has been no indication that his pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem captors plan to free him. Former hostage Brian Keenan of Northern Ireland, who was released on Aug. 24, said he spent part of his more than four years in captivity with Anderson. He said Anderson, whom he last saw ``some time ago,'' suffered from a digestive ailment and was frequently in pain. But Keenan noted that Anderson bore his pain stoically because ``in truth, all pain and illness was generally dismissed by our keepers, although they would eventually supply us with some form of antibiotics.'' He said Anderson, who with other hostages was kept in chains and blindfolded much of the time, suffered ``periods of despair and would seek solace in his family.'' But he noted that Anderson has been allowed to receive letters from his family and has a photograph of his youngest daughter, Sulome, 5, who was born three months after he was kidnapped. ``Terry and myself would sit through those long nights and speak with great pain and remorse and longing for his daughter,'' Keenan said. On Saturday, Lebanese newspapers plan to publish letters to Anderson from Sulome, her Lebanese mother, Madeleine, and Peggy Say, his sister. The Arabic-language papers said they will also publish the original English texts of the letters in the hope that Anderson will be allowed to read them. Anderson did not know Arabic when he was kidnapped. During his captivity, he has lost his father, Glenn R. Anderson, and elder brother, Glenn Richard Jr. Both died of cancer. As far as is known, Anderson is unaware of those deaths. Anderson's father died 11 months after the kidnapping and his 46-year-old brother died June 7, 1986, four days after making a videotape from his hospital bed pleading with Anderson's kidnappers to release him. Apart from Anderson, the missing Westerners include five other Americans, four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian. Altogether, 89 foreigners have been kidnapped or disappeared in Lebanon since January 1984. Sixty-seven have been freed or said they escaped and nine have been killed. Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and the U.S. military deployment in the Persian Gulf have complicated efforts to free Anderson and the other Americans, with pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem leaders close to the kidnappers denouncing both developments. Hussein Musawi, reputed mentor of some of the hostage-holders, has repeatedly emphasized that an early release of the American captives was unlikely. ``We denounce Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait and we also denounce the American military deployment in Moslem lands,'' he said. A fundamentalist Shiite faction called Islamic Jihad, or Islamic Holy War, claims to hold Anderson and another American, 58-year-old educator Thomas Sutherland, who was kidnapped on June 9, 1985. The last statement from Islamic Jihad that referred to Anderson and Sutherland was issued on Oct. 24, 1989. It renewed the group's demand that 15 convicted terrorists imprisoned in Kuwait be freed. But the terrorists, jailed for bombing the U.S. and French embassies in Kuwait in December 1983, are no longer in Kuwaiti hands. At least two witnesses who escaped from Kuwait when the Iraqis invaded said they saw the terrorists getting into cars before the Iraqis reached Kuwait's central prison. The 15 were mostly Iraqi Shiites opposed to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, but they included two Lebanese Shiites related to Islamic Jihad leaders. The prisoners were apparently set free by their guards. Shiite sources have reported that the two Lebanese terrorists, whom Islamic Jihad particularly wanted freed, were now back in Lebanon. Syria, the main power-broker in Lebanon, recently helped crush a rebellion by a Lebanese Christian general, but neither the Syrians nor the Lebanese army has challenged the fundamentalists in their Beirut strongholds where the Western hostages have been held. One Shiite source, who is familiar with the kidnappers' thinking, said the issue of the American captives has become ``a puzzle.'' ``The American military deployment in the gulf makes it embarrassing for Iran to pressure the captors into releasing Americans,'' he said, adding that even Iranian moderates such as President Hashemi Rafsanjani would find such a move difficult. ``Of course, the kidnappers are pro-Iranian and can be influenced by Iran, but one shouldn't forget that America has been the Great Satan in Iran's eyes since Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini rose to power in 1979,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Rafsanjani, leader of Iran's so-called pragmatists, has been seeking to have all the Westerners freed in line with his drive to improve Tehran's relations with the West and attract badly needed investment and advanced technology. But he is opposed by Iran's anti-Western radicals.

DOC.HEAD: House OKs Spending for Washington Metro
DOC.TEXT: The House agreed Friday to spend $1.3 billion over the next eight years toward completing the Washington area subway system. The legislation, passed by voice vote, calls for local governments to provide $780 million as their portion of constructing 13.5 miles of Metro's green line. The bill, already approved by the Senate, goes to President Bush, who is expected to sign it. Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., chairman of the District of Columbia Committee, called the subway ``an essential part of the national capital transportation system.'' He said the portion to be completed ``serves the most transit-dependent population'' in the area. ``It is unfortunate that the neediest will be the last to have access to mass transit,'' said Dellums, noting that the first sections of the system served more affluent areas.

DOC.HEAD: Rhode Island Governor Hopes for Political Miracle
DOC.TEXT: Trailing by 40 points in the polls, Republican Gov. Edward D. DiPrete is up against two tough opponents. One is Democrat Bruce G. Sundlun. The other, more formidable according to political scientists, is the region's battered economy. ``I would say it's almost impossible for Gov. DiPrete to come back,'' says Brown University political scientist Darrell West. ``Whether he deserves it or not, people are tying him to the economy.'' DiPrete is quick to pull out a Moody's credit report that says the state's long-term fiscal management has been solid, although the current budget threatens to hemorrhage red ink. ``I wouldn't concede it's out of anyone's control, but it's certainly making it more difficult for us to get our message out,'' a subdued DiPrete said. His consultant, Paul J. Manafort, the architect of President Bush's victory, says that if voters don't buy the forget-the-past-I-am-the-future message: ``I wouldn't say we're dead. We just don't win.'' DiPrete portrays Sundlun's promise to slash millions of dollars of waste from the $1.5 billion state budget as Draconian, cutting into services needed by the poor and elderly. But fiscal experts within and outside government suggest DiPrete may have to do the same thing. The governor, seeking his fourth two-year term, says he alone has enough experience to lead Rhode Island through a recession - and that he is the bulwark against Democrats who dominate every other Statehouse office and the General Assembly. He's proposed sweeping ethics and campaign finance reforms, a broad restructuring of state government and apologized for any mistakes he might have made. But the reaction generally has been: Why not before this? ``He's running an election where Paul Manafort can't control the agenda,'' said one of the state's highest Republican officeholders, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``To make it work, he's got to raise Bruce Sundlun's negatives, and it just won't fly.'' DiPrete, 56, has spent more than $2 million and Bush twice has attended fund-raising events. Sundlun, a millionaire businessman who largely finances his own campaigns, has spent about $3 million in the race, including the cost of the bitter three-way primary he won Sept. 11. Sundlun, 71, never known for the light touch in two previous campaigns against DiPrete, has played like an incumbent while contending he's not a professional politician. But he's is trying to guard against cockiness. ``One of the problems I have right now is that the media is trying to make me the governor, and I'm leaning over backwards not to be the governor,'' he said. ``That would be presumptuous.'' It's that touch of overconfidence that DiPrete hopes will cause Sundlun to make a major gaffe. ``I'm playing the role of the underdog,'' DiPrete said. ``And yet I think I can reverse this if I can pull him out a little.'' But it won't mean much if people don't vote, and there's every indication they may not rush to the polls Nov. 6. There were 12,300 requests for mail ballots in 1988. This year, the number of requests is down by 5,000. However, there were 4,000 ballot requests for the September primary, twice the usual number. ``They were mad in September,'' said Henry Kinch, an aide to Secretary of State Kathleen Connell. ``Now, they're just fed up.''

DOC.HEAD: Original Copy of Declaration To Be Put on Display
DOC.TEXT: A 214-year-old copy of the Declaration of Independence will be put on display, according to an agreement announced this week. The Society of the Cincinnati, which owns the 18th-century house where the document was discovered several years ago, has agreed to let the state display the mint-condition copy 100 days a year. The document was one an estimated 600 printed in Philadelphia 214 years ago. Only 23 are known to have survived. Charles Clarke, a descendant of the man who told Exeter residents of the nation's independence on July 16, 1776, read the document Thursday during a news conference where officials announced the agreement. John Taylor Gilman read the declaration on the courthouse steps when it was news to New Hampshire colonists. The group also announced plans for a museum to house the document and other historic items.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate Hampered by Skinny-Dipping Allegations to Stay in Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with leaders calling for Grunseth to quit; pick up 6th graf, `Grunseth's campaign ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Two top Minnesota Republican leaders today urged GOP candidate Jon Grunseth to drop out of the governor's race, hours after Grunseth had been on the brink of doing so before changing his mind. Grunseth, whose campaign has been crippled by allegations that he swam nude with teen-age girls nine years ago, called a news conference Thursday to announce he was dropping out of the race but switched at the last minute. Senate Minority Leader Duane Benson and House Minority Leader Bill Schreiber held a news conference at the Capitol today to publicly urge Grunseth to leave the field to state Auditor Arne Carlson, a Republican running as a write-in candidate. ``My message here today is a very simple one, that Jon Grunseth's candidacy is hurting the entire ticket,'' said Benson. ``Senator Benson and I are of one mind on this issue,'' said Schreiber. ``There is no question that the governor's race is bringing down politics in Minnesota to a level never before experienced.'' Grunseth, 44, who held up his news conference for more than three hours while he reconsidered late Thursday, said he had definitely decided to quit the race earlier in the day. ``But there has been just an incredible outpouring of love and affection and support and prayer,'' he said. ``We spent hours agonizing over this decision, and we decided about a half-hour ago that we were going to press forward no matter what.'' The decision leaves next month's gubernatorial election a three-way race between the Grunseth, Carlson and Democratic incumbent Rudy Perpich. Carlson lost to Grunseth in the Republican primary. He mounted his write-in effort after fellow Republicans began to urge Grunseth to quit the race. Grunseth's campaign was thrown into turmoil Oct. 15 when it was reported that two women said in sworn statements that he tried to get them to swim nude with him during a 1981 pool party at his home. The women, who were then 13 and 14, said they refused but that Grunseth, his teen-age daughter and a 16-year-old girl took off their bathing suits. One of the women also said Grunseth tried to pull down her bathing suit top and touch her breast. Grunseth has denied the allegations. Some Republicans complained Thursday that his decision not to quit could give the Nov. 6 election to Perpich, who seeks an unprecedented fourth term. ``If he can't have it his way he'll take the whole business down to catastrophe,'' said former Gov. Elmer L. Andersen, a Carlson supporter. Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., indicated earlier in the day that the Republican Party couldn't unseat Perpich with two candidates. ``Our base simply is not big enough to cut it in half,'' he said. ``So that we're going to have to some way repair that situation.'' Perpich was preparing for tonight's debate with Grunseth and Carlson and was unavailable for comment, spokesman Ray Bohn said today. A member of Grunseth's finance committee said that after Grunseth told 15 to 20 committee members he was dropping out, they tried to get him to change his mind. ``Jon told us he definitely was not going to stay in,'' said Rod Hendrickson. ``But after some very persuasive conversations by certain members, we felt he was going to reconsider.'' Committee members told Grunseth they would provide him an additional $200,000 in campaign funds if he would remain in the race, the Saint Paul Pioneer Press reported today. One contributor offered Grunseth $90,000 if he would stay in the running, the Star Tribune of Minneapolis reported. Campaign manager Leon Oistad said Grunseth won't hold that person to the offer, which was made in the emotion of the moment, but the campaign would welcome it.

DOC.HEAD: Cubans Don't Know It but Soviet Daily Says Castro Has Wife, 5 Kids
DOC.TEXT: Unbeknownst to the Cuban people, President Fidel Castro has a wife with whom he has had five children, a Soviet newspaper says. He also has 32 houses and 9,700 guards responsible for his personal security, it says. These tidbits - all unverifiable - about Castro's personal life appeared in a recent edition of Komsomolskaya Pravda, a leading liberal daily in Moscow. They added a new dimension to the trend toward more candid reporting about Cuba in the Soviet press. ``This is the most biting article yet because it goes after Fidel Castro personally,'' one Bush administration official said. A translation of the article appeared in a U.S. government publication that monitors the foreign media. Castro's private life is a mystery to the Cuban public. Cubans are aware that he was married in the late 1940s, has a son, Fidelito, by that marriage, and that he was divorced in the mid-1950s. ``All details concerning the personal life of Fidel Castro and the whole party-state elite in Cuba are shrouded in an impenetrable veil of secrecy,'' begins the article by A. Novikov. It said that apart from Fidelito, Castro also has an illegitimate daughter, Alina Fernandez Revuelta, about 34 years old. Castro's ``present wife'' works in the Cuban Institute of Oceanography and they have five sons, all of whom have first names starting with ``A'' - Aloin, Alex, Anatolio and so on, the story said. The sons all studied in the Soviet Union, it said, and were taken care of by a married couple who were Cuban state security employees. Some details in the article were corroborated by Georgie Ann Geyer, a syndicated columnist who has written a soon-to-be-released biography of Castro, ``Guerrilla Prince, The Untold Story of Fidel Castro.'' The woman referred to in the article apparently is Daria Soto del Valle, Ms. Geyer said. She, too, said that the couple has produced five children and added that her research indicates Castro may have fathered 14 or more offspring over the years. Explaining Castro's passion for secrecy, Ms. Geyer said, ``A charismatic leader's power depends on his not being known.'' The Komsomolskaya Pravda article continued: ``Fidel has 32 houses (state houses, of course) scattered around the whole country. In Havana, he has three houses and two underground bunkers, where, if need be, the commander in chief can hide, together with his retinue of 57 generals.'' The account apparently touched a raw nerve in Cuba. When a Mexican television crew in Moscow reported on the story earlier this week, Cuban authorities retaliated by expelling a crew from the same network which was on assignment in Havana. Komsomolskaya Pravda is described as a leading practitioner of the new wave journalism introduced in recent years in the Soviet Union. It is a supporter of the country's best known radical politician, Boris Yeltsin, who is president of the Russian Republic. U.S. officials said the details of Castro's personal life apparently were leaked to the publication by Soviet officials who believe Moscow should loosen its ties to Cuba. Relations remain outwardly cordial but trade between the two countries has fallen sharply, partly because of the economic chaos in the Soviet Union. The story said that the marriage of Castro's brother, Raul, broke down five years ago but the couple still appear together in public. Raul is No. 2 in the Cuban hierarchy. ``At the moment, Raul is `illegally' married to a Bulgarian woman and apart from this, has an illegitimate daughter by a woman who is the director of Cuban television,'' it said. None of the contentions in the article could be verified independently. The article says that Castro's personal guard numbers 9,700 people throughout the country, 2,800 of whom are in the capital. But when he visits any province, the deployment of additional units can mean that up to 28,000 people are mobilized for ``the security of one single person,'' it said. When Castro goes bathing or sailing on one of his three yachts, 122 divers ``comb the sea bed inch by inch in search of underwater mines and traps,'' it added. Cuban officials have justified the tight security around Castro by citing U.S.-sponsored assassination attempts against him. A Senate study 15 years ago concluded ther were eight such attempts while Castro himself has put the figure at 25.

DOC.HEAD: President Renewing Attacks on Democrats
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Combines pvs, with new material and editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today blamed Democrats for the higher taxes his administration is negotiating with lawmakers, saying the Democratic-controlled Congress ``has been on an uncontrolled spending binge for years.'' Bush, who promised during his presidential campaign he would not support tax increases, said he was forced to compromise to get a deficit-reduction agreement through the House and Senate. Noting that Democrats for 36 years have controlled the House, he said that ``year after year after year they have presided over these budget deficits and they appropriate every dime and they tell me how to spend every dime.'' ``Yes I've had to compromise, haven't liked that a bit, but I've done it because the president must at certain times put the overall good of the country first,'' he told a fund-raising breakfast for the California Republican Party. In accepting his presidential nomination at the 1988 Republican National Convention, Bush said: ``And the Congress will push me to raise taxes, and I'll say no, and they'll push, and I'll say no, and they'll push again. And I'll say to them: Read my lips. No new taxes.'' Bush complained that a top Democrat was criticising his leadership in this morning's newspaper - apparently a reference to statements by Rep. Richard Gephardt published today in The Washington Post. ``I think George Bush can be beaten in 1992,'' said Gephardt, House majority leader. ``In the last two months, he's shown a real failure of leadership. He needed to explain to the American people why they were being asked to swallow strong medicine, but he didn't do it.'' Bush said, ``The American people know that strong medicine ... is required because the Democratic Congress simply has been on an uncontrolled spending binge for years. You don't have to be a rocket scientist to know that Congress has been spending more than we take in for far too long. ``The (deficit-reduction) agreement that we get won't be the best deal possible but in my judgement it will be the best deal possible with this Congress,'' he said. Bush was to appear later at a campaign luncheon for Sen. Pete Wilson, California's GOP gubernatorial candidate running against former Democratic Mayor Dianne Feinstein of San Francisco. Wilson did not attend this morning's breakfast, speaking instead by telephone loudspeaker. He said he stayed in Washington to work on the budget negotiations which are nearing completion. In the budget fight, members of the president's own party defected from the bipartisan package he approved earlier because it contained tax increases. Charles Black, spokesman for the Republican National Committee, said earlier that Bush was preparing a new, ``partisan sharp message'' but holding off on the most venomous anti-Democratic rhetoric until the bipartisan budget agreement was signed. After his California appearances, the president was heading to Hawaii to stump for Senate candidate Rep. Pat Saiki, and meet with leaders of 11 Pacific island nations. En route home, he will make another stop for Wilson in San Francisco and then in Oklahoma to campaign for GOP gubernatorial candidate Bill Price. Bush delayed his Thursday departure and canceled stops in Arizona and New Mexico while final details of the budget pact were nailed down. His trip ends Monday, just a week before election eve, and continues his pattern of helping Republicans whose loyalty to him has been selective. Wilson and Saiki have bucked the White House on key issues. Both helped defeat the deficit-reduction pact, backed by Bush, that was the forerunner to the package emerging this week. Wilson, in a neck-and-neck race against Democrat Dianne Feinstein, issued a statement at the time saying its ``tax hikes will only encourage Congress to spend more and more.'' Saiki also voted for the sweeping civil rights legislation that Bush vetoed. She was preparing to vote to override his veto before the override was killed in the Senate, her office said. In a related development Thursday, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater all but invited the National Republican Congressional Committee to fire co-chairman Edward J. Rollins for a recent memo in which he told House GOP candidates: ``Do not hesitate to oppose either the president or (budget) proposals advanced in Congress.'' Fitzwater said Rollins' remarks ``were not helpful. I think the ... committee will be able to take charge of this situation.'' Asked whether Rollins should be dismissed, he said: ``That's up to the committee.''

DOC.HEAD: European Leaders Will Hold Summit on Gulf, Trade, Political Union
DOC.TEXT: European Community leaders get their first formal chance this weekend to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, but their talks may be overshadowed by a sharp clash over plans for modest cuts in farm subsidies. The leaders of the dozen West European nations will open a mini-summit Saturday evening at the Palazzo Madama, or Italian senate, in Rome and wind it up Sunday morning. Italy holds the community's rotating presidency. During the eight hours of talks, they are expected to cover issues ranging from the gulf crisis and troubles in the Soviet Union to futuristic plans for giving the community a single voice in foreign policy. But the meeting could turn sour if the leaders are forced to break a deadlock over a community proposal for snipping farm subsidies by 30 percent over 10 years. Such a discussion would be ``totally unproductive and I would even say disastrous,'' said Jacques Delors, president of the community's executive body. But British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is expected to raise the issue if agriculture and trade ministers are unable to end the dispute before the summit. ``It would be disastrous not to have it on the agenda,'' said a British source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, whose government faces elections in December, opposes the plan for farm cuts. His aides insist on special aid to offset any income losses suffered by farmers. Germany's action, backed by France and Ireland, has threatened the ambitious Uruguay round of international trade talks, a four-year effort to revamp the world trade system. Final bargaining will begin in five weeks. The leaders are expected to discuss the gulf situation and possibly aid to Jordan, Turkey and Egypt, hard hit by the trade embargo on Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait. The leaders have discussed the issue in bilateral talks but not all together. The economic woes of the Soviet Union and the new democracies in Eastern Europe also will be on the agenda, although new aid offers appear unlikely. At a June summit in Dublin, the leaders asked aides to put together proposals for short-term loans and other assistance for the Kremlin. But community officials say they are not ready. The work has been hampered by the Soviets' lack of statistics and delay in adopting an economic reform plan. They also say the Soviet Union, the world's largest crude oil producer, will be helped by the recent surge in oil prices. The leaders may spar, as in the past, over far-reaching plans to form a political merger with a common foreign and security policy and an economic and monetary union with a joint currency and central bank. Special conferences will open in mid-December to make changes in the community's founding Treaty of Rome to set out new powers. Mrs. Thatcher has opposed some of the more radical suggestions for joining forces with her allies on the continent, arguing against giving up national powers to new institutions. ``We see no prospect of a United States of Europe,'' she said in an interview with London's Independent newspaper. ``But there are many practical ways in which Europe can grow together,'' she said. ``The community should not stand still.'' She is certain to oppose a push by Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti to set a date, likely Jan. 1, 1994, for the start of work on a central bank. Moreover, Andreotti, according to spokesman Pio Mastrobuoni, will urge support for eventual creation of a single currency - an idea flatly rejected by Mrs. Thatcher. Turning to political union, a new Italian report said the community ``is increasingly a major factor of stability in Europe and one of the major players in international affairs.'' ``It will be able to fully play this role only if it acquires stronger unity and (can act) with its own identity on the international scene,'' the report said. Germany, aware of fears the newly united nation will become too powerful, supports closer political ties. ``It is essential for us that we strengthen Europe,'' said a German source, speaking on condition of anonymity. But Britain and France want to retain a good deal of power in their own hands, while smaller countries worry about being left out. ``Our interests would be better protected in an organized structure where there is room for everybody, not just the larger countries,'' a Dutch official said. Some want the community to take on a defense role, too. Italian Foreign Minister Gianni De Michelis wants the community to adopt the Western European Union, a security grouping of nine EC nations. But neutral Ireland would balk at any attempt to turn the community into a military powerhouse, while close U.S. allies oppose moves to weaken the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Supreme Court Reinstates Convictions Of Two In Collapse Of Ohio Thrift
DOC.TEXT: The Ohio Supreme Court today reinstated the convictions of the former owner and the former president of Home State Savings Bank, whose whose failure five years ago triggered a state savings and loan crisis. Marvin Warner and David Schiebel were convicted of charges relating to the collapse of the Cincinnati-based Home State, of which Warner was owner and Schiebel president. The convictions were overturned last year by a state appeals court. Home State collapsed on March 8, 1985, four days after ESM Government Securities Inc. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was declared insolvent. Home State lost $144 million through its securities transactions with ESM. Home State's collapse caused a run on the state's 69 other Ohio savings and loans institutions whose deposits were insured by the Ohio Deposit Guarantee Fund. The privately owned, state-chartered fund was similar to the federal deposit insurance agencies. The crisis forced Gov. Richard Celeste to temporarily close the thrifts and order them to obtain federal deposit insurance or merge with companies that had federal protection before they could reopen. Warner was convicted of nine felonies - six counties of misapplying about $14 million in bank money through unauthorized payments to ESM and three counts of securities violations. He was acquitted of 76 other counts. Schiebel was found guilty of three securities violations. The convictions on March 2, 1987, came in a four-month trial in Hamilton County Common Pleas Court. Warner had been sentenced to 3{ years in prison and Schiebel to six months, but both were free on bond pending their appeals. Another former president of the thrift, Burton Bongard, was convicted of 82 counts of missapplication and unauthorized transfer of funds. Bongard later pleaded guilty to loan violations and received a 4{-year prison sentence. He was released from prison in July 1989 on probation. A three-judge panel of the 1st Ohio District Court of Appeals in Cincinnati overturned the convictions of Warner and Schiebel on Nov. 15, 1989. The court reversed Warner's and Schiebel's convictions on the three securities counts that alleged they covered up Home State's precarious financial position in circulars distributed to raise money for Home State's operations in 1984. That portion of the case was sent back to the lower court for possible new trial. In its ruling that was reversed today, the appeals court also dismissed Warner's convictions on the six counts that he oversaw unauthorized transfers of Home State money to ESM. The court said the state did not present sufficient evidence. The appellate court also threw out the lower court's order that Warner pay $22 million in restitution to Ohio and $250,000 in court costs, and that Schiebel pay $25,000 in court costs.

DOC.HEAD: Drive To Cut Deficit Doesn't Halt Scramble For Pet Projects
With AM-Congress Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Congress' struggle to find $20 billion in spending cuts this year as a part of a five-year, $500 billion deficit-reduction plan is not stopping lawmakers from taking care of their home states and districts. Indiana Rep. John Myers, the top Republican on the House Appropriations subcommittee on energy and water projects, got $4.8 million for a new technology center at Indiana State University. Another subcommittee member, Rep. Wes Watkins, D-Okla., got $5 million for a technology research center at Oklahoma State University. Yet another, Rep. Virginia Smith, R-Neb., got $5.7 million for biochemistry and chemical engineering research at the University of Nebraska. The panel's chairman, Rep. Tom Bevill, D-Ala., got $10 million for biomedical research. Its No. 2 Democrat, Rep. Lindy Boggs of Louisiana, also got $10 million, for an energy research park at the University of New Orleans. None of the spending had been sought by the Bush Administration or authorized by any House committees with jurisdiction over scientific research. All of it, plus another $45 million that key members of the Senate Appropriations Committee wanted, showed up in a negotiated compromise between the two houses directing President Bush just where to spend Department of Energy funds next year. ``This is research that has to be done,'' Myers maintains. ``Maybe they are located in some of the districts of (appropriations committee) members, but we know more about them there.'' But to many of the 449 members of Congress who don't hold seats on the House or Senate Appropriations Committees, the 29 senators and 57 who do often abuse their power of the purse in directing just where $183 billion for various domestic programs will be spent in fiscal 1991. ``I'm over outrage; I'm into nausea,'' says Rep. Robert Walker of Pennsylvania. ``The fact is that when we are allocating money, it is not based upon merit other than the people who are sitting in the room divvying up the money.'' Walker, the top Republican on the House Science, Space and Technology Committee, tried in vain last week to stop what he called ``the unauthorized pork-barrel projects.'' The House voted against him nearly 3-to-1. ``The word on the floor'' was ``you, better be with us on this, or we're going to take a look at your projects, too,'' he said. Sometimes lawmakers' efforts involve more than just getting money for their home states and often it requires more than a single year's effort. For example, Hawaii Sen. Daniel K. Inouye, the No. 2 Democrat on the Senate Appropriations Committee, got $5 million for his state's Department of Business and Economic Development to verify potential geothermal resource sites. But he also set in motion getting $50 million next year to help pay for renovating the medical center of George Washington University in Washington. A graduate of the university's law school and now a member of its board of trustees, Inouye got the Senate last week to authorize a $50 million grant for the school as part of the Medical Devices Act. An aide to him described it as a ``lure'' to help the university raise $100 million in matching funds from its alumni so that Inouye can seek actual appropriations for the project next year as part of the fiscal 1992 budget. The unabashed champion of directing federal money to his home state is Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the president pro-tempore of the Senate and Democratic chairman of its Appropriations Committee. A 32-year Senate veteran, he gave up the more prestigious majority leader's job two years ago to succeed retiring Mississippi Sen. John Stennis as appropriations chairman ``where I can best serve the people of my state.'' Byrd included $10 million for Alzheimer's research at West Virginia University in the measure that Walker tried to stop. He also helped ax $55 million that President Bush wanted for hiring 1,000 new IRS agents to instead build a new $80 million federal courthouse in Charleston. And last spring, he won $185 million to relocate the FBI's fingerprint laboratory, ``a law enforcement priority that would have to be built somewhere,'' from Washington to Clarksburg, W.Va. ``My proposals for West Virginia come under the sharpest scrutiny, more so because I'm the chairman,'' Byrd said this week, citing the depressed economy in his state. ``This nation must invest in its infrastructure, its research and its people .... My efforts to strengthen West Virginia's economic bases reflect that belief.''

DOC.HEAD: Child's Report of Brother's Fatal Beating Dismissed by Emergency Operator
DOC.TEXT: An emergency operator told a 7-year-old girl to ``get off the phone'' when she called to report her brother being fatally beaten, a newspaper reported Friday. Troy and Jane McCants pleaded guilty Thursday to involuntary manslaughter in the June death of their 6-year-old son, Antwon Dumas. The couple originally was charged with second-degree murder. The plea agreement was prompted in part by records showing their daughter's 911 emergency call was ignored, The Detroit News said. ``My brother been murdered,'' Iyesha McCants told a 911 operator, according to police recordings. The operator responded, ``Get off the phone, ... get off the phone right now,'' according to the newspaper. It said the girl's continued pleadings were obscured by the operator's voice telling her to hang up. Jane McCants called for an ambulance five minutes later, according to the tape, but the boy was dead when the ambulance arrived. Authorities said they were not certain whether the boy could have been saved five minutes earlier. Wayne County Prosecutor John O'Hair said the operator, who wasn't identified, has been disciplined. O'Hair would not say what measures were taken. Judge Robert Ziolkowski ordered the McCants to undergo a psychiatric evaluation and set sentencing for Nov. 5. The couple could receive 15 years in prison. At a preliminary hearing in July, Iyesha McCants testified that her parents had three extension cords they used to beat her brother. She said her mother beat him with a leather belt the day he died. Assistant Prosecutor Nancy Diehl said the guilty pleas will save the girl from the trauma of testifying again. ``One young life was ended needlessly,'' Diehl said. ``We do not want to harm another.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Report Blames Police for Indiscriminate Firing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with final pages of report saying police fired indiscriminately during Temple Mount masscre. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Israeli investigation into the Temple Mount killings said today that police use of live ammunition was justified but that there was indiscrimnnate shooting. The probe severely criticized Israel's police chief and Jerusalem's two top officers for ignoring advance signs of trouble at the holy site. The three-man commission also that Palestinians provoked the riot, but that police showed little sensitivity to the Temple Mount as a holy place for Jews and for Moslems, who call it Haram es-Sharif. The report said that when police broke into the Temple Mount compound to confront Palestinian rioters, ``there was indiscriminate use of live ammunition.'' It said the use of live ammunition ``was unavoidable'' to rescue two policemen thought to be trapped in a station on the Temple Mount and to secure their armory of three submachine guns and 43 pistols. However, the report did not give details of the indiscriminate shooting, discussing it only in general terms near the end of the 59-page report and not even mentioning it in the report's main conclusions. But the report implied that police may have fired when they were not in danger and may have continued firing after it was no longer necessary to gain control of the area. ``The use of live fire was without strict supervision by officers,'' it said. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir named the commission two days after the rioting on Oct. 8 to examine what led to the confrontation, which began after Arabs stoned Jews praying at the Western Wall, below the Temple Mount. Police said at the time that 19 Palestinians were killed and more than 140 wounded in Israeli gunfire, but today's report said 20 were killed. The massacre prompted two U.N. Security Council resolutions, both of which brought the United States into conflict with Israel, its closest ally in the Middle East. The United States was the chief sponsor of a resolution approved Oct. 12 by the Council that condemned Israel for the shooting deaths of the Palestinians on the Temple Mount and called for a U.N. investigation. The United States voted against Israel again on Wednesday for refusing to admit U.N. investigators. Israel fears accepting the U.N. mission would be tantamount to accepting world objections to Israel's annexation of predominantly Arab east Jerusalem, captured with the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip in the 1967 war. Israel had said its internal investigation will be adequate. Today's report justified the police use of force to capture the area up to the line of the two mosques on the Temple Mount, but questioned whether police needed to go north of the line and make arrests. ``Groups and individuals acted on their own judgment north of the line of the mosques,'' it said. Some of them ran into ``difficult situations'' and had to open fire. ``But it is doubtful whether the cleaning up of the area and the conduct of arrests ... was essential in the conditions that prevailed on the Mount,'' the report said. It said that the force that charged onto the Mount was unsupervised, put together at random and not fully briefed. The report referred without elaboration to ``initiatives'' taken by commanders after the stabilization of the mosque area. These could be justified in an emergency, it said, ``but on the Temple Mount, because of its distinctiveness and in non-emergency conditions, such an initiative is dangerous.'' It cited one such case, saying: ``We did not find that this officer's initiative caused injury or loss of life, but the action remains grave.'' The report said police had prior reports of the possibility of riots on the Temple Mount. It said police commanders failed to recognize passions aroused by the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising, Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, and ``the inflammatory calls'' of Moslem clerics a week earlier to block a rumored march to the Mount by Jewish zealots. The report criticized the top police echelon for being absent even when it became obvious a dangerous situation was brewing. Jerusalem Police Commander Aryeh Bibi ``should have hurried immediately to the Temple Mount,'' while Jerusalem District Commander Rahamim Comfort should have joined him ``to supervise the situation personally,'' the report said. It said the police ``who were attacked by an incited mob ... feared for their lives and the lives of tens of thousands worshipers who were at the Western Wall for a holiday prayer. ``After the massive pelting with stones and other materials, the police fired (tear) gas grenades and rubber bullets and hoped this would deter the rampaging crowd and force it some way back from the Western Wall,'' the report said. It said the police fell back through a gate leading out of the mosque compound, which the Arabs then blocked while continuing to throw stones at the Western Wall, also known as the Wailing Wall. The police, having fled, then heard over their walkie-talkies ``a desperate cry'' for rescue by two policemen manning a regular post inside the compound, which also contains ``dozens of weapons and ammunition,'' the report said. The police charged back into the compound, not knowing the two officers were by now safe, and used ``gas grenades and even live fire as the crowd bombarded them with rocks and other materials that threatened their lives.'' ``It was at this stage that the heavy losses of life were caused among those congregated on the Mount and when the congregants went into the mosques an order to cease fire was given,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: International Poll Watchers: No Evidence to Support Fraud Claims
DOC.TEXT: International poll watchers said Friday they found no evidence to support ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's claims that her party lost a parliamentary election because of widespread voter fraud. Ms. Bhutto rejected the findings and declared: ``Today we have a constitutional dictator after an electoral coup d'etat.'' The winning alliance said it hoped the investigation would persuade Washington to resume vital economic and military aid to Pakistan. Ms. Bhutto's center-left Pakistan People's Party was defeated by the right-wing Islamic Democratic Alliance more than 2-1 in Wednesday's election. The 37-year-old former premier, whose government was dismissed Aug. 6 on corruption and mismanagement charges, has refused to concede defeat. She has accused the army-backed caretaker government and her opponents of massive vote-rigging and said she will challenge the election results in court. The alliance, a loose-knit coalition of 18 parties, called Ms. Bhutto a sore loser and said such large-scale tampering would be impossible. At a news conference in this southern port city, a 40-member observer team from the Washington-based National Democratic Institute said it had found no evidence to support Ms. Bhutto's claims. ``We have not found any evidence of irregularities which could have altered the outcome of the elections significantly. Voting took place in a peaceful and positive atmopshere,'' said Vahit Halefaglu, a prominent Turkish diplomat and leader of the delegation. Halefaglu said the team, which monitored 30 constituencies nationwide, would probably release its final report in about three months. The institute sent observers from 18 countries to monitor the election of a new National Assembly, the law-making lower house of Parliament that will choose Pakistan's next prime minister. Earlier this week, a 15-member team from India, Nepal, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh said its preliminary findings showed the poll was fair and free. Both teams will monitor legislative elections in Pakistan's four provinces Saturday, seen as a test of strength for the alliance and a measure of the erosion of Ms. Bhutto's popularity. Ms. Bhutto's lawyer and former interior minister, Aitzaz Ahsan, said the People's Party stands by its claims regardless of the institute's findings. ``The tampering is self-evident. If then NDI is saying this was a fair election, then the NDI hasn't seen anything,'' Ahsan said. Sartaj Aziz, finance minister in the caretaker government and an alliance member, said he hoped the institute's initial findings would reinforce the notion that Pakistan's political institutions are able to hold free, fair elections. The United States and other Western countries had threatened to cut off hundreds of millions of dollars in economic and military aid if the election was rigged and Ms. Bhutto victimized. Earlier this month, Washington suspended a $573 million aid package because Pakistan had not given enough guarantees that it did not possess or want to possess nuclear weapons. Before asssitance resumes, Congress has demanded certification that this week's polls were free and fair. Halefaglu said that although the group did not rule out the possibility of some rigging, the voting overall was orderly and peaceful. ``Despite these positive conditions, the election process was not without problems,'' he said, The team found the monthlong election campaign was conducted in a highly polarized political environment, he said. That was in part because of the dismissal of Ms. Bhutto's government and the establishment of special tribunals to try her and members of her government for corruption. Halefaglu was critical of election coverage by state-run television, saying it was heavily biased in favor of the caretaker government. He also said the team had received complaints of party workers being killed, reports of armed attacks on election officials and of ballot boxes being switched. The team is investigating complaints and also comparing the final ballot count to voter lists, Halefaglu said. Even if the complaints were proved, he said, it would not have altered the outcome.

DOC.HEAD: Transplant Patient Starts Breathing On Her Own
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old girl was breathing on her own Friday after receiving part of her mother's lung in what's believed to be the nation's first live-donor lung transplant, hospital officials said. The operation offers hope to perhaps hundreds of children a year who suffer from certain lung diseases because transplanted tissue from a relative reduces the risk of rejection, said Dr. Vaughn Starnes, who led the surgical team. Mother and daughter remained in good condition a day after surgeons replaced the daughter's right lung with a lobe removed from the mother's right lung, said Joyce B. Thomas, a spokeswoman for Stanford Medical Center. ``Both are doing fine,'' Thomas said. The mother started breathing on her own shortly after the four-hour operation Thursday. Doctors had given the girl 12-18 more months to live, but they now expect her to fully recover. Doctors expect the girl to remain hospitalized for several weeks. The mother will probably go home earlier. Doctors said its likely the transplanted lung will expand capacity and may even grow. ``The girl probably won't be a sprinter, but certainly she can go to school, participate in games and activities and go on dates, do all the normal things that kids can do,'' Stanford spokesman Mike Goodkind said. The mother's lifestyle is not expected to be changed by the procedure, Goodkind said. ``Very commonly, for lung cancer for example, an entire lung is removed. People can function normally with one lung,'' Goodkind said. Transplants from related, live donors are important for children because they have a higher rate of rejection than adults, which ``might have something to do with their more active immune systems,'' Starnes said. The most likely benefactors are patients with a large hole in the diaphragm, high blood pressure on the lung or scarring of the lung, said Goodkind. ``The fact is this is not a procedure that would have wide application for millions of people. It is a specific treatment for a select group of child patients who are terminally ill,'' Goodkind said. ``The fact that it was a live-donor transplant was, in this case, subordinate to the idea that the recipient was so closely related to the donor.'' The 46-year-old mother and her child matched on four of six genetic markers, or tissue antigens, compared to no more than two such matches in Stanford's previous brain dead-donor lung and heart transplants, Starnes said. Seven of 14 children who have received heart-lung transplants at Stanford suffered rejection severe enough to impair lung function. That's nearly twice the rejection rate of 71 adults who have undergone the same operation, according to Stanford. The girl suffers from a rare malady called bronchopulmonary dysplasia, which causes scarring of the lungs and high blood pressure. The condition was the result of being placed on a respirator after being born prematurely, said Goodkind. The malady also affects her remaining left lung, but won't impair the transplanted tissue, Goodkind said. The patients' names were withheld at the family's request.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Reportedly Seeks Peace With Kurdish Minority
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with two more Americans reportedly taken into custody by Iraqis. Pickup 7th, `What is...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein is seeking to make peace with Iraq's Kurdish minority, a Baghdad newspaper said today. The Kurds have in the past been the target of poison gas attacks and forcible relocation by the Baghdad government. Saddam's reported bid to reconcile with the Kurds comes several weeks after the Iraqi president made peace with another longstanding foe, Iran, so he could move tens of thousands of troops from the Iranian border to occupied Kuwait and the Saudi Arabian border. It was not immediately clear why Saddam would want to placate the Kurdish minority, but he may want to eliminate all internal opposition to prepare for possible combat with the multinational force arrayed against him. The Iraqi forces occupying Kuwait have arrested two Americans who had been hiding in the occupied emirate to avoid internment in Saddam ``human shield,'' Western diplomats disclosed today. Uwe Jahnke, 47, of Washington Depot, Conn., and John Stevenson, 44, of Panama City, Fla., were brought to Baghdad on Oct. 22, a day after their arrest in Kuwait, said the diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity. They said the pair were taken to the government-run Mansour-Melia Hotel, where scores of other foreigners are being held. In another development, Iraq's foreign minister criticized the United States and Britain, saying they were trying to block any Arab solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. Tariq Aziz, in remarks reported today by the official Iraqi News Agency, also accused the U.S-led multinational force of seeking to seize control of the region's oil resources. If the multinational force eventually moves to evict Iraq from Kuwait and the emirate is destroyed in the process, that will not be too high a price to pay for liberation, Kuwait's exiled prime minister was quoted as saying today. ``What is left of Kuwait after what Saddam's soldiers did to it?'' said Prime Minister Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, according to the Saudi daily Asharq al-Awsat. ``As a citizen and a responsible official, I am ready to sacrifice everything for the sake of regaining my land and liberating it, and that is how each ordinary Kuwaiti thinks,'' said Sheik Saad, who is also the crown prince. Kuwait's government-in-exile has also disclosed that casualties from the invasion were far higher than initially reported. The government-run Kuwait News Agency, monitored in Bahrain, said 4,200 Kuwaitis were killed during the invasion. Initial reports had said several hundred died. The news agency, citing Kuwaiti government officials, also said 12,000 Kuwaiti soldiers weretaken prisoner, out of a total pre-invasion Kuwaiti military force of about 20,000. Fears about war in the gulf sent oil prices up more than $3 per barrel in the futures market Thursday. Light sweet crude rose $3.17 to $34.25 a barrel for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange, a key market. It was crude oil's third-biggest one-day jump in the Mideast crisis. When the market reopened today, oil prices jumped again, up 95 cents to $35.20 per barrel. ``It's definitely just the increased war fears and seeing the war premium getting put back in the market,'' Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., said in New York. In the report about Saddam's effort to make peace with the Kurds, the Baghdad newspaper, al-Jumhuriya, reported the Iraqi president visited the northeastern Kurdish province of Suleimaniya on Thursday. It said he walked the streets and prayed with residents. ``Give us five years during which we will not resort to the rifle and if we see that the situation is improving, we will go ahead and bury the rifle and say that the issue has come to an end,'' Saddam was quoted as telling one resident. There are up to 3.5 million Kurds in Iraq. They have campaigned since the beginning of the century for an independent homeland together with fellow Kurds in Iran and Turkey. Kurds were suspected of collaborating with Iran during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war that unofficially ended in 1988 and Baghdad used poison gas to kill thousands of them. The killings drew international outcry. Iraq also relocated thousands of Kurds to areas away from the Iranian border region. Saddam is ready to use chemical weapons against if the predominantly American multinational force in the gulf attacks him, former Prime Minister Edward Heath has told British legislators, Press Association reported today. Heath met with Saddam on Sunday and negotiated the release of 32 British passport holders. Britain's domestic news agency said Heath was understood to have told Conservative Party lawmakers at a private meeting Thursday that Saddam said he also would mistreat foreign hostages if attacked. ``Mr. Heath is said to have expressed the view that the Iraqi leader was ruthless, cold and calculating, but not mad,'' Press Association reported.

DOC.HEAD: Test Tube Hair Could Lead to Cure for Baldness
DOC.TEXT: A hair-raising experiment at Cambridge University has raised hopes for bald men, but experts said Friday it could be years before scientists can apply their test tube hair growth to shiny heads. ``This is the real thing,'' said Dr. Terence Kealey, leader of the research team which grew hair in a synthetic blood product at the Department of Clinical Biochemistry. ``We have for the first time succeeded in getting hair to grow in vitro,'' he said. The balding scientist stressed in a BBC radio interview that growing hair in a test tube ``is not in itself a cure for baldness.'' But, he added, it provides the perfect medium for experiments and could lead to effective treatment within 10 years. The results of the research are to be published in the Journal of Cell Science next month. Experts welcomed the achievement, saying it could lead to preventing hair loss in men genetically disposed to baldness. ``Any knowledge of how hair grows and metabolizes could have various offshoots in preventing baldness from happening,'' said Dr. Ken Maxted, a dermatologist with the Glasgow Health Board who went bald at 18. ``Whether it is a cure for people who are bald, I'm not quite sure. I think it's rather nice having a waterproof head,'' he said in an interview. Dr. John Firmage, a consultant at the Scalp and Hair Hospital in London, said the research was an important first step to understanding what affects hair growth and loss. ``Until now, it has been very difficult to know what happens'' except that the process of balding is hereditary, Dr. Firmage said. ``Hence the many lotions and potions which are produced.'' Dr. John Romano at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in New York said scientists would be able to test new chemicals on test-tube hair without worrying about injuring someone's scalp. ``Researchers can use many more different chemicals because they don't have to worry about toxicity,'' he said in a telephone interview. Kealey said the next step is to find out why many middle-aged men suffer a disruption in the normal mechanism that triggers the growth of new, replacement hair. ``I hope that within 10 years we could come up with a cure for baldness,'' he said. The successful growth of test tube hair came after a team member, Dr. Michael Philpott, devised a method for extracting hair follicles from the skin without damaging the roots, Kealey said. This is done by carefully slicing away the top two layers of skin to remove hair follicles with fine tweezers. The follicles then are grown in a synthetic blood substitute maintained at body temperature, he said. Watching hair growing in a test tube is ``an amazing sight,'' Kealey said. ``It grows absolutely identical to normal hairs - at the same rate of 0.012 inches a day and in the same shape.'' The research was funded by the Anglo-Dutch consumer giant Unilever and Britain's Science and Engineering Research Council, he said. Kealey said the research also could lead to a more effective depilatory for removing unwanted hair. Hairs grow for about two years and then spontaneously shed, he said, adding that a natural depilatory would result if the shedding process could be hastened. ``In fact, what we can do now in the laboratory is persuade hairs to shed in this very natural manner and so we hope that we might quite quickly start trying to work on improved depilatories,'' Kealey said. Cambridge University is known for its contributions to scientific research, including discovery of the electron, the neutron and the structure of DNA, the building blocks of genetic material. Kealey said that although he was ``thrilled'' at the team's breakthrough, as an intellectual achievement ``it has to be viewed as rather trivial.'' Nevertheless, many men will find the breakthrough welcome news since, Kealey said, the onset of balding can be ``intensely traumatic - maybe because it is the first visible sign of advancing age.'' ``I am myself bald, but I don't think it's something that bothers me very much,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Pumpkin Bags Sprouting on Lawns Across America
LaserPhoto HF2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 260-gallon cq
DOC.TEXT: Not all the pumpkins decorating homes this fall were scooped out and carved into jack-o'-lanterns. Some are 5 feet high, 4{ feet wide and stuffed with leaves. Giant Stuff-A-Pumpkins, 260-gallon plastic leaf bags with black pumpkin faces, are the rage this Halloween season, ornamenting millions of lawns across America. ``We don't have any trees in our yard, so we went out one night and robbed the leaves of the people next door,'' said Betty Brown, a West Hartford mother of three whose family of Stuff-A-Pumpkins peer down from her front-porch roof. ``It was fun filling them,'' said her 11-year-old daughter, Jennifer. ``Kids on the bus see them on the roof and they ask me, `Where'd you get em?''' The bags are made by Stamford-based Sun Hill Industries Inc. Sun Hill gave the world those tiny, stick-on digital clocks, plastic banana ears and Cool Sounds, a beach cooler with a radio built into the lid, along with mostly seasonal novelties like floating ghosts, pumpkin lampshade-covers and Easter egg decorating kits. The Giant Stuff-A-Pumpkin is its biggest seller ever, said Benson Zinbarg, president of the company. ``It's a self-advertising product,'' he said. ``When people see it on their neighbor's lawn, they want to have it in their yard.'' One of Sun Hill's executives dreamed up the idea in late 1988, during one of its brainstorming sessions. Zinbarg couldn't get bank financing to develop and market the pumpkin bags. He ended up gambling all his savings and persuading friends to invest. The bags were in stores last fall, but didn't take off until this year. They are now sold in nearly every major retail chain, said Zinbarg, a former plastics engineer. Zinbarg wouldn't disclose sales figures for his privately held company, but said he will be able to pay off his creditors by next month thanks to the Stuff-A-Pumpkin. His employees can except a nice bonus, too, he said. Susan Feinberg, a spokeswoman for K mart Corp. in Troy, Mich., said the chain ran out of the bags within a couple of weeks at its 2,100 stores nationwide. The Giant Stuff-A-Pumpkin sells for $3.98 retail, but can be found for as little as $1.98 in some discount stores. Sun Hill recently added ``Pumpkin Patch'' bags, in papa, mamma and baby sizes of 32 gallons, 21 gallons and 11{ gallons. Then there's the Stuff-a-Bat, Stuff-a-Cat and Stuff-a-Witch. But the Giant Stuff-A-Pumpkin is the blockbuster, Zinbarg said. Stamford-based Sun Hill obtained a patent for its Stuff-A-Pumpkins in August. A few imitations have cropped up, but five manufacturers have agreed to stop producing the phonies, Zinbarg.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Sentenced to Six Month Prison Term
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 13th graf, Barry ducked... to UPDATE with mayor's reaction; SUBS 2nd graf to fix spelling of `truly'
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry was sentenced today to six months in prison, fined $5,000 and given one year probation for his conviction on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge. Barry declared himself ``truly remorseful'' and asked U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson for leniency. But Jackson told the mayor he had abused his office and the collective trust of the community. ``Having failed as the good example he might have been, the defendant must now become an example of another kind,'' Jackson said. The sentencing ended a 10-month legal drama that began with the mayor's arrest Jan. 18 in an FBI sting operation that caught him on videotape smoking crack cocaine with a former girlfriend. The night before sentencing Barry, in a letter to the judge, said he wasa ``recovering alcoholic and drug addict.'' ``I stand here truly remorseful and ask this court to impose community service as a sentence,'' Barry told Jackson at today's hearing. Barry said he was willing to ``take full and personal responsibility for all my actions, all my attitudes.'' But Jackson said Barry's position as mayor and ``his breach of public trust alone warrants an enhanced sentence.'' The judge also said: ``The public rumors of defendant's frequent and conspicuous drug use - never dispelled and now unfortunately shown to have been true - has given aid, comfort and encouragement to the drug culture at large and contributed to the anguish that illegal drugs have inflicted on this city in so many ways for so long.'' Jackson also said he found evidence from the trial that Barry had obstructed justice. However, the judge gave some weight to Barry's admission that he was an alcoholic and a cocaine user. In issuing the sentence, Jackson forged a middle ground between the recommendations of prosecutors who urged that Barry be given the maximum one-year sentence and the defense. Jackson also ordered Barry to join a drug rehabilitation program while in prison and said the mayor will be subject to random drug testing during his year of probation. The mayor, whose term expires in January, is currently running for city council. The sentence does not affect his position as mayor or his candidacy. Barry ducked reporters waiting for him outside the U.S. Courthouse and left by a side entrance, but his attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, said he planned to appeal the conviction and the sentence, saying ``The final chapter has not been written.'' The mayor, asked later about his sentence, said, ``I should have been shocked and stunned, but I'm not. I understand that there are different sets of standards for different people, and that's the American injustice system.'' Asked whether he should continue his bid for a city-wide council seat, Barry responded, ``Absolutely. Why not?'' Mundy said he and the mayor were disappointed by the sentence. The defense attorney said prosecutors had made Barry ``a whipping boy for all the ills that beset the District of Columbia.'' U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens said he would comment later in the day. Barry was convicted on Aug. 10 of a single cocaine possession charge and acquitted on another after a dramatic 10-week trial. The jury deadlocked on the remaining 12 counts, and prosecutors said they would not seek a new trial. The judge made clear that he disagreed with the jury's failure to convict the mayor of the other charges. Jackson said he would ignore ``what I perceive to have been the defendant's efforts ... to induce the jury to disregard the law and the evidence.'' ``The jurors will have to answer to themselves and to their fellow citizens for the way in which they discharged their duty,'' he said in a stinging criticism of the panel. Barry's place of confinement has not yet been determined and will be assigned by the federal Bureau of Prisons.
