The bride's 2-year-old son will come as a green dinosaur and the flower girl will adorn the wedding aisle with dead leaves. Black candles, jack-o'-lanterns carved with scary faces and music by the band Road Kill will greet guests at a Monster Mash reception after the ceremony Saturday. The wedding cake will be trimmed in black and orange and decorated with a miniature Frankenstein's monster and his bride. The bride-to-be said her fiance, Glen Hettenbach, 42, wasn't thrilled by the ghoulish nuptials at first. ``It was my idea, but he had to think about it for a while,'' she said. The couple researched Mary Shelley's book ``Frankenstein'' and the original 1935 movie starring Boris Karloff to ensure their wedding garb would be authentic. Jittery grooms have been known to get a little green around the gills as the time to tie the knot nears, but Hettenbach is going all out - with green skin and bolts in his neck to keep his head on straight.

DOC.HEAD: Precede IRVINE
Bush Blames Democrats for Making Him Back Higher Taxes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Bush's civil rights comments in top 13 grafs, picking up in 10th graf pvs, ``Some think
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, trying to escape blame for higher taxes, accused the Democratic-controlled Congress on Friday of creating the federal budget mess that made him abandon his no-new-tax pledge. Bush also accused Democrats of playing politics with the civil rights bill that he had vetoed on the grounds that it would force employers to adopt hiring and promotion quotas. ``They're sitting around up there now,'' Bush said of Congress. Referring to his alternative hiring-discrimination proposal, Bush said, ``They could pass it in 20 minutes if there was a genuine interest in civil rights and less interest in trying to embarrass the president of the United States.'' Bush unleashed his partisan attacks as he opened a four-day Western campaign swing that will take him as far as Hawaii. He spoke at a GOP fund-raiser in conservative Orange County and then flew to Los Angeles to stump for Sen. Pete Wilson in his close race for governor. Some veteran Hollywood stars turned out to welcome the president, including Frank Sinatra, Andy Williams, Mel Torme, Buddy Ebsen and Donald O'Connor. The president praised Democrats for helping forge a budget deal but then turned around and blamed them for creating the deficit by being on ``an uncontrolled spending binge for years.'' ``It is the United States Congress that must be changed if this country is going to move ahead,'' Bush said. ``You don't have to be a rocket scientist to know that Congress has been spending more than we take in for far too long.'' Seizing on voters' discontent with politicians, Bush endorsed the idea of limitations on the terms of members of Congress. He said it was ``one way to correct the abuse of power and the unbridled influence of an entrenched congressional staff. And I say it's an idea whose time has come.'' With Election Day 11 days away, Republicans are worried that they will suffer heavier-than-expected political losses. Bush himself has plunged in the polls amid deep Republican divisions over taxes and confusion over the president's stands. In accepting his presidential nomination at the 1988 Republican National Convention, Bush said: ``And the Congress will push me to raise taxes, and I'll say no, and they'll push, and I'll say no, and they'll push again. And I'll say to them: Read my lips. No new taxes.'' He took back that pledge back months ago, saying revenue increases as well as spending cuts were necessary to fight the soaring federal deficit. Congress was putting the final touches on the budget package Friday, and Bush was expected to sign it. However, Bush said that Democrats in Congress were the real problem, and he declared, ``I believe the American people have had enough.'' Bush met with Republican congressional leaders at the White House on Thursday to plot the themes of his stump speeches and he came out of the gate swinging on Friday. ``Some think that the differences between the parties are blurred and to that I say nonsense,'' Bush said. ``Republicans believe that power should be in the hands of people, not in the government in Washington, D.C.'' Bush said the deficit-reduction package had forced him to make unpleasant compromises. ``Yes, I have had to compromise, haven't liked that a bit,'' he said. Yet, Bush said presidents sometimes have to bend for the good of the country. Even so, he placed the blame for the deficit - and thus the need for higher taxes - squarely on the Democrats. In particular, Bush bridled at comments by House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, who accused the president of failing to tell Americans ``why they were being asked to swallow strong medicine.'' ``For 36 years his party, the Democratic Party, has controlled the House of Representatives, and year after year after year they have presided over these budget deficits. They have appropriated every dime and they tell me how to spend every dime. ``But the American people know all too well that strong medicine ... is required because a Democratically controlled Congress simply has been on an uncontrolled spending binge for years,'' Bush charged. The president blended his attack with an appeal for approval of the deficit-reduction deal. ``The agreement that we get won't be the best deal possible but in my judgment, it will be the best deal possible with this Congress,'' he said. He briefly complimented House and Senate Democratic leaders for cooperating on the deficit-reduction plan. ``For that, I salute them because I firmly believe that we must get an agreement to start getting these deficits under control,'' Bush said. He did not mention the House GOP revolt that helped scuttle the original deficit-reduction deal. Democrats control the Senate by 55-45 and the House by 258-175. Republicans had hoped to trim the Senate margin and hold their House losses to fewer than 10 seats next month. In addition to his Orange County appearance, Bush was attending a Los Angeles luncheon for Sen. Pete Wilson, who is in a tight race for governor. With Congress still in session, Wilson remained in Washington but spoke to the Irvine group by telephone. After his California appearances, the president was heading to Hawaii to stump for Senate candidate Rep. Pat Saiki, and meet with leaders of 11 Pacific island nations. En route home Monday, he will make another stop for Wilson in San Francisco and then stop in Oklahoma to campaign for GOP gubernatorial candidate Bill Price.

DOC.HEAD: Bridge Segments Crash Into Inlet, Island Stranded
LaserPhotos RA3,XNAG3
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people were stranded without power Friday on Hatteras Island after gale-force winds tore a dredge from its moorings and slammed it into the Bonner Bridge, toppling a 369-foot segment. The 2{-mile span - the only road link between the mainland and Hatteras - may be closed for months. No injuries were reported. State Highway Patrol Sgt. A.C. Joyner rushed to close the bridge early Friday after it was struck by the dredge Northerly Island. The wind was blowing at 45-50 mph and gusting to 60 mph when the collapse occurred less than an hour later. ``You could see both of the guard rails move toward the west and then it just snapped,'' Joyner said. ``Nothing's built for that kind of stress,'' said Clayton Jenson, superintendent of McLean Contracting of Chesapeake, Va., which built the 26-year-old bridge. Another section of the bridge was unstable, Jenson said. ``It's just a guess, but I think it's going to take five to six months to fix the bridge,'' Jenson said. The accident, combined with storms that kept ferries in port, stranded thousands of people on the island and without power. An estimated 5,000 people live year-round on the island. Water supplies were limited, state officials said. Tourism officials said the loss of the bridge at the peak surf fishing season could devastate Hatteras' economy. Authorities said ferries would be used Saturday to shuttle food, fuel, and people across the inlet. The bridge carries telephone and power lines to Hatteras, and the accident left some of those lines dangling over the inlet. Power was out on Hatteras and on much of nearby Ocracoke Island, home to 500-600 people. Electric and telephone companies were waiting for weather conditions to ease before trying to restore service. Gwen A. White, a Dare County spokeswoman, said the county hoped to be able to run lines that could restore electricity within 48 hours. Cars lined up at the ferry landings on Hatteras and at Ocracoke, waiting for service to resume. The accident came at the peak of the surf fishing months, said Gene O'Bleness, director of the county Tourist Bureau. He estimated that if the bridge was closed for three months, it would mean an $18 million to $20 million loss. Gov. Jim Martin declared a state of emergency after flying to the coast to survey the situation. State Transportation Secretary Thomas Harrelson said the state was looking at landing points for ferries and was planning to set up a temporary crossing of the bridge. ``If we could get one lane it would be a big help ... a good shot in the arm for the people of Hatteras Island,'' Mikey Daniels, chairman of the County Commissioners, told Martin. Without the bridge to Hatteras Island, the detour for someone trying to reach Nags Head, about 10 miles north of the severed bridge, would take more than 5{ hours. That trip includes more than 125 miles of driving and two ferry rides - one lasting 40 minutes and another taking 2{ hours. Four of 10 people on the 200-foot dredge scrambled up its 3-story-high pilot's cabin to the top of the bridge before the collapse. The six others decided to remain aboard to try to save the vessel. The Coast Guard said they were fine. The dredge was under contract to the Army Corps of Engineers to dig the channel, said Richard Adams of North American Trailing Co. of Oakbrook, Ill., which owns the dredge.

DOC.HEAD: Intoxicated Heart Attack Victim Dragged From Store On Stomach
DOC.TEXT: The mayor attempted on Friday to defuse racial tensions at a grocery story after an intoxicated customer who died of a heart attack was dragged outside on his stomach. Angry residents of the poor, predominantly black area were urging a boycott of the store, owned by a family of Korean-ancestry. The man who died, James Drumright, 57, was black and many area residents said he would not have been dragged from the store if he was white or Korean. At the request of Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke, however, residents dispersed and owner Kenny Kang closed the B&M Market for the day, Schmoke's spokesman Clint Coleman said. Kang also apologized for the incident. ``The mayor does not want the community to overreact to what is clearly an unfortunate situation,'' Coleman said. Drumright lay on the sidewalk for 20 minutes Thursday morning before a passer-by ran to a fire station for help. About the same time, the owner came to check on the man and called 911 for an ambulance. Drumright died a short time later at a hospital. Drumright had a blood-alcohol count of more than .20 percent when he died, John Smialek, chief state medical examiner, said after an autopsy was performed Friday. The level of legal intoxication in the state is .10 percent. The autopsy also showed evidence of liver disease, indicating Drumright was a chronic alcoholic, Smialek said. ``We've determined that Mr. Drumright died from severe heart disease,'' Smialek said. ``But he was also intoxicated from alcohol so it could have been difficult for someone to tell what was happening to him.'' An informal picket was set up outside the store Thursday night. Police escorted Kang out when he closed for the night. The store's manager, Marcus Gaffney, who is black, said Friday he removed Drumright from the store when he found him slumped against a meat counter with a bottle of liquor poking out of his back pocket. Gaffney said Drumright urinated on himself when Gaffney tried to rouse him. A cashier said the store owner ordered the man removed. ``If we had any idea he had had a heart attack, we would have called the paramedics,'' Kang said. ``(The protestors) have a false assumption that they dragged him out knowing he had a heart attack.'' Cashier Charelle M. White said Kang told Gaffney and another worker to take the man outside. ``They dragged him on his stomach outside the store,'' where he lay until paramedics were called, White said. Many Korean-American store owners operate in predominantly black neighborhoods in Baltimore and cultural differences have caused misunderstandings. Some storekeepers have been the targets of violent crime. In New York City, blacks have been demonstrating over an incident in Brooklyn in which a Haitian woman complained of being attacked by a Korean store worker.

DOC.HEAD: Weld Says Silber Has `Crazy Ideas' About Working Women
DOC.TEXT: Democratic gubernatorial candidate John Silber suggested some women have neglected their children by deciding to work outside the home. ``If the woman wants to be the lawyer and have the husband stay home with the child (that) is perfectly sound,'' Silber said during a radio interview on WHDH-AM. ``But what worries me is out of a desire to be as well-to-do financially as possible, both husband and wife leave the child in what I described as a third-rate day care center,'' he said. ``That is happening all the time.'' Women's groups Friday criticized Silber and Republican opponent William Weld accused Silber of harboring ``crazy ideas.'' Silber's position ``reeks of ... mean-spiritedness,'' said Molly Yard, president of the National Organization for Women. The vast majority of parents cannot afford the choice of staying at home to care for their children, said Ellen Convisser, president of the National Organization for Women's Boston chapter. She said Silber has demonstrated ``a whole perspective of being out of touch with reality.'' Convisser's group has not endorsed either gubernatorial candidate. Regarding Weld, Silber said he did not need to be lectured by a multimillionaire ``whose mother never worked a day in her life.'' Ray Howell, a spokesman for Weld, said the GOP nominee's mother, who died in 1986, taught drama at Barnard College in the 1930s and worked as a volunteer for a non-profit company that helped place handicapped people in jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Mom Decorates AIDS Victim Ryan White's Grave for Halloween
DOC.TEXT: The mother of the late AIDS victim Ryan White has decorated his grave for Halloween with a smiling, 2-foot plywood ghost. The wooden apparition is intended to represent White, who became an international spokesman for people with AIDS. He was 18 when he died in April of complications from the disease. The ghost was among other decorations placed at the grave by Jeanne White, said her secretary, Shelly Henson. ``She just gets a lot of enjoyment thinking spiritually he's aware of what's taking place,'' Ms. Henson said. ``She just thinks he would like that.'' A shock of cornstalks stands left of the large granite gravestone, and a plastic skeleton and black plastic spider dangle from a plant holder. A couple of wooden ghosts lurk in the floral decorations, along with a plastic jack-o'-lantern and two small pumpkins. A ghostly white windsock waves in the autumn breeze. ``Holidays were Ryan's favorite times, especially Christmas, and she feels he would really like that,'' Ms. Henson said. White, a hemophiliac who contracted AIDS from blood-clotting products, won a court battle to continue attending public school in Indiana. He spent his last years speaking on behalf of AIDS victims.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Approves Restricting Logging In Alaska's Tongass Forest
DOC.TEXT: The House on Friday passed legislation to reduce logging in Alaska's Tongass National Forest, sending the president a bill that attempts to balance timber industry and environmental interests. The measure, approved by voice vote, is the work of a House-Senate conference committee which melded differing bills on Tongass approved by the two bodies. The Senate gave its final approval to the bill by voice vote Wednesday. Rep. Don Young, R-Alaska, who fought the bill every step of its way through Congress, said it would seriously damage the economy of southeastern Alaska. ``It was not a compromise,'' he said. ``It was the environmental groups across this nation not understanding what they were doing to the Alaskan people.'' But Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., who chairs the subcommittee that handled the legislation, said some factions wanted an even bigger part of the forest removed from logging. ``We believe this is a compromise that brings some finality to this issue,'' he said. Environmental groups for years have criticized logging practices allowed by a 1980 law governing the 17 million-acre Tongass forest. Though 5.5 million acres were precluded from timber harvesting by that law, it also contained a business arrangement with logging companies allowing taxpayer-owned timber to be sold at extremely low prices. It required $40 million of federal funds to be spent each year on road-building and other activities to help logging companies. It set a harvest goal of 450 million board feet a year. The new legislation requires the Forest Service to prepare only enough timber for sale to meet ``market demand.'' It eliminates the automatic appropriation of $40 million for timber management, requiring that the forest compete with others federal forests each year for funds in the normal budget process. It modifies the contracts with the timber companies working in the Tongass to bring them in line with agreements governing other national forests. The legislation also declares about 1 million acres off-limits to timber harvesting and creates off-limits buffers 100 feet wide along rivers and streams important to fishing. The original bill passed by the House legislation would have protected nearly twice as many acres from timber cutting. The Tongass, stretching across the Alaska panhandle, is the country's largest national forest and home to a rich array of wildlife including grizzly bears and bald eagles. It also is a major source of timber.

DOC.HEAD: Gregory Hines To Debut New Dance With L.A. Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Song title in 3rd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Audiences will get a first look this weekend at a tap dance choreographed by Gregory Hines and sponsored by the National Endowment for the Arts. Linda Sohl-Donnell, director of the dance company Rhapsody in Tap, won an $8,000 matching grant from the federal agency to have Hines choreograph a work for the 9-year-old company. The result is a six-minute piece called ``Toeing the 3rd and Fifth.'' Hines was to perform the piece Friday and Saturday at the Japan America Theater with Sohl-Donnell and company members Monie Adamson, Pauline Hagino, Marci Juris, Karol Lee and Beverly Scott. ``They wanted something powerful and arhythmical, so that's what we did,'' Hines said. He praised the dancers' contributions to the piece. ``I didn't want to censor myself in any way, and I didn't need to because their ability is very high. ``It's as much their piece as it is mine.''

DOC.HEAD: Albania Attacks Writer for Defecting
DOC.TEXT: The government Friday condemned the country's leading writer, saying his defection to France was an ``ugly act'' that placed him ``in service of the enemies of Albania.'' The charge carried by the state news agency came a day after Ismail Kadare announced his defection during a visit to France with his wife and two daughters. France granted him immediate asylum. Kadare is probably Albania's best-known public figure after President Ramiz Alia, who has been making gradual moves to lift Albania out of three decades of virtual isolation from the rest of the world. Albania on Thursday hosted its first high-level international meeting in decades, a conference of foreign ministers from Yugoslavia, Bulgaria, Romania, Greece and Turkey. Alia was asking those countries to help Albania renew its ties with Europe. Albania, whose late President Enver Hoxha turned his back on the Soviet Union in 1961 and China in 1977 because of the ``revisionist'' form of Communism in those countries, is seeking to join the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. Albania refused to sign the 1975 Helsinki human rights accords that spawned the CSCE. The United States, the Soviet Union, Canada and all other European nations are signatories. ATA reported Kadare's defection a day late, after the foreign ministers' meeting was over. It cited foreign press reports as the source for the news. ``Through this ugly act, that is a grave offense for the patriotic and civic conscience of our people, he abandoned the people and homeland and placed himself in service of the enemies of Albania and the Albanian people,'' ATA said. The Association of Albanian Refugees in France issued a communique in Paris criticizing France for the quickness it granted Kadare's asylum request. It noted hundreds of Albanian refugees who arrived in France in July are awaiting rulings on asylum applications. Kadare was seen in Albania as a spiritual leader for reform and the nation's greatest author. Last year, he was made deputy chairman of the Communist-run Democratic Front and had begun speaking out for human rights. Kadare's elevation to a leadership role indicated the ruling party was warming to his liberal ideas. But in his statement from Paris, Kadare said the regime was merely paying lip-service to reform. ``The promises made were not kept, and my disillusion, like that of the immense majority of Albanians, was all the more bitter,'' he said. The government this year has liberalized travel regulations, abolished the death penalty for those caught fleeing the country illegally and lifted some restrictions on religious life. A draft election law published this week would allow more than one candidate to compete for each Parliament seat and provide for secret ballots. However, it does not foresee a multiparty system. About 5,000 dissatisfied Albanians took refuge last July in foreign embassies until they were permitted to emigrate.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Hickel Moving Ahead in Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: Wally Hickel has moved from third to first place in the governor's race, with a slight advantage over Republican Arliss Sturgulewski and a significant lead over Democrat Tony Knowles, a statewide poll indicates. The poll shows 35 percent of the respondents supported Hickel, 30 percent favored Sturgulewski, 24 percent preferred Knowles and 10 percent were undecided. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percentage points. The Anchorage Daily News and Anchorage radio station KENI commissioned the poll by Dittman Research Corp. of Alaska. The random telephone survey of 523 registered voters who cast ballots in the 1988 general election or 1990 primary was conducted Monday through Wednesday. Dittman's poll two weeks earlier showed Sturgulewski with 34 percent, Knowles at 29 percent and Hickel with 25 percent. Hickel who only entered the race last month. He is a former Republican governor of the state and was secretary of interior in the Nixon administration.
DOC.HEAD: Wellstone Nearly Out of Money Before Latest Poll
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota Senate candidate Paul Wellstone nearly ran out of money days before a newspaper poll brought his fund-raising back to life, according to his latest campaign finance report. The Democrat had $37,060 left in the bank on Oct. 17. He listed debts of $42,007. Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, on the other hand, still had more than $1 million stashed away. The Republican had maintained a double-digit lead in the polls through September and the first half of October. But Wednesday, the Star Tribune of Minneapolis published a poll showing that the race had closed to a statistical dead heat. Campaign aides say Wellstone's fund-raising picked up considerably with the new poll. Wellstone reported raising $207,951 from Oct. 1 through Oct. 17 and spending $251,760. Wellstone has spent $728,708 so far this year. Boschwitz, who has been winding down his fund-raising, raised $97,703 from Oct. 1 through Oct. 17 and had $1.05 million in the bank. He spent $158,974 during the period. Boschwitz has spent $2.5 million so far this year. His total expenses since his last race in 1984 are expected to reach $7 million.
DOC.HEAD: Candidate for Town Board Arrested For Public Drunkenness
DOC.TEXT: A town council candidate was charged with public drunkenness while he was doing some last-minute campaigning the day before the election. Harold W. Vaughn, 48, was arrested Thursday afternoon after he struck a mailbox while trying to drive into a driveway, according to police. Vaughn is running for a seat on the Mount Carmel Board of Mayor and Aldermen. He said he had taken a shot of vodka with a soft drink and that apparently had an adverse reaction with some medication he was taking. ``I had been doing last-minute campaigning, and I was just tired. A friend offered me a drink,'' Vaughn said. ``I don't usually drink. I'm not an alcoholic or anything like that. I was just tired.'' When asked if he believes the incident will affect the outcome of the election, Vaughn said, ``I hope not. It was just one of those things.'' He faces two other opponents for the city seat in Friday's election.

DOC.HEAD: Contra Police Put in Charge of North-Central Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: The government put former Contra rebels in charge of the police in a northern region that witnessed some of the heaviest fighting during Nicaragua's nine-year war, an official said Friday. The unprecedented concession of power to the ex-rebels was made by the Interior Ministry - controlled by the leftist Sandinistas although they lost February's presidential elections - after several weeks of disturbances in the area. Interior Ministry envoy Jaime Cuadra on Thursday night ordered Sandinista Police officers in Rio Blanco, 150 miles northeast of Managua, to withdraw to the local army battalion and turn the police station over to the former Contras. The Sandinista police force consisted of about 20 men. Cuadra also put ex-Contras in charge of the towns of Mulukuku, Waslala and the surrounding hamlets, encompassing a rural area inhabited by about 20,000 people. He told The Associated Press the move was ``provisional, until the government makes a final decision.'' The Contra force that will take control of the police is called the Rural Police. The unit originally was authorized by the government to police areas where former Contra rebels were being resettled after laying down their arms. Residents of Rio Blanco had held street protests for two days against the Sandinista Police over grievances that began when a former Contra rebel was killed in town. A Sandinista Police officer suspected in the murder was arrested and sent to the provincial capital, Matagalpa, where he was promptly released. ``The authorities had given no response to complaints by the population of crimes and abuses,'' said Rio Blanco town council member Adonay Meza. ``That is why the people had public demonstrations, to demand the substitution of noxious elements in the police.'' Cuadra's home in Matagalpa was bombed earlier this month, a few days after he returned from putting down other Contra disturbances in the northern towns of Quilali and Waslala. The residents of the region around Rio Blanco, a mountainous area of small cattle ranches and farms, were among the strongest backers of the Contra rebels during the war. About 20,000 Contra fighters demobilized in June after an agreement with the government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, which defeated the Sandinistas in Feb. 25 elections and took over two months later. The former rebels remain deeply resentful that the Sandinistas kept control of Nicaragua's police and army, which even retain the name ``Sandinista'' and still are largely made up of Sandinista Front militants. They also have complained that Mrs. Chamorro's government has dragged its feet on promises to help them. The Contras ended the war with promises they would be given farmland, food, clothing, medicine and materials with which to build simple homes in the countryside. Most of the decomissioned rebel soldiers are peasants. Former Contras also were involved in protests last week in the remote Atlantic town of Puerto Cabezas, where they looted government warehouses to protest a lack of provisions. Sandinista police arrested 21 people.

DOC.HEAD: Two Irishmen Fly Home from Iraq, Thanked by Saddam
DOC.TEXT: Two Irishmen flew home from Iraq on Friday saying Iraqi President Saddam Hussein granted them permission to leave as thanks for good work on his new palace. Nick Drury, 19, and Michael Sands, 31, said they were confident that other foreigners working on the project would soon be allowed to leave Baghdad. Sands, a civil engineer, said his company had been negotiating for six weeks for the release of all the men working on the palace. He did not provide the name of the company. ``We were given a letter by Saddam Hussein after he visited the palace saying we could all get out. He was impressed with the work and wanted to reward the foreigners by giving them exit visas,'' Sands said. He said that he and Drury were the first British citizens to test Saddam's promise. On Wednesday, 26 Portugese workers on the project were allowed to leave, he said. Sands said he believed all 27 workers from Northern Ireland and 23 Britons would be allowed to leave ``over the next three weeks'' in a phased release. ``I am confident it will happen,'' said Drury, a student who had initially gone to Iraq to visit his father and had taken a temporary construction job at the palace. ``He gave us his word and I don't think he'll go back on it.'' Drury's father, George, was not part of the palace project and had not been permitted to leave Baghdad. ``I am concerned, but he was pleased to see me getting away. Hopefully he will be back with us by Christmas,'' Drury said. The two men said the foreigners remaining in the Iraqi capital were beginning to show signs of stress. ``Tempers are maybe a bit shorter. But to counteract that, people are trying to put on a good face,'' Sands said. He said life was ``fairly normal'' for the Britons and that they all had enough food. But Drury added: ``The stress really does get to you. I never realized it until I was actually on the plane home. It was like a big hand being lifted from my shoulder.'' Both men arrived at London's Heathrow Airport via Zurich and were to continue to Belfast later Friday. The Foreign Office says there are about 650 Britons left in Kuwait, mostly in hiding like other Westerners, and about 800 Britons trapped in Iraq, including 340 held at strategic locations since the Aug. 2 invasion. On Wednesday, former Prime Minister Edward Heath brought home 32 holders of British passports from Iraq. The release followed two days of negotiations between Heath and Saddam.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba VP: Government Talking to Exiles Who Want Castro Exit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to specify that exiles are the ones seeking democracy; graf 4 cites Miami Herald as source; UPDATES graf 5, ``In Washington,'' with additional State Dept. comment, picking up 6th graf pvs, ``In Miami.''
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Cuba-Expose, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Cuba's vice president said his government has opened a dialogue with moderate exile groups that seek a transition to democracy and the peaceful replacement of President Fidel Castro. Vice President Carlos Rafael Rodriguez's comments were broadcast on state radio and monitored here Thursday, a week after a coalition of moderate exile groups publicly invited discussions about democratizing the communist nation. Rodriguez said Cuba shunned contacts with more militant anti-communist exiles in Miami but confirmed the government has opened discussions with moderates, whom he did not identify. He said those exiles propose ``to liquidate Fidel Castro (through) dialogue; they are offering talks,'' The Miami Herald reported. In Washington, U.S. State Department officials said they believed it was premature to suggest the Cuban leadership was open to democratic reform, but the Rodriguez statement was potentially significant. The officials spoke with The Associated Press on condition of anonymity. In Miami, Carlos Alberto Montaner, whose exile party belongs to the moderate Cuban Democratic Platform umbrella group, said his organization has met with Cuban officials to seek a solution to Cuba's mounting problems. ``There have been indirect contacts with Carlos Rafael and other important officials in the regime,'' Montaner said. ``We all agreed that the era of Castro's communism has reached its end, and that we must look for a Czechoslovakian solution before intransigence imposes a Romanian solution on us.'' Montaner referred to the peaceful transfer of power from Czechoslovakia's communist leaders to the current democratic government, in contrast to the bloody Romanian revolution that led to the execution of former communist leader Nicolae Ceausescu. In the long interview, the Cuban vice president divided the exiles into three groups. He criticized the ``reactionary and ultrarightist'' wing headed by Jorge Mas Canosa, who leads the powerful Cuban American National Foundation, and Armando Valladares, U.S. representative to the U.N. Human Rights Commission. A second group, he said, consisted of people trying to return to Cuba for visits. The third group, which he did not identify by name, consists of ``ex-reactionaries'' who have abandoned violent strategies. ``We are increasing relations with the third group,'' he said. ``There is an ongoing process.'' Mas dismissed Rodriguez's comments about his group, saying the foundation and Valladares were working with the Bush administration ``to bring liberty to Cuba.'' He said he was not aware of Cuban government conversations with other groups.

DOC.HEAD: Jazz Bassist Major Holley Dies
DOC.TEXT: Jazz bassist Major ``Mule'' Holley, who performed with a long list of musical greats including Duke Ellington, Woody Herman, Ella Fitzgerald and Benny Goodman, has died of a heart attack. He was 66. Holley, a Detroit native, died Thursday night at a friend's home in suburban Maplewood, N.J., according to his brother, Oscar Holley. ``He had just returned from Germany where he did some one-nighters and was scheduled to play on a cruise ship next week,'' his brother said in a telephone interview from Detroit. ``He took ill on the plane and died two days later.'' Holley, who had an apartment and music studio in Manhattan, was a protege of jazz great Slam Stewart. Born Major Quincy Holley Jr., Holley's musical inspiration came from his father, who was a bass singer. Holley began playing the violin at age 7 and learned the tuba and every other wind-related instrument in the bass family as well as piano during a 1940s stint in the Navy. That's also where he got his nickname. Oscar Holley said his brother was in the Navy with Clark Terry and as part of a band he used to carry all the instruments. ``Clark told him he looked like a pack mule and the name just stuck.'' Holley's first professional gig was in San Diego in 1946 where he performed in an ensemble led by saxophonists Wardell Gray and Dexter Gordon. He moved to New York after getting out of the service. He went on to perform with a long list of music greats including Charlie Parker, Art Tatum, Fitzgerald, the Kenny Burrell Trio, Ellington, Oscar Peterson, Rose Murphy, Zoot Sims and Al Cohn. ``You name it and he played with them,'' Oscar Holley said. He also performed ``Mack the Knife'' on Frank Sinatra's 1986 ``L.A. Is My Lady'' album, at the invitation of record producer Quincy Jones. He taught at Berklee College in Boston from 1967 to 1970 and toured Europe with the Kings of Jazz in the mid-70s. In a 1987 newspaper interview, Holley said he was not a jazz pioneer. ``I've just continued trends. When I was in Duke Ellington's band, I sounded like Duke's bass players. I remained applicable to the circumstances of where I was - whether it was Coleman Hawkins or a Broadway show or Judy Collins.'' Holley, who was not married, is survived by five sisters and three brothers. A funeral will be held Oct. 31 in Detroit.

DOC.HEAD: Pinochet Bodyguard Assasinated by Gunmen
DOC.TEXT: Unidentified assailants firing from a speeding car on Friday assassinated an army intelligence agent who served as a bodyguard for former military ruler Gen. Augusto Pinochet, police said. Police said Sgt. Victor Valenzuela was shot five times as he left his house Friday morning in a working-class neighborhood in southern Santiago. Interior Minister Enrique Krauss said Valenzuela was a member of the army intelligence service, and was assigned to Pinochet's protection. Pinochet stepped down from power last March after ruling 16{ years, but remains commander in chief of the army. No one claimed responsibility for the attack on Valenzuela. However, a local television station, Megavision Channel 9, said pamphlets of the Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front, a leftist guerrilla band, were found by police in the car, which was abandoned by the attackers.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Charged With Leaving Child In Car Pleads Guilty
DOC.TEXT: A woman who said she locked her 5-year-old daughter in her car because she didn't trust baby sitters pleaded guilty Friday to a reduced charge. In an emotional plea for leniency, Chante Fernandez, 24, admitted it was wrong to leave her daughter in the car while she worked weekends at a shopping mall, but said she felt she had no other choice. ``I was only trying to get us out of the situation we were in,'' Ms. Fernandez told Superior Court Judge Robert Figarotta. ``I hope somehow you can understand.'' Ms. Fernandez pleaded guilty to a disorderly persons offense, was given a $100 suspended fine and was spared probation. She had faced a maximum of 30 days in jail and a $500 fine. Ms. Fernandez, from Elizabeth, was arrested Saturday after police found her pajama-clad daughter Anjuli in the back of her car at the Woodbridge Center Mall, where she worked part-time on weekends. Anjuli is being cared for by the state Division of Youth and Family Services, which scheduled an Oct. 30 hearing to determine whether to reunite mother and daughter. Ms. Fernandez was initially charged with criminal restraint and spent two days in jail before posting $5,000 bail. She faced up to five years in prison and a $7,500 fine, but prosecutor Alan Rockoff said he decided to reduce the charge after his office was flooded with telephone calls in support of Ms. Fernandez. He said his review of the case led him to believe Anjuli was not neglected. ``She has lost her child in the last several days, she has been in the trepidation of feeling she was destitute without a job,'' Rockoff said. ``I think that's punishment enough.'' After her arrest, Ms. Fernandez was fired from a full-time job at an Elizabeth lumber company, but the company has since offered to rehire her. Her former employer at the shopping mall also has offered to make her position full-time. Ms. Fernandez said she left her daughter in the car while she worked at the shopping mall because she could not find a baby sitter she trusted. She also said she could not get government child care services. She said she checked on her daughter during work breaks and left the rear seat folded down so Anjuli could sleep in the trunk. Ms. Fernandez was desperate and did what she did ``out of love for her child,'' said her lawyer, Kenneth Weimer. ``My client made a bad judgment call. She was up against the wall,'' Weimer said. After the hearing, Ms. Fernandez and Weimer said the lenient sentence was a surprise and that they would concentrate on reuniting mother and daughter.

DOC.HEAD: Mid-Atlantic Storm Strands Thousands on Hatteras Island
DOC.TEXT: Gale-force winds battered the mid-Atlantic Coast on Friday, toppling part of a bridge linking the North Carolina mainland with Hatteras Island and leaving thousands of people stranded without power. No injuries were reported in the storm that also struck the Virginia coast, uprooting trees, downing power and phone lines and flooding streets. The National Weather Service reported winds gusting to 92 mph along the Chesapeake Bay Bridge-Tunnnel. The bay was ``just churning,'' said G. Wayne Brown, a Norfolk planning commissioner. ``The water is right up to the dune line.'' The storm was off the Delaware Coast by early afternoon and headed northward. High wind warnings were posted over southeast New York and northern New Jersey and storm warnings remained in effect for the Atlantic coastal waters of Virginia, Delaware and Maryland. By mid-afternoon, rain was scattered from the southern coast of Maine across the Delaware coast. Snow fell over east-central New York. Skies were fair elsewhere. Rainfall during the six hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included two-thirds of an inch at Virginia Beach, Va. In the Southeast, temperatures were unseasonably cool Friday. Low temperature records broken or tied Friday included Fort Lauderdale, Fla., with 55 degrees, Grand Rapids, Mich., with 23 degrees, Mobile, Ala., with 37 degrees, and Ozark, Ark., with 29 degrees. Jamestown, N.D., and Rapid City, S.D., each had record highs of 80 degrees. The nation's low temperature was 17 degrees, recorded this morning in Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 pm EDT ranged from 32 degrees at Saranac Lake, N.Y., to 98 degrees at El Cajon, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Medicare Recipients To Pay More, But Get More Protection
With AM-Congress Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Medicare recipients would see their out-of-pocket health costs rise under Congress' compromise deficit-cutting plan, but the elderly would also find new protections against Medigap insurance abuses. The plan also would expand Medicaid with new spending to help more low-income elderly pay their Medicare premiums and to provide them with home care that could keep them out of a nursing home. Senior citizens say the package is kinder to them than a previous one put together by the White House and congressional leaders but rejected by the House. But they still say the budget-cutting strategy hits them hard. ``The damages are less extensive, but it's still going to hurt,'' said John Rother of the American Association of Retired Persons. Under the plan, the elderly and disabled on Medicare would see their monthly premiums for doctors' coverage rise from $28.60 this year to $46.20 in 1995, and their annual deductible would go from $75 to $100. Over the next five years, the plan would reduce spending on Medicare - the fastest growing federal program - by $42 billion. Beneficiaries would contribute about one-quarter of that savings, with doctors and hospitals providing most of the rest. Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., said the Medigap changes he helped engineer would offer seniors not only new protections against abuses by insurance companies selling them the supplementary health-care coverage, but the possibility of cost savings as well. ``This is one of the few things a member (of Congress) can take home and say: `This will help keep your health costs down,''' Wyden said. More than 80 percent of senior citizens have Medigap policies - extra coverage beyond Medicare - and as many as 30 percent of those have more than one. The measure would prohibit agents from selling a policyholder duplicate coverage and would standardize coverage into 10 different policies. The changes also would require Medigap insurance companies to pay 65 cents in benefits for every dollar in premiums. If they don't meet this loss ratio they would have to give policyholders a refund to make up the difference, Wyden said. The Medicaid expansions include $580 million for use by state Medicaid programs to cover home health care for low-income elderly so they can avoid more costly nursing home care. Medicaid, which pays the Medicare premiums for senior citizens whose incomes are up to 90 percent of the poverty line, would pay these costs for seniors up to 120 percent of poverty by 1995. Another expansion was to allow more children access to Medicaid services, but details on that were still being worked out Friday afternoon. On the savings side, Medicaid would save $1.9 billion over the five years by requiring drug companies to offer price discounts to the program, as many companies already do for volume buyers such as the Veterans Administration and health maintenance organizations.

DOC.HEAD: Last Defendant Sentenced in Operation Uncover
DOC.TEXT: A retired defense consultant was sentenced Friday to pay a $10,000 fine for passing on a secret document to someone not entitled to it. The consultant, Bernard Zettl, 65, of nearby McLean in the Washington suburbs, also was sentenced to two years probation and to perform 150 hours of community service. The sentencing by U.S. District Judge James C. Cacheris was the last in the government's five-year ``Operation Uncover'' investigation and prosecution of the trading of secret Pentagon documents among defense contractors. Five other individuals were convicted and five companies paid fines totaling $14.9 million. Zettl was convicted of passing on a copy of the Pentagon's five-year spending plan when he was working for a subsidiary of GTE Corp., one of the five companies. He testified that possession of these plans, classified secret, was widespread in the defense industry.

DOC.HEAD: Spain Cheers Gorbachev, Who Holds Out Hand for Economic Help
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Gorbachev alluding to new signs from Iraq, talks between foreign ministers, color, background. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet-Republics, Bjt
LaserPhoto MAD1
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday took a break from headaches on the home front and opened a three-day Spanish visit, seeking to convert his personal appeal abroad into aid for the struggling economy. ``Torero! Torero!'' hundreds of Spaniards, some hanging from balconies, yelled to the 59-year-old Kremlin chief, using an accolade usually reserved for courageous bullfighters. Gorbachev, grabbing Madrid Mayor Augustin Rodriguez Sahagun by the arm, waded into the crowd, crossing yellow barriers and a cordon of police outside Madrid's 17th-century City Hall. The reception served to remind Gorbachev - increasingly unpopular at home because of worsening economic conditions and ethnic tensions - of the respect he commands in foreign lands. Though Gorbachev is seeking help for the Soviet economy, he also had some hard words for the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait. ``We favor taking advantage of all possibilities for a politicial solution. Nevertheless, no one should take the search for these joint or bilateral solutions as a sign of weakness, or for vacillation over implementation of U.N. Security Council resolutions,'' Gorbachev told the Spanish parliament's Foreign Affairs Committee. The United Nations has condemned Iraq for its Aug. 2 invasion and ordered an international embargo on Iraqi trade to force President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his forces from Kuwait. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on Friday told his Spanish counterpart, Francisco Fernandez Ordonez, there were new, but still not encouraging, signals from Iraq. ``It appears that Iraq is searching for some kind of dialogue, but there is no possibility of that until Iraq withdraws from Kuwait unconditionally,'' a Spanish Foreign Ministry spokesman quoted Shevardnadze as saying. The pair met at the ministry offices. The ministry spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, did not elaborate on reports that Iraq might be open to discussions. For his part, Saddam told Channel 3 radio of Algiers, Algeria, ``When the greater interest demands it, everything is open to consideration.'' But he went on to rule out ``ceding our rights.'' Gorbachev was scheduled to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis with Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez later Friday and Saturday, their spokesmen said. The two met for 2{ hours earlier Friday and discussed European economic aid to the Soviet Union. It was Gorbachev's first foreign trip since receiving the Nobel Peace Prize Oct. 15 and the first by a Soviet head of state to Spain. Like the prize, the visit highlighted the importance Gorbachev's personality has played in winning Western support for the Soviet Union. ``Dobro Pozhalovat Gorbachev!'' the newspaper El Mundo trumpeted in a front-page headline in the Cyrillic alphabet. ``Welcome Gorbachev!'' Smiling and looking relaxed, Gorbachev rode in a vintage Rolls Royce from the Madrid airport to the Pardo Palace, where a band played the Soviet and Spanish national anthems. He was accompanied by his wife, Raisa. Red Soviet flags and the yellow and red Spanish flags flew throughout downtown Madrid, and Spanish television broadcast live Gorbachev's arrival and the official welcoming ceremony at the palace, official residence of visiting heads of state. During three days of talks in Madrid and Spain's second-largest city, Barcelona, Gorbachev will meet businessmen interested in getting a piece of the action as the Soviet Union switches from a centrally planned to a market economy. Gorbachev on Friday ordered a series of decrees that include a sharp devaluation of the ruble and 100 percent foreign investment in a Moscow announcement that came after he arrived in Spain. Foreign investment and trade is a central element of a plan to accomplish the transformation approved by the Soviet legislature earlier this month. In an interview with Spain's largest daily newspaper, El Pais, Gorbachev made a pitch to Spanish business leaders to promote economic ties with the Soviet Union. ``I think that Spanish entrepreneurs should act more vigorously and compete more boldly with businessmen from other countries who now show an immense interest in the Soviet Union,'' he said. Gorbachev and Gonzalez were scheduled to sign up to a dozen accords for boosting trade and investment and improving ties. Under one agreement, Spain would extend the Soviets a $1.5 billion line of credit to buy Spanish equipment to modernize Soviet plants that make consumer goods, food and construction materials. The Soviets plan to spend an additional $2-3 billion on Spanish consumer goods, clothing and food, Soviet television reported. Gorbachev told El Pais foreign aid will be particularly important during the next few months, when the Soviet Union begins its transition to a market system. But Miguel Gil, a government undersecretary, said Gonzalez told Gorbachev the Soviets still have ``a long way to go'' before gaining the confidence of Western investors. At least one Spanish company stepped in immediately. Tabacalera, the Spanish national tobacco monopoly, announced it would give the Soviets 200,000 packs of Ducado cigarettes. Cigarettes are among the many items in short supply in the Soviet Union as the old economic structure breaks down.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Urges Federal Quarantine for Infested Grove Area
DOC.TEXT: A citrus industry committee on Friday asked state and federal authorities to impose a quarantine and fruit shipping restrictions around a grove infested with a virulent strain of citrus canker. The quarantine would establish a strict inspection and eradication program and restrict marketing of fruit from the grove owned by Florida Citrus Commissioner Ed Smoak. Canker is a bacterial disease that could spread and devastate Florida's billion-dollar citrus industry, scientists say. Steve Poe, a scientist representing the U.S. Department of Agriculture on the committee investigating the canker infestation, said the agency may impose a quarantine within the next two weeks. But the U.S. Department of Agriculture won't rush because the 400-acre grove is isolated and not productive, so the disease is unlikey to spread to Florida's 700,000 acres of commercial groves. ``That's one reason we're taking our time on this,'' Poe said. ``It's really pretty sparsely inhabited and only a total of about 55 acres are in production in there.'' The Asiatic or A-strain of the disease blemishes and blisters tree stems, leaves and fruit. Other citrus-producing states like Texas, California and Arizona rely on federal shipping embargoes and quarantines to keep the disease from spreading into their groves. The outbreak has tentatively been traced to another small infestation discovered elsewhere in Florida in 1986. State agriculture officials believe a former employee of the canker-eradication program took infected material to his home near the Smoak grove. Leon Hebb, acting director of the state's canker eradication program, said the man may have taken the infected material for private research. Poe said the USDA was working with state investigators to determine if the man caused the infestation. ``It's a real detective story,'' Poe said. ``We're doing everything to trace the whole thing down.''

DOC.HEAD: Sweden Slashes its Welfare State
DOC.TEXT: The Social Democratic government began dismantling the welfare state it built Friday, proposing sharp cuts in benefits and state jobs to stop the country's economic decline. Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson presented an austerity package to slash $2.65 billion from the national budget and eliminate 10 percent of the approximately 185,000 civil service jobs over the next three years. The government proposed cuts in sick pay, defense, education and price subsidies in an attempt to control inflation, increase worker productivity and restore confidence in the currency. ``I think voters realize that we have a problem,'' Carlsson said. He acknowledged the ``forceful steps'' represent a drastic turnaround from the traditional policies of the Social Democratic Party, which has dominated politics in this country of 8 million people for more than 50 years. In the past, the party has focused on a bigger, better public sector with more services for the people. Now, Carlsson said, his government aims to consider the high costs and the poor results of some of the state's largesse. But union spokesmen, opposition party leaders and economists said the proposals were insufficient to slow the 11.5 percent inflation rate. Inflation in Western Europe averages less than 5 percent. Carlsson also said he would push for Sweden to join the European Community. Militarily neutral Sweden previously has preferred to remain outside the 12-member community of Western European nations. ``The conditions have improved with all that has happened in Europe during the last year,'' he said. Finance Minister Alan Larsson predicted this week the austerity measures would cause a public uproar among Swedes used to cradle-to-grave security. Generous social spending and liberal working conditions have resulted in low worker productivity, which in turn has led to high inflation and taxes. Last week the Central Bank was forced to twice raise interest rates, from 12 percent to 14 percent and then to 17 percent, because foreign currency was flowing out of the country at the highest rate ever amid rumors the kronor would be devalued. Most of Carlsson's proposals would not be implemented until Parliament considers a new budget in January. In holding a news conference to announce them, Carlsson hoped to stem the rumors of instability. The next elections are due in September 1991$. Polls show the lowest level of support ever for the Social Democrats, who remain in power only because backing for conservative parties is fragmented. The Moderates, the second largest party in Sweden, have been pushing many of the proposals that Carlsson announced Friday for years. About $1 billion of the cuts would come out of the state's sick benefits program. Care of the sick has been one of the cornerstones of Social Democratic policy. Swedes take an average 25 days per year of sick leave, among the highest rates in Europe. Several other proposals, particularly in connection with education, involved reallocating rather than cutting funds. The government suggested making Sweden's higher education more internationally competitive by diverting resources from administration to teaching. It also suggested sending children to school earlier, to save money on the vast child day-care programs. The government also proposed reducing tariffs, which would lower the price of food; and increasing some real estate taxes. Food prices in Sweden are the highest in Europe, the daily Dagens Nyheter reported this week.

DOC.HEAD: Governing Party Trailing as Vote Nears
DOC.TEXT: Saturday's elections are likely to give New Zealand a new government unless the ruling Labor Party can win over a large segment of apathetic voters. Opinion polls released this week showed the conservative National Party leading Labor by 11 to 16 percentage points, with nearly a quarter of the electorate undecided. Polls had given the conservatives a 21-point lead eight weeks ago, when Prime Minister Geoffrey Palmer resigned. Palmer's successor, Mike Moore, 41, is a popular politician who draws heavily for his image on his working-class backgound and impoverished childhood with a widowed mother. But a sagging economy has spurred widespread disillusionment with Labor policies and boosted the fortunes of National Party leader Jim Bolger. Unemployment, at 7.9 percent the highest since since World War II, tops voter concerns in the South Pacific island nation of 3.5 million people. The two main parties differ primarily on domestic issues. The National Party has pledged to maintain Labor's ``no nuclear'' policy of refusing to allow port calls by U.S. warships because they would not state whether they were carrying nuclear weapons. In response to the policy, the United States in 1986 cut high-level contacts with New Zealand and dropped the country from the ANZUS military alliance, which also includes Australia. The National Party says it would seek a reconciliation of some sort with Washington. U.S. officials welcomed Bolger at a time hen they were shunning top Labor officials. If poll results hold true, Bolger, the 54-year-old son of Irish immigrants who left school to work on the family farm, is likely to win a three-year term as New Zealand's 35th prime minister. National has pledged to cut unemployment by half, hold inflation under 2 percent, lower taxes and hire additional police. Economic policy has been the most vexing problem for Labor. Palmer became prime minister 15 months ago with the resignation of the charismatic David Lange. Lange ostensibly quit due to health reasons. But he also suffered from the fallout of a political dispute over economic reform.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Nuclear Board Out of Line
DOC.NOTE: EDs; SUBS 6th graf: ``The commission,'' to restore dropped word ``regulates''
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court ruled Friday that a board set up by Congress to regulate the safety of the government's nuclear weapons plants cannot meet secretly. A three-judge panel unanimously rejected arguments by the Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board that it was exempt from both the Freedom of Information Act and a law requiring open meetings by government agencies. ``We find nothing to indicate that Congress intended to excuse the Board from complying with FOIA or the (Government in the) Sunshine Act,'' the court said. The five-member board, appointed by the president subject to Senate confirmation, was set up last year to police the safety of the nuclear weapons plants operated by the Energy Department where serious environmental problems have been uncovered in recent years. Until the board's creation, the Energy Department had sole responsibility for monitoring the safety of the plants, which are exempt from oversight by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The commission regulates commercial nuclear power plants. The ruling by a three-judge panel of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia was made on a lawsuit brought by environmental groups to force the five-member board to hold public meetings and respond to requests for documents. It reversed an earlier finding by U.S. District Judge John G. Penn that the board was exempt from the information act and the sunshine law. The five-member board has already held several secret meetings, said Dan Reicher, an attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Counsil. Reicher said Congress created the board to ``ensure that the long-secret environmental problems in the weapons plants were exposed to public scrutiny.'' ``This is the agency that is going to make some very fundamental decisions about whether the nuclear weapons plants, which are shut down all over the country, should be restarted,'' he said. ``The secrecy they were trying to maintain would have done nothing to add to the public's faith in the decisions they made,'' Reicher said. The ruling against the Bush administration was the first opinion written by Circuit Judge A. Raymond Randolph, recently appointed by President Bush. Randolph was joined by two conservative appointees of former President Reagan, D.H. Ginsburg and James L. Buckley. There was no answer at the office of the board. Its five members are Chairman John Conway, former executive vice president of Consolidated Edison Co.; Andrew Eggenberger, a private nuclear energy consultant; Herbert Kouts, formerly a physicist for the Energy Department's Brookhaven National Laboratory; John Crawford Jr., a former deputy assistant energy secretary, and Edson Case, a former official at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Seeking Payment of Judgment Target Metzger Assets
DOC.TEXT: An attorney said Friday he hoped to force white supremacist Tom Metzger and his son ``out of the hate business'' by having their assets seized to satisfy a $12.5 million judgment in a racist killing. Attorney James McElroy said he planned to go after all the Metzgers' assets, including their home, bank accounts and cash contributions sent to their white supremacist organization, the White Aryan Resistence. ``We will have the very nice irony of those who are contributing to WAR putting money in the pockets of the victims of their hate. I think that's poetic justice,'' McElroy said. The elder Metzger did not immediately return a telephone message The Associated Press left at his television repair shop in Fallbrook, 65 miles north of San Diego. Monday, a Portland jury ruled in a wrongful death lawsuit that Metzger, his 22-year-old son, John, and two of their followers should pay damages to the family of a black man beaten to death by racist ``skinheads.'' The jury found that the Metzgers and WAR helped incite the hate and violence of the Portland skinheads, including those involved in the 1988 beating death of Ethiopian immigrant Mulugeta Seraw. McElroy is an associate of Morris Dees, the lead attorney for Seraw's family. The attorneys have donated their time and any assets seized from the Metzgers will go to Seraw's father and son, McElroy said. The asset forfeiture proceedings are expected to take weeks. ``We have two goals: to compensate the family for the loss of their son,'' McElroy said. ``The second goal is to put Mr. Metzger out of the hate business. This is a for-profit business. This is how he makes his money. He peddles hate and hate turns into violence.'' McElroy said the Metzgers will have to testify and produce documents at the assets hearing. Attempts to hide assets or improperly transfer them to someone else's control could lead to further penalties or even criminal charges, he said. McElroy said he already has blocked a move by Metzger to transfer ownership of the family's $90,000 home to his wife's name. Meanwhile, the Metzgers show no signs of abandoning their white supremacist preachings. ``Don't think, because of the recent court proceedings in Portland, Ore., that our activities will cease,'' vowed a message on WAR's telephone hot line. ``This case has convinced us to go the extra mile, take the extra steps to put the blood on the streets. We're putting the system on notice that if you want to play hardball with the big boys, you'd better be prepared to pay the piper.''

DOC.HEAD: American Singer Ruth Reese Dies in Oslo
DOC.TEXT: Singer, writer and poet Ruth Reese has died in Oslo, where she had lived for 30 years, friends and family said. She was 69. The black artist collapsed Thursday during an address to Norway's SOS Rasisme after the anti-racism group made her its first honored member, said its leader Khalid Salimi. He said she died immediately. Cause of death was not known. Reese was born March 10, 1921 in Alabama, grew up in Chicago and studied music in New York and London. She settled in Norway in 1960, after having made visits to the country during her European tours. She sang classical music, spirituals, gospel and blues, and had said she wanted to increase understanding of black culture. Reese wrote two books in Norwegian, one of which was printed in English under the title, ``My Way.'' Reese won the the 1989 Golden Poet award from the U.S. association, World of Poetry, for a work called, ``To Stop a Story,'' said Salimi. She is survived by her husband, Paul Shetelig. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Governor's Office Criticizes State Official's Survelliance of Employees
DOC.TEXT: The governor's office Friday criticized state Tax Commissioner John Boehm for staking out a newspaper building where his employees had gone to complain to a reporter that he was stifling their free speech. ``From this administration's viewpoint, that was a severe error in judgment,'' said Natalie Peetz, chief of staff for Gov. Kay Orr. ``I think John realizes that and we certainly agree with his statement.'' ``In retrospect, I made a mistake,'' Boehm said Thursday. ``It was an error in judgment.'' Orr spokesman Doug Parrott said the situation ``is a departmental matter and it is being handled at that level. Mr. Boehm's assessment that he made a mistake is accurate.'' Boehm was appointed to office by the Republican governor, who is waging a tough fight for re-election against Democrat nominee Ben Nelson. Earlier this month, a dozen Department of Revenue employees went to the Journal-Star Printing Co. building to talk to a reporter. Boehm acknowledged that he and Deputy Tax Commissioner Anne Erwin drove around the building, which houses the Lincoln Journal, The Lincoln Star and Lincoln office of The Associated Press. A day later, Boehm distributed a memo to department administrators. It discussed discipline for employees who made insubordinate remarks during staff meetings about the governor, department heads or other supervisors. Three of those who went to the newspaper building said Thursday that department employees felt they put their careers in jeopardy if they disagreed with Boehm or criticized the Orr administration. They said Boehm's surveillance of the building enhanced their concerns. ``Their fears are unfounded,'' Boehm said. ``I went there because I had been told that maybe 40 or 50 department people were going to be there and I was curious. I wasn't taking names.'' ``I knew who the ringleaders were ... everyone in the department knew who the instigators of this were,'' Boehm said. Boehm said employees who talked to reporters would not be disciplined.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Said to Reach Broad Agreement on Anti-Iraq Resolution
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council reached broad agreement Friday on a new draft resolution that takes a step toward establishing Iraq's responsibility for war crimes, diplomats said. The resolution invites nations to collect information on serious abuses of Kuwaitis and other civilians contrary to the Fourth Geneva Convention and share it with the council. Ambassadors ranging from America's Thomas R. Pickering to Cuba's Ricardo Alarcon said the council was now working on details of the resolution's language and structure, and predicted a vote overnight. The new resolution also would hold Iraq liable for war damages caused by its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and invite nations, companies and individuals suffering losses to document the damage for the council. It does not provide for punitive reparations. The draft resolution threatens Iraq with unspecified new punishment under the U.N. Charter if it doesn't stop mistreating and oppressing Kuwaitis and release its foreign hostages. It also says Iraq must allow the immediate provision of food, water and basic services to diplomats and foreigners in diplomatic missions in Kuwait City. Iraq says Kuwait is now a province of Iraq and that the diplomats must move their operations to Baghdad. It has cut off water and electricity to the missions. All those provisions were part of a draft put forward by Britain and the United States. The resolution would be the 10th since the invasion. In previous resolutions, the 15-member council has isolated Iraq with an economic embargo and permitted U.N. member countries to use their flotillas of warships in the Persian Gulf to enforce it.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Clean Air
DOC.TEXT: Here are major provisions of the clean air bill.

-Requires a 15 percent cut in smog-causing emissions from automobiles in six years and 3 percent annually after that until federal air quality standards are met. Cities must achieve federal air standards within five to 17 years, except the Los Angeles area, which is given 20 years. -Mandates cuts in smog-causing emissions from factories and thousands of businesses through new control equipment.

-Requires reductions of 30 percent in unburned fuel and 60 percent for nitrogen oxides in automobile exhausts by 1998, cuts smoke and soot emissions by 50 percent from urban buses. -Requires new, larger canisters on automobiles to capture fuel vapors. -Establishes a gradual introduction of alternate-fuel vehicles for fleets, and annual production of 300,000 such vehicles for private use annually beginning in 1999 under a pilot program in California. -Sets up sale of cleaner gasoline blends in nine cities with worst smog problems. Compliance likely through ethanol blends or other ``reformulated'' gasoline. Also requires sale of gasoline with increased oxygen in cities failing carbon monoxide standards.

-Requires ``maximum achievable control technology'' to reduce the release of 189 toxic chemicals, many of them carcinogens, by 90 percent by 2000. -Requires further controls to assure ``an ample margin of safety'' from exposure to cancer-causing industrial emissions. The environmental Protection Agency must develop urban air pollution control programs to reduce cancer risks by 75 percent over five years. -Creates a chemical safety board to investigate chemical accidents and requires new monitoring and reporting of accidents.

-Reduces annual sulfur dioxide emissions from coal-burning electric power plants by 10 million tons in two stages by the year 2000. Reductions in release of nitrogen oxides, also a precursor of acid rain, also are required. -Allows utilities to buy and sell ``pollution credits'' to reduce the cost of emission controls at dirty plants. Utilities that already operate clean plants can use credits for emissions in new plants to allow for growth.
-Gradually forbids manufacture and import of chemicals that cause depletion of protective ozone layer high in the stratosphere and requires recycling of these chemicals after 1992.
DOC.HEAD: PENALTIES
DOC.TEXT: -EPA may assess up to $25,000 a day in civil penalties for violators. Corporate executives who knowingly pollute and significantly endanger health may be subject to criminal prosecution.
-Allows for $250 million over five years to help workers who lose their jobs because of tougher air pollution controls and can demonstrate need.

-White House estimates: $11 billion cost a year to the economy by 1995 and between $22 billion and $25 billion by year 2005. -Industry estimates: $35 billion to $60 billion a year by 2005. -Current air pollution controls cost the economy $32 billion a year, according to government estimates. The American Lung Association estimates clean air will eventually reduce health care costs by $50 billion a year.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers for Keating, Co-Defendants, Want Fraud Evidence Kept Secret
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with judge ordering transcripts unsealed, quotes from Keating's lawyer, Keating. No pick up.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA14
DOC.TEXT: A judge said Friday he will unseal transcripts of secret grand jury proceedings in the Charles H. Keating Jr. securities fraud case but delayed disclosure for a week to give lawyers a chance to appeal. Superior Court Judge Lance Ito rejected arguments by lawyers for the Arizona developer and his co-defendants, who said publicity surrounding such a disclosure would damage the chances of finding unbiased jurors for the trial. Ito accepted the position of lawyers for the Orange County Register and the Los Angeles Times, which argued that First Amendment case law supports free access to court records. The judge said he would excise from the 4,600-page transcript the prosecution's opening statement and closing argument, which he said were slanted against the defendants and might be prejudicial. ``If I am not precluded by any higher court, I will order next Friday for the grand jury reporter to disseminate transcripts to anyone with a checkbook,'' the judge said. The grand jury stenographer sells transcripts he produces. Keating, the former head of American Continental Corp., was jailed for 33 days on a 42-count indictment. He posted a reduced bail of $300,000 last week. American Continental controlled the Irvine-based Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. Experts have estimated Lincoln's failure may cost taxpayers $2 billion, making it the costliest thrift failure yet. Keating and three top officials at his companies are charged with setting up a scheme to steer elderly investors away from government-insured certificates of deposits at Lincoln branches and into risky ``junk bonds'' issued by American Continental. The bonds became worthless when American Continental declared bankruptcy and Lincoln was seized by regulators. Prosecutors have said more than 17,000 bondholders lost more than $250 million on the junk bonds. The indictment, however, lists only 20 victims who lost $1.1 million. Prosecutors said they wanted a clear, tight case. Keating was originally held on $5 million bail set by a state Superior Court. A federal judge reduced the bail to $300,000, ruling the original amount was excessively high. Bail was posted by family members who pledged houses as security. Keating came to symbolize the excesses of the thrift industry with his investments in risky real estate ventures and junk bonds. He maintains he's being made a scapegoat by regulators and legislators hoping to avert blame for the debacle. Keating, 66, controlled Lincoln Savings through American Continental, drawing huge salaries and maintaining a lavish personal lifestyle. The indictment carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison. The criminal case is separate from charges in civil lawsuits that contend Keating looted Lincoln. Keating's lawyer suggested outside court that Keating is anxious to testify before the Senate Ethics Committee if he is granted immunity in return for the testimony. ``Mr. Keating has a wealth of information and insight,'' attorney Stephen Neal told reporters. ``If it were up to Mr. Keating, he would be talking to all of you about it. At the present time that is just not appropriate. Reports surfaced earlier this week that the committee was considering giving Keating limited immunity to testify in its probe of five senators to whose campaigns and causes Keating gave $1.3 million. The reports were denied. ``If I were an appointed or an elected public official ... I would think long and hard about ways to enable Mr. Keating to share the information and insights he has on all of the issues, including campaign financing,'' Neal said. It was Keating's first court appearance since he was released from jail. He stood beside his attorney but would not comment. Asked if he had anything to say, he declared, ``I'm hungry and I'm going home to eat.'' On a defense request, the judge delayed until Nov. 9 a hearing on motions to throw out the criminal indictment.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Supreme Court Reinstates Convictions of Ex-Home State Bank Executives
DOC.TEXT: Th state Supreme Court on Friday reinstated the convictions of former executives of the Home State Savings bank for their part in bringing down the thrift, a collapse that shut down scores of other lenders. Marvin Warner, former owner of the Cincinnati-based bank, and David Schiebel, a former bank president, were convicted in 1987 of charges related to the thrift's failure. Warner was sentenced to 3{ years in prison and ordered to pay $22 million in restitution to Ohio. Schiebel was sentenced to six months in prison. Both were free pending their appeals, which succeeded last year when a state appeals court said the lower court made prejudicial mistakes in the bankers' trials. In reinstating the convictions, the high court ruled unanimously that the trial court acted properly on all the issues. It also affirmed $12.2 million of the restitution order. The rest was sent back to the trial court to deal with. Home State failed on March 8, 1985, four days after ESM Government Securities Inc. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was declared insolvent. Home State lost $144 million through its securities transactions with ESM. Home State's collapse caused a crisis for 69 other privately insured Ohio savings and loans institutions whose deposits were insured by the Ohio Deposit Guarantee Fund. Gov. Richard Celeste temporarily closed the thrifts and said that to reopen they needed either to get federal deposit insurance or merge with companies that had it. Warner was convicted of misapplying about $14 million of the bank's money through unauthorized payments to ESM. Warner and Schiebel were both convicted of securities violations for hiding Home State's precarious financial status in a circular distributed in 1984 to raise money for the bank. Warner now lives in Florida. Pat Young, a secretary for Warner, said he had no comment. Schiebel's home phone number is unlisted. His lawyer, Roger Makley, would not comment, saying he had not seen the opinion. Special prosecutor Lawrence Kane Jr. said the state will go to court next week to have Warner and Schiebel start their sentences. The state has spent $6 million prosecuting the bankers but has recovered $135 million through lawsuits. Mark Stachler, a businessman who led the Home State Depositors Association, said he would not be satisfied until Warner was in prison. The group was formed to lobby state officials and legislators to protect their deposits during the crisis. ``I will be happy ... when Marvin Warner starts sending his Christmas cards from the penitentiary,'' he said. Another former president of the thrift, Burton Bongard, was convicted of misapplied and unauthorized transfer of funds. He later pleaded guilty to loan violations and received a 4{-year prison sentence. He was released on probation last year but returned to prison after his conviction on federal charges in the case. A U.S. District Court jury cleared Warner in June 1987 of federal fraud and conspiracy charges in the failure of Home State.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgaria to Train Military Contingent for Gulf Deployment
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Friday approved a motion to train a small volunteer medical contingent for deployment with the multinational force in Saudi Arabia, the state news agency reported.
