The decision came one day after Vice President Atanas Semerdzhiev returned from a mission to Iraq to seek the release of more than 600 Bulgarians still in Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Semerdzhiev said he received assurances from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein that all Bulgarians who have completed contracts in Iraq may leave the country if they wish. He said 430 of the 690 Bulgarians in Iraq were expected to return to Bulgaria. Parliament approved the decision to train volunteers for a military medical unit which will include a group specializing in chemical weapons defense, the state BTA news agency reported. The size of the unit was unclear.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Finds Jordan In Compliance With Embargo Of Iraq
Desk: Inserts 15th graf: ``The Saudi,'' to update. FYI, Thursday, Friday in that graf is CQ
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration for the first time Friday declared the kingdom of Jordan in compliance with U.N. sanctions against neighboring Iraq and suggested wealthy countries such as Saudi Arabia help its stricken economy. Although State Department spokesman Richard Boucher did not explicitly urge Saudi Arabia to end its oil cutoff and ease its icy stance toward King Hussein's government, the message was obvious. ``The Saudis have been very forthcoming and generous,'' Boucher said. Jordan fell into disfavor both in Washington and in Saudi Arabia when it hesitated on applying sanctions against Iraq after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Questions were raised about the kingdom's adherence to the ban on trade imposed by the U.N. Security Council, although Jordan shouldered a heavy burden of caring for refugees from Iraq. At the same time, King Hussein avoided criticizing Iraqi President Saddam Hussein for his occupation of Kuwait and, along with the Palestine Liberation Organization, staked out a middleman role in seeking a negotiated settlement. The king's ambiguous approach was considered by some analysts an attempt to stay on relatively good terms with Western democracies while not alienating Saddam Hussein, his powerful and unpredictable neighbor. Jordan's diplomatic effort has not been productive, and Jordan's economy has continued to sink. Its treasury is short of hard currency and trade is suffering. Japan, Germany and a few other wealthy countries are assisting Jordan with aid to offset the cost of taking care of the refugees. Criticism of Jordan's behavior on sanctions ebbed, meanwhile, leading up to Boucher's announcement that ``after some initial concerns we now consider Jordanian compliance with sanctions good.'' The spokesman added that the United States has made known its concerns and ``Jordan has addressed them and taken steps to meet them.'' Boucher said Jordan's economy ``warrants generous support.'' Later, a U.S. official, who demanded anonymity, said the Bush administration intended to provide special assistance to Jordan through various emergency funds. The idea, the official said, is to pump more hard currency into Jordan's treasury. The Saudi ambassador to Washington, Prince Bandar Bin Sultan, discussed Jordan's plight Thursday with Undersecretary of State Robert Kimmitt. ``It is our view, Jordan's complicity warrants generous support in the expectation that Jordan will continue to meet its obligations to enforce U.N.-mandated sanctions,'' the State Department said in a statement Friday night. Meanwhile, on Capitol Hill, lawmakers clashed over President Bush's failure to declare a national emergency in activating the reserves to support Operation Desert Shield in the Persian Gulf. Short of declaring a national emergency, Bush has the authority to activate up to 200,000 selected reserves, including combat reserves for a period of 90 days, with a 90-day extension. The Senate, in giving final approval to the 1991 defense bill, questioned a provision in the bill doubling the call-up period for combat reserves from 180 days to 360 days. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, contended that doubling the length of time for the call-up without declaring a national emergency goes beyond the law's intent. But Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, chairman of the Senate Appropriations subcommittee on defense, said the measure was the only option left for his panel since Bush has failed to declare a national emergency. ``We're risking the lives of 240,000 men and women. If that is not an emergency, I don't know what is,'' Inouye said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Step Inside Jury Box - On Stage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Production begins at 8 p.m. EDT.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing.
DOC.TEXT: Lawyer Jack Litman said Friday rehearsing for the role of a juror in this weekend's benefit production of ``Twelve Angry Men'' reinforced his belief that intellect alone cannot sway a jury. Litman is one of 12 top New York attorneys stepping inside the jury box for the showing at a law school of Reginald Rose's play, which starred Henry Fonda in the 1957 film version. ``You can't ignore the palpable emotions people have. ... You can't address (jurors) on a purely intellectual level,'' said Litman, a defense lawyer. Litman represented Robert Chambers in his 1988 murder trial. Chambers unexpectedly pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter in the strangulation of Jennifer Levin in Central Park in 1986. ``Twelve Angry Men'' is a play about a jury deciding the fate of a boy accused of stabbing his father to death as they argued in their tenement apartment in New York. As the jurors begin deliberations, there are 11 votes for a guilty verdict and one vote for acquittal. But the lone juror in favor of acquittal - played here by Michael Kennedy, Ivana Trump's lawyer, and Fonda in the movie - gradually persuades the other 11 to change their votes. The character Litman plays - a violent man obsessed with his son who ran away from home - is the last to change his mind. Among other lawyers starring in the production is Gus Newman, the lawyer for U.S. Rep. Floyd Flake, a New York Democrat who pleaded innocent in August to conspiracy, fraud and tax evasion charges stemming from allegations that he diverted money from programs of the church where he was a pastor. Also in the show is is Robert Fogelnest, from the so-called pizza connection drug-trafficking conspiracy case. Thirteen men were convicted. Litman, president of the New York Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, said he came up with the idea to do the show because ``I thought it would be a good vehicle to get away from the frenetic law practice, have a lot of fun and raise money for a good cause.'' The show's proceeds will help create scholarships for Legal Aid attorneys, public defenders and attorneys for the indigent. It was scheduled to run Friday and Saturday nights at New York University School of Law. Toni Kotite, winner of the first Bob Fosse fellowship for directors and choreographers, said she cast Litman as Juror No. 3 because ``he is a very strong man, very driven and with a huge, high energy level.'' Kennedy was her choice for the Fonda role because ``his approach to problems is laid back and he is a cool calculator. And I wanted (Juror) No. 8 to be a man of reason but also a grand master of the art of manipulation.'' The lawyers were naturals for their roles, Kotite says. ``They are playing the jury, the people they manipulate all the time,'' she says. ``These guys are really pretty good actors in real life. They aren't plumbers or professors. They are used to thinking publicly and persuading.''

DOC.HEAD: International Aviation Group Tries to Block Iraqi Use of Jets
DOC.TEXT: The International Civil Aviation Organization asked member nations Friday to impound and return 15 Kuwaiti commercial jets seized by Iraq during its invasion. The general assembly of the aviation organization, a U.N. agency, made the call in a resolution that also condemned the confiscation of the jets, now being used by Iraqi Airways. It was not immediately clear what impact Friday's decision might have on Iraq's commercial air operations. Jaber Mubarak Al-Sabah, head of Kuwait's civil aviation authority, praised the decision. The official said it prevents the Iraqis from using the jets abroad, and he said they are not suitable for domestic use. He called aviation agency's move a ``victory for the whole world'' because it adds to the international outcry over Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. But he also said it is unlikely the aircraft, now registered as part of the Iraqi Airways fleet, will be returned to Kuwait. The motion, sponsored by Kuwait and five other Persian Gulf states, passed without a formal vote because neither Iraq nor any other state requested one. However, the Iraqi delegation had opposed the resolution, saying the agency is a technical organization and should not consider a motion motivated by ``political pressures.'' ``Kuwait is a province of Iraq, and whatever is in Kuwait belongs to Iraq,'' Tariq Salbi, head of Iraq's civil aviation authority, said during a break in the meeting. The seized aircraft are valued at a total of $800 million, not including confiscated spare parts. Iraqi Airways did not have any jets of the type taken from Kuwait, which include five Airbus 310s and three Airbus 300s. Kuwait Airways is now operating from Egypt with several planes, including jumbo jets, that were abroad at the time of the invasion. Friday's resolution also calls for the return of foreign aircraft trapped on the tarmac during the invasion, when Iraq bombed Kuwait International Airport. A British Airways Boeing 747 is the only aircraft that has not been allowed to leave the region. Fred Neal, head of Britain's delegation to the U.N. agency, called on Iraq to allow the departure of the aircraft and more than 150 passengers and crew still being held. The 162-member International Civil Aviation Organization deals with international safety and security issues.
