DOC.HEAD: State Supreme Court Removes Ballot Proposal on Lottery
DOC.TEXT: The Arkansas Supreme Court stripped from the Nov. 6 ballot a proposal to establish a state lottery. The court said the wording of the referendum lacked sufficient information. The justices voted 4-3 to remove the proposal, which would have amended the state constitution. The decision came amid a state police investigation of allegations from lottery opponents that some signatures on petitions getting the proposal on the ballot were forged. Col. Tommy Goodwin, state police director, said the inquiry won't be stopped by the court's decision. In a 16-page opinion, Associate Justice David Newbern said the referendum as explained on the ballot failed to tell voters how much power the amendment would give the five-member lottery board. Those five people were already chosen and four of them were among drafters of the referendum. The five names appeared on the petitions, although one subsequently died. Newbern said the ballot title failed to mention how the commission would be a part of the checks and balances of state government. The Supreme Court also questioned the validity of signatures gathered since the death of one of the lottery board members. Associate Justice Steele Hays said in a dissenting opinion that voters, not the courts, should decide on a lottery. The Supreme Court challenge was brought by lottery opponents. One man who worked to get the proposal on the ballot said Friday the court decision was no surprise. ``Maybe it was the best thing that could happen,'' said Robert Walker, referring to the controversy the referendum provoked. W.H. Sutton, a Little Rock attorney who led opposition to the lottery proposal, said the court did the right thing. ``We're very gratified with the court's decision. It was such a terrible amendment. It was nothing to fool around with, so I'm glad that it's dead, no matter how it's disposed of,'' Sutton said.

DOC.HEAD: Press Plane Accompanying Bush Turns Back Because Of Engine Trouble
DOC.TEXT: A chartered jumbo jet carrying the press corps accompanying President Bush to Hawaii turned back over the Pacific Ocean Friday after one engine was shut because it was overheating. The Pan Am 747 landed safely at Los Angeles International Airport and another aircraft was procured for the press corps to resume the trip to Honolulu, where the president was making a campaign appearance. Passengers on the flight which left around 3:30 p.m. noticed that the plane shuddered twice less than an hour after takeoff. About 80 media representatives and White House aides were aboard. About an hour into the flight the pilot announced that the engine had been shut down and that a decision had been made in the interest of safety to return to Los Angeles. A smaller group of reporters was flying separately with the president aboard Air Force One, which was notified of the problems with the press plane as it continued on its flight to Hawaii. rcb/rlv

DOC.HEAD: Runway Robbery: Thieves Stop Jet
DOC.TEXT: In a new twist on highway robbery, two thieves forced a taxiing jet to halt Friday, but they fled without the huge gold shipment reportedly aboard the plane. The KLM Boeing 737 with 110 passengers had just landed at Amsterdam's Schiphol Airport on a flight from Zurich, Switzerland, and was rolling to the passenger gate, said KLM spokesman Nico Harmse. The thieves parked a stolen airport service van on the runway, jumped out and motioned for the pilot to stop, which he did, Harmse said. They opened the jet's rear cargo hold but fled before police arrived, and nothing was missing from the plane, National Police spokesman Rik Hirs said. Dutch television and radio stations reported the thieves were after a shipment of 770 pounds of gold worth $4.14 million. Harmse would not confirm that account. The police spokesman said the attempted robbery appeared to be an inside job. No arrests was reported.

DOC.HEAD: School Bus Runs Off Road, Injuring 13 Children and Driver
DOC.TEXT: A school bus carrying students home from classes ran off a road and into a gully Friday, injuring 13 children and the driver, authorities said. The driver lost control of the bus for unknown reasons about 4 p.m. on a two-lane road in a rural area about 20 miles southwest of this north-central Texas community, said Sgt. John Stahl of the state Department of Public Safety. The eastbound bus swerved into the westbound lane, overturned once and came to rest upright in a gully, Stahl said. The sun was shining and the pavement was dry when the accident occurred. Patsy Jackson, 8, was in critical condition with internal and head injuries, hospital officials said. The child was airlifted to Cook Children's Medical Center in Fort Worth, where she was undergoing surgery late Friday, said hospital spokeswoman Robin Worthington. The other 12 children - ranging in age from 5 to 13 - and the bus driver, 33-year-old Elena Rouse, were treated at hospitals for minor to moderate injuries, hospital officials said. An unidentified child was hospitalized in stable condition and the rest were expected to be discharged, said hospital officials. Ms. Rouse was in fair condition with head injuries at Harris Methodist Hospital in Stephenville, said emergency room supervisor Janie Kelly. Mineral Wells is about about 50 miles west of Fort Worth.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Victim Wants $1 Million From Dentist's Insurance
DOC.TEXT: A woman who says her now-dead dentist gave her AIDS will be allowed to file a $1 million claim with his malpractice insurance company, a judge ruled. Kimberly Bergalis got permission Thursday to pursue the claim from a judge who denied approval of the dentist's will, which leaves assets to his mother. Bergalis, 22, who went to Dr. David Acer to have some teeth pulled, told reporters she doesn't want the money for herself. ``It's not going to buy me a cure,'' she said. ``I might not ever see this money. It could take a year or so. I don't know if I'll still be alive.'' She added: ``Maybe I could take a trip somewhere, but it's not for me. My parents are still paying off my college education. It's for them.'' Bergalis wants CNA Insurance Co., which provided malpractice insurance to Acer, to pay her the maximum limit on his policy by Nov. 1. If CNA refuses, Bergalis' attorneys said they would file a lawsuit against the estate of the dentist, who died Sept. 3 of AIDS-related cancer, and seek a much larger amount. ``It will be a showing of bad faith and I think they would be liable for any award more than $1 million by a jury,'' said one of her lawyers, David Eaton. The insurance company's lawyer, Dennis Vandenberg, said the company ``probably will not pay on Nov. 1. It's too premature.'' Bergalis' attorneys said the insurance policy is the only ``valuable'' asset of Acer's estate. Eaton said he plans to file a lawsuit next week against CIGNA, the insurance firm that sent hundreds of patients, including Bergalis, to Acer for dental care. Bergalis tested positive for acquired immune deficiency syndrome. She says she is the woman referred to in a July report by the national Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, which said a Florida woman had likely contracted AIDS from her dentist when he pulled two of her teeth in 1987. Two days before Acer died, he wrote an open letter to his patients, saying he doubted he had infected any patients, but he urged them to be tested for the virus. State health officials said 543 of Acer's patients have been tested at the Martin County Public Health Unit. Of the 497 results received, two of the tests came back positive, an HRS spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Contest Winner A Real-Life Charlie Brown
DOC.TEXT: Good grief, Jerry Seifert! The paper mill worker was picked from about 1,000 entrants as the man who most resembles ``Peanuts'' character Charlie Brown in a nationwide contest by United Feature Syndicate. To celebrate the comic strip's 40th anniversary, the syndicate asked readers of the 1,200 U.S. newspapers that carry ``Peanuts'' to submit photographs of people who looked like Charlie and essays about them. Seifert, 29, who lives with his parents near Erie, was as wishy-washy as his look-alike when asked about the award. ``I guess I consider it an honor,'' he said. ``But I didn't think I looked like Charlie Brown. I guess a few other people do.'' Seifert's mother, Carol, submitted a photo of him with a kite caught in a tree. She wrote in her contest essay that Seifert is ``truly a Charlie Brown in looks as well as life.'' ``Once he borrowed a friend's new car only to have someone cross the center line and hit him head-on,'' she wrote. ``Without a thought of himself, he ran and gave aid to the guy who hit him. ``While hunting, he hit a house accidentally and gave himself up, only to lose his hunting license ... and the list goes on.'' Seifert won a trip for four to Knotts Berry Farm's Camp Snoopy in Buena Park, Calif., and an original strip signed by ``Peanuts'' creator Charles Schulz. ``Well, I guess I'm looking forward to meeting Joe Garagiola,'' who chose him as the winner, Seifert said. ``Maybe he's really not going to be able to meet me, though. ... I don't know.''

Congress approved legislation Friday to give consumers more nutrition information on the labels of the foods they eat, sending the bill to President Bush. The House, on a voice vote, approved the bill passed Wednesday by the Senate setting specific standards for nutrition labels and requiring them to be on packaged foods. The legislation also mandates that bulk food in bins, raw fish and fruits and vegetables be displayed with a sign or brochure providing nutritional information. Food sold by restaurants, cafeterias, hospitals and grocers with annual sales of less than $500,000 is exempt. ``Consumers have long demanded this information, but under current law it is optional, said Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., chairman of the Energy and Commerce subcommittee on health. ``This bill will once and for all settle the confusion surrounding health claims'' on food. Labels would be required to display: -Serving size. -Number of servings per container. -Calories per serving and number of caloriers from fat. -Amount of fat, saturated fat, cholesterol, sodium, total carbohydrates, complex carbohydrates, sugars, dietary fiber, protein. The measure requires the Department of Health and Human Services to publish draft regulations 12 months after enactment, and final regulation six months later. Waxman said the bill prohibits terms like ``light, high and low'' unless they have been defined in a manner consistent with the Food and Drug Administration's definition. It forbids disease prevention claims unless the FDA has found the contention supported by science. ``Health claims were not permitted on food until the 1980s,'' said Waxman. ``When the FDA relaxed its rules during the early years of the Reagan administration, it lost control of the marketplace and many unfounded claims began to be used for food. ``This bill will reorganize the marketplace so only truthful claims can be used for food,'' he said. A private citizen, Phil Sokolof, of Omaha, Neb., was made an unofficial co-sponsor of the bill for his unyielding lobbying of the Senate to get a vote on the bill. Earlier this week, when the measure appeared stalled in that body, Sokolof spent thousands of dollars of his personal fortune to run full page ads in major newspapers calling on the senators to pass the bill. ``His ads played such an important role in educating the public and the Congress,'' said Waxman. ``What he was able to do on his own as an individual is an inspiration. This bill is a tribute to his tenacity.''

DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Commissioner Candidate Blasts Opponent's Lawnmower Mishap
DOC.TEXT: State Agriculture Commissioner Jim Hightower's loss of a fingertip in a lawnmower accident shows his ``total lack of common sense,'' his Republican rival, Rick Perry, said Friday. ``It's unbelievable Perry is trying to make this a campaign issue,'' Hightower's campaign said in response. ``It is an indication that Perry doesn't have serious programs and ideas to talk about,'' said Brigid Shea, Hightower's campaign spokesman. Last week, Hightower cut off the tip of a finger while mowing. ``I managed to put my finger under a lawn mower,'' he quipped Thursday. ``If you'll check your manual and remember what your Mama said and what common sense tells us, is don't do that.'' Perry said of the accident: ``It's probably a good thing Hightower is not a farmer, because there are machines much more dangerous than lawn mowers on the farm, like shredders and bush hogs and balers.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Some Air Bags Faulty
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. said Friday it was recalling 55,000 cars to search for approximately 133 of them believed to have defective driver's side air bags. Three other automakers - General Motors, Mazda and Honda - are notifying owners to return another 50 cars that were equipped with the faulty bags, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said. Devices that cause the bags to inflate apparently were damaged during assembly, the government agency said in a statement. The manufacturer, TRW Inc., discovered the defect. The bags could malfunction when deployed in a crash, said Jerry R. Curry, administrator of the agency. The bags would not inflate properly and might eject hot gases that ordinarily would flow through filters and cooling devices. ``Chances of an improper deployment during a crash are remote,'' Curry said. ``Some of the vehicles affected by this recall have been in service for more than a year, and no improper air bag deployments have been reported.'' But if the bags malfunctioned, the gases could cause serious injury, he said. ``Therefore, owners of vehicles covered by this recall should limit their use until the vehicle has been inspected.'' TRW has discovered 183 potentially defective inflators and is looking for others, Curry said. GM identified the owners of its 39 cars believed to have faulty air bags and is notifying them by telephone and first-class mail, a spokesman said. Also notifying owners are Honda, which has sold nine affected cars, and Mazda, which has sold two. Ford is recalling 55,000 cars because it could not pinpoint the 133 it has sold that have the defective equipment. Covered by the recall are the 1990 and 1991 Ford Crown Victoria and Mercury Grand Marquis and the 1990 Ford Taurus, Mercury Sable, Lincoln Continental, Ford Tempo and Mercury Topaz. Owners of those cars should take them to a dealer for inspection. Any car found to have the defect will be repaired free.

DOC.HEAD: Burma Military Tells Politicians to Sign Accord or Go to Jail
DOC.TEXT: Burma's military rulers are telling their democratic opponents to either go to jail or sign an accord with only a vague timetable for a transfer of power, a political source in Rangoon said Friday. This week, authorities summoned the leaders of opposition parties at the rate of six a day and ordered them to sign a paper outlining the military's timetable, the source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``The handcuffs were right there on the table, and they were given the choice between a ballpoint pen or the handcuffs,'' the source said. The source said the political leaders were from some of the 93 political parties that took part in the May 27 parliamentary elections. The National League for Democracy won the elections, but the military regime of Gen. Saw Maung refused to allow the winners to take power and placed many under house arrest. On Tuesday, authorities detained 12 league's leaders, including four members of its central committee. Opposition leaders want the parliament to begin operating in September. The military says it won't step down until a new constitution is drawn up. A conference would be convened at an unspecified date to provide guidelines for the parliament to draft the constitution. Reports from Mandalay, 350 miles north of Rangoon, said troops had raided and occupied the major Buddhist monasteries there since Monday and detained as many as 50 monks. The monks have been refusing to minister to soldiers since troops reportedly killed four people at an Aug. 8 pro-democracy demonstration in Mandalay. The refusal is tantamount to excommunication in the mostly Buddhist country. The government on Sunday empowered army commanders to try dissident monks in military tribunals, which can dispense the death penalty. Authorities in Rangoon had searched the headquarters of the National League for Democracy each of the previous three nights and shut some of the party's offices down, the political source said. The league's chairman, Tin Oo, was jailed by a military tribunal in December on charges of subversion. Its general secretary, Aung San Suu Kyi, has been under house arrest since July 1989. The league's acting leader, Kyi Maung, and several other senior officials were arrested last month. Amnesty International, a human rights group, says the military government has arrested thousands of people for political reasons since it took power by crushing a popular uprising in 1988. Authorities at that time killed hundreds of people.

DOC.HEAD: Europeans Threaten Retaliation for US Limit on Wine
DOC.TEXT: Europe's top trade representative complained Friday that U.S. authorities are holding up the sale of nearly $200 million worth of European wines without good reason. He threatened retaliation. ``If a speedy solution is not found in the near future, the European Community will have to consider ways to safeguard its interests,'' said a statement issued by the community's delegation in Washington. At issue in the wine fight is a chemical called procymidone, used to kill fungi on grapevines. U.S. authorities have not completed their investigation of it. Wines from the Beaujolais and Burgundy regions of France, from the Italian region of Asti and a cooking wine from Spain are the primary varieties affected. The statement in the name of Andreas van Agt, head of the Washington delegation, did not say how the Europeans might protect their wine trade. Often in such disputes the side that considers itself injured stops an equivalent amount of the exports from the offending country. The dispute comes at a time when the United States and the Europeans are at odds over the bigger issue of subsidies to farm products in general. The Bush administration wants to reduce subsidies faster than the Europeans do. The issue is threatening the success of four years' negotiations by about 100 countries in the ``Uruguay round'' of trade talks trying to write new rules for trade of all kinds before the end of this year. Van Agt quoted the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency as saying that it did not believe that levels of procymidone found in imported wine amounted to a health risk. ``Unfortunately, it appears that notwithstanding certain differences between E.C. and U.S. regulatory procedures, concerns other than consumer safety appear to be involved,'' van Agt said. He did not specify what concerns he meant. European growers reportedly have been asked not to use procymidone on plants producing for the U.S. trade and the chemical is said to have been almost entirely eliminated this season. But earlier vintages still have traces of it and shipments have been held up in U.S. porss.

DOC.HEAD: Wayne Gretzky First Hockey Player to Reach 2,000 Points
DOC.TEXT: Wayne Gretzky, who already holds almost every National Hockey League scoring record, became the first player Friday to reach 2,000 points. The Los Angeles Kings player hit the mark when he set up a goal by Tomas Sandstrom at 14:32 of the first period against Winnipeg. The game was stopped momentarily as Gretzky's teammates poured onto the ice and a sellout crowd at the Winnipeg Arena gave Gretzky a standing ovation. Gretzky, in his 12th NHL season, eclipsed Gordie Howe as the league's all-time leading scorer with his 1,851st point Oct. 15, 1989, in a game at Edmonton. He has been the NHL's career assist leader since March 1, 1988, when he passed Howe's total of 1,049. That milestone came against the Kings, just five months before Gretzky was traded from the Edmonton Oilers to Los Angeles. Gretzky's assist total is 1,316. Gretzky's 1,000th point also came against the Kings, on Dec. 19, 1984. Gretzky's only remaining target is the league's goal-scoring record. He has 693 goals, fourth on the all-time list behind Howe, with 801, Marcel Dionne, with 731, and Phil Esposito, with 717.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Dead in South African Township Violence
DOC.TEXT: Police fired on protesters in a township outside Cape Town and black factions clashed there, leaving eight people dead and dozens injured, police said Friday. Four died in violence elsewhere. In a separate development, the South African Press Association reported that a warrant was issued for the arrest of Winnie Mandela after she failed to appear in court to face charges involving alleged business irregularities. Mrs. Mandela is the wife of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela. The Khayelitsha black township, about 25 miles outside Cape Town, was generally calm Friday after the day of violence. The fighting, which began Thursday and continued into the night, broke out afteran explosion and fire damaged the local government building. Many residents of black townships oppose the local councils and consider council members collaborators with the country's white-led government. Police fired birdshot, rubber bullets and tear gas at a crowd of at least 800 blacks who tried to march on the government building. Blacks also clashed with each other and police throughout the day Thursday. At least 50 shacks were burned. Police said eight people were killed in the violence, three of them in clashes with police. The independent South African Press Association and several newspapers said seven people had been killed in the clashes with police. Police denied those reports. Tension has been high in Khayelitsha since the slaying last week of Momsa Mapongwana, the wife of an anti-apartheid leader in the township. Her funeral was scheduled for Saturday. A separate police statement Friday said four people were killed in black faction fighting in Natal Province during the previous 24 hours. A group of blacks with rifles attacked a house at Ntzuma, killing two men and wounding a woman, the statement said. Two black men were killed at Mnjamda, but police gave no details. Three blacks were hurt in Pretoria when passengers jumped out of a moving train after men with whips attacked people on the train, police said Friday. The attackers in the incident late Thursday were trying to enforce a work boycott, authorities said. The warrant for Mrs. Mandela's arrest was issued Thursday when she failed to appear in a Johannesburg magistrate's court on charges involving alleged failure to pay unemployment insurance for employees of her food shop, the South African Press Association said in its report. She allegedly failed to pay contributions between January and August and also failed to file necessary documents relating to the insurance contributions, the agency said. A warrant for Mrs. Mandela's arrest was issued in March for failing to appear in court on similar charges, the Press Association said. In April, the warrant was canceled after a fine of $40 was paid on her behalf, as well as more than $80 owed to the unemployment insurance fund, the news agency said. In February, Mrs. Mandela and seven of her former bodyguards are scheduled to stand trial on kidnapping and assault charges involving the alleged abduction and beating of four young men in her Soweto home in December 1988. One of the youths, 14-year-old Stompie Seipei, was killed. The former head of Mrs. Mandela's bodyguards has been convicted of murder in the case and sentenced to death. Mrs. Mandela has denied any wrongdoing.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: An AMs separate on Holley as a0748 and on Garcia as a0705. A separate on Sanders and Oosterbaan moved on the sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Jazz bassist Major Holley, who performed with a long list of musical greats including Duke Ellington, Woody Herman, Ella Fitzgerald and Benny Goodman, died Thursday of a heart attack at age 66. Holley's first professional gig was in San Diego in 1946 where he performed in an ensemble led by saxophonists Wardell Gray and Dexter Gordon. He moved to New York after getting out of the service. He performed ``Mack the Knife'' on Frank Sinatra's 1986 ``L.A. Is My Lady'' album, at the invitation of record producer Quincy Jones. He taught at Berklee College in Boston from 1967 to 1970 and toured Europe with the Kings of Jazz in the mid-70s.

Guillermo Garcia, a Cuban chess grand master, died Friday in an auto accident at age 36. Garcia, Cuban champion in 1974, 1977 and 1983, first drew international attention at age 14 when he defeated Argentina grand master Oscar Panno. He had played on Cuban national chess teams in world competition since 1974.

Former Chargers general manager Johnny Sanders, who ran the club in the team's glory years, died Friday of heart failure at age 68. Sanders, a member of Occidental's Hall of Fame and Van Nuys' Hall of Fame, taught and coached in the Los Angeles City Schools system before joining the Los Angeles Rams as a part-time scout in 1952. He became director of player personnel for the Rams in 1964 and assistant general manager in 1969. In 1975, he joined the Chargers as an assistant to the late Chargers owner Gene Klein, who promoted Sanders to general manager in 1976. Sanders was named NFL executive of the year in 1979.

Bennie Oosterbaan, a three-sports varsity star and the last University of Michigan coach to win a national championship, died Thursday at age 84. In the 1920s, Oosterbaan lettered in football, basketball and baseball. He led the Big Ten in touchdowns in 1925 with eight. He was an All-American in basketball in 1928, and also that year topped the Big Ten in hitting in baseball. He became an assistant coach in 1928 and head coach in 1948, winning the national championship his first year at the helm. During his 11 years as head coach, Michigan won three Big Ten championships and a Rose Bowl victory in 1951. He compiled a 66-33-4 record. Oosterbaan was director of athletic alumni relations until he retired in 1972.

John F. Davis, a lawyer, a former deputy executive director of the Department of City Planning and a former executive editor of The New York Amsterdam News, died Monday of lung cancer at age 50. In 1963, at the age of 22, Davis, became the youngest full-fledged member to be appointed to the board of directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Davis was executive editor of the Amsterdam News from 1981 to 1983 and later contributed articles to The Village Voice. He is survived by five sisters, Mildred Booker, Shirley Davis, Lillian Price, Catherine Johnson, and Marion Barnett; and a brother, Reuben.

Robin Chu, a sociologist and member of Parliament in Taiwan, died Wednesday of stomach cancer at age 71. In the 1960s, Chu taught at Manhattan Community College. In the last two decades, he studied Chinese communities in North America and published three books on the subject in Taiwan. Chu was elected to Parliament in Taiwan in 1988 and became chairman of its committee on overseas Chinese affairs.

Robert N. Thorn, a former deputy director of Los Alamos National Laboratory who developed more than a dozen nuclear warhead designs, died Thursday after a lengthy illness at age 66. Thorn joined the lab in 1953 as a staff member in the theoretical division, and conducted pioneering weapons research during his first nine years at the laboratory. In 1962, he became leader of the lab's thermonuclear weapons physics and design group. In 1971, he was appointed leader of the lab's theoretical design division. Thorn was a deputy director at the lab from 1979-85 and was the acting director twice - for five months in 1979 and for four months in late 1985 and early 1986. He was the senior adviser at the lab at the time of his retirement in 1989. Thorn had served on advisory groups to the Central Intelligence Agency, the Defense Intelligence Agency and the Air Force.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Value of Harvard's South African-Related Investments Increased
DOC.TEXT: The value of Harvard University's stake in South Africa-related businesses has increased for the first time in three years, a report shows. The improvement reflects market fluctuations, officials say. Harvard's direct investments in companies with South African holdings increased 32 percent, or more than $54 million, from December 1989 to June 1990. The increase was noted Thursday in the annual report of a subcommittee of the Harvard Corporation, the school's main governing body. Last year, Harvard's holdings in South Africa-related stocks dropped 30 percent in value. ``This is really an accident of the market at a particular time,'' said Elizabeth Gray, the subcommittee's secretary. ``Much of this is due to an appreciation of stocks we already held. There's an ebb and flow in the market and we may have a low point in our next financial report.'' In the past, Harvard students have staged demonstrations to press the university to divest its holdings in companies with business in South Africa. In February, South African Archbishop Desmond Tutu, a member of Harvard's governing Board of Overseers, urged the school to sell off its investments with South African ties until promised changes are made there. The report said investments in companies that do business in South Africa increased from $168.6 million to $223.3 million during the six-month period.

DOC.HEAD: Durkin Charges Auto PAC Trying to Buy Smith a Senate Seat
DOC.TEXT: Democrat John Durkin on Friday criticized a group of auto dealers for trying to elect people who support ``Japan's right to dump whatever it wants on the U.S. market.'' Durkin was protesting a planned television advertising campaign against him by the Automobile Dealers and Drivers for Free Trade PAC. Durkin is running against U.S. Rep. Bob Smith for the Senate. The PAC, which he said represents Japanese automakers, plans to spend $317,200 on the ads, which begin Sunday. ``That is more than we're probably going to spend in this entire campaign,'' Durkin said. According to the Almanac of Federal PACs 1990, the PAC's primary objective is to promote free trade with Japan. Contributors market Japanese-made vehicles, including Toyota, Nissan, Honda, Mitsubishi and Subaru. Durkin refuses PAC contributions and has repeatedly attacked his opponent for taking them. Smith says the groups support his pro-business positions and denies the money influences his votes. He's raised close to $1 million, half from PACs. PAC spokesman Frank Glacken, based in Jamaica, N.Y., said the auto dealers' group had no contact with Smith ``because that would jeopardize the independence of the effort.'' He said the PAC represents ``independent American businessmen and women who sell imported cars all over the country.'' Glacken said the committee opposes Durkin because he voted with labor interests when he served in the Senate from 1975-80. Glacken said the committee gave no money to Smith because ``that would be illegal.'' Asked about the ad campaign, Smith spokeswoman Lisa Stocklan said Smith ``knew nothing about it. It is not authorized by the Smith campaign.''

DOC.HEAD: Most Americans Will Pay More, But Tax Bite For Many Relatively Light
With AM-Congress Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS graf 6, ``GASOLINE:,'' to CORRECT date, Dec. 1 sted Jan. 1; SUBS graf 13: ``Cut to,'' to show other parts of bill likely to eliminate that particular tax cut
DOC.TEXT: Hardly any person who pays federal taxes would go unaffected by the tax bill on which congressional negotiators were completing work Friday. Most Americans would pay higher taxes, but on their purchases rather than on their earnings. The bite would be relatively light for all but the well-to-do. Those with incomes over $200,000 a year would see their federal tax liabilities rise by an average of 6.3 percent. Many of the 70 million couples and individuals with incomes under $20,000 would get a slight tax cut, thanks to expansion of the earned-income credit for poorer, working families with children. The National Taxpayers Union, a nonpartisan organization that campaigns for lower taxes, estimated the bill would boost the taxes of a $30,000 family by an average of $109. A $40,000 family would pay $166 more; at $50,000, $214; $70,000, $277 more; $100,000, $542 more, and families at the $225,000 level would face an average tax increase of $3,572. Here are major provisions: GASOLINE: Raise the 9-cent gasoline tax to 14 cents a gallon and the 15-cent diesel tax to 20 cents on Dec. 1. A motorist driving 10,000 miles a year in a car that gets 22 miles per gallon would pay about $23 more. ALCOHOL: Double the beer tax to 32 cents a six-pack; raise the $12.50-a-gallon tax on 100-proof liquor by $1, or 20 cents a fifth; raise taxes on most wines, including, for example, table wine, which would go from 3 cents a 750-milliliter bottle to 21 cents. TOBACCO: Raise the 16-cent cigarette tax by 4 cents in 1991 and another 4 cents in 1993. Snuff, cigars and other tobacco would face 25 percent tax increases each year. AIR TRAVEL: Raise to 10 percent the 8 percent tax on airline tickets, which had been scheduled to drop to 4 percent at year end. The average round-trip ticket, which costs about $300, would increase by $6. TELEPHONES: Make permanent the 3 percent tax on local and long-distance phone service, which otherwise would expire Dec. 31. LUXURIES: Impose a 10 percent tax on the portion of the price of cars above $30,000; boats above $100,000; jewelry and furs above $10,000 and private planes above $250,000. A $40,000 car, for example, would face a luxury tax of $1,000. TAX RATES: Raise to 31 percent the 28 percent top income tax rate paid by the 600,000 couples and individuals with the highest incomes. That would raise taxes on singles making more than about $125,000 a year and couples with incomes above the $200,000 range. Cut to 31 percent the 33 percent rate that as many as 4 million upper-middle-income people pay on part of their earnings. This would reduce taxes for single people with incomes between about $60,000 and $125,000 and couples between about $100,000 and $200,000. However, other parts of the bill would take back that tax cut in most cases. Raise from 21 percent to 24 percent the alternative minimum tax, which is paid by fewer than 100,000 high-income people with large amounts of deductions that otherwise could reduce tax liability to near zero. CAPITAL GAINS: Tax profits from the sale of investments at a maximum rate of 28 percent. This would provide a break for those investors who now pay a maximum rate of 33 percent. There is no deep across-the-board cut in capital-gains taxes as President Bush has demanded. ITEMIZED DEDUCTIONS: Reduce by 3 percent the value of certain itemized deductions that may be written off against adjusted gross income over $100,000. Only 97 percent of deductions would be allowed against the portion of income above $100,000; thus the allowable deduction would be reduced by $300 for each $10,000 of income above $100,000. The restriction would not apply to deductions for medical expenses, casualty losses or investment interest. The provision would affect about 2.5 million couples and individuals. EXEMPTIONS: Reduce personal exemptions - which now are $2,050 for a taxpayer and each dependent - as adjusted gross income rises above $100,000 for a single person and $150,000 for a couple. This would raise taxes for people at those levels. The exemptions would be reduced by 2 percent for each $2,500 that income exceeds those thresholds. The exemptions would be lost once income tops $225,000 (single) or $275,000 (couple). LOW-INCOME: Increase the earned-income tax credit, which benefits about 5 million low-income working families with children, as a way of offsetting some of the higher excise taxes. MEDICARE TAXES: Increase to $125,000 the $51,300 maximum annual wage to which the 1.45 percent Medicare tax applies. This would affect about 8 million wage-earners. The tax is withheld as part of the Social Security tax and paid by employees and employers. MEDICARE PREMIUMS: Raise the $28.60 monthly premium for Medicare Part B insurance to $29.90 next year and $46.20 by 1995. About 30 million elderly and 3 million disabled people are enrolled in Part B. MEDICARE DEDUCTIBLE: Raise to $100 through 1995 the present $75 deductible, which beneficiaries must pay before Medicare starts paying for doctor bills. SOCIAL SECURITY: Require the 3.8 million state and local government workers not covered by a public pension to pay Social Security taxes. ENERGY INITIATIVES: Provide $2.5 billion worth of tax incentives for increasing U.S. oil and gas exploration and production. EXPIRING BENEFITS: Increase through 1991 at a five-year cost of $5.9 billion 11 targeted tax breaks that are expiring. Principal beneficiaries include workers who receive tuition aid or group legal services from employers; businesses that hire the poor; investors in low-income rental housing; self-employed people who buy their own health insurance; businesses that increase spending for research; and low-income people buying a first home. BUSINESS: Raise taxes on life insurance companies by $8 billion. Extend for five years an expiring 0.2 percent surtax that employers pay for unemployment insurance. Raise the interest rate corporations must pay on overdue taxes.

The final bill dropped several provisions that had been the subject of intense negotiations. Tey included: A new tax on home-heating oil; forgoing next year's scheduled ``indexing'' adjustment of tax brackets and exemptions, which protects against inflation; requiring that veteran state and local government workers pay the Medicare tax; imposing a surtax on millionaires; and allowing a special break to high-income people who donate appreciated art works to museums.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Threatens Reprisals Against Civilians Working for British Army
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 8th graf `The mainly' with Sinn Fein member killed; picks up 9th pvs, `Earlier, two...'
DOC.TEXT: The IRA on Friday threatened more reprisals against civilians working for the British military after turning a Defense Ministry handyman into a ``human bomb'' this week. Police identified the man as Patrick Gillespie, 42. He was killed Wednesday when IRA gunmen forced him to drive a 1,000-pound bomb into a military checkpoint near Londonderry, Northern Ireland's second city. Five soldiers also died in the blast and a sixth soldier was killed in a simultaneous bombing at Newry, 100 miles southeast of Londonderry. A bomb failed to explode in a third attack. In all three attacks Roman Catholic men who worked for the British security forces were tied up inside bomb-laden vehicles and ordered to drive into the checkpoints. ``Those involved in such work should desist or be prepared to suffer the consequences,'' the outlawed Irish Republican Army said in a statement. It was sent to the Belfast office of the British domestic news agency, Press Association. The family of John McEvoy, the ``human bomb'' in the Newry attack, said Friday they were cutting all contact with security forces. McEvoy survived the bombing but suffered a broken leg. McEvoy's family owned a gasoline station outside Newry which served security forces. ``No service will be provided for troops or police at the service station,'' the family said in a statement without making further comment. The mainly Catholic IRA is fighting to end British rule and unite this Protestant-dominated province with the Republic of Ireland under a leftist admiistration. The IRA is banned on both sides of the border. Gunmen killed a member of the political wing of the IRA who was visiting friends Friday near Cookstown, 30 miles west of Belfast, police said. Sinn Fein, the political arm of the IRA, blamed Protestant guerrillas for the death of the man, identified as Tommy Casey, a house painter. Earlier, two other victims of the spate of killings this week were buried in separate funerals. They were a Protestant taxi driver, William Aiken, who was shot by the IRA, and a Catholic taxi driver, Frank Hughes, who was killed by Protestant gunmen in retaliation. Three IRA suspects appeared in court in Belfast charged with the murder last weekend of a former member of the locally recruited army, the Ulster Defense Regiment, who was ambushed in his car. They were ordered held in jail until another court appearance on Nov. 21. In London, six months of negotiations between Britain and the Irish Republic aimed at restoring local government to Northern Ireland ended in deadlock late Thursday. British and Irish officials said they would try to overcome differences, but the outlook was bleak. ``We have gone as far as we can, and that is generally accepted. The situation is somber,'' Irish Foreign Minister Gerry Collins told reporters. The officials said the main sticking point was when the Irish government should become involved in the negotiations between Northern Ireland's Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders. The Irish Republic wants to be involved at every stage, while the Protestants, who are the majority in Northern Ireland, envision a role for Dublin only at the last stages.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 2 grafs to update with beginning of Senate debate and scheduling of final vote Saturday; picks up 3rd graf: ``The cost,'' Should stand for AMs
DOC.HEAD: Wioth BC-House Clean Air Roll Call
DOC.TEXT: The House approved the first overhaul of federal clean air laws in 13 years Friday night, requiring new pollution controls to sharply reduce urban smog, acid rain and industrial release of toxic chemicals. The 1,100-page bill passed by a vote of 401-25 and immediately was sent to the Senate. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, scheduled a vote Saturday. The cost for meeting the new requirements eventually are expected to exceed $22 billion a year and affect virtually every segment of society. Many of the handful of congressmen who opposed the measure did so because of the burden imposed on Midwest utilities that will have to undertake expensive measures to curb pollutants that cause acid rain. But supporters hailed the legislation as the most far-reaching piece of environmental legislation to be considered by Congress in years. ``This bill will be the standard by which we will judge environmental legislation in the '90s,'' declared Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla. Despite its lopsided approval, the bill was the product of months of intense bargaining by House members among themselves behind closed doors. The highly technical and far-reaching bill requires tighter emission controls on cars, cleaner-burning gasoline blends and pollution controls on businesses to combat urban smog. Smog-producing emissions from automobiles must be cut by 30 percent to 60 percent and gasoline sold in areas with smog problems must be 15 percent cleaner toward the end of the decade. More than 100 cities that are failing to meet federal air-quality standards will have to impose pollution-control plans to bring their air into compliance over the next five to 17 years, depending on the severity of the problem. The Los Angeles area is given 20 years. At the same time, the measure directs industry to cut toxic air pollution by 90 percent over the next eight years by installing new pollution-control equipment to capture 189 hazardous chemicals and requires coal-burning electric power plants to reduce chemical releases that cause acid rain by more than 10 million tons. The industrial Midwest will be hit hardest because plants in such states as Ohio, Indiana and Illinois rely heavily on high-sulfur coal and will carry the greatest burden of reducing sulfur dioxide emissions, which cause acid rain. Failure to meet the new federal requirements could open polluters to civil penalties of up to $25,000 a day. Criminal penalties may be sought against corporate executives for willful release of hazardous air pollutants that pose a serious health threat. Most of the new pollution requirements would be phased in over 10 to 15 years. The requirements for cleaner burning motor fuels and reductions in sulfur dioxide emissions from coal-burning power plants take effect by 1995. The clean-air requirements are expected to have widespread effects on society. Consumers are likely to pay slightly more for automobiles as well as gasoline and, in many of the Midwestern states, more for electricity. Small businesses and huge petrochemical plants alike will have to invest in pollution-control equipment and improve the monitoring of chemical releases. Cost estimates for the new controls have varied widely. The bill's supporters have said the legislation will cost the economy about $10 billion a year beginning in 1995 and about $22 billion by the year 2005, when most of the requirements will be in effect. Industry estimates have been much higher, with some studies predicting annual costs from the legislation by 2005 of more than $60 billion. Environmentalists have criticized the industry figures as being based on ``inflated estimates and extreme or false assumptions.'' The latest push for overhauling the 1970 Clean Air Act, which was last changed in 1977, began nearly 17 months ago when President Bush unveiled his proposal for cleaning up the nation's air, noting that for nearly a decade ``political paralysis has plagued ... progress against air pollution.'' But the task proved to be far from simple. It took three weeks of intense closed-door negotiations between Senate leaders and the White House to craft legislation that would satisfy divergent regional and economy interests affected by the bill. Finally the Senate passed a bill April 3 by a vote of 89-11. Six weeks later, the House approved its version 401-21 after also after working out scores of tradeoffs and compromises. But negotiations bogged down as the House and Senate tried to resolve differences in the two bills, each of which ran to nearly 700 pages. Facing increasing time pressures, negotiators for the two houses finally agreed on a compromise bill Monday, barely in time for final floor action before Congress adjourns.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Leader Calls for Attack, Two More Americans Detained
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 21 `French President' to DELETE second full reference to Mikhail Gorbachev. Picks up 22nd pvs, `We have...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait's exiled prime minister was quoted Friday as appealing for a military strike to oust Iraqi forces from his homeland. Diplomats said the occupiers had seized two American men who evaded capture for weeks. Iraq gave new indications it might be willing to negotiate a settlement. President Saddam Hussein told Channel 3 radio of Algiers, Algeria, ``When the greater interest demands it, everything is open to consideration.'' But he went on to rule out ``ceding our rights.'' Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, opening a three-day visit to Spain, said his country favors a ``political solution.'' Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, traveling with him, reportedly said Iraq appears to be seeking international talks. However, the Soviet leaders said Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait. President Bush has asked Secretary of State James A. Baker III to visit Saudi Arabia early next month for discussions on the Persian Gulf standoff, the White House said Friday. Press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said news reports that Baker would ask the Saudi government to approve military action against Iraq were ``not true.'' Baker might also stop in Egypt and other countries, other officials told The Associated Press. There were also reports from Washington that Saddam has adopted a ``scorched-earth'' strategy if his troops are forced out of Kuwait. Administration sources said Iraq had used American and other hostages to wire Kuwait's four oil refineries with plastic explosives capable of knocking out the emirate's entire refining capacity. In his comments, Kuwait's exiled prime minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, urged a military strike to reclaim his own homeland - even if it meant leaving the emirate in ruins. ``What is left of Kuwait after what Saddam's soldiers did to it?'' the Saudi daily Asharq al-Awsat quoted him as saying in an interview published Friday. ``As a citizen and a responsible official, I am ready to sacrifice everything for the sake of regaining my land and liberating it, and that is how each ordinary Kuwaiti thinks,'' said the prime minister, who is also crown prince. Kuwaiti officials earlier agreed with U.S. declarations that the international economic boycott should be given time to work before a military attack is contemplated. The Americans who were seized were identified by Western diplomats in Baghdad as Uwe Jahnke, 47, of Washington Depot, Conn., and John Stevenson, 44, of Panama City, Fla. The diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the pair was brought to Baghdad on Oct. 22, a day after being picked up in Kuwait,and taken to a hotel where scores of other foreigners are being held. After his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Saddam prevented thousands of foreigners from leaving Iraq and the conquered emirate. Hundreds have since been released, but Saddam is apparently seeking anew to pry concessions from Western governments in exchange for their citizens' freedom. German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said Iraq had set a ``series of conditions'' for the release of about 400 Germans, but that Germany would only accept their unconditional release. He did not list the Iraqi demands but said one was that he himself travel to Baghdad. Genscher made his remarks after meeting with British Foreign Minister Douglas Hurd, who also called for the unconditional freeing of all foreign hostages. In Canada, Prime Minister Brian Mulroney rejected the idea of sending a high-level envoy to win release of Canadian hostages in Iraq, calling it a bid by Saddam to divide the nations allied against him. ``I think a special envoy is a ploy of Saddam Hussein for publicity purposes, for propaganda purposes, to destabilize the solidarity of the alliance - that's all it is,'' Mulroney told reporters in Ottawa. Iraq has said French nationals would be free to leave beginning Saturday, and France has insisted no deal was struck with Saddam to win their freedom. French officials also denied any knowledge Friday of a letter Saddam reportedly sent to French and Soviet leaders offering to discuss Mideast problems. French President Francois Mitterrand and Gorbachev are to hold two days of talks in Paris beginning Sunday. The French television network La Cinq said Saddam told the two leaders he was open ``to all ideas'' in resolving the gulf crisis. ``We have no information regarding such a letter,'' said an official at the French presidential palace. In his remarks in Spain, Gorbachev said Friday, ``We favor taking advantage of all possibilities for a politicial solution. Nevertheless, no one should take the search for these joint or bilateral solutions as a sign of weakness, or for vacillation over implementation of U.N. Security Council resolutions.'' The United Nations has condemned Iraq for its invasion and ordered an international embargo on Iraqi trade to force Saddam to withdraw his forces from Kuwait. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on Friday told his Spanish counterpart, Francisco Fernandez Ordonez, there were new, but still not encouraging, signals from Iraq. ``It appears that Iraq is searching for some kind of dialogue, but there is no possibility of that until Iraq withdraws from Kuwait unconditionally,'' a Spanish Foreign Ministry spokesman quoted Shevardnadze as saying. In Washington, the Bush administration for the first time declared the kingdom of Jordan to be in compliance with U.N. sanctions against Iraq. Jordan had dragged its feet on enforcing the trade embargo, drawing the ire of both the United States and Saudi Arabia. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher stopped short of urging Saudi Arabia to end an oil cutoff aimed at Jordan now that it was complying, but said its economy ``warrants generous support.'' Jordan was a major trading partner of Iraq before the invasion, and it has been hit hard by the sanctions against Iraq. Saddam, meanwhile, was said to be seeking reconciliation with Iraq's Kurdish minority. He has attacked the Kurds with chemical weapons in the past. The Iraqi president's motives were unclear, but he could be seeking to quell internal dissent as he faces a huge multinational force in the gulf region. A report in the Baghdad newspaper al-Jumhuriya on Friday said Saddam visited Kurdish homes in a northeast province on Thursday, chatting and even praying with residents. Iraq's 3.5 million Kurds have fought for decades for an independent homeland. In other developments: -Kuwait says casualties from the invasion were far higher than initially reported. The government-run Kuwait News Agency, monitored in Bahrain, said Friday that 4,200 Kuwaitis were killed during the invasion. Initial reports had said several hundred died. -In Japan, opposition mounted to a proposal to send Japanese troops to the gulf. Thousands of demonstrators marched on the parliament building in Tokyo on Friday to protest the plan. Critics claim the deployment of troops, even in non-combat roles, violates Japan's postwar constitution.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS $403 billion to $403 million in last graf
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Congress-Military Spending
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, is a comparison of the provisions of the 1991 defense bill spending approved by Congress and the initial requests made by President Bush in January.
DOC.HEAD: TOTAL SPENDING
DOC.TEXT: Bush proposed spending $303 billion on defense in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Congress adopted a spending plan that calls for $268 billion for the Pentagon.
DOC.HEAD: STRATEGIC DEFENSE INITIATIVE
DOC.TEXT: Bush requested $4.7 billion for the antimissile shield, commonly known as Star Wars. Congress slashed the budget to $2.9 billion, a reduction of $700 million from last year's level.
DOC.HEAD: B-2 STEALTH BOMBER
DOC.TEXT: The administration proposed spending $4.6 billion on two planes in fiscal 1991 and parts for six planes in the next fiscal year. Congress provides $4.1 billion for the program, but does not specifically authorize the purchase of two radar-evading bombers.
DOC.HEAD: LAND-BASED NUCLEAR MISSILES
DOC.TEXT: Bush called for $2.2 billion for the MX missile and its plan to move the 50 missiles from fixed silos to rail cars. The administration also proposed spending $202 million on development of the Midgetman missile. Congress created a $680 million pot for the two missiles.
DOC.HEAD: TROOP CUTS
DOC.TEXT: The administration proposed a cut of 38,000 from the 2.1 million level of active duty forces. The bill adopts a reduction of 78,500.
DOC.HEAD: V-22 OSPREY
DOC.TEXT: For the second straight year, Bush proposed canceling the program to build the tilt-rotor aircraft, which takes off like a helicopter but flies like a plane. The legislation calls for $403 million in procurement and research money of the Marine Corps' aircraft in fiscal 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Weighs Visit To Saudi Arabia, Egypt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lede and INSERTS 5th graf: ``Later, aboard,'' to note Fitzwater quote on topics, including military options
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has asked Secretary of State James A. Baker III to visit Saudi Arabia early next month for a general discussion with Saudi leaders of the Persian Gulf standoff, including military options, the White House said Friday. It is ``not true'' that Baker will ask the Saudi government to approve military action against Iraq, said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``We want the United Nations resolutions to be complied with,'' Fitzwater said. There have been several Security Council resolutions demanding an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. No date has been set for the trip, Fitzwater said. Later, aboard Air Force One en route to Hawaii, Fitzwater said Baker would discuss ``the implementation of U.N. sanctions, the status of U.S. and multinational forces in the gulf, general defense needs, arab unity and military options.'' Fitzwater announced the trip in Los Angeles, where Bush was making a campaign appearance. The president, he said, discussed Persian Gulf matters by telephone from his hotel suite with German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti and Dutch Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers. Baker likely will stop in Egypt and possibly other countries as well, officials told The Associated Press. The secretary's itinerary will be set by Bush meeting with his four principal advisers - Baker, Cheney, national security adviser Brent Scowcroft and Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Colin Powell - one official said. A trip by Baker to the region would underscore U.S. resolve to force Iraq out of Kuwait, which it invaded 12 weeks ago. On Thursday, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said as many as 100,000 additional U.S. troops may be sent to the Persian Gulf in response to the continuing buildup and fortification of Iraqi occupation forces in Kuwait. Last month, Baker visited Saudi Arabia, Egypt and the United Arab Emirates. He also saw the ousted leaders of Kuwait during his visit to Taif, the Saudi summer capital. His purposes were to coordinate strategy against Iraq and obtain assistance from Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates to help offset the costs of the U.S. military buildup in the gulf. Officials who discussed a possible Baker trip with The Associated Press before Fitzwater's announcement said Baker's time would be squeezed if he went. The United States wants new Security Council resolutions against Iraq, and Baker will have to be involved in planning for those. Among the resolutions would be a demand that Iraq pay reparations for its annexation of Kuwait and seizure of the emirate's oil-fields. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is a strong advocate of the measure. These officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Baker's trip would have three purposes: to review the campaign against Iraq, to make further preparations and to discuss the campaign at the United Nations which the Bush administration hopes to push into high gear. And yet, they said, Baker has other commitments in the weeks ahead. He will attend, with the President, a 34-nation summit in Paris in mid-November and go with him to Monterrey, Mexico, after Thanksgiving. Also, Andreotti is visiting Washington next month.

DOC.HEAD: Journalist Wounded, Wife Killed in Ambush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Barrera quotes, new campaign developments. ADDS byline. No Pickup
DOC.TEXT: Two men riding a motorcycle shot and gravely wounded the director of a Central American news agency Friday in the second such attack on a journalist in two weeks. The journalist's wife died in the attack. Byron Barrera Ortiz, 37, was in critical condition. Slain was his wife Refugio Aracely de Barrera, 39, said Fire Department spokesman Haroldo Juarez. A friend of the couple, Luis Roberto Gatica, 25, was wounded. The three were driving in a car when the motorcyclist closed in and opened fire at close range. Humberto Gonzalez Gamarra, a radio station owner and leftist politician, was murdered in similar fashion on Oct. 15. Barrera's brother, Adolfo Barrera, blamed the attack Friday on right-wing extremists. Death squads linked to various security forces have been blamed for countless murders in Guatemala the last three decades, though such cases are rarely solved. ``Why did they assassinate Refugio?'' Byron Barrera asked of a small group of journalists who visited him in hospital. ``My dear wife was the innocent victim of acts of violence like this one that has orphaned my children.'' ``Too much blood is being shed, and what is worse is that no one is arrested,'' Barrera said, speaking with difficulty. Barrera said he became aware on Thursday that he was being watched, and advised Claudia Arenas Bianchi, the presidential spokeswoman. ``They were near my home and they followed me from there to my office,'' Barrera said. Bianchi said Friday that President Vinicio Cerezo had ordered an investigation. ``The government reiterates its determination to look for those responsible in order to overcome this situation that brings mourning to Guatemalan society,'' she said. Barrera fled into exile in Mexico during the 1978-82 presidency of Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia, a crest of official terror during which thousands of labor leaders, politicians and social reformers were killed or disappeared. He returned in 1986, after an elected civilian government took office, and founded a liberal newspaper, La Epoca. The newspaper was forced to close last year after its plant was destroyed in a fire also blamed on rightists. Barrera, who is also vice president of the Guatemalan Journalists' Association, left Guatemala for Costa Rica after the fire, but returned to head the Central American News Agency, known by its Spanish acronym ACEN-SIAG. There has been a sharp rise in political violence blamed on the far right the past year. Cerezo, a Christian Democrat, has been sharply criticized for failing to curb human rights violations. The climate has been particularly tense the past few weeks as the Nov. 11 general elections near. One leading candidate, former President Jose Efrain Rios Montt, a retired general, was ruled ineligible because of a constitutional clause that prohibits former dictators from being elected president. But Rios Montt has continued to campaign, and accused Cerezo's government of plotting electoral fraud. Another candidate, Alfonso Cabrera Hidalgo of Cerezo's centrist Christian Democratic Party, has been critically ill in the hospital since Wednesday with acute inflammation of the pancreas. Cerezo decided to cancel a trip to Honduras because of his friend's illness, said Foreign Minister Ariel Rivera Irias. Both she and Col. Carlos Fernando Duran, the army spokesman, denied rumors Cerezo had postponed his trip due to restiveness in the army because of Rios Montt's removal from the presidential race. Besides Rios Montt, the presidential field includes 12 candidates.

DOC.HEAD: Trial To Be Held In El Paso Despite Publicity
DOC.TEXT: A convicted rapist accused of killing six women and girls and burying them in the desert will be tried here despite wide publicity about the case, a judge ruled Friday. District Judge Peter Peca decided against ruling on a motion he filed himself earlier this month to move the trial of David Leonard Wood outside the city. But Peca also said he will make a list of alternate venues if attorneys are unable to find an unbiased jury in El Paso. Wood denies he killed the women. Despite the publicity, neither prosecutors nor Wood's attorneys wanted to move the trial, which was set to begin Jan. 14. A grand jury indicted Wood on July 13 on capital murder charges in the deaths of of six El Paso women. Their bodies were found between Sept. 4, 1987, and March 14, 1988, in shallow graves about 18 miles northeast of El Paso. Wood is serving a 50-year sentence for a 1987 rape that occurred near where the bodies were found. If convicted of the capital murder charges, he could face life in prison or the death penalty.

DOC.HEAD: Parents Accused of Taking Toddler Plan to Fight Extradition
DOC.TEXT: A couple who say they snatched their ailing child from a Tennessee welfare office out of love plan to fight extradition attempts in a legal tangle that started with a stolen car, a lawyer said Friday. ``The correct result from the standpoint of the child is for him to remain in Massachusetts and for the family to be reunited,'' said Meade Burrows, the father's attorney. ``They have family here and the baby was being treated by doctors here,'' he said. The couple appeared at a hearing before U.S. Magistrate Michael A. Ponsor. Paul Thaddeus Komorowski, 28, and his pregnant wife, Candy, 18, were jailed after they called the FBI Wednesday from a friend's home in nearby Chicopee and surrendered with their 23-month-old son, John Paul. They said they wanted to spend time with the child, who has tested positive for the AIDS virus. The parents were accused of making off with their son after visiting him at a Bristol, Tenn., welfare office Oct. 17. ``We love him so much and there is not much time in his life,'' Komorowski said. ``We gave him a good time and did things like visit Disney World and went swimming, things he may never be able to do again. And he was fine. He did not get sick,'' he said in an interview before his arrest. The couple's troubles in Tennessee began in June as they were driving through he state on their way to Texas and the boy suffered a seizure, said Kenneth Neiman, Mrs. Komorowski's lawyer. Driving to a hospital they were pulled over by police, who discovered the car had been reported stolen in Massachusetts. The police arrested Komorowski. When Springfield police declined to seek extradition, the father was indicted on Tennessee charges of possession of stolen property. Komorowski spent three months in jail before pleading guilty Sept. 6. He was then placed on one year's probation. Meanwhile, the Tennessee Department of Human Services obtained legal custody of the child, Neiman said. Now Tennessee officials want the parents brought back to face charges of interfering with custodial care. Ponsor set hearings on the request for next Friday. Even if the judge agrees, more hearings would be required in Massachusetts courts before Tennessee authorities could take the parents, lawyers said. The baby was examined by doctors and ``seems to be doing fine,'' said Lorraine Carli, a spokeswoman for the Massachusetts Department of Social Services. She said the baby was placed temporarily in a foster home and doctors were conducting tests to further check his condition.

DOC.HEAD: Midshipman Expelled for Sexual Misconduct
DOC.TEXT: A midshipman was expelled from the Naval Academy for having sex on campus with a woman who had accused him of rape. The junior midshipman, who was not identified by the academy, was initially accused of raping the woman, but academy spokesman Noel Milan said investigators never found enough evidence to support the allegation. ``Very early on, it was determined that there was not enough evidence to proceed with the (rape) case,'' Milan said. The student told authorities he met the woman at a downtown bar, brought her back to the academy and had sex with her early May 13, a Navy official said. The midshipman was found guilty of violating a rule that bars midshipmen from having sex on academy grounds and expelled earlier this month, Milan said. Officials are considering whether the midshipman may also have to reimburse the academy for his education. ``That decision is yet to be made,'' Milan said. The expelled student may be required to serve time in the Navy or reimburse the Navy for the cost of his education. The expulsion is the latest of several reports of mistreatment involving the 4,500-student academy. Annapolis police are investigating a report that a midshipman broke into a woman's home Sept. 8 and chased her around her house until she locked herself in a bedroom. A female midshipman resigned last spring after reporting she was handcuffed to a urinal. Other women and minorities later came forward with stories of mistreatment at the academy by male officers and students.

Drivers, smokers and drinkers are about to be socked to cut the federal deficit. But many wealthy Americans, especially those with big families, may feel they're being soaked. A $150 billion, five-year tax increase making its way through Congress would hit especially hard at high-income people. One new provision affecting the well-to-do is being criticized as nothing less than a tax on children. It would phase out the tax saving from personal exemptions as family income rises above $150,000 a year. Losing that tax saving would have the effect of raising the marginal tax rate on those families - and the larger the family, the higher the rate. ``The dependent exemption is the most vital pro-family feature of the income tax code,'' Gary L. Bauer, president of the conservative Family Research Council, said Thursday. ``By phasing out this exemption, members of Congress are thumbing their noses at the practice of adjusting tax liability to reflect differences in household size.'' ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - The Pentagon is sending additional troops to Saudi Arabia partly to counter a recent hardening of Iraq's defenses in occupied Kuwait, officials say. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Thursday that more American GIs - possibly as many as 100,000 - will be shipped to the Saudi desert to join the 220,000 U.S. forces already in the Persian Gulf area following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. He said no final decision has been made on which additional units will be sent. Cheney and other officials said the troop addition does not signal a switch in U.S. policy from defending against a possible Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia to laying the groundwork for an offensive against Iraq. ---= MOSCOW (AP) - Kazakhstan has become the 14th of the 15 Soviet republics to declare sovereignty, defying the national legislature and banning nuclear tests on its territory in Central Asia, Soviet media reported. The action Thursday came after environmental activists claimed Kazakhstan's 15 million people suffer an elevated cancer rate and other health problems because it is the site of one of the country's main testing grounds for nuclear warheads. In Moldavia today, authorities in the republic bordering Romania planned to send police to the Gagauz region, where an ethnic minority has declared sovereignty and begun holding elections. Busloads of college-age volunteers were also headed for the area today. ---= LOS ANGELES (AP) - Republicans enlisted Bart Simpson without his permission, Chevy Chase added $50,000 to Dianne Feinstein's campaign and Angela Lansbury was lambasted for what critics called ``Distortions, She Wrote.'' It's lights, camera and political action in Hollywood, where a few golden words from a celebrity can speak decibels louder than dozens of stump speeches by politicians. Movie and television stars are getting behind gubernatorial candidates from both parties, as well as Big Green, a sweeping state environmental initiative. ``There are many entertainers who by their past work have become trusted by the public, and for them to research and then support an issue like Big Green helps us spread the word,'' said initiative spokesman Duane Peterson. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - Management published the Daily News today despite a strike. Delivery trucks driven by non-union replacement drivers ran a gantlet of pickets throwing rocks and bottles. Police reported seven arrests but no serious injuries. The strike called Thursday night at the nation's second-largest metropolitan daily newspaper capped a 10-month dispute over management's efforts to gain more control over operations. Police in riot gear escorted delivery trucks out of a Daily News printing plant in Kearny, N.J., through hundreds of strikers hurling bricks, stones, eggs and bottles. Vehicle windows were covered with protective tape to prevent shattered glass from injuring those inside. ---= STRASBURG, N.D. (AP) - Resentment is bubbling over congressional approval of $500,000 to restore the birthplace of Lawrence Welk, the king of champagne music. The project's leader defended the plan to renovate the sod farmhouse where Welk was born and develop a German-Russian history museum and other tourist attractions. ``People are saying we're taking money away from farmers. It's not so,'' Rosemary Schaefbauer, president of Welk Heritage Inc., said Thursday. ``This money was allocated for rural development. North Dakota is going to benefit a whole lot from it.'' The grant is included in a $52.2 billion agricultural appropriations bill that the House passed Monday and sent to President Bush.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv29 ^For release Monday PMs, Oct 29, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Dolly Parton Says ``Merry Christmas'' - In October
DOC.TEXT: There are those who would say ``Bah, humbug!'' to the idea of taping a Christmas show in October. Dolly Parton is not one of them. In fact, she was talking about it on the phone recently from her East Tennessee theme park, Dollywood, in Pigeon Force. She had just finished a Christmas show there that ABC will air in early December. She even admitted to doing a little studio work on the show in July, when she also recorded a Christmas album with the same name as her special - ``Home for Christmas.'' Weird as it may sound, it isn't all that unusual for show folk with busy schedules to tape their Christmas specials a tad early, even during muggy summers, when Santa's ``ho-ho-ho'' is more of a ``gasp-gasp-gasp.'' It's not odd, she said, ``not if if you're a show person and not if that's the only way you can do it. And if you've got a child-like spirit, which I do, you can make it happen nearly all the time.'' The tiny star, whose nature tends to be sunny side up, has had a good run as a singer, songwriter and actress, despite such accidents as the film version of ``Best Little Whorehouse in Texas.'' Last year, she was in a film success as a co-star of ``Steel Magnolias.'' This brought new film and television offers, she reports: ``Anytime you have a successful thing, it always opens up new stuff for you.'' In the wings, for example, is a gospel musical film for Paramount, ``Sister Sunshine,'' about the rise and fall of a female evangelist, she says. She's also recording a new album next month, ``Eagle When She Flies.'' And farther down the country road is a planned TV movie - all three networks are interested, she says - she'd film in Nashville. It's called ``Beula Faye.'' She hopes it'd lead to a TV series, also done in Nashville. The film is about the country music business, she said. She'd play ``a singer-host of a television show. It's about the lifestyle, about being on the road and work in the studio and trying to keep the business running. ``It's something I've wanted to do for a long time, and basically it's what I had tried and wanted to do with my other TV show that got so out of hand.'' She meant ABC's splashy ``Dolly'' variety series of 1987, yet another network attempt to apply Hollywood flash to country music. Begun in a blaze of publicity, it fizzled out in one season. ``It never really got off on the right foot,'' Parton said, although she readily took responsiblity for what happened. ``It was so hyped, had so much attention drawn to it, we never really had a chance.'' When and if she returns to a TV series in ``Beula Faye,'' she said, ``I hope not to advertise it all that much, and just let the people decide. At least it won't be under such a magnifying glass.'' That was one main problem with ``Dolly,'' she said. The other was ``too many chiefs and not enough Indians.'' By chiefs she meant a swarm of executives from New York and Hollywood who ran around the show, issuing orders, giving advice, changing orders and throwing Tums at each other. She indicated it might have been wise to have the Jolly Green Giant sit on them until each show was finished. ``But it's okay,'' she said. ``I learned a lot from it, a lot of things not to do.'' A major ``not'' is not to do another series in any place but Nashville. ``Most of these people ain't willing to move to the South,'' she said. ``I'd be safe here.'' --- Elsewhere in television... DEPT. OF SUSAN LUCCI: Susan Lucci, the world's most Emmy-nominated co-star of ABC's ``All My Children,'' seems to be starring this month in what you might call ``All My Networks.'' She did a stint on NBC's ``Saturday Night Live,'' then appeared Oct.21 on ABC in ``The Bride Wore Black,'' playing a woman left at the altar because her beloved was gunned down before the wedding. This Friday, she returns to the widow business as the mysterious Sheila Foley in the season premiere of CBS' venerable ``Dallas.'' End Adv PM Mon Oct. 29
