DOC.HEAD: Economy Falls, Voter Tempers Rise
DOC.TEXT: America burned while Washington fiddled. That's what Albert Sindlinger said to himself as the numbers came from his computers. They showed 10 more states had fallen into recession in the two weeks ended October 22, while Congress debated and delayed the budget. ``I was prepared for bad news,'' he said, ``but nothing like this.'' Sindlinger, a student of economics and politics for more than 60 years, has been analyzing them professionally for more than three decades. His information comes from the people. His staff telephones hundreds each week. Much of the resulting information is distributed to corporate customers, whose marketing departments pay dearly for it, and to analysts of various sorts. Washington, too. His latest report, he says, will wake them up. That report shows a deepening recession that envelopes the District of Columbia and all but 10 of the lower 48 contiguous states. The rest are weakening steadily. He does not measure Alaska or Hawaii. The 10 states that fell into recession during the past two weeks included what had been some of the strongest, such as Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin, ``states that had been holding the economy together.'' They not only fell, he said, they fell badly. They leave only Nevada, Washington and Oregon still safely in economic plus territory. The others - Idaho, Montana, Utah, Wyoming, Missouri, Minnesota and Kansas - are borderline. Among the questions asked by Sindlinger & Co. from its office in Wallingford, Pa., is one on the president's popularity. That too has taken a nosedive, from 82.6 percent positive on Sept. 17 to 54.9 percent Oct. 22. Especially irritating, he says, is that much of the economic and political damage could have been avoided. He contends that if government hadn't fudged job and gross national product figures, a recession would have been obvious. Had that been the case, the threat of automatic cuts via the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Act would have been lifted, and so also the necessity of making drastic budget cuts. A recession threat would have delayed enforcement. Instead, Congress remained confronted with the threat of automatic cuts, sought to avoid that eventuality but instead got caught up in what much of the country viewed as a futile debate. The economy sank, said Sindlinger. The octogenarian analyst, who says he got some of his polling ideas from none other than a pre-White House Herbert Hoover, knows all this, he says, because survey respondents express their feelings in each 12-minute interview. ``They're scared to death,'' he said. ``They're angry, concerned and disgusted.'' Moreover, he said, their pocketbooks are hurting. Sindlinger's staff determines if a household is in recession through a measurement it calls household liquidity, based on answers to four questions. A household is said to have negative liquidity when any question is answered negatively, and a state is said to be in recession when more than half the households fall into the negative category. These are the questions: 1. Is total combined household annual income up or the same as it was six months ago? 2. Will the total combined household's annual income remain the same or be higher six months from now? 3. Will there be more or the same number of jobs where you work six months hence? 4. Will business conditions be the same or better in your community six months from now? Eight hundred five calls were made in the week ended October 22, making a total of 3,283 for the four weeks September 28 - October 22. Those 3,283 sample calls were projected to be representative of 90.82 million telephone households and a total of 156.47 million heads of households. Of the latter, only 61.006 million, or about 39 percent, had positive liquidity. To Sindlinger, the big political question is whether a disgruntled public will simply stay home and not vote, or will they vote and take out their anger on incumbents?

DOC.HEAD: IMF, in Search of More Space, Building New Home for Neighboring Church
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The International Monetary Fund, which pumps billions of dollars into debt-plagued economies around the world, is taking on a project closer to home - building a new church for a small congregation that's been its neighbor since 1973. Some time in the next few weeks, the IMF expects to close a deal to acquire the quarter-acre property of the Western Presbyterian Church, bringing to a close negotiations that began in the 1960s. In return, the fund is buying a new site, a few blocks away, where it will build Western Presbyterian a new, slightly larger home with a kitchen for feeding the homeless. It will move the church's English Gothic sanctuary, fieldstone by fieldstone and stained glass window by stained glass window, and rebuild it as part of the new structure. Not only that, it will provide Western Presbyterian with an endowment, reported to be $4 million, to do such things as construct housing for the homeless and help two congregations in Ghana build churches. All in all, counting acquisition costs and an $8.5 million construction budget, the deal totals around $22.5 million. So how did a church with about 135 worshipers on a good Sunday come into such a bonanza? One might say by being in the right place at the right time. In the 1960s, the IMF, a specialized agency of the United Nations with the mission of stabilizing currency exchange, found itself short of space and in need of a new home. It found the location it wanted, three blocks from the White House and next door to the World Bank. ``Since the block was residentially zoned at the time, the only way the IMF could get the bulk and density it wanted for an office building was to offer forth a plan that contemplated developing the entire block,'' said James B. Kaiser, IMF projects manager. There was just one problem. The Western Presbyterian congregation didn't want to move from the block. The church, started in 1855, was already in its third home. Its first was a warehouse not far from the new site. After a few years there, the congregation built a new church across the street from its present structure. It moved to its current location in 1935. ``The sanctuary is gorgeous, and they didn't want to lose that,'' said the Rev. John W. Wimberly Jr., pastor of Western Presbyterian. Also, they might have had to move out into the suburbs, where land prices are somewhat cheaper. ``There was considerable sentiment about the symbolic value of having the building located here, in the middle of what people call the Wall Street of the World,'' Wimberly said. So the IMF proceeded to develop the rest of the block, finishing one phase in 1973 and the second 10 years later, with the church nestled into a U-shaped green space. Meanwhile the fund's staff continued to grow. It now numbers about 2,000 from 100 countries. Since only 1,700 could be squeezed into the building, the agency paid an estimated $3 million a year to lease office space for the other 300. ``It came to our attention a couple of years ago that there had been some changes that would make it more favorable for us to reopen negotiations,'' said Kaiser. The church was growing, too. When Wimberly became its pastor in 1983, he said, there had been about 90 people in the congregation and most of them were over 65. Now about half of the 135 worshipers are 45 or younger. Western Presbyterian began feeding the homeless, and now feeds about 200, using a kitchen designed for potluck suppers. It threw open its doors for noontime meetings of Alcoholics Anonymous and groups grappling with drug problems. The church was still reluctant to move, and the IMF asked if there were any conditions under which the congregation might consider it. Western Presbyterian listed some: -They wouldn't leave the neighborhood. -IMF would have to rebuild the sanctuary as it was. -They would need a commercial kitchen to feed the homeless. -They wanted air conditioning and underground parking, neither of which the present church has. -IMF would pay the lawyers and the architects. -The job would be done in phases, so the congregation would not miss a day of worship or the homeless miss a meal. -IMF would create an endowment to enable the church to expand its mission. ``We debated it at great length and finally took a vote and the vote was 2-1 in favor of making the move,'' Wiberly said. The executive board of the IMF also approved. Architect David Cox said it is hoped that construction can start in the spring and be completed in about two years. Kaiser said IMF hopes to start work on its expansion at that time. ``The fact the IMF was willing to take the sanctuary with us, I think, was at the crux of it,'' said Wimberly. ``We could say, `When you go down there, you're not going to be worshiping in some glass palace or something.' People become very, very involved with the place where they worship. It is a beautiful sanctuary. There is something very humble in its beauty that kind of matches a lot of the people that worship here.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, Oct. 30

DOC.HEAD: New Choice for Options Traders
DOC.TEXT: Though they were planted in a less than ideal climate, the seeds of a new investment product appear to be taking root on Wall Street. The securities in question, known as long-term stock options, made their debut Oct. 5 at the Chicago Board Options Exchange and the American Stock Exchange. Since then the number of these options outstanding in the two markets has increased steadily, surpassing 6,000 by late lsst week. Observers describe that as a respectable showing, especially given the depressed state of enthusiasm right now for just about anything associated with stocks. ``It's very hard to persuade people to enter the stock market these days, let alone the options market,'' says Harrison Roth, an options specialist at the firm of Cowen & Co. ``It's still a little too early to tell, but I think this product will be successful.'' At the CBOE these vehicles are known by the trademarked anagram LEAPS, for long-term equity anticipation securities. The Amex has been content so far with the generic name long-term stock options. Whatever you call them, they are closely related to the short-term options on individual stocks that have been bought and sold on Wall Street for decades in two basic forms: Calls, which give their owners the right to buy a specified stock at a set price within a stated time period, and puts, which carry the right to sell the stock in question under similar terms. Conventional puts and calls traded in organized markets generally have lives of nine months or less. The new long-term options, by contrast, can run for as long as almost two years. To would-be speculators in options, that can represent a big difference. They might, for instance, feel much more confident staking their money on the chances for a market recovery by mid-1992 than by next spring or summer. But the extra time comes at a price. Last Thursday, for example, when the stock price of Merck & Co. stood at $81.87, a call option to buy 100 shares at $95 between now and January went for $50, excluding commissions. LEAPS at that same price, not due to expire until July of 1992, traded at $687.50 apiece, reflecting the significantly better chance that Merck stock will climb above $95 in the next 15 months than within 90 days or so. That example illustrates how important it is in options trading to be able to evaluate relative levels of option ``premiums'' - the time value built into their prices over and above their worth if they were exercised immediately. In some ways at least, long-term options can be seen as a more conservative vehicle than their established short-term cousins. Roth suggests that investors who can't commit the time and energy required for short-term options trading may have a better chance at operating successfully in the long-term arena. ``You still have to keep track of your investment,'' he advises, ``but you may not need to monitor it every day hour-by-hour.'' Furthermore, if strategies employed with long-term options require less frequent buying and selling than is common with short-term contracts, the burden of commission costs can be lightened. No matter what the scheduled life of a stock option, some things remain the same. A call on a stock that never reaches the exercise price can be relied on to approach a value of zero by the time it expires. Risks can be even greater for investors who ``write'' (create and sell) calls on stock they don't own, or engage in other unprotected maneuvers. Says Roth: ``The obvious comment here has to be `look before you LEAP.'''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Oct. 29

DOC.HEAD: One Year Later, a Nation and a World Transformed
LaserPhotos planned
DOC.TEXT: The opening of the Berlin Wall did far more than allow East Germans to dance across broken concrete into the dazzling world outside. It let the outside world come in. Less than a year later, two nations were wiped off the map and replaced with one. Breaching the barrier was a desperate act by a dying regime trying to placate a people massed in revolt. Although the opening of the wall Nov. 9, 1989, took the unromantic form of lifting travel restrictions, everyone recognized it as the end of the Cold War's most famous symbol. It was the dominant image in a breathtaking year of revolution in the Soviet bloc. What no one predicted was the resulting maelstrom of forces that led to German unity, an inexorable process that forced the superpowers to recognize a new world order and reach new levels of cooperation. Today, the nation that built the Berlin Wall is a territory transformed, no longer a Communist state, no longer a closed society, no longer a nation. It is a region whose destiny lies completely in the hands of people who live in what used to be another country. Uniting with mighty West Germany has given the East Germans an experienced hand to lead them and a mattress stuffed with money to rest on. But it also has forced the old nation to make Eastern Europe's fastest, most turbulent, most radical transition to a free-market democracy after four decades of sleepy, unchanging communism. Poland, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Romania and Hungary are proceeding much more gently, by comparison dipping a toe into the cold waters of capitalism as they peer through the dust and smoke of their revolutions. So swiftly has East Germany become distinct from its neighbors that ``it is inaccurate and unfair to even compare them,'' said Heinrich Vogel, an analyst at the Federal Institute for Eastern Economic and International Studies in Cologne. He said eastern Germany is in ``a distinctly privileged situation,'' sharing a language, legal system, government, currency and borders with a rich and stable region. East Germany also has thrown its fate to the West, however, while the other former Soviet satellites still have autonomy and some control of their destiny on the longer, less certain road to prosperity. What eastern Germany has in common with the other former Communist states are profound similarities in public mood. ``They are all sharing exaggerated expectations to a large extent,'' Vogel said. ``They have all inherited the structural handicaps, the mental decay, the system of mistrusting each other and society.'' In eastern Germany, Westerners have seized control swiftly, from the man in charge of selling its factories to the governor of its largest state to clever squatters who have claimed its vacant tenements. Leading eastern politicians have western campaign managers and aides. The East German women's swimming team, which dominated the world for years, has a West German coach. Children who have been drilled their entire classroom lives in the correctness of communism are using estern textbooks. The food in the old nation's stores, the cars on its streets, the money in its banks and the flag flown atop its public buildings - all have changed in the single year from revolution to reunifiction. Political extremism, overt racism, crime and drug abuse have crept through the wall or simmered up from the darkest corners of a long-suppressed national psyche. Embracing the West has ruined the homegrown economy and its overstaffed, inefficient enterprises, which once were the strongest of the Soviet bloc but now are literally being killed by the competition. Since March, about one-fourth of the 8 million workers in eastern Germany have lost their jobs or are working fewer hours at lower, government-subsidized wages. A recent report by the five leading German economic institutes said nearly 4 million could be in the same situation next year, and that the pace of recovery was much slower than expected. Except for some perky areas of the service industry, virtually no sector of the eastern economy can survive without western help, said economist Heine Flassbeck of Berlin, one of the report's authors. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government, facing national elections Dec. 2, has dismissed the report as too pessimistic. Hans Peter Stihl, president of the German Chamber of Commerce, said a new survey showed half of all western German businesses will have invested in the east by the end of 1991. If there is disagreement over the timetable for eastern Germany's elevation to western standards, there is little doubt about its inevitability. On a single day soon after the Germanys were joined Oct. 3, three unrelated announcements illustrated why East Germany was more fortunate than its old Warsaw Pact allies: -Mercedes-Benz said it would begin building cars at a struggling East German truck plant near Berlin, saving or creating 6,000 jobs. -The government increased pensions to help 2.7 million retired people pay higher prices and rents. -Another department announced plans to spend 10 billion marks ($6.5 billion) on fixing up 300,000 homes. Romania, Poland and the other former Communist states could use a day like that, but many of citizens have decided not to wait for it. Thousands of Eastern Europeans have poured into eastern Germany in hopes it will be the new gateway to the West, creating a German immigration crisis. Soviet soldiers, who once died by the millions fighting the Nazis and now must leave the nation they conquered, are deserting in hundreds and asking to stay. Even Jews, subjected to hideous crimes under Hitler, are arriving from the Soviet Union in search of better lives. All this in a country millions of people could not wait to leave last year, where pent-up desperation brought down the hard-line Communist leader, Erich Honecker. The uprising forced his successor, Egon Krenz, to bow even more to the masses and do the unbelievable: change history in a single autumn day by opening the Berlin Wall.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, Nov. 5

DOC.HEAD: A Year Ago, as the Wall Came Down
With AM-After the Wall
DOC.TEXT: They came by the millions, pouring through the new gaps in the Berlin Wall, rejoicing in the simple ability to move freely in their city for the first time in nearly three decades. When East Germany suddenly announced on Nov. 9, 1989 that it was opening its borders, I witnessed an outpouring of joy that became the biggest party Berlin has ever seen. It was nearly 7 p.m. when the stunning announcement was made at a news conference in East Berlin. I jumped into a car and toured several border crossings at the wall. Confused guards on both sides still could not say exactly when unhindered passage would be allowed. As midnight approached, thousands of East Germans massed on the eastern side of the barrier that symbolized the Cold War. At midnight, they rushed through crossing points, some on foot, some in sputtering Trabant cars. West Berliners greeted them with champagne, tapping on the roofs of the cars in boisterous welcome. At Checkpoint Charlie, Germans from both sides kissed, cried for joy and danced. Relatives embraced for the first time in a generation. I saw East German border guards transformed in minutes from dour, arrogant guardians of communism into friendly helpers, smiling and chatting with West Berlin police. They even stopped checking documents. Hundreds of people danced atop the wal at the Brandenburg Gate in one of the most memorable scenes of that incredible Thursday night. By 2 a.m., West Berlin was one gigantic party. Thousands of people streamed along the glittering Kurfuerstendamm outside the Associated Press office. Authorities had closed the street to traffic and it became a sea of people, ebbing and flowing in the chilly night to marvel at the wonders of capitalism. A giant screen on a department store alternated announcements that the wall was open with flashes of ``Welcome, Welcome'' to the visitors from the east. Hardly anyone slept in Berlin. Bars stayed open through the night, offering free drinks to East Germans. At 5 a.m., I set out on the 10-minute walk from the AP office to my hotel, and spent nearly an hour wading through the dancing and singing crowds. Strangers hugged me. Others handed me paper cups filled with champagne. At 8 a.m., I watched the East Germans open a large section of the wall at Bernauer Strasse, where some of the most spectacular escapes and bloody failures had taken place. That weekend, Berlin became one, months before the official reunification of Germany.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, Nov. 5

DOC.HEAD: Emigres Who Helped Bring the Wall Down Still Prefer the West
With AM-After The Wall
DOC.TEXT: When Bernhard Leich and his family loaded their Trabi for the long trip to freedom a year ago, he had no idea they were helping arrange East Germany's funeral. The Leichs are among tens of thousands of East Germans whose flight through Hungary and Czechoslovakia helped reunite the nation. They have a good life in western Germany now, in the Bavarian town of Hof. On Oct. 2, 1989, Leich, his wife Christine and their two children chugged for Prague in their blue Trabant to join other East Germans waiting to go West. ``At the border, customs officials tore our car apart and asked us endless questions, like `Don't the children have to go to school?' and `Where are you going to stay?'' Leich recalled. They crossed into Czechoslovakia and reached Prague, left the car and went by taxi to the West German Embassy. More than 10,000 East Germans waiting for trains to take them West had turned the embassy grounds into a squalid refugee camp. After two nights there, the refugees crowded into the unheated cars of special trains East Germany provided for the last leg of their journey to freedom. In the first part of the trip, through southern East Germany, police beat back people who tried to jump aboard as the trains passed slowly through stations. Leich, 33, saw a young woman with a child trying to board at Plauen, East Germany. A security officer led the woman away. ``People were screaming out the windows, but there was nothing anyone could do,'' he said. On Oct. 5, The Leichs' train arrived at Hof. On Nov. 9, East Germany opened the Berlin Wall in a desperate attempt to stop the mass flight. Bernhard Leich found work as an electrician in Hof and Christine is a saleswoman. Daniel, 8, likes his school and Stefanie, 5, has new friends. Chancellor Helmut Kohl recommended last month that emigres return to eastern Germany to help build the united country, but Leich says that's out of the question. ``I've been able to put my own life back together in the year I've been here,'' he said. ``My wife and I have jobs, a home and the kids are happy. If we went back, we'd have to start out all over again.'' There are reports that the exodus from former East Germany has not stopped since the union Oct. 3. German news reports say people from poor eastern Germany have been crossing into the wealthy west at the rate of 30,000 a month. Leich never got his Trabi back and isn't sure where it is. ``I was told it was taken back to the DDR (East Germany), but I haven't been able to find it,'' he said. ``Maybe some old Communist has it now.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, Nov. 5

DOC.HEAD: Democrats in Tough Races in Nation's Largest States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for 18th graf pvs, Minnesota was, to UPDATE with write-in campaign in Minnesota governor's race.
DOC.TEXT: Democrats expect to improve their hold on the nation's governorships this year, but they face tough battles to wrest control of the largest states from the Republicans. Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste, the head of the Democratic Governors' Association, predicts a net gain of one to four governorships for his party this year. Republicans, who gained eight seats when many of these same governors were up four years ago, would be content just to hold their own this time. Democrats have the upper hand in the nation's statehouses going into the elections, controlling 29 governorships to the GOP's 21. But the party that controls the biggest states will be pleased no matter the outcome of the rest. ``Much more important than the raw number of gains or losses is which states go which way,'' says political analyst Charlie Cook. ``Unlike House or Senate seats, all governorships are not created equal, and it is the megastates this year that really count.'' The reason is redistricting. Legislatures will draw new congressional district lines next year that may change of face of their U.S. House delegations. Both parties would like to hold the veto stamp in states facing big gains or losses in their congressional delegations. Republicans control the governorships in four of the biggest states that are up this year: California, Texas, Florida and Illinois. California's legislature will figure out how to distribute as many as seven new congressional seats next year, based on the state's population gain in preliminary Census figures. Democrats control the legislature there, and Republicans say they need the governorship to ensure a fair map. Texas and Florida will gain new House seats too, while Illinois stands to lose two seats. In only one of those states, Florida, is the incumbent seeking re-election. Florida Gov. Bob Martinez has come from behind to a virtual tie with Democratic challenger Lawton Chiles, the former senator. The high-stakes California race is considered deadlocked too. Republican Sen. Pete Wilson faces Democrat Dianne Feinstein, the former mayor of San Francisco. Republican Gov. George Deukmejian is retiring after two terms. In Texas, flamboyant Republican Clayton Williams has held a lead over Democrat Ann Richards. Richards has pulled closer in recent polls, however, and has accused Williams' campaign of encouraging reports she once used drugs. In Illinois, Republican Jim Edgar once led in his bid to replace retiring Gov. Jim Thompson. But in a reversal of normal tax rhetoric it is the Democrat, Neil Hartigan, who has trumpeted a no-tax pledge to turn the race into a tossup. Among the Democratic governors who control big states, Michigan's Gov. Jim Blanchard has a substantial lead in his bid for a third term. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo is a sure thing for re-election. So is Pennsylvania Gov. Bob Casey, the most prominent anti-abortion Democrat. In other contested states that Democrats now control: - Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis retires reviled just two years after leading his party to presidential defeat. Democrat John Silber, a university president, won the nomination in a repudiation of Dukakis. He leads his GOP opponent, although Republican William Weld is within striking distance. - Republican George Voinovich, the former Cleveland mayor, leads in the Ohio governor's race, where Democrat Celeste is retiring. The Democratic candidate, Anthony Celebrezze, has tried to make his support for abortion rights a deciding issue. But Celebrezze has been criticized for his dramatic switch from an abortion opponent late last year. - Minnesota was a state Republicans had hopes of reclaiming from Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich. But Republican Jon Grunseth's chances plummeted with allegations that he swam nude with teen-age girls at a party nine years ago and invited some as young as 13 and 14 to join him. GOP primary loser Arne Carlson has entered as a write-in candidate, and Grunseth went to the brink of withdrawal before deciding to remain in the race. Republican frustration with the turmoil is increased by polls showing a variety of GOP candidates other than Grunseth would defeat Perpich in a two-way race. ``Our base simply is not big enough to cut it in half,'' said Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., who has his own re-election worries. ``We're going to have to some way repair that situation.'' - Democrats are in danger of losing Connecticut, where Gov. William O'Neill is retiring. The Democratic nominee is running third behind former GOP Sen. Lowell Weicker, who is running as an independent. - In Oregon, another state where a Democrat is retiring, the race between Republican Dave Frohnmayer and Democrat Barbara Roberts is close. Republican incumbents are in danger in at least four states: Rhode Island, Nebraska, Kansas and Maine. Worst for Republicans is Rhode Island, where Gov. Ed DiPrete is far behind Democrat Bruce Sundlun, who lost to DiPrete in the last two elections. Nebraska Gov. Kay Orr and her Kansas neighbor, Mike Hayden, both have been in trouble for tax increases, but both have narrowed the gap by which they trailed Democratic challengers. Hayden has rebounded as his Democratic opponent, Joan Finney, has struggled to explain her opposition to abortion. Recent polls have shown Hayden winning the women's vote. Maine's Republican Gov. John McKernan has also made a partial recovery in the polls but still faces a tough race with Joseph Brennan, a former governor who replaced McKernan in Congress four years ago. Among other Republican incumbents, Alabama's Guy Hunt and Iowa's Terry Branstad both hold leads against strong challengers. Republicans face uphill battles to hang on in Oklahoma and New Mexico, where GOP incumbents are retiring. Democrats expect to hang on to the Arizona seat, which they took over when Republican Gov. Evan Mecham was impeached. In Alaska, the entry of former GOP Gov. Walter Hickel as third-party candidate has confused a toss-up race. Former GOP Gov. Richard Snelling leads in Vermont, where the Democratic incumbent is retiring. Democratic incumbents have leads in polls or are rated likely winners in Colorado, Hawaii, Maryland, Nevada, Tennessee, Idaho and Wyoming. Republican incumbents are rated favorites in South Carolina, South Dakota, Wisconsin and New Hampshire.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Oct. 28

DOC.HEAD: Recession: Blame It On Credit
DOC.TEXT: By the time the current economic slump goes into the history books, many Wall Street analysts believe it will be recorded as a recession bought with credit. They see debt problems as by far the most menacing worry facing the stock market and the economy, overshadowing other issues like soaring oil prices and falling consumer confidence. Should widespread forecasts of only a moderate recession, ending some time next year, prove too optimistic, these observers say an upheaval in the banking and credit system will very likely be the culprit. In the same vein, they contend that an eventual recovery in economic growth, corporate profits and stock prices will depend to a great degree on how well the process of cleaning up the credit mess goes. ``The recession that we think began in the summer started like no other in the postwar period,'' said Jack Lavery, director of global research at Merrill Lynch. ``On the negative side, financial stresses are much more pronounced and widespread, and policymakers can do little to stimulate the economy. ``On the plus side, the excesses in the real economy, which usually intensify a downturn, are actually mild.'' If there is such a thing as a typical recession, it unfolds as unsold inventories of goods back up in the pipelines of the economy. That, in turn, forces manufacturers to cut back production. Unemployment heads upward with layoffs in the producing, distribution and retailing sectors of the economy as the business slowdown takes hold. The whole process begins to reverse, however, as the surplus inventories are worked off. This time around, analysts maintain, there is no glaring problem with inventories of conventional merchandise. Instead, they say, the system is clogged by bad debts and assets financed with those debts - most notably, real estate that nobody wants to buy or occupy. ``The easy credit conditions of the 1980s have led to excesses in both the real estate market and in corporate America,'' says Suresh Bhirud, chief portfolio strategist at Oppenheimer & Co. ``The banking systems' loan portfolios have suffered significant writeoffs as a result of these problems. ``The banks' ability to make new loans has diminished dramatically. This is not surprising considering that in many cases the balance sheet of the lender may be even weaker than that of the borrower. ``The bottom line is that even if there is a substantial easing by the monetary authorities, it would not necessarily lead to a turnaround in the economy.'' With such matters weighing on stock prices, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 84.65 points to 2,436.14 in the past week. The New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 3.69 to 166.71; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market lost 3.01 to 334.36, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was down 2.32 at 291.39. Volume on the Big Board averaged 143.98 million shares a day, against 180.28 million the week before. In the view of some analysts at least, a day of reckoning with debt has been a long time coming, and its effects may not be easily dispelled. Throughout most of the long expansion of the American economy after World War II, say economists David A. Levy and S. Jay Levy in Chappaqua, N.Y., memories of the Great Depression of the 1930s served as a strong influence for prudence. But eventually, the maintain, ``prudence waned. Consumers' qualms about incurring debt diminished. ``Speculators helped to bid up the prices of homes, other real estate, works of art and even household objects deemed to be `collectibles.' Conspicuous consumption was back. ``The waning of the prudence engendered by the Depression was reflected in the unwise financing of assets whose utility was questionable and whose prices were inflated.'' The Levys conclude: ``The fallout from these excesses will linger after the recession.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions Oct. 27-28
For Release Weekend Editions Oct. 27-28
DOC.HEAD: No Quick Fixes on Oil, the Budget or Banks
DOC.TEXT: For every worry about rising oil prices there's a hope that the Persian Gulf crisis will be settled and things will get quickly back to normal. Those hopes actually eroded some of the ``war premium'' on oil early this past week, but getting back to normal won't be as easy as knocking $5 or $10 off a $40 barrel of oil. Case in point: airlines. On Tuesday, Pan Am Corp. and UAL Corp. announced a $400 million deal that would give UAL, parent of United Airlines, most of Pan Am's valuable London routes. Within 48 hours another powerful player, American Airlines, had emerged to say it wanted to bid on the routes. Meanwhile, Continental Airlines was saying it had scrapped a plan to seek bankruptcy court protection but was still searching for ways to cut costs, including such measures as lightening planes by removing the ashtrays. The wrenching changes and desperate cost cutting promised to shift the balance of power in the industry dramatically - and more than temporarily. The high cost of jet fuel since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 was accelerating a Darwinian evolution already set in motion by increased competition and sluggish demand for air travel, the experts said. Robert J. Aaronson, president of the Air Transport Association of America, predicted ``some constriction'' and perhaps a ``total restructuring'' of the industry, should jet fuel prices remain at $1.25 per gallon or more, up from 60 cents before the Persian Gulf crisis. The industry association predicted that as the strong grew stronger and the weak looked for ways to shrink back to profitability, travelers would find fewer flights and higher fares.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: Gulf Trickles Down to Home Sales
DOC.TEXT: Not all the trickle-down effects of the Persian Gulf crisis have to do with oil prices. A real estate trade group said September sales of existing homes were down 8 percent, partly because so many potential homebuyers have been shipped to the Saudi desert for military duty. The South, where bases have dispatched big contingents, led the sales decline with a 10 percent drop.
DOC.HEAD: BUDGET: Does Agreement Mean Lower Rates?
DOC.TEXT: After so much haggling, few were cheering the latest federal budget agreement, which promised to cut the deficit by trimming spending and raising taxes. Before the first compromise fell apart earlier this month, expectations ran high that the Federal Reserve would answer the budget agreement with easier credit terms. The Fed could still come through with lower rates, but the spectacle of a president and Congress haplessly fumbling to reach agreement over the last few weeks has sapped public confidence, some experts said. If that drop in confidence restricts investment and consumer spending, the short-term economic benefits of the budget agreement could be severely limited. The new budget plan was a bit less stringent than its ill-fated predecessor, but still called for higher income taxes on the rich and stiffer excise taxes on gasoline, alcohol, cigarettes and luxury items. It also would cut spending on Medicare. The fiscal restraint, once viewed as a cure-all for the economy's ills, looked more like the first step on a long road to recovery.
DOC.HEAD: BANKERS: I'm OK, You're OK
DOC.TEXT: The nation's bankers convened in Orlando, Fla., in the shadow of Disney World, to kibitz on their mounting financial problems. The scene was the annual convention of the American Bankers' Association, a traditional getaway for the men and women of pinstripes. But even in the Magic Kingdom there was no escaping the deepening recession in the financial industry, nor the growing skepticism about the safety of banks and savings institutions. ABA President Richard A. Kirk, newly enthroned at the convention, said the public's trust in banking was the key issue facing the industry. Comptroller of the Currency Robert Clarke, known for frankness, was more blunt, blaming bankers themselves for precipitating a crisis of confidence. He faulted the industry for risky lending in real estate and said banks ought to raise more capital to cover potential lending losses and claims by depositors.
DOC.HEAD: PEOPLE: Milken's Boss Testifies
DOC.TEXT: The highlight of the week at the pre-sentencing hearing for Michael Milken, who awaits his fate on six felony counts, was the appearance of his former boss, Frederick Joseph. The silver-haired Joseph, former chief of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said Milken may have violated some company policies and misled him while cutting the deals examined at the hearing. The confrontation between ex-employer and employee intrigued those who have tracked the long-running Milken saga, but featured fewer dramatics than your average episode of ``L.A. Law.'' Joseph's testimony, while hostile, was no more damaging to the fallen financier than any of the other volleys discharged during the course of the two-week hearing. Few could be described as much more than glancing blows. U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood ordered the hearing to weigh the government's claims that Milken deserved a harsh sentence because he committed many more crimes than he admitted in his plea bargain. The only ``verdict'' to be rendered will be the judge's sentence, which can't exceed the maximum 28 years set by the plea agreement.
DOC.HEAD: COMPANIES: The Bad News Continues
DOC.TEXT: The news was mostly bad on the corporate front. The earnings picture, though not disastrous, was anything but pretty. Sears' earnings were off 30 percent, Delta and USAir recorded losses, UAL's profits were down 4 percent for the quarter. One of the bleakest reports was issued by Unisys, the struggling technology firm, which announced a big loss and the resignation of its chairman W. Michael Blumenthal. RJR Nabisco demonstrated that those accustomed to heavy debts may carry them best. The company reported a net loss for the quarter but said an increase in operating income was helping reduce the mountain of debt piled up when the company was taken private in a $25 billion buyout last year. Philips, the Dutch electronics giant, said it would cut 45,000 jobs or nearly 16 percent of its worldwide staff in an effort to stem heavy losses. The cuts came on top of 10,000 previously announced.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions Oct. 27-28

DOC.TEXT: Consumers would pay more for gasoline, cigarettes and beer under the deficit-reduction plan nearing completion in Congress. But the wealthiest Americans would face income-tax increases averaging 6.3 percent as well. As many as 4 million slightly less well-to-do couples and individuals - including most members of Congress - could get a tax cut because the top rate on their earnings, now 33 percent, would drop to 31 percent. ---

Declining consumer confidence and the Persian Gulf crisis pushed September sales of existing homes down 8 percent, a real estate trade group reported. It was the slowest pace in nearly three years. The National Association of Realtors said Thursday sales totaled a seasonally adjusted 3.22 million houses, the slowest pace since a 3.20 million rate in January 1988. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Analysts said wage inflation might be stabilizing after a government report said Americans' wages, salaries and other benefits jumped 5.2 percent over the past year. The number makes it even more unlikely the Federal Reserve could ease its inflation-fighting campaign and lower interest rates, especially in light of the oil shock brought on by the Persian Gulf turmoil, an analyst said Thursday. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Ex-Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. trader James Dahl testified that boss Michael Milken ordered him to buy Caesars World Inc. bonds at a time the government claims Milken had inside information about the company. The developments came Thursday, the eighth and possibly final day of a hearing into unproven criminal charges beyond the six felony counts to which Milken has pleaded guilty. ---

After five tense weeks, and in a desperate effort to survive, a high-flying company of the 1980s obtained help in sorting out debts exceeding 1 billion pounds, or $1.96 billion. The rise and fall of Polly Peck International PLC, the conglomerate that owns Del Monte fruit and Sansui stereos, marks one of the most traumatic corporate demises in British history. The High Court on Thursday granted Polly Peck's request that it appoint court administrators, and assigned three accountants. ---

Oil prices shot up more than $3 per barrel in the futures market on a combination of news and rumors that all pointed to war in the Persian Gulf. Light sweet crude rose $3.17 to $34.25 a barrel Thursday for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It was crude's third-biggest one-day jump in the Mideast crisis, after rises of $3.56 per barrel on Aug. 6 and $3.37 per barrel on Oct. 3. ---

Philips, the Dutch electronics manufacturing giant, said it will cut nearly 16 percent of its worldwide staff and eliminate stock dividends because of heavy losses and stiff competition. The company, which makes items ranging from light bulbs to televisions under a range of brands, said it lost nearly $1.3 billion in the third quarter of the year. The company will trim up to 45,000 of its 285,700 workers by the end of next year. Most of the job cuts were expected to be in Europe. ---

American Airlines Inc. tried to muscle into the market for Pan Am Corp.'s lucrative London operations, saying it could make a fatter offer than the $400 million that rival UAL Corp. agreed to pay. The surprise announcement Thursday lobbed a potential obstacle into the deal announced Tuesday between Pan Am and UAL, parent of United Airlines. It also showed the enormous importance American attaches to obtaining routes to London, the gateway to Europe and a crucial destination for any global airline. ---

Barring an outbreak of war in the Persian Gulf, gasoline prices will hover between $1.30 and $1.62 per gallon over the next year, an administration energy expert told a Senate panel. U.S. Energy Information Administrator Calvin Kent also predicted Thursday that home heating oil would cost between $1.13 and $1.45 per gallon through 1991, roughly equal to the high levels heating oil reached in last winter's cold snap. ---

The stock market pulled back Thursday, faced with revived upward pressure on oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up about 7 points in the early going, was down 20.05 at 2,484.16 by the close. The dollar rebounded against major currencies and gold prices advanced. Bond prices rose moderately in light trading. Grain and soybean futures retreated, and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Price Hikes Planned for Wall Street Journal, Barron's
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices on Wall Street may be in a funk, but the cost of a copy of the paper named after America's best-known financial byway is going to jump 50 percent in December. Dow Jones & Co. Inc. said Thursday it will raise the newsstand price of The Wall Street Journal to 75 cents a copy from 50 cents on Dec. 3, giving it the highest cover price for a leading national daily newspaper. The move comes at a time when newspaper company profits are slumping, but opinions were mixed on whether the Journal's move would prompt other papers to risk circulation losses by hiking prices. At USA Today, one of the Journal's chief competitors, Larry Lindquist, senior vice president for circulation, said the paper had no plans to raise its cover price of 50 cents in 1991. Dow Jones is also boosting the annual subscription price for the Journal by 7.8 percent to $139 from $129, effective Jan. 2, 1991. It said the price hikes reflect higher transportation and other publishing costs and rising newsprint and postage rates. Earlier this month, the company announced a 17.5 percent drop in its third-quarter earnings, due in part to a decline in ad revenue. It later disclosed a cost-cutting plan that included a freeze on capital spending and total salaries, postponement of a new magazine, and a reduction in the number of special reports in the Journal. While several special-interest daily newspapers sell for more than 50 cents a copy, the American Newspaper Publishers Association said the Journal will be the first general-interest daily paper with a newstand price of 75 cents. The newsstand price of the Journal has been 50 cents since April 1984, when it was raised from 40 cents a copy. Subscription rates were last raised two years ago. The Journal has the largest daily circulation of any U.S. newspaper, averaging nearly 1.86 million copies in the six months ended Sept. 30. Roger May, a spokesman for Dow Jones, said newsstand sales account for under 300,000 in sales or less than 20 percent of the total. He said newsstand sales fell slightly after the 1984 price hike but circulation eventually recovered all lost ground. ``We can't predict what the impact of this increase will be but the outlook for the long term is that we will gain back whatever we lose,'' he said. Everette Dennis, executive director of the Gannett Center for Media Studies at Columbia University, characterized the Journal as a special case with a relatively affluent audience that could well afford to pay the extra quarter for the daily paper. But others said the trend toward higher prices at the newsstand was generally established. With a weak advertising market putting a drag on newspaper revenues throughout the country, more increases could be on the way. Joseph Lorfano of the Newspaper Publishers Association said the average single copy price of newspapers has been rising steadily, reaching 30 cents per copy on average last year, up from 25 cents in 1987. May said 64 newspapers including the Journal have cover prices of 50 cents a copy, up from only four at that figure in 1985. Dow Jones also said it was raising the newsstand price of Barron's National Business and Financial Weekly to $2.50 a copy from $2 effective with the Dec. 3 issue. The annual subscription price will rise to $109 from $99 effective with the Jan. 7, 1991 issue. Barron's last raised it newsstand price in January 1989 and its yearly rate in January 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Final Government Witness Testifies at Hearing
DOC.TEXT: The final government witnesses against Michael Milken described a longtime secret securities ``parking'' scheme with a big Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. customer but failed to link him decisively to insider trading. Eight days of testimony concluded Thursday on charges levied by the government to try to persuade a federal judge that the former junk-bond financier deserves a long prison term. No further witnesses were expected to testify in the Manhattan federal court hearing. Both sides were to present written summations to U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood, who then would set a sentencing date. Milken has pleaded guilty to six felony counts related to illegal trading. He has agreed to pay $600 million in penalties and faces up to 28 years in prison. On Thursday, former Drexel trader James Dahl testified that Milken ordered him to buy Caesars World Inc. bonds at a time the government claims Milken had inside information about the company. He also said Milken and the Columbia Savings & Loan Association routinely engaged in secret securities ``parking'' arrangements from before 1983 until 1986, which the government contends was illegal. But Dahl said he knew of no similar arrangements with other Drexel customers. Dahl further testified about a secret bathroom conversation with Milken, drowned by a running faucet, after speculator Ivan Boesky's 1986 deal to cooperate with prosecutors. The government sought to suggest Milken may have wanted Dahl to destroy evidence. The government alleges the charges it has raised in the pre-sentencing hearing show Milken to be a pervasive lawbreaker. The defense says he is innocent of the additional claims and that his admitted crimes were aberrational. On the Caesars claim, the only charge of insider trading offered of three alleged illegal transactions presented at the hearing, Dahl said Milken in early July 1983 told him and other Drexel salesmen to purchase as much of Caesars securities as possible. Milken had attended a meeting with Caesars and Drexel executives on June 29 where the government claims the possibility of Drexel managing a debt restructuring offer was discussed. Dahl testified that on July 8 he purchased $2 million in Caesars bonds, then sold them to Columbia S&L, so it appeared as though Drexel no longer owned them. But Dahl said Columbia was actually ``parking'' the bonds, or holding them secretly for Drexel, which can be illegal. Furthermore, Dahl testified, Drexel and Columbia had a longstanding arrangement in which Columbia would secretly hold securities for Drexel with an agreement to return them later. Asked by prosecutors who initiated these transactions, Dahl said, ``Mike.'' Drexel on July 15 announced it was advising Caesars on a debt restructuring that sent the bonds soaring in value. Under cross-examination from Liman, Dahl said he did not know whether Milken was aware Drexel had been negotiating to manage the Caesars debt restructuring. Prescott Crocker, manager of a large high-yield bond fund that agreed to sell Drexel $1.2 million in the Caesars bonds on July 14, testified that after the restructuring was announced he accused Dahl and Drexel of insider trading. Crocker said Milken denied any advance knowledge of the Caesars debt restructuring, saying the deal was handled by Drexel's San Francisco office, and that Milken offered to make up the gains from the bonds in future trades. Dahl said Milken called him to Drexel's Beverly Hills, Calif., high-yield bond department on Sunday, Nov. 16, 1986, two days after Boesky's decision to cooperate in a probe of Wall Street corruption. Boesky later became Milken's chief accuser. Dahl said Milken took him into the men's room, turned on a faucet, washed his hands and said in hushed tones: ``There haven't been any subpoenas issued. Whatever you need to do, do it.'' Asked later what Milken meant, Dahl testified: ``I wasn't sure what he was saying. `Do whatever you have to do.' What does that mean? I didn't know.'' He also said Milken never ordered him to destroy documents or not cooperate with investigators.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rebounds, Stock Prices Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to fix cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rebounded today against the Japanese yen in Tokyo, while stock prices fell. The dollar closed at 128.50 yen, up 1.35 yen from 127.15 yen on Thursday. After opening at 128.03 yen, it ranged between 128.00 yen and 128.98 yen. The dollar fell 1.23 yen Thursday, after a four-day rally of 3.98 yen. ``The yen is weakened by recent polls that show declining support for Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu,'' said Hiroshi Masuda, deputy general manager of the Daiwa Securities Co.'s foreign exchange section. But he noted the dollar has previously fallen as polls have shown support for President Bush is also eroding. Uncertainties about efforts to reduce the growth in the U.S. budget deficit are also hurting the dollar, analysts said. Mahiko Nagai, a trader with Manufacturers Hanover Trust said, ``For the moment, market sentiment is neutral.'' ``There's very little action because it's a battle between two currencies that are both in bad shape,'' Masuda said. On the Tokyo stock exchange, where the strong dollar dampened the market mood, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average closed at 25,005.64 points, down 346.99 points or 1.37 percent from Thursday's finish of 25,352.63 points. Reports suggesting war may break out in the Middle East sent share prices tumbling, traders said. U.S. Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney warned that some 100,000 more American troops might be dispatched, while Iraq was reported as now having 500,000 troops in southern Iraq and occupied Kuwait. French President Francois Mitterrand was also reported as indicating military action in the Gulf was imminent. Brokers said there was an early rush to sell as rising oil prices fanned fears of inflation. The Japanese government's consumer price data for the Tokyo area released today showed a 3.1 percent increase in October. The stock market had been slowly recovering from a slide that began in January. The Nikkei index was off 48 percent for tthe year through Oct. 1 when it closed at 20,221.86. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 84.31 points at 3 p.m. from Thursday's 84.79-point finish. Their yields rose to 7.855 percent from 7.745 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Canada, Canadian Auto Workers in Tentative Pact
DOC.TEXT: The tentative contract agreement between Chrysler Canada Ltd. and the Canadian Auto Workers Union resolves the fifth of six labor negotiations between the Big Three automakers and their unions in the United States and Canada. The final unresolved set of talks involve Chrysler Corp. and the United Auto Workers union in the United States, but there are promising signs. The UAW union has scheduled a meeting for next Thursday of its Chrysler bargaining council. The session could be used to review details of a tentative agreement, to inform local union leaders on progress in talks or to set a strike date. Notices of the meeting of the 200-member council of local presidents and bargaining committee chairs were mailed Thursday, UAW spokesman Bob Barbee said. Word of the meeting came as the Canadian Auto Workers union and Chrysler Canada, Chrysler's Canadian subsidiary, reached a tentative agreement on a new contract covering about 10,000 workers. The agreement reached Thursday afternoon wraps up CAW bargaining with Canadian subsidiaries of each of the Big Three automakers. In the United States, the UAW has ratified new agreements with General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. The unresolved Chrysler contract will cover about 63,000 U.S. hourly and salaried Chrysler employees. The CAW and the UAW have pressed the Big Three and their Canadian subsidiaries to bargain essentially two contracts - one in Canada and one in the United States. ``The new three-year agreement with Chrysler Canada meets the all-encompassing auto pattern set by the CAW at Ford of Canada and subsequently met by GM of Canada,'' a CAW statement said Thursday. ``The decision by Chrysler Canada to meet the Canadian pattern when it is indicating opposition to meeting the U.S. pattern is an important turning point in the history of labor relations,'' the statement said. Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca and other company executives have said the UAW pattern agreement is so expensive that Chrysler may not be able to afford it. Chrysler has not asked for concessions but said it needs special consideration from the union. The UAW has said there must be a pattern contract among the Big Three automakers in the United States. Aside from lapel pins which say ``pattern or picket,'' there has been little bargaining rhetoric since talks between the UAW and Chrysler intensified earlier this week. Company and union officials said talks were continuing mostly in meetings of subcommittees, which focus on specific areas of the contract such as health care, time off and job security. The UAW-GM and UAW-Ford agreements call for three years of income protection for workers laid off when plants shut down because of slumping sales. They also provide for a 3 percent base wage increase in the first year and 3 percent lump-sum payments in the second and third years. GM attempts to clarify plant-shutdown language in a letter attached to its contract with the UAW, for the first time promising to consult with the union before shutting down a plant. The letter, obtained by the Detroit Free Press and published in part today, said both sides would review options to closing before the automaker took action. The pattern agreements have no changes in health care provisions, a critical concern of Chrysler. The company said it spent about $684 million on health-care benefits last year. In Canada, where a national health-care plan is in effect, there is little concern about medical costs. The pattern agreement in Canada provides for raises of 7.5 percent in the first year, 6.7 percent in the second and 4.8 percent in the third year of the agreement.

DOC.HEAD: MNC To Sell $1 Billion Credit Card Operation
DOC.TEXT: MNC Financial Corp. plans to sell its profitable $1 billion credit card operation, one of the country's largest, in an attempt to shore up its faltering finances. MNC Financial, the parent company of Maryland National Bank, mde the announcement Thursday as it reported a third-quarter loss of $173 million, or $2.05 a share, because the bank holding company put $350 million into its reserves for possible credit losses. David S. Penn, a bank analyst for Legg Mason Wood Walker, said MNC is selling one of its best divisions ``so the company survives no matter how bad things get.'' He estimated that the bank will be able to get between $1.2 billion and $1.8 billion for the credit card operation. The $350 million loan loss provision increases the reserve for credit losses to $791 million or 94 percent coverage of total non-performing loans. With assets of $27 billion, MNC is the largest bank holding company in Maryland. It is the parent company of Maryland National Bank and American Security Bank in Washington. Because of the decision to sell MBNA America, the bank has canceled an agreement with MNC chairman and chief executive Alfred Lerner to buy up to $180 million of preferred stock. Lerner is the company's largest stockholder, with 8.9 percent of the outstanding shares. The company and its banking subsidiaries also have entered into written agreements with the Federal Reserve Board and the office of the comptroller of the currency, giving the regulators broad powers in the running of the company. MNC said its total non-performing loans increased 40 percent from $602 million June 30, to $844 million as of Sept. 30. Of that total, $450 million of the non-performing loans are related to commercial real estate. The increase in non-performing loans compares with a 45 percent increase in the reserve for possible credit losses over the same period; $297 million of the non-performing loans were either contractually current or past due by fewer than 90 days as of Sept. 30. MNC had a net income of $68.8 million, or $1.13 per share, during the 1989 third quarter. The third-quarter results increased MNC's nine-month loss to $241.9 million, or $2.91 per share, compared with a net income of $192.9 million, or $2.24 per share, for the same period a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Miners Vote To Form First Independent Mass Workers' Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with detail on wages, self-management. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A nationwide congress of coal miners put aside divisions today and adopted a plan by radical miners to form the Soviet Union's first independent trade union. The new Independent Trade Union of Miners has a potential membership of 2 million miners and could evolve into a potent new political and economic force with power over energy supplies. The miners have been the most unified labor group in organizing protests and strikes. Their walkout in 1989 threatened to leave much of the country without fuel. The 900 delegates meeting in this industrial Ukrainian city vowed today to push ahead with demands for workers' rights and better living conditions. Delegates said they were prepared to strike again to enforce their demands, but not until after the legislature of the Russian republic, now in session in Moscow, has had time to act on their complaints. ``The majority is for creating a new union, but there is a minority that believes in the survival of the old (official) union,'' said Konstantin Fesenko, a miner from Donetsk, the heart of a major coal region 600 miles southwest of Moscow. The government-sponsored National Congress of Trade Unions voted on Wednesday in Moscow to disband and form a voluntary association of unions, but the miners said they weren't interested in joining. ``The old and new at some point may negotiate to come together, but the current apparatchiks in the old union must go first,'' Fesenko said. Delegates today voted 525-11 with 40 abstentions to accept a detailed plan for a new confederation of independent mine unions. The plan was drawn up by radical miners based in Siberia's rich coal fields who started the nationwide strike in 1989. A group of 130 radical miners, fed up with five days of debate, held a separate meeting Thursday night to create a new union with or without their colleagues' support. ``I was happy last night. Now I'm not so sure,'' said Vyacheslav Golikov, leader of the Kuzbass Council of Workers' Committees, which called the meeting. He said he was afraid the congress would water down their principles for the new union, but added: ``I hope it will still be a success.'' Golikov has been dubbed the Lech Walesa of the Soviet Union for his effort to create a workers' opposition movement. In addition to higher wages, the principles would guarantee job security, give rights to workers to choose their own union leaders and define who could belong to the union. The new wage figure has not been specified, but officials have said the miners should receive twice the average Soviet salary. Under Soviet economic reforms now under way, controls on wages will be lifted. The plan calls for regular miners' congresses and the creation of a representative council and an executive body to coordinate the new union's actions. The new union would be a confederation, allowing scores of smaller unions to maintain their independence within an umbrella organization. When news of the radical miners' decision reached the congress this morning, many delegates angrily denounced congress organizers and demanded to join the new union. After a heated debate, the congress sent negotiators to talk with the new union. They agreed to create a temporary organizing committee to prepare the first congress of the independent union. No date was set. The 1989 miners' strikes began with demands for better working and living conditions but quickly escalated to include demands for regional economic autonomy for the main mining regions. The government persuaded the miners to return to work by promising to meet most of their demands. But most of the promises remain unfulfilled, an issue that has spurred new strikes. The miners have also sought regional control so the mines can form self-managed local and regional associations that can sell coal to the highest bidder.

DOC.HEAD: Diamond-Star to Get Another Car for Chrysler and Mitsubishi
DOC.TEXT: A new two-door coupe will be among a new line of cars made at the joint-venture assembly plant in Illinois owned by Chrysler Corp. and Mitsubishi Motors Corp. The decision announced Thursday deepens the relationship between the two companies. Chrysler owns 12.1 percent of the Japanese company Mitsubishi. The two companies issued a joint statement Thursday announcing the new generation of cars to be split evenly between them. Chrysler currently gets about 55 percent of the cars made at the plant in Normal, Ill. Neither company would say when the plant would begin making the cars or give the details of the new cars - a three-door sports car and a four-door sedan in addition to the new two-door coupe, said a Chrysler official speaking on the condition of anonymity. Diamond-Star makes the Mitsubishi Eclipse and Mirage, the Plymouth Laser and the Eagle Talon and Summit. The Eclipse, Laser and Talon are two-door sports cars and the Mirage and Summit are four-door sedans. Chrysler officials have said the company was talking with Mitsubishi about building a new vehicle to replace the Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon subcompact cars that Chrysler, the third biggest U.S. automaker, axed in February. However, the Chrysler official said the new car for the Diamond-Star plant would not be an Omni-Horizon replacement. The official also said the new cars will use more domestic parts than the current Diamond-Star cars, which contain about 60 percent U.S. parts. The increase will come from more use of Chrysler engines and transmissions, a joint statement from the two companies said. The two companies each own 50 percent of Diamond-Star. The first Diamond-Star cars, the Eclipse and Laser, began rolling off the assembly line Sept. 1, 1988. The Talon was added next and the Summit and Mirage came later. In addition to Diamond-Star, Chrysler and Mitsubishi are linked through the Dodge and Plymouth Colt line of small cars made by Mitsubishi. The Dodge Stealth, a new car for the 1991 model year, also is designed and built by Mitsubishi with the exception of the outer body panels, which Chrysler designed.

The stock market declined broadly today as the price of oil continued its recent rise. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 14.61 to 2,469.55 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by nearly 4 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 167 up, 630 down and 381 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 17.35 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. The price of crude oil for December delivery rose about 80 cents a barrel, to just above $35 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The buying came amid intensifying speculation that the showdown in the Persian Gulf might be moving closer to open conflict. Analysts said that gave little encouragement to investors already worried about the shaky state of the domestic economy. Sharply higher costs for gasoline, heating oil and a wide range of other goods are expected to act as a drag on consumer spending and business investment at a time when the economy is already burdened with debt problems and a battered real estate market. Aetna Life & Casualty dropped | to 30[ in active trading. The company reported lower third-quarter earnings and announced plans for an overhaul of its operations. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost .99 to 168.52. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .40 at 292.38. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 20.05 to 2,484.16. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 4 to 3 on the NYSE, with 620 up, 850 down and 486 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 141.46 million shares, against 149.29 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Grills Industry, Administration Officials On Oil Prices
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, Kent's forecast . . . to show it is retail prices that are slow to fall on peace rumors, not oil prices in general, UPDATES with oil prices rising in new last graf, RECASTS penultimate graf to show closing oil price from Thursday
DOC.TEXT: An administration energy expert says consumers can expect the price of gasoline to hover between $1.30 and $1.62 a gallon over the next year, provided that no war breaks out in the Persian Gulf. U.S. Energy Information Administrator Calvin Kent also told a Senate panel Thursday to expect home heating oil prices to range between $1.13 and $1.45 per gallon through 1991, roughly equal to the high levels heating oil reached in last winter's cold snap. Kent's forecast came in the opening session of a three-day hearing on why retail gasoline and heating oil prices shoot up on the slightest rumor of trouble in the Mideast but don't seem to fall when rumors of peace send crude oil prices tumbling. Kent told the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee that an improvement in the Mideast situation might lower the price of crude oil, but an immediate response at the gasoline pump shouldn't be expected. ``Prices go up more quickly than they come down,'' Kent said. Kent's price estimates assume that the Persian Gulf crisis does not dissolve into war, that the winter is normal in severity and that market factors such as inventories and daily oil production remain relatively stable. Also assumed in his forecast was that crude oil remains at about $30 per barrel. That assumption seemed open to question even as he testified; on the New York Mercantile Exchange oil jumped $3.17 to $34.25 per barrel for December contracts on Thursday. Oil was rising again in early trading today.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 336.35 down 3.39 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: RTC Talking to Japanese Firm's Subsidiary About Acquiring Loans
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. subsidiary of a Japanese securities firm is talking to the Resolution Trust Corp. about acquiring $1 billion in commercial loans of failed savings and loans, a published report said today. The Wall Street Journal reported that officals of Nomura Securities Co. division met Wednesday with the RTC's Lamar Kelly, who is in charge of selling assets the government agency assumes from failed thrifts. The proposed transaction would betthe RTC's largest and one of the first with a Japanese investor. The deal wouldn't close until February at the earliest, the Journal reported. The Journal story said a source it did not identify by name said Nomura asked about acquiring the loans from a variety of failed thrifts that have not yet been packaged. Nomura in May repackaged $1 billion worth of loans from U.S. banks, including Citicorp and Chase Manhattan Corp., and sold them through a new Dutch company. The loans were purchased primarily by institutional investors in the United States, Britain and Japan. The RTC's only major transaction with a Japanese firm was earlier this year when it retained a subsidiary of Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd. to help sell its junk bond portfolio.

DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were modestly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, extending Thursday's losses. A weekly government report showed little improvement in export sales of U.S. grain last week, and expectations for a large Soviet purchase of U.S. corn have faded, analysts said. Meanwhile, weather conditions remain ideal for seeding winter wheat in the central and southern Plains and for corn and soybean harvesting in the Midwest. Gerald Zusel, a vice president in the grain-trading division of E.D.& F. Man International Futures Inc., said the soybean harvest could be finished within a week, leaving farmers to concentrate on getting in the rest of the corn. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent to 1\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.62{ a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 1} cents lower with December at $2.29\ a bushel; oats were 1 cent to 1\ cents lower with December at $1.22} a bushel; and soybeans were 1\ cents to 3 cents lower with November at $6.03 a bushel. DOC.HEAD: SEC Wants Investors To Know High-Yield Means High-Risk
DOC.TEXT: These are times when the complex world of high finance is stumping even the highly financed. The Securities and Exchange Commission wants junk bond mutual funds, which are targeted at individuals rather than big insitutional investors, to explain that high yield means high risk. With many junk bond yields passing 20 percent, mutual funds that invest in the bonds are also touting high returns. As the market gets pessimistic about the likelihood of junk bond investments paying off, the price gets beaten down. The lower price means even higher and more enticing yields. The SEC is afraid bond fund investors are making decisions by comparing the high yields to the interest rates offered on investments at their local bank, money market funds and bond funds that invest in higher quality debt. The average annual yield on high-yield funds tracked by Lipper Analytical Securities Corp. has risen from 12.9 percent last September to 15.4 percent this September. ``The significantly higher yields do not reflect the income stream investors can expect but rather the risk that their investment may lose a substantial portion of its value in a financial restructuring or default,'' Gene Gohlke, the SEC's acting director of the Division of Investment Management, said in a letter to the funds last week. While the yields have soared, the plunging prices made the average junk bond fund lose 11.2 percent in the year that ended Sept. 30, said Lipper, a mutual fund research firm. The SEC said high-yield funds should consider hiring telephone operators who can explain the risk to shareholders, pressure brokers to be forthcoming with investors and exclude yield quotations from advertisements or add information explaining the risk. Bond funds say they're thinking about it. While some funds already have changed their prospectuses to detail the high risk inherent to high-yield bond investing, the SEC suggestions go beyond these complicated and often hard-to-read explanatory documents. ``The focus is on sales practices rather than adding another lengthyddisclosure requirement to the prospectus. I think that's good to focus on the marketing of funds,'' said Stanley Griffith, associate general counsel at Boston-based Fidelity Investments. ``If you're going to put a big yield number up there then you've probably got an obligation to go further,'' he said. Griffith said Fidelity recently had begun showing the lower coupon rate, rather than the yield to maturity, in advertisements for its Fidelity High Income Fund. At Oppenheimer Management Corp., Paul Suckow, director of fixed income investing, said the firm has changed its prospectus and asked brokers to explain high-yield risk. ``I think today, however, with prices substantially lower than where they were a few years ago, the risks are less,'' he said. ``People should now be looking at this and saying with the prices so much lower, the risks are less than existed a couple years ago when prices were so much higher,'' Suckow said.
