DOC.HEAD: Oil Keeps Rising on War Fears
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices moved up about $1 per barrel on the futures market this morning, as traders kept betting on war in the Persian Gulf. ``It's definitely just the increased war fears and seeing the war premium getting put back inthe market,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Light sweet crude oil, the key grade, was up 95 cents to $35.20 per barrel for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange late this morning. Contracts for delivery in later months were all trading higher as crude moved up sharply for a third straight trading session. Oil regained all of the ground it lost in Monday's record tumble of $5.41 per barrel. But trading was erratic, and speculators were left uncertain on oil's future direction. ``It's a market that has gotten increasingly emotional and is very much reacting to the situation in the Middle East,'' Hittle said. Recently, big jumps in oil prices, both up and down, have seem to come with greater frequency as the market has appeared to become even more volatile, analysts say. ``There is some sense from previous reports that time is running out on the situation,'' said William Byers, an analyst with Bear Stearns & Co. ``Whether that's a correct perception, I don't know.'' Byers said many traders believe any attack on Iraqi forces might occur either just before or just after the U.S. elections, now less than two weeks away. Traders had been expecting even sharper rises today after the London oil futures prices jumped dramatically. But before the New York market opened, a French television report of a conciliatory letter from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to French President Francois Mitterrand had a calming effect. Refined petroleum products were on the rise along with crude oil. Unleaded gasoline futures were up 2.45 cents to 96.05 cents per gallon on November contracts. Contracts for delivery in later months were all trading higher. Home heating oil was up 2.23 cents to 93.90 cents per gallon for November delivery. Later delivery months were all higher. Natural gas futures showed little change, with December delivery contracts falling 1.6 cents to $2.43 per 1,000 cubic feet. Later delivery months were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News Management Publishes Despite Strike; Trucks Barraged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE arrest total from 10 to 11, add scene at newspaper building this morning; picking up 5th graf, `The strike...' SUBS 13th graf pvs, `Five people...' to UPDATE arrest figure. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY19, NR1
DOC.TEXT: Daily News managers published and tried to distribute a newspaper today using non-union replacement drivers who ran a gantlet of protesters throwing rocks and bottles. Police reported at least two minor injuries and at least 11 arrests, including two men held after a delivery truck was firebombed. Copies of today's paper, reduced to only one edition, were trucked out of the printing plants about three hours late, under police escort. It was not immediately known how many were printed and delivered, but the News was absent from some midtown Manhattan and suburban railroad station newsstands during rush hour. A half-dozen pickets marched outside the News headquarters this morning, and union leaders stood outside to direct workers to go home. The strike called Thursday night at the nation's second-largest metropolitan daily newspaper capped a 10-month dispute over management's efforts to gain more control over money-losing operations. Police in riot gear escorted delivery trucks out of a Daily News printing plant in Kearny, N.J., through hundreds of strikers and their supporters hurling bricks, stones, eggs and bottles. Vehicle windows were covered with protective tape to prevent any shattered glass from injuring those inside. One truck was firebombed in neighboring Harrison, N.J., Kearny police Capt. Anthony Gouveia said. No injuries were reported. Two men were arrested shortly afterward in Kearny on charges of possession of three Molotov cocktails, Lt. Micheal Davitt said. Another man was arrested for allegedly throwing rocks at a truck at the Kearny plant, Gouveia said. ``He was the only one we could catch,'' Gouveia said. ``It was ugly out there.'' Delivery trucks also rolled past hundreds of jeering protesters outside News plants in the New York City borough of Brooklyn and in Garden City on Long Island. Strikers broke the windows of a News truck in Brooklyn, and the driver was taken to a hospital for treatment of facial injuries, said police spokeswoman Sgt. Mary Wrensen. She said other strikers pelted a News truck in Manhattan, causing the driver to lose control and hit two parked cars. A security guard inside the truck sustained minor injuries in a scuffle with two strikers, she said. Six people were arrested, mostly on charges of disorderly conduct, outside the Lon Island plant, Garden City police Lt. William Fitzpatrick said. Two were arrested outside the Brooklyn plant, where a fireworks-style explosive was ignited beneath a truck, police said. Eight unions with about 1,800 members went on strike and the Newspaper Guild said its 800 members would honor picket lines, including one at the main News offices in Manhattan. Management crews produced today's edition. Its lead headline concerned a police crackdown on drug dealing near city schools, but a smaller headline beneath it said ``UNIONS STRIKE NEWS'' and had a picture of a News delivery truck burned after a dispute Thursday that triggered the strike. On Thursday, a union official was ejected from the Brooklyn plant while defending an employee's right to work while seated. The newspaper said workers then walked off the job. Union leaders say they were locked out. Sixty drivers with the most seniority then were fired and replaced by non-union workers. Fires were started and trucks were sabotaged. A ``To Our Readers'' box on page 3 said that because of Thursday's dispute, only 920,000 copies of Thursday's issue were distributed. The News has a normal weekday circulation of 1.18 million. ``The Daily News intends full publication and distribution of its Friday issue,'' the box continued. The News' normal weekday circulation is second only to the Los Angeles Times among metropolitan dailies. The nationally distributed Wall Street Journal and USA TODAY also have larger circulations than the News. Contracts for all 10 of the newspaper's unions ran out in March, and negotiations have stalemated. ``It is indeed unfortunate that a strike was provoked by these unions against the Daily News at a time when we were involved in the collective bargaining process to resolve our differences,'' said John Sloan, Daily News vice president for labor relations. He said replacement workers from other Tribune Co. papers in Orlando, Fla., and Chicago were being flown to New York. Over the past decade the News has lost about $115 million and daily circulation has dropped by about 700,000. The paper's managers say they need to end alleged labor abuses and save $50 million to $70 million annually. The unions said the paper is trying to break them and called for an advertisers' boycott. In a bar near the Brooklyn plant, workers said they had been expecting a showdown with management for weeks. ``The Daily News thinks they can put out a scab paper and they think New Yorkers will buy it,'' said a veteran driver who would not give his name. ``We can only hope and pray that New Yorkers don't.'' The paper is embroiled in one of the nation's fiercest newspaper wars. Analysts have questioned whether the city can support three tabloids and the broadsheet New York Times. The other two tabloids planned to increase their press runs today. The New York Post, which normally prints about 625,000 copies, expected a press run of 850,000 to 860,000. New York Newsday was expected to increase its press run from about 250,000 to about 400,000.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Push EC Inflation To 6.1 Percent, Highest Since July 1985
DOC.TEXT: Higher oil prices pushed the European Community's average annual inflation rate in September to 6.1 percent, the highest level more than five years, the EC statistics agency Eurostat said Friday. The EC rate for September, up from 5.9 percent in August, compared with 6.2 percent in the United States and 2.9 percent in Japan, Eurostat reported. It said it was the highest annual inflation rate since July 1985. The surge in oil prices following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August pushed up consumer prices by an average 0.7 percent in the EC in September, the agency said. Eurostat reported these annul inflation rates for the EC states in September: Belgium, 3.7 percent; Denmark, 3.0 percent; Germany, 3.0 percent; Greece, 21.8 percent; Spain, 6.5 percent; France, 3.8 percent; Italy, 6.8 percent; Luxembourg, 3.7 percent; Netherlands, 2.6 percent; Portugal, 13.7 percent, and Britain, 10.9 percent. Eurostat published no figures for Ireland which calculates it inflation rates quarterly.

DOC.HEAD: Rates on New 52-Week Treasury Bills Fall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 4 new grafs to reflect rescheduling 2-year note auction. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, It was . . .
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury Department on Friday sold $10.13 billion in 52-week bills at the lowest interest rates in more than two years and rescheduled for next Tuesday a $12 billion auction of 2-year notes. Both offerings had been postponed because of congressional failure to raise the debt limit after it fell from $3.195 trillion to $3.12 trillion on Oct. 20. But President Bush signed legislation on Thursday raising the ceiling to $3.195 trillion through Saturday which permitted Friday's auction. The budget package that Congress hopes to pass this weekend would raise the limit to $4.072 trillion and the Treasury said the 2-year note auction is contingent upon enactment before Tuesday. The average discount rate at Friday's bill auction was 7.01 percent, down from 7.25 percent at the last auction on Sept. 20. It was the lowest rate since 52-week bills averaged 6.74 percent on May 5, 1988. The bills will carry an equivalent coupon interest rate of 7.51 percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,293.20. Sales totaled $10.13 billion out of bids of $47.13 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Former Western Savings Owner Charged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 8 new grafs to UPDATE with court appearance; ADDS byline; Picks up 6th graf pvs, The charges...
DOC.TEXT: The former owner of a failed Dallas savings and loan who has been accused in a criminal indictment of diverting funds to keep the thrift afloat was released on a personal recognizance bond today. Jarrett E. Woods Jr., former owner of Western Savings Association, agreed in federal court today to surrender his passport and limit his travel to the continental United States. Woods was accused Thursday in the indictment of illegally diverting $18 million to pay off delinquent loans as a way of postponing the highflying thrift's $1 billion collapse. Prosecutors did not oppose the personal recognizance bond in an 8-minute initial appearance before U.S. Magistrate Jane Jackson. Woods' next court appearance is scheduled for Nov. 1. Woods, who was described by the U.S. attorney general as one of the industry's biggest ``bandits'' in Texas, had no comment upon leaving the hearing. His attorney, Shirley Lobel, said she could not comment because of a gag order. The 37-count indictment returned by a federal grand jury in Dallas charges Woods with bank fraud, misapplication of bank funds, making false ledger entries and conspiracy. ``We have corralled one of the biggest savings and loan bandits in Texas,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh told reporters Thursday. ``The freewheeling lifestyle and fraudulent management practices that led to Western's collapse helped set the trend for our national thrift crisis.'' Thecharges carry a maximum sentence of 185 years in prison and fines totaling at least $8.2 million or twice the loss proven by prosecutors. Western's failure in 1986 when it was taken over by federal regulators cost the taxpayers $1 billion, the Justice Department said. A civil suit filed earlier this week by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. seeks to collect $560 million from Woods. It accuses Woods of spending $7 million of depositors' money in the months before Western failed. The thrift, which Woods purchased in 1982 with $2 million in borrowed money, grew from $70 million in assets to $2 billion four years later, said U.S. Attorney Marvin Collins. Collins said the case ``can be fairly characterized as an example of a real estate developer, Jarrett Woods, buying up a sleepy little S&L, moving it to Dallas, pumping it full of high-cost brokered funds and then lending the money out on high-risk loans. ``The indictment shows the great lengths that people will go to deceive regulators,'' Collins said. The indictment charges that Woods diverted $16 million from a $60 million loan for a Houston real estate deal to businessman James Reagin, a major borrower who was behind on loan payments to Western. Most of the money, plus $2.26 million that was diverted from the sale of Western property, was used to help Reagin pay off loans so that Western would not have to write them off as bad debts. At one point, Reagin was behind on loans worth $64 million, Collins said. ``Just the loans to James Reagin would have likely caused the failure of Western Savings Association,'' Collins said. Reagin, a Houston businessman who faces sentencing in connection with the failure of the Glen Ellyn Savings and Loan in Illinois, is cooperating with prosecutors in their investigation of Woods, officials said. Woods is not accused of pocketing any of the funds diverted to Reagin. But Collins said Woods, as 100 percent owner of Western, was motivated by a desire to keep regulators from taking over the S&L. The indictment also charges that Woods arranged for a Western subsidiary to pay a $48,000 commission to a company that had not earned the money. The indictment alleges the money was actually used to pay off a gambling debt Woods owed. ``There is nothing you can do basically in the short run to address these cases quickly,'' Collins said of the department's four-year effort to get Woods. ``You must have a long, large concerted effort.''

DOC.HEAD: Litton Executive Steps Down as President
DOC.TEXT: The president of Litton Industries will step down after 30 years as part of his plan for early retirement. Roland O. Peterson, who is also chief operating officer, will become a senior vice president and group executive for Litton's Components and Industrial Products business until he retires Nov. 1, said Litton spokesman Robert Knapp. He has been president since 1988. Litton's board Thursday selected Alton J. Brann, a vice president and group executive, to succeed Peterson. Brann, 48, who joined Litton in 1973, will be a candidate for director at the annual shareholder meeting in December. Litton makes advanced military electronic equipment, microwave components and automated assembly lines.

DOC.HEAD: Administrator Optimistic Polly Peck Will Survive
DOC.TEXT: An administrator called in to rescue debt-ridden Polly Peck International PLC said Friday he was optimistic the British food and electronics conglomerate will survive. Richard Stone, an accountant, said he believed there was plenty of opportunity to restructure the company, though he admitted it could end up ``somewhat different'' than its present form. The administrators are expected to sell off Polly Peck assets to reduce the company's debt, but it's not known how many assets or which ones. Polly Peck owns such diverse brands as Del Monte fruit and Sansui stereos. Meanwhile, British Trade Secretary Peter Lilley called for information on Polly Peck to see whether a full government inquiry into the company's affairs should be undertaken. Polly Peck Chairman Asil Nadir earlier had unsuccessfully sought such an inquiry. Polly Peck asked a court Thursday to appoint administrators to keep creditors at bay and help sort out its debt load of 1.3 billion pounds, about $2.5 billion. The problems have been developing since the company suspended trading in its stock after the share price plummeted 55 percent on Sept. 20 on news that the Serious Fraud Office had raided the offices of South Audley Management Ltd. The fraud office is investigating allegations of possible misconduct. South Audley is an investment company linked with a Nadir family trust. Nadir and the company have denied any knowledge of wrongdoing. On Friday, the Department of Trade and Industry issued a statement saying Lilley ``will look at all the information available to him arising from the move into administration of Polly Peck and the events leading up to it.'' ``In particular he will want to hear from the administrator at the earliest opportunity whether the administrator thinks there are any matters that need investigating,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes S&L Whistleblower Protection
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with House passing whistleblower protection measure; picks up 5th graf pvs bgng, Also on. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The House passed legislation today to protect employees of banking agencies who expose cases of abuse in the government's effort to clean up the savings and loan industry. The proposal by Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., was part of a money laundering bill passed by voice vote in the waning hours of the 1990 congressional session. Employees of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., the now-defunct Federal Home Loan Bank Board and other banking agencies were not covered by the Whistleblower Protection Act of 1989. The Annunzio would extend that protection to them, retroactive to Jan. 1, 1987. S&L regulators, currently unprotected by federal whistleblower laws, are like police officers who can't make any arrests, Rep. Charles E. Schumer, D-N.Y., told a hearing Thursday. The lack of protection for thrift regulators who point out cases of abuse harms the government's S&L cleanup effort, Schumer said. ``Imagine putting a cop on the corner, taking away his gun, badge and nightstick, and telling him that he'd be fired if he tried to make any arrests,'' he said. ``That's about what we've done with our S&L regulators.'' Also on Thursday, federal regulators approved a plan to sell or close about 192 failed savings and loans over the next six months. The Resolution Trust Corp. oversight board approved the plan, which involves assets valued at $119 billion. The proposal must be approved through the congressional appropriations process. Schumer spoke at a hearing of the House Budget Committee's Task Force on Urgent Fiscal Issues, which he chairs. Two S&L agency employees who were fired testified at the hearing. John M. Geddes, a former employee of the now-defunct Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp., was fired in August 1989. He had told the agency about serious errors he found in the adjustable-rate mortgage portfolio of American Federal Savings & Loan of Anderson, Ind. Geddes said errors involving adjustable-rate mortgages, which he discovered at various S&Ls around the country, could mean $8 billion to $15 billion in liability for the lending industry and the government. In some cases, he said, borrowers have been overcharged by almost $10,000 on loan balances of $25,000. Several law firms consulted by Geddes had warned the FSLIC that its failure to correct the errors could expose the agency to allegations of fraud. ``I was not the only employee who was informed not to rock the boat,'' Geddes said. ``Other employees were passed over for advancement or given the worst jobs until they could not take it any more and resigned.'' In June, the FDIC ordered an investigation into overcharges on adjustable-rate mortgages. The other whistleblower, Lisa R. Walleri, was an examiner for the Federal Home Loan Bank of Seattle. She testified that she was fired for refusing to sign a report on Far West Federal Bank that distorted its financial condition to make it look more healthy than it was. John F. Downey, an official of the Office of Thrift Supervision, said his agency agreed with Ms. Walleri that the Seattle FHLB's report on Far West was inaccurate. He said the OTS found ``various deficiencies'' in the Seattle agency, including failure to comply with policies and procedures, and inadequate guidance and oversight. ``She deserves an apology,'' Downey said of Ms. Walleri. He added that the OTS would consider offering her a job. The Whistleblowers Protection Act shields federal employees who disclose governmental wrongdoing against reprisal. Lawmakers who drafted last year's S&L bailout legislation say they unintentionally neglected to provide such protection for banking agency workers.

DOC.HEAD: Two Pilots Get Year In Prison, Third 16 Months, In Drunken Flying Convictions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with further quote from judge; CORRECT `a' to `of' in 3rd graf. Picks up 7th graf pvs, Prouse, who. ADDS 1 graf to include that pilots were fired, lost licenses. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Three former Northwest Airlines pilots convicted of flying a passenger plane while intoxicated were sentenced to prison today, two for a year and the other to 16 months. U.S. District Judge James Rosenbaum also imposed three years' probation on each, telling them: ``Gentlemen, you are good men who have done a bad thing.'' The judge said the pilots' actions amounted to a breach of faith between the traveling public and the pilots. ``It is a crime against our sense of security. In that sense, all of us are a victim of this crime,'' he said. The sentences were within federal guidelines, which recommended 12 to 18 months; the maximum would have been 15 years. Rosenbaum left open the possibility that they could remain free pending their appeals. The defendants - Capt. Norman Lyle Prouse, 51, of Conyers, Ga.; 1st Officer Robert Kirchner, 36, of Highland Ranch, Colo.; and flight engineer Joseph Balzer, 35, of Antioch, Tenn. - were convicted of flying while intoxicated on a hop from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis the morning of March 8. At the sentencing hearing, Assistant U.S. Attorney Elizabeth de la Vega asked for a ``substantial'' sentence while the pilots' lawyers argued for lenient treatment. As he announced his decision, Rosenbaum said he was particularly disturbed that all three pilots had been under the influence. ``Who can comprehend an entire crew alcohol-impaired?'' he asked. Prouse, who had the highest blood-alcohol concentration in a test given two hours after the flight landed, was the one who received the 16-month sentence. The judge told him that his acknowledged alcoholism was not ``a license to kill.'' In the tests after the flight was completed, Prouse had a blood-alcohol concentration of 0.13 percent, Kirchner's was 0.06 percent and Balzer's was 0.08 percent. At the trial, the pilots had argued that the fact that the 40-minute flight, which had 91 passengers, was uneventful showed that they were not rendered incapable of flying by the alcohol they had drunk the night before. They were the first pilots to be convicted under a 1986 law aimed at cracking down on substance abuse in the transportation industry. Prouse admitted to drinking more than 15 rum and colas at a lounge the night before the flight. A waitress testified that Prouse fell as he left the bar at about 11:30 p.m. and returned to get directions to his hotel, which was about three blocks away. Balzer and Kirchner shared at least six pitchers of beer and left the bar about an hour before Prouse, according to testimony. The plane left at 6:30 the next morning, and the crew members were arrested after they arrived at Minneapolis-St. Paul. Northwest fired the pilots after the incident for drinking within 12 hours of a scheduled flight, and the Federal Aviation Administration revoked their pilots licenses.

DOC.HEAD: Former Western Savings Owner Released on Own Recognizance
DOC.TEXT: Former Western Savings Association owner Jarrett E. Woods Jr., accused of illegally diverting $18 million in funds from the thrift, was released on a personal recognizance bond Friday pending arraignment next month. Woods is expected to enter a plea to a 37-count indictment on Nov. 1. He is charged with illegally diverting thrift funds to pay off delinquent loans as a way of postponing the high-flying thrift's $1 billion collapse. Prosecutors did not oppose his release on personal recognizance during an 8-minute initial appearance before U.S. Magistrate Jane Jackson. Woods had no comment upon leaving the hearing. His attorney, Shirley Lobel, said she could not comment because of a gag order issued Thursday by U.S. District Judge Robert Maloney. The indictment returned Thursday by a Dallas federal grand jury charges Woods with bank fraud, misapplication of bank funds, making false ledger entries and conspiracy. Western's failure in 1986 when it was taken over by federal regulators cost the taxpayers $1 billion, the Justice Department said. The charges carry a maximum sentence of 185 years in prison and fines totaling at least $8.2 million or twice the loss proven by prosecutors. A civil lawsuit filed earlier this week by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. seeks to collect $560 million from Woods. It accuses him of spending $7 million of depositors' money in the months before Western failed.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Prices Plunge on Harvest Pressure, Technicals
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices tumbled below $6 a bushel Friday to a 2{-month low on the Chicago Board of Trade in a late sell-off ahead of the biggest harvest weekend of the year. Corn, wheat and oat futures also closed mostly lower. Soybeans opened lower amid speculation that the soybean harvest will move rapidly toward completion this weekend in the Midwest. Selling by speculative funds snowballed when the price for November soybean deliveries slipped below $6 bushel about 45 minutes before the close, said Gerald Zusel, a vice president in the grain-trading division of E.D.& F. Man International Futures Inc. ``We had a technical breakdown,'' he said. ``There was big, big fund selling in there today.'' He said the soybean harvest could be finished within a week, leaving farmers to cocentrate on getting in the rest of the corn. At the close, wheat futures were 2\ cents lower to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.62\ a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 2} cents lower with December at $2.28 a bushel; oats were 3{ cents to 4\ cents lower with December at $1.19} a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents to 11 cents lower with November at $5.94{ a bushel.
Stock prices tumbled today amid new uncertainty over oil prices and prospects in the Persian Gulf. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 43.57 at 2,440.59.

DOC.HEAD: Aetna Announces Layoffs, Earnings Drop
DOC.TEXT: Aetna Life and Casualty Co. on Friday announced a restructuring plan, including layoffs, to tighten operations and save hundreds of millions of dollars. The Hartford-based insurance company also announced a 51 percent drop in third-quarter earnings that included a one-time, $60 million charge for severance benefits and other costs associated with the reorganization. Analysts said the restructuring may be good medicine not only to Aetna but the ailing insurance industry, which has been suffering from soft premiums and poor returns in its real estate and bond investments. Aetna's announcement ``might set the tone for the insurance industry in general,'' said Denise A. Petsis, an analyst with Argus Research Corp. ``The insurance industry is in a down cycle. ... There's very little room right now to improve revenue, so what they're trying to do is hold the line on costs. ``When the insurance industry rebounds, I think a lot of these companies, Aetna included, will be in a much better position,'' Petsis said. Aetna, one of the nation's top five insurance companies, said it would save up to $95 million a year by reorganizing its three domestic insurance divisions into two groups. In the process, 2,600 jobs will be eliminated through layoffs and attrition. ``Our goal is to build on the many areas of excellence Aetna must retain, and to solidify our position as a leader in insurance, related financial services and managed health care,'' said James T. Lynn, Aetna chairman. Aetna's competitors are also retrenching. Travelers Corp., also based in Hartford, recently cut its dividend to save $100 million and said it will become choosier about where it sells coverage. Philadelphia-based Cigna Corp. is consolidating its domestic property and casualty operations to pull in any loose ends. The `90s will be the era ``where focus will count,'' said Michael Frinquelli, an insurance analyst with Salomon Bros. ``I don't think we will necessarily wind up a decade from now with fewer companies in the business. We will end up with same number - smaller and more focused,'' he said. Aetna said it earned $88.6 million, or 80 cents per share, in the three months ended Sept. 30 compared to earnings of $183 million, or $1.63 per share, a year earlier. Revenue slipped 1.2 percent to $4.84 billion in the quarter from $4.90 billion for the same period last year. Premiums rose slightly, to $3.3 billion from $3.2 billion last year. Under the reorganization, to be put in place March 4, two new groups will be created. One will include managed health care, group insurance, small business employee benefits markets, pension and financial services, individual annuity and pension and sponsored sales. The other will be made up of commercial markets, national commercial accounts, bond, personal auto, homeowners and individual life insurance. ``All our existing businesses remain, it's just a matter of how they will be grouped and how they will be funded,'' said company spokesman John C. Hawkins. Aetna said most of the job eliminations would come from its three offices in the Hartford area. About 17,400 of its 45,200 employees work in Hartford, Middletown and Windsor, Conn. He said it was too early to tell how many of the jobs would be lost through layoffs. The third-quarter earnings also include net capital losses of $38 million because of additions to reserves and write-downs related to the company's mortgage loan and real estate porfolios. For the first nine months of 1990, Aetna reported net income of $472.2 million, or $4.23 per share, down 10.3 percent from $525.8 million, or $4.67 per share, a year earlier. Nine-month revenue slipped 0.6 percent to $14.43 billion from $14.51 billion in 1989. Premiums fell slightly to $9.66 billion from $9.7 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Chevron Blames Third-Quarter Decline On Mideast Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Chevron Corp. on Friday reported a 3 percent drop in third-quarter earnings, blaming the decline on rising oil prices due to tension in the Middle East. The nation's largest importer of crude oil reported earnings of $403 million, or $1.14 a share, for the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with $417 million, or $1.22 a share for the same period last year. Chevron said some of its losses were offset by $80 million in special items, compared to just $7 million for such items last year. After adjusting for those items, the company said operational results declined 21 percent. Ken Derr, Chevron's chairman and chief executive officer, attributed the decline to turmoil in the Middle East after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug 2. ``Product prices ultimately must reflect raw material costs and we would expect the competitive marketplace will have to acknowledged this,'' he said. Higher prices of crude oil helped increase total revenues to $10.6 billion for the quarter, compared with $8 billion in the third quarter of last year, Chevron said. The rising cost of crude oil also has benefited Chevron's exploration and production earnings, the company said. U.S. exploration and production income rose from $58 million to $201 million in the quarter, while income from foreign exploration and production increased to $197 million from $121 million. But Derr said Chevron, a net buyer of crude, lost money because the higher cost of oil has not yet been recovered through higher prices for petrleum products. Chevron said it charged an average 26 cents more per gallon for those products, while they cost the company an average 35 cents more per gallon in September than in July. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Derr said Chevron has responded to the crisis by boosting U.S. oil and natural gas production and increasing the amount of gasoline and other light products extracted from crude. Chevron also started production in Australia to offset declines in Canada, Nigeria and the United Kingdom. ``Our strategy should certainly encourage conservation, but it must also stimulate environmentally safe development of our resources,'' Derr said. For the first nine months of 1990, Chevron reoprted net income of $1.5 billion or $4.30 a share, on revenues of $28.8 billion. That compares with $1.1 billion or $3.31 a share, on revenues of $23.9 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold End Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mixed Friday in extremely quiet trading on world currency markets amid some nervousness over the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf. Gold prices slipped overseas, and the decline accelerated in domestic dealings. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery fell $4.90 to settle at $370.90 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank later quoted gold at $371.00, down $5.25 an ounce. Traders said there was spotty dollar-buying as some investors sought a safe haven in the U.S. currency ahead of an uncertain weekend in the Middle East. Adding to their concern was the disclosure that United States plans to send up to 100,000 more troops to the area. ``It appears with the situation in the Persian Gulf very, very tense, people wanted to buy back a few dollars,'' said Robert Hatcher, a corporate dealer with Barclays Bank PLC. The dollar typically is considered the currency of choice in times of global turmoil. But countering the advance was an underlying bearish sentiment toward the U.S. currency based on the expectation of lower interest rates and a weakening economy. The market is anticipating that the Federal Reserve will notch interest rates lower once the deficit-reducing budget package is in place. Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less attractive to investors. Michael Malpede, a senior analyst with Refco Group Ltd., characterized trading as trendless. ``There's no commitment to either'' buying or selling of dollars, he said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 1.35 yen to a closing 128.50 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted lower at 128.00 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 128.25 yen, unchanged from Thursday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9555 from $1.9545 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.9565 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.9505. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.5130 German marks, down from 1.5185; 1.2810 Swiss francs, down from 1.2845; 5.0670 French francs, down from 5.0820; 1,134.00 Italian lire, down from 1,136.50, and 1.1644 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1657. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates: 1.5155 German marks, up from 1.5130; 1.2795 Swiss francs, up from 1.2765; 5.0740 French francs, up from 5.0645; 1.7083 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7050; 1,135.50 Italian lire, up from 1,132.75; and 1.1653 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1676. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $373.75 a troy ounce from $376.25 bid per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal slipped to a closing bid of $373.40 an ounce from $374.80. Financial markets in Hong Kong were closed for a holiday. Silver prices also declined. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.050 a troy ounce, down from $4.204 on Thursday. Earlier in London, the metal fell to a late bid price of $4.14 an ounce, from $4.24.

DOC.HEAD: Hills Says Solving Agriculture Dispute Vital to Trade Talks
With AM-EC-Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said Friday that resolving a dispute over agricultural subsidies is vital for the current round of international trade talks to meet its end-of-year deadline. Hills said the dispute could scuttle four years of work on a new trade agreement for the 105 nations which are parties to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Several European nations led by Germany oppose cuts in government subsidies to farmers. The United States wants these subsidies eliminated or reduced severely to allow agricultural products to be traded more freely on world markets. U.S. farmers would see their exports grow considerable if the subsidies are cut, Hills said. The GATT negotiations, called the Uruguay Round of talks, are aimed at reducing international subsidies, tariffs and other trade barriers. Hills told a gathering sponsored by the European Community Chamber of Commerce in the United States that it would be extremely unlikely for the talks to be extended beyond their December deadline. ``We have been at this four years,'' she said. ``The topics have not changed.''

DOC.HEAD: Hearing Shows Milken No Crime Kingpin, No Boy Scout Either
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: The biggest criminal investigation in Wall Street history couldn't do it. A shattered career and humbling six-count guilty plea couldn't do it either. So why should eight days of testimony on three transactions out of countless thousands over 20 years solve the mystery of Michael Milken, one of the most enigmatic figures in Wall Street history? At a court hearing to help U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood determine punishment, the government failed to stick the fatal dagger in Milken's persona, but the junk-bond pioneer didn't emerge as the Boy Scout his admirers would have him. The hearing was the first public clash of facts, ideas and opinions on Milken, who transformed Drexel into a powerhouse investment firm, now defunct, on the back of IOUs called junk bonds that reshaped high finance. Prosecutors, who began investigating Milken in 1986, didn't decisively prove him guilty of the crimes alleged in three transactions. But they did demonstrate a pattern of impropriety based on strong suggestions of illegality. One thing was clear: Drexel's junk bond offices on Wilshire Boulevard in Beverly Hills, Calif., was a place of intrigue, derring-do, outlandish pay and sometimes sleazy behavior in the tumultuous 1980s. The witnesses themselves formed a sort of class picture of the ideals and attitudes of the decade - Drexel trader James Dahl's $23 million take in 1988 (Milken made $550 million the previous year); $450,000-a-year trader Peter Gardiner's jealousy over a $1.5 million colleague; secret ledgers, lying to a grand jury, hints to destroy evidence and a symphony of water faucets drowning out clandestine conversations. The government made three basic allegations against Milken: stock manipulation in Wickes Cos., insider trading in Caesars World Inc. and misappriation and bribery in Storer Communications Inc. As described, the alleged schemes ratcheted up the level of cheating by the 44-year-old Milken beyond his admitted crimes. That was the government's intent in requesting the special hearing. But the defense appeared to deflect the main allegations. Prosecutors ``have certainly shown suggestive testimony that may well convince future historians . . . Mr. Milken did everything the government has alleged, but they haven't proven it in court,'' said John Coffee Jr., a securities law professor at Columbia University. ``In terms of a gear shift that shows higher level involvement in more culpable crimes such as insider trading, I don't think the government can be very happy at the way the evidence looks in court,'' he said. Milken's lawyers characterized the six felony counts to which he pleaded guilty as aberrations in an otherwise exemplary career. The government said they were the tip of an iceberg of illicit behavior. The common wisdom after the hearing was that neither picture was entirely accurate. On Wickes, Drexel trader Cary Maultasch testified he manipulated the company's stock with speculator Ivan Boesky under orders from Gardiner. Gardiner blamed Milken, but couldn't offer any direct evidence beyond a shouted price and an inference of bad intent. On Caesars World, again the link was hazy at best. Dahl said Milken ordered him to buy Caesars bonds at a time Milken might have had inside information about the company. But it appeared the trades might have been part of a legitimate strategy requested by a customer. The testimony on Storer may have been the most damning. Milken appeared to offer fund managers favors in the form of personal investments in Storer, which experts say is illegal. But no evidence supported the government's theory of bribery. Beyond the specific allegations, though, a picture emerged of less than ethical and possibly illegal activity by Milken, underlings and some outside excutives. Former Drexel traders described routine securities ``parking'' at the junk-bond department, which has been prosecuted criminally in other cases. Dahl said Columbia Savings & Loan Association regularly over four years secretly held bonds for Drexel, purchased back at a set time and price. Asked who initiated the parking, Dahl said, ``Mike.'' Such behavior seemed second nature. ``I parked securities routinely,'' Gardiner testified. Infleunce-peddling, back-scratching and strong-arm tactics also occurred at Drexel, testimony showed, supporting the popular notion of the firm's power and arrogance. An investment fund manager said a Drexel executive - not Milken - helped him land a job and then demanded control over his work. Perhaps most damaging to Milken's character were stories about the period following the Nov. 14, 1986, announcement of Boesky's plea deal with the government that led investigators to Milken. Dahl testified Milken bent over near a running water faucet in a bathroom meeting and said, ``whatever you need to do, do it.'' Drexel trader Terren Peizer said Milken ordered him to give a secret ledger to a close Milken friend and colleague. When Peizer was searching for documents in response to government subpoenas, he said Milken opened an empty drawer and said ``if you don't have them, you can't provide them.'' But none of the former Milken subordinates - who cut deals to cooperate in exchange for a no-prosecution guarantee, one after lying repeatedly to a grand jury - said Milken ordered them to destroy evidence, lie to investigators or convey inside information. Through his skill and power and authority to dole out millions, Milken achieved the loyalty of his minions, which eroded under government threats of prosecution. Still, on the stand, they praised his business acumen and integrity in selling deals. Their testimony offered no smoking guns, but it may support the government's theory that Milken was the only one at Drexel who could control a corrupt organization, and was careful to insulate himself well. The defense maintains that amounts to no more than a conspiracy theory. Judge Wood is expected to sentence Milken within two weeks. ``When someone has the visibility and celebrity that Michael Milken has,'' defense attorney Arthur Liman said during the hearing, ``it's easy to say that everything that ever happened at Drexel was his fault.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Falls in Erratic Trading
DOC.TEXT: Oil zigzagged wildly on the futures market Friday, closing down more than $1 per barrel after a rally based on war fears ran out of steam and traders began selling. ``They've taken it all over the place,'' said Thomas Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. ``The market is so hungry for news, and without the rumors and news, it's come off slightly.'' Light sweet crude, the key grade of oil, fell $1.24 to $33.01 per barrel for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil had gone to a high of $35.40 per barrel before the selloff began. Later delivery months all closed lower after they retreated from gains made early in the session. Oil had begun the day by moving up about $1 as speculators once again bet war was likely in the Persian Gulf. Crude then began tumbling on hints of possible diplomatic solutions to the crisis. Traders were responding partly to a news report that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein reportedly sent a conciliatory letter to French President Francois Mitterrand, although French officials said they had no knowledge of such a letter. The market was also moved by news of Soviet diplomatic efforts in the Mideast. Prices were also coming off as many traders expressed a reluctance to hold too many oil contracts over the weekend. Fresh in their minds was Monday's record plummet of $5.41 per barrel. Oil rebounded strongly with gains of $1.71 on Wednesday and $3.17 on Thursday. For the week, crude was down 78 cents for next-month delivery. Oil's big swings seemed to be coming closer together, sending the market farther in less time than it had been moving in recent weeks. ``The volatility's been extremely high,'' said William Byers, an analyst with Bear Stearns & Co. ``There is some sense that time is running out on the situation. Whether that's a correct perception, I don't know.'' Many traders have been thinking any military action against Iraq is likely to occur shortly before or shortly after the U.S. elections, less than two weeks away, Byers said. Blakeslee said the wild swings have been occurring on light volume, as small players in the market feel the need to rapidly make trades on headlines. ``The market will move very quickly on their panicking, if you want to call it that, or buying,'' he said. ``Someone with deep pockets will withstand these moves.'' As crude shot up and them tumbled, futures contracts for refined petroleum products moved in a similar pattern. Wholesale home heating oil closed down 3.42 cents at 88.25 cents a gallon for November delivery contracts, with most later contract months moving lower. For the week, heating oil dropped .15 cent. Wholesale unleaded gasoline fell 2.13 cents to 91.47 cents per gallon on November contracts, with most other delivery months trading lower. For the week, gasoline was up 3.56 cents.

DOC.HEAD: Plans Sale of `Substantial' Equity Stake
DOC.TEXT: Retailer R.H. Macy & Co. Inc. is considering the sale of a significant equity stake to help reduce debt, it was disclosed Friday. Macy, which already has sold small stakes to finance buybacks of some of its bonds, said it was considering more equity sales and was ``exploring the possibility of selling a more substantial equity interest to a buyer who shares our view of Macy's value and future.'' The retailer, which disclosed its plans in a letter to stockholders, did not identify any prospective investors. Macy said the sale ``will allow us to make a major reduction in our interest costs.'' It was likely the proceeds of the sale would go toward retiring some Macy high-yield junk bonds. The risky IOUs were used to finance the retailer's 1986, management-led, debt-financed takeover, known as a leveraged buyout. The letter accompanied Macy's 10-K filing, the annual report that companies with publicly held securities are required to issue and file with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In the report, Macy said it lost nearly $80 million in its fourth quarter, compared with a loss of $57.4 million in the same period of 1989. Earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation - the key measure of fiscal health for a firm after a leveraged buyout - totaled $144 million after accounting provisions, down from $156 million a year earlier. The company's sales, which Macy said were hurt by the economic weakness that plagued other retailers, rose to $1.63 billion from $1.59 billion. Macy's fourth quarter ended July 28. For the full year, Macy said it lost $215.3 million, compared with a loss of $63 million in fiscal 1989. Sales for the year rose to $7.27 billion from $6.97 billion the previous year. Macy's losses were not a surprise as they became public last week after a meeting between Macy executives and some of the company's creditors. They also had been expected since the company announced earlier this year that it had suffered a disastrous Christmas 1989 season. Macy and other retailers were forced to take steep markdowns to compete with highly indebted Campeau Corp.'s department stores, which slashed prices in hopes of bringing in sales and avoiding bankruptcy court. In its letter, Macy noted several previously announced steps it has taken to reduce debt, including the sale of credit operations to GE Capital Corp. Macy said the move would lower its $4.8 billion debt burden by $1.5 billion. The company also noted it had reduced inventory by $600 million and lowered expenses to compensate for the sluggish retail environment. Macy and other retailers are expecting the upcoming Christmas season to be difficult, as consumers have become reluctant to spend amid the uncertain economic climate and with the Middle East crisis unresolved. ``We are prepared for the sluggish economy and we are taking advantage of market conditions to imrprove the financial structure of the company,'' the retailer said in its letter. Besides its flagship Macy stores, located mainly in the East and Texas, the company owns I. Magnin and Bullock's stores in California and the West. It also owns specialty stores including Charter Club, Aeropostale and Fantasies by Morgan Taylor, which are stocked with Macy's private label apparel brands.

DOC.TEXT: The stock market dropped sharply Friday, unsettled by worries about the banking industry and prospects in the Persian Gulf. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 48.02 to 2,436.14, finishing the week with a loss of 84.65 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by more than 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 364 up, 1,164 down and 451 unchanged. Oil prices fluctuated erratically amid intensifying speculation that the showdown in the Persian Gulf might be moving closer to open conflict. Analysts said that gave little encouragement to investors already worried about the shaky state of the domestic economy. Sharply higher costs for gasoline, heating oil and a wide range of other goods are expected to act as a drag on consumer spending and business investment at a time when the economy is already burdened with debt problems and a battered real estate market. Brokers said traders seemed to have grown increasingly uneasy about the health of many large banks. Manufacturers Hanover fell 3 to 17 after remarks by a company official that were interpreted as raising the possibility of a dividend reduction. Among other prominent commercial banking issues, Citicorp dropped { to 11[; Chase Manhattan \ to 11~; Chemical Banking 1 to 11\; BankAmerica 1[ to 18}; NCNB 1 to 17~, and Security Pacific 1| to 18|. Dime Savings Bank of New York tumbled 1\ to 2|. The company posted a $153.62 million loss for the third quarter, citing an increase in its loan-loss reserve, and suspended its dividend. Elsewhere in the financial-services sector, American Express fell 1[ to 18|; Primerica 2 to 19, and Merrill Lynch 1} to 17~. But Aetna Life & Casualty, which reported lower third-quarter earnings and announced plans for an overhaul of its operations, rose \ to 31. Unisys led the active list, down 1[ at 2\. On Thursday the company reported a loss of $356.8 million for the third quarter and said it might be in the red for the fourth quarter as well. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 130.19 million shares, down from 141.46 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 171.59 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $47.16 billion, or 1.63 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 2.80 to 166.71. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 6.34 to 358.50, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 5.46 at 304.71. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 5.38 to 334.36. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 291.39, down 1.39.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Deficit Balloons To $220.4 Billion In Fiscal 1990
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs of Persian Gulf expenditures after 6th graf, The fiscal. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The federal deficit soared to $220.4 billion, the second highest ever, in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, the Treasury Department reported Friday. It was the 21st straight year in which the government spent more than it took in. The fiscal 1990 red ink was 43.7 percent more than the $153.3 billion imbalance last year. The Bush administration had forecast a $123.8 billion deficit in its initial forecast last February. But by its midyear estimate in July, the administration had boosted its projection to $220.1 billion. The Treasury announcement came as the administration and Congress appeared to be nearing completion of a package of tax hikes and spending cuts designed to erase $500 billion from the deficit in five years, including $40.1 billion in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. But the administration says government red ink still will total $253.6 billion during the current fiscal year - if the administration and Congress can stick to the budget reduction goal. Ifnot, the administration projects a whopping $293.7 billion gap. The fiscal 1991 projection excludes the estimated $1 billion a month the government is spending on its military forces in the Persian Gulf, although it expects to regain half of that from contributions from other nations. Despite inclusion of the Persian Gulf operations in the last two months of the fiscal 1990 budget, Defense Department spending was $500 million less than the administration's July forecast of $290.2 billion. Brady and Darman explained that while Operation Desert Shield boosted spending by $1.2 billion, the outlays were offset by $1.7 billion in cuts in military construction and other programs. The deficit had reached $241.7 billion in the 11 months ending Aug. 31, surpassing the previous record of $221.2 billion set in fiscal 1986. But that was cut because the government spent $25 billion in August that it normally would have spent in September to avoid late payments due to the Labor Day weekend, thus erasing that amount from the final month's outlays. The federal deficit had fallen beneath $200 billion during each year following 1986, dropping to $149.7 billion in fiscal 1987, $155.2 billion in 1988 and $153.3 billion in 1989. It was the 24th deficit in the last 25 years. The government has not operated in the black since posting a $3.2 billion surplus in fiscal 1969. Revenues amounted to $102.9 billion in September, pushing receipts for the year up 4.1 percent to $1.03 trillion. But outlays totaled $82.0 billion last month and $1.25 trillion for the year, surpassing 1989 spending by 9.4 percent. The deficit is the difference between income and outlays. September's $20.8 billion surplus compared with a $6.1 billion deficit during the same month of fiscal 1989. Contributing to the red ink was smaller tax collections than anticipated. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and budget director Richard G. Darman said in a statement that individual income taxes totaled $466.9 billion, $9.2 billion less than projected last July. At the same time, corporate taxes totalled $93.5 billion, $4.7 billion less than estimated. The Resolution Trust Corp., the federal agency charged with bailing out the savings and loan industry, cost the government $8.8 billion in September and $46.5 billion during the year - $10.6 billion less than forecast in July. Brady and Darman said the smaller outlays were due to ``slower-than-anticipated resolution of failed thrifts.'' The government hopes to regain much of the bailout cost by selling real estate, loans, securities and other assets from failed thrifts. That would help reduce the deficit in future years. As usual, the biggest spending categories were the military, Social Security and other programs of the Department of Health and Human Services and interest on the national debt. Military spending totaled $20.5 billion in September and $289.8 billion for the year, down 1.7 percent from 1989. Social Security payments amounted to $759 million for the month and $245.0 billion for the year, a 7.7 percent increase over 1989. Other HHS payments, including Medicare and Medicaid, totaled $14.0 billion in August and $193.7 billion for 1990, up 12.4 percent. Interest on the national debt amounted to $17.3 billion for the month and $264.9 billion for the year, a 10.0 percent increase over 1989. It was the second straight year that interest has exceeded Social Security spending.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Hit 2{-Month Low Ahead of Big Harvest Weekend
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices tumbled below $6 a bushel Friday to a 2{-month low on the Chicago Board of Trade in a late sell-off ahead of what was expected to be the biggest harvest weekend of the year. Grain futures also closed lower. On other commodity markets, oil futures weakened, precious metals fell and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Soybean futures settled 4 cents to 10} cents lower in Chicago with the contract for delivery in November at $5.94} a bushel, the lowest daily settlement for a near-term soybean contract since Aug. 8. The market opened lower amid speculation that the soybean harvest will move rapidly toward completion this weekend due to forecasts for mild, dry weather in the Midwest. Grain and soybean prices typically fall at harvest time as the new supplies come to market. Some analysts said Friday's sell-off partly reflected profit-taking by speculators after a run up to prices near $6.15 a bushel earlier this week. Selling by speculative funds snowballed when the price for November soybean deliveries slipped below $6 bushel about 45 minutes before the close, said Gerald Zusel, a vice president in the grain-trading division of E.D.& F. Man International Futures Inc. ``We had a technical breakdown,'' he said. ``There was big, big fund selling in there today.'' He said the soybean harvest could be finished within a week, leaving farmers to concentrate on getting in the rest of the corn. The Agriculture Department said earlier this week that the soybean harvest was 57 percent complete as of last Sunday. Analyst David Armstrong of AgriVisor Services Inc. in Bloomington, Ill., said soybean harvesting was already nearly over in Iowa, Nebraska and South Dakota. ``It's kind of hard to find a reason to be bullish right now,'' Armstrong said. ``If the weather stays good, the Corn Belt states will clearly be in a wrap-up or at least a wind-down situation by a a week from now.'' Wheat futures settled 1} cents lower to } cent higher with December at $2.62\ a bushel; corn was 2 cents to 2} cents lower with December at $2.27} a bushel; oats were 3} cents to 4 cents lower with December at $1.20 a bushel; Crude oil and refined products for near-term delivery fell sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange, giving up some of Thursday's gains. The selling reflected pre-weekend profit-taking and a lack of significant fresh developments in the Persian Gulf, analysts said. Light sweet crude oil futures settled 32 cents to $1.68 lower with December at $33.01 a barrel; heating oil was .24 cent to 3.42 cents lower with November at 88.25 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.13 cents lower to .22 cent higher with November at 91.47 cents a gallon. The drop in oil prices prompted heavy selling of gold, which had rallied along with crude oil on Thursday. A 48-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrials average spurred further selling of precious metals on perceptions that industrial demand for gold, silver and platinum would decline in a weakened economy. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold settled $4.90 to $5.40 lower with October at $370.90 a troy ounce; silver was 15.4 cents to 17.9 cents lower with October at $4.05 a troy ounce. Pork futures fell sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid slack retail demand and unprofitable operating margins for packers, analysts said. Cattle futures were little changed. Live cattle settled .25 cent lower to .13 cent higher with December at 77.87 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .25 cent higher with November at 87.17 cents a pound; live hogs were .18 cent to .87 cent lower with December at 52.95 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.47 cents to 1.9 cents lower with February at 62.95 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: American Says UAL-Pan Am Deal Worth $100 Million More
DOC.TEXT: Pan Am Corp. could get at least $100 million more for the London routes it has agreed to sell to UAL Corp. for $400 million, American Airlines Inc. Chairman Robert Crandall said Friday as he again tried to thwart the sale. ``Although our analysis is not yet complete, we estimate that the route authorities alone are worth in excess of $500 million,'' Crandall wrote Pan Am Chairman Thomas G. Plaskett in his second letter in two days. ``We would welcome an opportunity to make an offer to acquire those authorities on terms substantially better'' than UAL's, Crandall said Friday. New York-based Pan Am received the letter, but had no comment, said spokeswoman Elizabeth Hlinko. A spokesman for Chicago-based UAL also declined to comment. On Thursday, Crandall sought to start an auction for the London routes, saying Fort Worth-based American could top the $400 million UAL agreed to pay Pan Am. The deal also includes two Boeing 747 jets, plus participation in joint marketing and frequent flier programs. Plaskett responded that Pan Am had a binding agreement with United. ``Our board, after careful consideration of all of the detailed terms of the United proposals, determined that it was in the best interests of Pan Am to enter into the legal, binding agreement with United that was announced on Tuesday,'' said Plaskett, a one-time marketing executive at American. ``I had understood from our many conversations, including our most recent one, that American would be interested only in buying routes and did not wish to enter into a broad-scale agreement with Pan Am,'' Plaskett said. But Crandall replied Friday, ``Frankly, I do not recall your ever broaching the subject of a long-term marketing program in our discussions concerning American's interest in acquiring Pan Am route authorities.'' Pan Am's deal with UAL came after fruitless efforts by Pan Am to find a merger partner or buyer for the airline, which has suffered big losses in recent years. Crandall's effort shows the enormous importance American attaches to obtaining routes to London, the gateway to Europe and a crucial destination for any global airline.

DOC.HEAD: Murdoch Suspends Men's Life Magazine After One Issue
DOC.TEXT: Murdoch Magazines said Friday it suspended publication of Men's Life magazine after one issue due to the depressed economy. The quarterly went on sale in September. It was one of a flurry of new or revamped general-interest magazines aimed at upscale male readers announced in recent months. ``Reader response to the first issue was very encouraging, but it will take time to build the necessary circulation and advertising, and it is too costly to go ahead in the present economic environment,'' said Leslie Hinton, president of Murdoch Magazines, a division of Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. ``When the economy improves we will relaunch Men's Life as a monthly,'' he added. Men's Life was aimed at men 30-50 years old with a median income of $48,000. Among other men's magazines launched recently were a revamped Details and Men Inc., a combination of the men's fashion magazine called M and Manhattan Inc., a business magazine that folded. In addition, Straight Arrow Publishers Inc., which puts out Rolling Stone and Us magazines, said it is developing a men's magazine for next fall. Advertising revenue has dropped sharply for many magazines and newspapers in recent months as the economy has faltered.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Fall on Nervousness Over Budget, Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices fell Friday as traders had some last-minute jitters about the federal budget agreement and as tensions appeared to increase in the Middle East. The price of the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond slipped 7-32 point, or about $2.18 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises as the bond's price falls, edged up to 8.77 percent from 8.75 percent late Thursday. Analysts said the market was worried that the House, which was preparing for vote on the budget agreement, might not approve the measure. The credit markets have been waiting anxiously for Congress to pass a budget cutting bill because the Federal Reserve has made a budget package a prerequisite for lower interest rates. Analysts said traders also were unsettled by news that more U.S. troops were being sent to Saudi Arabia. In announcing the move on Thursday, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said the extra troops will give U.S. military authorities more leverage in dealing with Iraq's huge army. The news reawakened fears that war could break out in the Persian Gulf, leading to even higher oil prices and accelerated inflation. Bond traders fear that if inflation speeds up, the Fed will have less leeway to push interest rates lower. The market ignored a decline in oil prices Friday. The December contract for light, sweet crude fell $1.24 to $33.01 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities ranged from 1-32 point higher to 1-32 point lower, intermediate maturities fell 1-16 point to 3-32 point, and long-term issues slipped between [ point and 7-32 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 0.70 to 1,156.54. Yields on outstanding three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.37 percent as the discount fell 4 basis points from the levels in Thursday's auction to 7.15 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 7.45 percent as the discount slipped 5 basis points from the levels in Thursday's auction to 7.10 percent. Yields on one-year bills declined to 7.41 percent as the discount dropped 3 basis points to 6.96 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was 7 13-16 percent, down from 8 percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose [ point . The average yield to maturity fell to 7.72 percent from 7.73 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Big Deal Off Between Ball, Continental Can
DOC.TEXT: Peter Kiewit Sons' Inc. on Friday scrapped an agreement to sell Continental Can Europe to Ball Corp. because of what the companies called a lack of bank financing that they blamed on recent market turmoil. The tentative sale was announced in July. Ball said it was acquiring 33 European metal packaging plants from Continental Can, which would have given it a foothold in one of the world's most rapidly expanding markets. Continental was to have received $625 million in cash and $400 million in stock, giving it a 29 percent stake in Ball, the fifth-largest producer of beer and soft drink cans in the United States. But the plug was pulled on Friday, the companies said in a joint statement. ``On a financial and operating basis, both Ball and CCE have been performing at record levels in 1990. Unfortunately, due in major part to the recent turmoil in world financial markets, and in particular the U.S. banking community, Ball has not yet arranged financing, and the certainty of closing the transaction on the agreed upon terms and time frame have become compromised,'' the statement said. The scrapped deal comes against a background of growing reluctance by commercial banks to make loans as economic growth has slowed and a crisis persists in the Persian Gulf, which has driven up oil prices and further weakened the U.S. economy. Most of the top commercial banks in the United States have reported sharply lower earnings recently because of rising defaults on existing loans, particularly to Third World countries and commercial real estate projects. Ball still plans to acquire the remaining interest in its 50 percent-owned Ball-InCon Glass Packaging Corp. joint venture. In that deal, also announced in July and due to be completed by the end of the year, Ball will pay $65 million in cash to its joint venture partner, Holland-American Investment Corp. The Continental Can purchase was designed to help the company enter the fastly growing European market. Ball is a major can supplier to the cola giants, and Ball Chairman Richard M. Ringoen said his company hoped to ride their coattails into Eastern Europe. Coca-Cola Co. receives 25 percent of its soft drink cans in Europe from Continental, a privately held business of Peter Kiewit Sons of Omaha, Neb. Continental Can Europe, which employs 10,000 people, had sales of $1.47 billion in 1989 and projects sales this year to grow to $1.66 billion. The company makes food, beverage and general metal containers, metal closures and plastic containers. Last year, Ball reported 63.9 percent of its sales came from packaging products. Combined packaging sales of Ball, Continental Can Europe and Ball-InCon last year would have been $2.78 billion, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: America West, Midway Report Quarterly Losses
DOC.TEXT: America West Airlines and Midway Airlines on Friday reported net losses for the third quarter. Both blamed higher jet fuel prices for at least some of their losses. America West, based in Phoenix, said it lost nearly $22 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, while Chicago-based Midway lost $18.7 million.
DOC.HEAD: America West
DOC.TEXT: America West reported a loss of $21.95 million or $1.21 per share in the quarter, compared to a net profit of $5.8 million, or 28 cents per share, for the third quarter of 1989. Operating revenue came to $338.6 million vs. $243.4 million last year. ``We are disappointed in the results for the quarter and are not optimistic about the balance of the year 1990,'' said Al Frei, chief financial officer, who said jet fuel costs rose $15.5 million in the quarter, or about 19 cents a gallon over last year. However, the company said it was in a much stronger position than in June because of a 40 percent increase in traffic and a ``sound cash position'' after last month's agreement to buy or lease 74 to 118 Airbus Industrie A-320s from three companies in a deal worth up to $5 billion. As part of the agreement, America West received cash advances, support and spare parts totaling $220 million, company officials said. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, the company reported a net loss of $18.4 million, or 94 cents per common share, compared to net income of $18.9 million, or 92 cents per common share, for the same period last year. Revenues rose to $969.6 million vs. $715.2 million.
DOC.HEAD: Midway
DOC.TEXT: Midway attributed its $18 million loss to skyrocketing fuel costs, as well as the company's expansion efforts and matching of competitors' discount fares. For the three-month period ending Sept. 30, it lost $18.73 million, or $1.96 per share, compared to a loss of $1.87 million, or 19 cents per share, for the period last year. Revenues increased to $166.6 million, up 36 percent from $121.8 million for 1989. Midway's aviation fuel costs rose $10 million per month since the Iraqi invasion, said David R. Hinson, chairman and chief executive officer. The increase forced Midway earlier this month to abandon its Philadelphia hub and cancel 61 daily flights by next spring. Deep discounts in other airlines' fares also prevented Midway from raising its rates to cover losses, Hinson said. For the first nine months, Midway lost $53 million or $5.58 per share, compared to a profit of $6.1 million or 57 cents last year. Revenues rose to $494.4 million from $365.5 million.
