DOC.HEAD: Monsanto Profits Down 41 Percent; Company Plans Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: Monsanto Co. on Friday reported a 41 percent drop in net earnings for the third quarter and announced a wide-ranging restructuring plan at its second-biggest subsidiary. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, the company had net earnings of $74 million, or 59 cents a share, down from $126 million, or 94 cents a share, for the same period a year earlier. Sales of $2.14 billion were 4 percent higher than $2.06 billion last year. The company said higher oil prices and the slowdown in the U.S. economy cut into profits severely, as did continuing drought conditions in Europe and the western United States. ``Our third-quarter financial performance was well below what we expected going into the quarter,'' said Richard Mahoney, chairman and chief executive officer. The planned restructuring of the Monsanto Agricultural Co. will include a 9 percent cut in the number of salaried workers, the planned sale of the company's animal feed ingredients business, and a reorganization of management style. The company's job reduction program will trim about 300 of the subsidiary's 3,400 workers, partly through the use of a voluntary retirement program, company spokesman Mark Schannon said. The sale of the feed ingredients business includes plants in Alvin, Texas, and Nitro, W.Va., as well as research facilities in St. Louis. The business had sales of $160 million in 1989. Robert Shapiro, president of the agricultural subsidiary, said the business did not fit the new direction in which the subsidiary was headed. Monsanto, headquartered in St. Louis, makes a wide variety of chemicals including compounds that are used in automobile dashboards, windshields and tires. The company also manufactures pesticides and animal feed supplements, owns a pharmaceutical subsidiary and sells Nutrasweet, an artificial sweetener. For the first nine months, Monsanto's net earnings were $515 million, or $3.96 a share, 13 percent lower than the $589 million, or $4.33 a share, reported for the first nine months of 1989. Sales for the first nine months were $6.79 billion, up 2 percent from $6.67 billion for the same period in 1989.

The federal deficit soared to $220.4 billion, the second highest ever, in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, the Treasury Department reported. It was the 21st straight year in which the government spent more than it took in. The fiscal 1990 red ink was 43.7 percent more than the $153.3 billion imbalance last year. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Iraq has used American and other hostages in Kuwait to wire oil refineries with plastic explosives that, if detonated, would wipe out the emirate's entire refining capacity, Bush administration sources said. Explosives also have been placed at other vital oil installations, including pipeline pumping stations, oil processing centers, oil wells and loading terminals, said administration and oil industry sources speaking on condition of anonymity Friday. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Oil zigzagged wildly on the futures market, closing down more than $1 per barrel after a rally based on war fears ran out of steam and traders began selling. Light sweet crude, the key grade of oil, fell $1.24 Friday to $33.01 per barrel for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil had gone to a high of $35.40 per barrel before the selloff began. --- NEW YORK (AP) - About 800 editorial employees at the Daily News walked out rather than accept management's midnight deadline to cross picket lines set up by eight other unions at the financially troubled tabloid. Management at the nation's second-largest city daily Friday flew in the replacement workers to help circumvent a violent strike that began Thursday night when 1,800 employees walked out. Substitutes were imported from Tribune Co. newspapers in Orlando, Fla., and Chicago. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Aetna Life and Casualty Co. announced a restructuring plan, including layoffs, to tighten operations and save hundreds of millions of dollars. The Hartford, Conn.-based insurance company also announced a 51 percent drop in third-quarter earnings that included a one-time, $60 million charge for costs associated with the reorganization. Analysts said the restructuring may help both Aetna and the ailing insurance industry. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Even if Congress agrees on a massive deficit-reduction plan, the nation's deficit is still expected to hit a record $250 billion this year and the $3 trillion federal debt will continue to swell. Analysts said many Americans are probably unaware that the $250 billion deficit-reduction plan - which Congress and the Bush administration spent months feuding over - will rein in deficit spending but won't eliminate it. --- DETROIT (AP) - Executives from the United Auto Workers union and Ford Motor Co. signed a three-year contract as the union and Chrysler Corp. continued work on their agreement. UAW President Owen Bieber and Ford Chairman Harold Poling were the first of more than a dozen bargainers on both sides of the table to sign the new contract. Bieber refused to comment on the talks with Chrysler, the last of the Big Three automakers to settle with the UAW. --- LONDON (AP) - An administrator called in to rescue debt-ridden Polly Peck International PLC said he was optimistic the British food and electronics conglomerate will survive. The administrator said he believed there was plenty of opportunity to restructure the company, though he admitted it could end up ``somewhat different'' than its present form. Polly Peck owns such diverse brands as Del Monte fruit and Sansui stereos. --- STAMFORD, Conn. (AP) - Giant Stuff-A-Pumpkins, 260-gallon plastic leaf bags with black pumpkin faces, are the rage this Halloween season, ornamenting millions of lawns across America. ``We don't have any trees in our yard, so we went out one night and robbed the leaves of the people next door,'' said Betty Brown, a West Hartford mother of three whose family of Stuff-A-Pumpkins peer down from her front-porch roof. The bags are made by Stamford-based Sun Hill Industries Inc. ---

The stock market dropped sharply Friday, unsettled by worries about the banking industry and prospects in the Persian Gulf. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 48.02 to 2,436.14, finishing the week with a loss of 84.65 points. The dollar was mixed and gold fell. Soybean futures prices fell below $6 a bushel. Grain futures also closed lower. Oil futures weakened, precious metals fell and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Tells Boeing To Correct Problems With New Missile
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Air Force has warned Boeing Aerospace & Defense Group that it could lose a nuclear missile contract if problems with the weapon aren't fixed. The service has sent Boeing a ``cure notice,'' giving it until Nov. 30 to describe how it will fix problems with the SRAM-2 missile, which is over cost and behind schedule, said a spokesman at the Air Force's Aeronautical Systems Division at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Ohio. Milt Furness, spokesman for Boeing Aerospace, said Wednesday that Boeing was preparing a response and would file it by the deadline. ``Basically, we're going to tell them how we will fix the problems and the schedule we will meet to do that,'' Furness said. Furness said the letter from the Air Force, dated Sept. 10, outlined problems with the missile's solid-fuel motor and with computer software for the missile's targeting and guidance systems. The rocket motor, supplied by Hercules Inc., has had problems with its solid propellant cracking during cold-temperature tests, Furness said. He said he could not give details on what was wrong with the software, which is being developed by Boeing. Boeing received a $214 million contract 3{ years ago to develop the SRAM-2, which stands for short range attack missile. Eventually, the Air Force hopes to buy more than 1,600 of the air-to-ground missiles at a total cost of $2.5 billion to $3 billion, Furness said.

DOC.HEAD: Polaroid Seeks Higher Award From Kodak; Kodak Wants To Lower It
DOC.TEXT: Polaroid Corp. asked a federal judge Friday to increase its record $909.5 million patent infringement judgment against Eastman Kodak Co. by $173 million. Kodak, meanwhile, asked the same U.S. District Court judge to reduce the award by $48 million. The motions follow Judge A. David Mazzone's Oct. 12 decision that ended a 14-year legal battle with what is believed to be the largest patent infringement award in history. Mazzone ordered Kodak to pay Polaroid the $909.5 million for infringing on Polaroid patents for instant cameras and film when Kodak entered the market in 1976. He also ruled the infringement was not willful. Cambridge-based Polaroid had sought $12 billion, and Mazzone's award was considered a disappointment in the investment community. In Friday's 40-page motion, Polaroid asks the judge to reconsider his calculations in four major categories, said Polaroid spokesman Sam Yanes. The categories involve calculations of such factors as interest rates, increased film sales in 1984 and 1985, lost film sales and special costs related to manufacturing capabilities, Yanes said. Kodak spokesman Paul Allen said his company based its 12-page motion on ``clerical errors'' in the calculation of damages, royalty and interest. Kodak, based in Rochester, N.Y., originally argued it should pay Polaroid $177 million, equal to about 5 percent of its sales of instant cameras and film from 1976 to 1985. After Mazzone issues his decision on the two motions, the two companies have 30 days to decide whether they will appeal his original judgment to the U.S. Appellate Court in Washington, D.C., the spokesmen said. Both Allen and Yanes said their companies were still considering an appeal. Brenda Lee Landry, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Co. in New York, said Friday's motions do not challenge the basic premises that Mazzone used in rendering his judgment. ``In other words, they're not asking him to change his logic or principles per say on any points of law,'' Landry said. Rendering a decision would involve ``whose calculations were right and whose computer was right,'' she said. Theoretically, Mazzone could grant both motions, which would mean that Polaroid would receive an additional $125 million, Landry said. Disappointed though Polaroid may be in the amount of the award, if the company appeals the decision, it may only do so on legal issues, not monetary amounts, Landry said. Moreover, Polaroid could end up with a lower award, she said. The case dates back to 1972, when Polaroid introduced the SX-70 color instant camera, and a deal with Kodak to make film for the camera fell through. Instant photography was invented by Polaroid founder Edwin Land in 1947 and first marketed in 1948. Polaroid held a monopoly for almost 30 years until Kodak entered the field in 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Seeks to Delay Payment on Pension Plan
DOC.TEXT: Troubled Pan Am Corp. said Friday evening it wants to delay the payment of $30 million into its pension plan. The request came in a filing with the Internal Revenue Service that would not be made public, Pan Am spokewoman Pamela Hanlon said. Pan Am refused to say how its business might be affected if the IRS turns down the request. ``We have submitted an application to the IRS to defer aproximately $30 million of pension payments that were due on the date of our transfer of our internal German service to Lufthansa German Airlines,'' Hanlon said. ``That sale took place today.'' The routes from the $150 million sale will be turned over to Lufthansa on Sunday, Pan Am said. Ms. Hanlon did not know how long Pan Am hoped to put off the pension payment, but she said the company will pay immediately if it must. ``We have the cash to pay it,'' Ms. Hanlon said. ``It is simply a determination on our part that by deferring the pension payment we would be able to maximize our cash position.'' She declined elaboration, but said Pan Am's move was related to higher jet fuel costs and a sluggish U.S. economy that have hit the airline industry hard. Pan Am had already deferred paying $53 million into the pension plan last month in an agreement with the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp., the federal agency that oversees pension fund administration by companies. The $30 million payment that Pan Am is now seeking to delay is part of that previous deferral, with the remaining $23 million due on Feb. 28. The IRS filing by Pan Am comes just four days after the carrier said it planned to sell prized routes from five U.S. cities to London in a $400 million deal with rival UAL Corp. AMR Corp., the corporate parent of American Airlines, then said it wanted a chance to bid on the routes. American said Friday that it believed the London routes were worth more than $500 million. Pan Am has said its deal with UAL, the parent of United Airlines, was more than just a sale of the London routes, because it also contained a marketing agreement in which the two carriers would try to feed each other passengers by coordinating certain flights.

DOC.HEAD: Pilots Sentenced to Prison for Flying While Intoxicated
DOC.TEXT: The first commercial pilots to be convicted for flying a jetliner while intoxicated were sentenced to prison Friday by a judge who reproached them for risking lives and breaking the trust of passengers. ``Who can comprehend an entire crew alcohol-impaired?'' U.S. District Judge James Rosenbaum said. ``It is a crime against our sense of security. In that sense, all of us are a victim of this crime.'' Rosenbaum indicated he reluctantly followed federal sentencing guidelines in ordering year-long prison terms for Robert Kirchner, 36, of Highland Ranch, Colo., who was flying the plane, and flight engineer Joseph Balzer, 35, of Antioch, Tenn. The flight captain, Norman Lyle Prouse, 51, of Conyers, Ga., was sentenced to 16 months. ``I have grave doubts that the guidelines fit the crime,'' said Rosenbaum, who considered stiffer sentences. Kirchner and Balzer were freed pending their appeals. Prouse didn't ask to be freed pending an appeal, but the judge gave him five days to file a request. The sentences also bar them from flying planes with passengers for the three years of their subsequent probation. It was the first federal prosecution under a 1986 law making it a crime to operate a commercial airplane under the influence of drugs or alcohol. The law presumes an operator is under the influence of alcohol at .10 percent blood-alcohol level. The law also applies to commercial boats, trains and passenger buses. The maximum penalty is 15 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. The judge said the three men put job security ahead of their passengers' lives March 8 when they flew a Boeing 727 from Fargo, N.D., to the Twin Cities after a night of heavy drinking at a bar. The plane, carrying 91 people, flew smoothly and landed safely at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, where the pilots were arrested. ``What difference does it make that you landed the flight safely?'' Rosenbaum said. ``The danger was there.'' Prouse admitted to drinking more than 15 rum and cola drinks at the bar. Balzer and Kirchner shared at least six pitchers of beer and left the bar about one hour before Prouse. They flew out the next morning. In tests about two hours after the plane landed, Prouse had a blood-alcohol level of .13 percent. Kirchner's was .06 percent. Balzer's was .08 percent. ``Did you think about your passengers?'' Rosenbaum asked. ``You certainly considered the risks to your jobs at Northwest Airlines - to your income.'' Rosenbaum was referring to a warning the pilots ignored before the flight took off. Acting on the anonymous tip from a patron at the bar, FAA inspector Verle Addison met the cockpit crew at their departure gate. He told the pilots he smelled alcohol and wondered aloud if they had violated the FAA rule against drinking within eight hours of a scheduled flight. He said there would be no violation unless the plane departed. While Addison was on the telephone to superiors in Chicago, the plane took off. The defendants expressed relief at the length of their sentences. ``It's less than what I expected,'' Prouse said. ``I'll do the 16 months one day at a time. I can't walk out until I walk in.'' Prouse, a pilot for 22 years at Northwest and a veteran of 160 combat flights in Vietnam, told Rosenbaum the arrest prompted him to seek treatment for alcoholism, a disease that killed both his parents. ``I just want to say I'm sorry,'' Kirchner said in court. ``I'm sorry to the public, aviation community, friends, family, wife and two sons.'' Northwest fired the pilots. The Federal Aviation Administration stripped their licenses. In April, a Northwest pilot refused to fly a plane bound for Atlanta after a passenger accused him of being drunk. Blood tests were negative.

DOC.HEAD: In Written Testimony, Drexel Executive Supports Milken on Caesars Charge
DOC.TEXT: A former top Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. official said in court papers filed Friday that Michael Milken was unaware of a 1983 agreement to advise a client central to a government charge of insider trading. John Kissick, ex-head of Drexel's West Coast corporate finance department, testified for Milken's defense in a bid to exonerate the former junk-bond financier from insider trading in Caesars World Inc. bonds. The government, in a pre-sentencing hearing that ended Thursday, offered testimony implying Milken knew Drexel was advising Caesars on a debt exchange when he ordered his traders to purchase bonds of the casino company. Sentencing of Milken on his guilty plea to six trading-related felony counts is not expected until after next week, a clerk for U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood said Friday. Milken attended a meeting with Caesars and Drexel executives on June 29, 1983, at which the government claims Milken was a ``leading proponent'' of a debt-for-equity restructuring for Caesars. Former Drexel trader James Dahl testified at the hearing that Milken at some point ordered him and other traders to purchase Caesars bonds from customers. But he couldn't when the directive was given. Drexel on July 15 announced it was advising Caesars on a debt restructuring, which sent the bonds soaring in value. The government claims Milken ordered the purchases because he had inside knowledge of Drexel's plans to manage the debt-for-equity restructuring. Prosecutors also claim Milken purchased $2.65 million worth of Caesars bonds on July 1 for a personal account and sold in late July at a $553,000 profit. Kissick testified the June 29 meeting had no formal agenda and several proposals for helping the company were discussed. ``I cannot recall who proposed what, but I have attended over 100 meetings like this with Michael Milken and it is not Mr. Milken's style to stress any one option,'' he said. Kissick said no decision was made at the meeting about Caesars, or even whether Drexel would be hired to advise the company. Kissick said that Caesars on July 1 told him it was interested in exchanging debt for equity. He said he assigned an executive in Drexel's San Francisco office to work with Caesars. ``To the best of my knowledge, Michael Milken had no involvement with our relationship with Caesars'' between June 29 and July 15, Kissick testified. Supporting testimony given Thursday, Kissick said Milken was out of the country on vacation for much of the period. Milken faces up to 28 years in prison. The eight-day pre-sentencing hearing was on alleged illegal trading beyong the six counts he has admitted the government said shows Milken deserves a lengthy prison term.

DOC.HEAD: Allied-Signal Earnings Down In Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Allied-Signal Inc. on Friday announced a 13 percent drop in third-quarter earnings, in part because of a worldwide economic slowdown. Though sales rose in the aerospace, automotive and chemical divisions of the company, profits were eroded by competitive pricing, the expense of new product development and the higher cost of petroleum-based raw materials, the company said. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, earnings totaled $105 million, or 76 cents a share, on revenues of $3 billion. That compares to earnings of $121 million, or 81 cents a share, on sales of $28 billion for the same period last year. ``Each of our three core businesses attained slightly higher sales, although we are starting to feel the effects of recessionary conditions both here and overseas,'' said Edward L. Hennessy Jr., chairman and chief executive officer. ``We are managing all our costs aggressively to combat the effects of the economic slowdown.'' The sharpest drop in profits was in automotive sales. Net income for the quarter rose to $961 million from $873 million for the same period last year, but profits dropped to $3 million from $11 million. Sales were fueled by a favorable foreign exchange and sales of antilock brakes and airbags, but profits were eroded by the cost of developing the products, the company said. Allied-Signals's nine month earnings totaled $355 million, or $2.54 per share, vs. $413 million, or $2.77 per share, in 1989. Nine month sales totaled $9.2 billion in 1990, vs. $8.9 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Shakeup After Ex-Chairman Testifies at Milken Hearing
DOC.TEXT: Enstar Group Inc. announced a restructuring Friday after its ex-chairman admitted at Michael Milken's pre-sentencing hearing that he had bilked the company of fees for personal profit. Enstar also said it had hired an attorney to review the activities of Richard Grassgreen, the ex-chairman and longtime Milken associate who agreed to pleaded guilty to two felony counts earlier this week. Enstar, which has retailing and financial services interests, is the successor to Kinder-Care Inc., a day-care company built largely with junk bond financing arranged by Milken and his old firm, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Grassgreen testified against Milken under a plea agreement related to pocketing up to $500,000 from investments made by his company through Drexel. The charges do not involve Milken. Grassgreen said at the hearing, though, that Milken personally offered him special equity investments in a 1985 takeover deal, a central allegation made by the government against the junk-bond financier. Grassgreen also pleaded guilty to failing to report that investment to Enstar's board. Under the plea deal, Grassgreen agreed to remit to Enstar all funds related to the previously undisclosed commitment fees for Enstar to participate in junk-bond offerings. The fees were placed in a partnership controlled by Grassgreen. Enstar said Friday that four of its eight board members had resigned. ``It's a positive step,'' said Jo Ann Paddock, who heads a stockholder group. ``They were too closely related to Grassgreen.'' Three of the four departed directors - Harris C. Friedman, Donald M. Kaplan and Stephen M. Lazovitz - will continue to be directors of American Savings and Loan Association of Florida, which is 50 percent owned by Enstar. The fourth director, Birmingham attorney J. Mason Davis, cited other time commitments in his resignation. Enstar's new chairman, investment banker Rod Frazer said he hopes to sell the thrift, as well as Enstar's insurance company, Western Reserve Life Assurance Co. of Ohio. Frazer said he wants to retain Enstar's retail subsidiary, which includes 735 Shoe City, Bargain Town, Simply 6 and Max 10 discount stores in 11 states. Enstar also said it no longer expects to meet a projection of $15 million in earnings for the year. A week before his resignation, Grassgreen announced cut the earnings projection from $30 million and laid off 70 corporate employees. Kinder-Care, formed in 1969, became the nation's largest chain of day-care centers and went on an expansion spree in the 1980s, using Drexel financing to buy retail chains, an insurance company, a thrift and a hunting magazine. Faced with mounting debts, Kinder-Care sold its day-care division to a new company, Kinder-Care Learning Centers, and renamed the rest Enstar Group Inc.
